PREFACE 
    This Code is a revision and codification of the ordinances of the Village of Hazel Crest of a general and permanent nature. As expressed in the Adopting Ordinance, the Code supersedes all ordinances not included therein or recognized as continuing in force by reference thereto. 
    The chapters of the Code have been conveniently arranged in alphabetical order and the various sections within each chapter have been appropriately catchlined to facilitate usage. Appropriate footnotes which tie related sections of the Code together and which refer to relevant state laws have been included. Also, the source of each section is included in the history note appearing in parentheses at the end thereof. The absence of such a note indicates that the section is new and was adopted for the first time with the adoption of the Code. 
    The numbering system used in this Code is the same system used in many state and municipal codes. Each section number consists of two component parts separated by a dash, the figure before the dash referring to the chapter number and the figure after the dash referring to the position of the section within the chapter. Thus, the first section of Chapter 1 is numbered 1-1 and the fourteenth section of Chapter 17 is 17-14. Under this system each section is identified with its chapter and, at the same time, new sections, or even whole chapters, can be inserted in their proper places, simply by using the decimal system for amendments. By way of illustration: If new material consisting of three (3) sections that would logically come between Sections 4-4 and 4-5 is desired to be added, such new sections would be numbered 4-4.1, 4-4.2, 4-4.3, respectively. New chapters may be included by the addition of a fraction after the chapter number; e.g., if the new material is to be included between Chapters 12 and 13, it will be designated as Chapter 121/2. Care should be taken that the alphabetical arrangement of chapters is maintained when including new chapters. New articles and new divisions may be included in the same way or, in the case of articles, may be placed at the end of the chapter embracing the subject, and, in the case of divisions, may be placed at the end of the article embracing the subject, the next successive number being assigned to the article or division. 
    The general index of the Code has been prepared with the greatest of care. Each particular item has been placed under several headings, some of the headings being couched in lay phraseology, others in legal terminology, and still others in language generally used by city officials and employees. There are numerous cross references within the index itself which stand as guideposts to direct the user to the particular item in which he is interested. 
    A special feature of this Code is the looseleaf system of binding and supplemental servicing for the Code. With this looseleaf system, the Code will be kept up-to-date periodically. Upon the final passage of amendatory ordinances, they will be properly edited and the page or pages affected will be reprinted. These new pages will be distributed to the holders of the Codes with instructions for the manner of inserting the new pages and deleting the obsolete pages. Each such amendment, when incorporated into the Code, may be cited as a part hereof, as provided in Section 5 of the Adopting Ordinance. 
    The successful maintenance of this Code up-to-date at all times will depend largely upon the holder of the volume. As revised sheets are received it will then become the responsibility of the holder to have the amendments inserted according to the attached instructions. It is strongly recommended by the publishers that all such amendments be inserted immediately upon receipt to avoid misplacing them and, in addition, that all deleted pages be saved and filed for historical reference purposes. 
    The publication of this Code was under the direct supervision of George R. Langford, President, and James S. Vaught, Editor of the Municipal Code Corporation, Tallahassee, Florida. Credit is gratefully given to the other members of the publisher's staff for their sincere interest and able assistance throughout the project. 
    The publishers are most grateful to Mr. Martin J. Kauchak, Village President, Mr. Mario H. Guidarelli, Village Attorney, Mrs. Rita C. Besse, Village Clerk and the members of the Village Board of Trustees for their supervision, cooperation and interest during the progress of the work on this Code. 
    This Code is presented for the use and benefit of the citizens of the Village of Hazel Crest, Illinois. 
MUNICIPAL CODE CORPORATION 
Tallahassee, Florida 
December, 1974 
ORDINANCE NO. 37-1974 
AN ORDINANCE ADOPTING AND ENACTING A MUNICIPAL CODE FOR THE VILLAGE OF HAZEL CREST, ILLINOIS; ESTABLISHING THE SAME; PROVIDING FOR THE REPEAL OF CERTAIN ORDINANCES NOT INCLUDED THEREIN, EXCEPT AS HEREIN EXPRESSLY PROVIDED; PROVIDING FOR THE MANNER OF AMENDING SUCH CODE; AND PROVIDING WHEN THIS ORDINANCE SHALL BECOME EFFECTIVE. 
BE IT ORDAINED BY THE PRESIDENT AND THE BOARD OF TRUSTEES OF THE VILLAGE OF HAZEL CREST, ILLINOIS. 
    Section 1.  That this ordinance, consisting of Chapters 1 through 29 inclusive, is hereby adopted and enacted as the "Municipal Code for the Village of Hazel Crest, Illinois," and shall be treated and considered as a new and original comprehensive ordinance which shall supersede all other general and permanent ordinances passed by the Board of Trustees on or before June 12, 1973, except such as by reference thereto are expressly saved from repeal or continued in force and effect for any purpose. 
    Section 2.  That all provisions of such Code shall be in full force and effect from and after January 10, 1974, and all ordinances of a general and permanent nature of the Village of Hazel Crest, enacted on final passage on or before June 12, 1973, and not in such Code or recognized and continued in force by reference therein are hereby repealed from and after the effective date of such Code, except as hereinafter provided. 
    Section 3.  That the repeal provided for in Section 2 hereof shall not affect the following: 
(a)  Any offense or act committed or done or any penalty or forfeiture incurred or any contract or right established or accruing before the effective date of such Code; 
(b)  Any ordinance or resolution promising or guaranteeing the payment of money for the Village, or authorizing the issuance of any bonds of the Village or any evidence of the Village's indebtedness, or any contract or obligations assumed by the Village; 
(c)  Any ordinance, or portion thereof, establishing regulations governing the operation, stopping, standing or parking of vehicles on specific streets or portions thereof; 
(d)  Any right or franchise granted by any ordinances of the Village; 
(e)  Any ordinance dedicating, naming, establishing, locating, relocating, opening, paving, widening, vacating, etc., any street or public way in the Village. 
(f)  Any appropriation ordinances; 
(g)  Any ordinance levying or imposing taxes not inconsistent with this Code; 
(h)  The zoning ordinance or any amendments thereto; 
(i)  Any ordinance establishing or prescribing grades of streets in the Village; 
(j)  Any ordinance providing for local improvements and assessing taxes therefor; 
(k)  The subdivision control ordinance, as amended, or any ordinance dedicating or accepting any plat or subdivision in the Village; 
(l)  Any ordinance extending or contracting the boundaries of the Village; 
(m)  Any ordinance prescribing the number, classification or compensation of any Village officers or employees not inconsistent herewith; 
(n)  Any ordinance establishing the boundaries of any precincts in the Village; 
(o)  Any ordinance, or portion thereof, establishing electrical or plumbing work permit fees; 
    Such repeal shall not be construed to revive any ordinance or part thereof that has been repealed by subsequent ordinance which is repealed by this ordinance. 
    Section 4.  That any and all additions or amendments to such Code, when passed in such form as to indicate the intention of the Board of Trustees to make the same a part thereof, shall be deemed to be incorporated in such Code so that reference to the "Municipal Code of the Village of Hazel Crest, Illinois" shall be understood and intended to include such additions and amendments. 
    Section 5.  That a copy of such Code shall be kept on file in the office of the Village Clerk, preserved in looseleaf form. It shall be the express duty of the Village Clerk or someone authorized by him, to insert in their designated places all amendments or ordinances which indicate the intention of the Board of Trustees to make the same a part of such Code when the same have ben printed or reprinted in page form, and to extract from such Code all provisions which may from time to time be repealed by the Board of Trustees. This copy of such Code shall be available for all persons desiring to examine the same and shall be considered the official Municipal Code for the Village of Hazel Crest, Illinois. 
    Section 6.  That in case of the amendment of any section of such Code for which a penalty is not provided, the general penalty as provided in Section 1-10 of such Code shall apply to the section as amended or in case such amendment contains provisions for which a penalty, other than the aforementioned general penalty, is provided in another section in the same chapter, the penalty so provided in such other section shall be held to relate to the section so amended, unless such penalty is specifically repealed therein. 
    Section 7.  That it shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation in the Village to change or amend by additions or deletions, any part or portion of such Code, or to insert or delete pages or portions thereof, or to alter or tamper with such Code in any manner whatsoever which will cause the law of the Village of Hazel Crest to be misrepresented thereby. Any person, firm or corporation violating this section shall be punished as provided in Section 1-10 of the Code for the Village of Hazel Crest, Illinois. 
    Section 8.  That all ordinances or parts of ordinances in conflict herewith are, to the extent of such conflict, hereby repealed. 
    Section 9.  That this ordinance shall be in full force and effect from and after its passage, approval and publication according to law. 
    YEAS: 7 Zimny, Heaney, Heilstedt, Kaindl, Sanko, Sutton, Kauchak 
    NAYS: 0 
    ABSENT: 0 
    PASSED AND APPROVED THIS 10 day of December, 1974. 
Martin J. Kauchak 
President 
ATTEST: 
Rita C. Besse 
Village Clerk

Chapter 1 - GENERAL PROVISIONS 

Sec. 1-1. - How Code designated and cited. 
    The ordinances embraced in the following chapters and sections shall constitute and be designated the "Municipal Code for the Village of Hazel Crest, Illinois" and may be so cited. 
(Code 1956, § 1.01) 
State Law reference- Revision and codification of ordinances, 65 ILCS 5/1-2-3 et seq. 
Sec. 1-2. - Rules of construction and definitions. 
    In the construction of this Code, and of all ordinances, the rules and definitions set out in this section shall be observed, unless such construction would be inconsistent with the manifest intent of the board of trustees. Terms not defined in this Code shall have the meanings prescribed by the Illinois Revised Statutes for such terms. The rules of construction and definitions set out herein shall not be applied to any section of this Code which contains any express provision excluding such construction, or where the subject matter or context of such section may be repugnant thereto. 
    Generally. All general provisions, terms, phrases and expressions contained in this Code shall be liberally construed in order that the true intent and meaning of the board of trustees may be fully carried out. 
    In the interpretation and application of any provision of this Code, it shall be held to be the minimum requirements adopted for the promotion of the public health, safety, comfort, convenience and general welfare. Where any provision of the Code imposes greater restrictions upon the subject matter than another more general provision imposed by the Code, the provision imposing the greater restriction or regulation shall be deemed to be controlling. 
    And, or. The word "and" may be read "or" and the word "or" may be read "and" if the sense requires it. 
    Board, board of trustees, village board. Whenever the term "board," "board of trustees" or "village board" is used, it shall be construed to mean the president and board of trustees of the Village of Hazel Crest. 
    Code. The words "this Code" shall mean the Municipal Code for the Village of Hazel Crest, Illinois, as designated in section 1-1. 
    Computation of time. The time within which any act provided by law is to be done shall be computed by excluding the first day and including the last, unless the last day is Saturday or Sunday or is a holiday as defined or fixed in any statute now or hereafter in force in this state, and then it shall also be excluded. If the day succeeding such Saturday, Sunday or holiday is also a holiday or a Saturday or Sunday, then such succeeding day shall also be excluded. 
    Corporate limits or village limits. The term "corporate limits" or "village limits" shall mean the legal boundaries of the Village of Hazel Crest. 
    County. The term "the county" or "this county" shall be construed to mean Cook County. 
    Delegation of authority. Whenever a provision appears requiring the head of a department or some other village officer to do some act or perform some duty, it shall be construed to authorize the head of the department or other officer to designate, delegate and authorize subordinates to perform the required act or perform the duty, unless the terms of the provision or section specify otherwise. 
    Employee. The word "employee" shall refer to any personnel of the village, other than officers to whom an oath of office is administered. 
    Gender. A word importing the masculine gender only shall extend and be applied to females and to firms, partnerships and corporations as well as to males. 
    Joint authority. All words giving joint authority to three (3) or more persons or officers shall be construed as giving such authority to a majority of such persons or officers. 
    Month. The word "month" shall mean a calendar month. 
    Nontechnical and technical words. Words and phrases shall be construed according to the common and approved usage of the language, but technical words and phrases and such others as may have acquired a peculiar and appropriate meaning in law shall be construed and understood according to such meaning. 
    Number. A word importing the singular number only may extend and be applied to several persons and things as well as to one person and thing. 
    Oath. The word "oath" shall be construed to include an affirmation in all cases in which, by law, an affirmation may be substituted for an oath, and in such cases the words "swear" and "sworn" shall be equivalent to the words "affirm" and "affirmed." 
    Officer. An officer of the village is a person so designated by statute or ordinance to whom an oath is administered. 
    Officers generally. Whenever any officer is referred to by title, such as "village treasurer," "village clerk," "chief of police," "president," etc., such reference shall be construed as if followed by the words "of the Village of Hazel Crest." 
    Owner. The word "owner," applied to a building or land, shall include any part owner, joint owner, tenant in common, tenant in partnership, joint tenant or tenant by the entirety of the whole or of a part of such building or land. 
    Person. The word "person" shall extend and be applied to associations, clubs, societies, firms, partnerships and bodies politic and corporate as well as to individuals. 
    Personal property. The term "personal property" shall include every species of property except real property, as herein defined. 
    Preceding, following. The words "preceding" and "following" mean next before and next after, respectively. 
    Property. The word "property" shall include real and personal property. 
    Real property. The term "real property" shall include lands, tenements and hereditaments. 
    Shall, may. The word "shall" is mandatory and the word "may" is permissive. 
    Sidewalk. The word "sidewalk" shall mean any portion of a street between the curbline and the adjacent property line intended for the use of pedestrians, excluding parkways. 
    Signature or subscription includes a mark when the person cannot write. 
    State. The term "the state" or "this state" shall be construed to mean the State of Illinois. 
    Street. The word "street" shall be construed to embrace streets, avenues, boulevards, roads, alleys, lanes, viaducts and all other public ways in the village, and shall include all areas thereof embraced between the property lines and dedicated to the public use. 
    Tenant or occupant. The word "tenant" or "occupant," applied to a building or land, shall include any person holding a written or oral lease or who occupies the whole or a part of such building or land, either alone or with others. 
    Tense. Words used in the past or present tense include the future as well as the past and present. 
    Village. The term "village" shall mean the Village of Hazel Crest, Illinois. 
    Written or in writing. The term "written" or "in writing" shall be construed to include any representation of words, letters or figures, whether by printing or otherwise. 
    Year. The word "year" shall mean a calendar year unless specifically referred to as fiscal year. 
(Code 1956, §§ 1.02, 1.04, 1.05) 
Sec. 1-3. - Catchlines of sections. 
    The catchlines of the several sections of this Code printed in boldface type are intended as mere catchwords to indicate the contents of the sections and shall not be deemed or taken to be titles of such sections, nor as any part of the sections, nor, unless expressly so provided, shall they be so deemed when any of such sections, including the catchlines, are amended or reenacted. 
Sec. 1-4. - Amendments to Code. 
    All ordinances passed subsequent to this Code which amend, repeal or in any way affect this Code may be numbered in accordance with the numbering system of this Code and printed for inclusion herein, or in the case of repealed chapters, sections and subsections, or any part thereof, by subsequent ordinances, such repealed portions may be excluded from the Code by omission from reprinted pages affected thereby, and the subsequent ordinances as numbered and printed or omitted, in the case of repeal, shall be prima facie evidence of such subsequent ordinances until such time as this Code and subsequent ordinances numbered or omitted are readopted as a new code by the board of trustees. 
Sec. 1-5. - Publication and recording of ordinances. 
(a)  All ordinances passed by the president and board of trustees shall be recorded by the clerk in a book kept for village ordinances. The original shall be filed in the office of the village clerk and due proof of publication of all ordinances requiring publication shall be procured by the clerk, which proof of affidavit of publication shall be attached to and filed with the ordinances. The clerk shall also note on his book of ordinances, at the foot of the record of each ordinance, a memorandum of the date of the passage thereof and, if published or posted, the date of such publication or posting. 
(b)  All ordinances passed by the president and board of trustees shall be written, printed or published on paper uniform in size and substantially the size of each page of this Code, with the left-hand margin thereof sufficiently wide for binding. They will bear a number starting from 1 at the beginning of each year and progressing numerically for each ordinance, followed by a hyphen and the 4 digits of the current year. The village clerk will bind all ordinances in a book or suitable cover in the order of passage, and will maintain therewith a complete index of all ordinances contained therein, together with a memorandum of the date of passage and, if published or posted, the date of publication or posting. The village clerk will have the current book or binder of ordinances available at each regular or special meeting of the board of trustees, and in addition thereto shall keep at least one copy of this Code, which he shall mark in the following manner: Whenever any ordinance which amends or makes an addition to this Code is passed and approved, he shall note in the margin of the section or sections amended that the amendment has been made and where the amendment may be found in the amendment book, and in the case of an addition, he shall make a notation in the appropriate place that such addition has been made, with a similar reference to the amendment book. 
(Code 1956, §§ 1.09, 2.01) 
Sec. 1-6. - Time in which ordinances take effect. 
    All ordinances, passed by the president and board of trustees of the village, shall take effect after due publication thereof, as required by law, and ordinances relative thereto. 
Sec. 1-7. - Unauthorized alteration or tampering with Code. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person in the village to change or amend, by additions or deletions, any part or portion of this Code, or to insert or delete pages, or portions thereof, or to alter or tamper with such Code in any manner whatsoever which will cause the law of the village to be misrepresented thereby. 
Sec. 1-8. - Effect of repeal of ordinances. 
(a)  When any ordinance repealing a former ordinance, clause or provision shall be itself repealed, such repeal shall not be construed to revive such former ordinance, clause or provision, unless it shall be expressly so provided therein. 
(b)  The repeal of an ordinance shall not affect any punishment or penalty incurred before the repeal took effect, nor any suit, prosecution or proceeding pending at the time of the repeal, for an offense committed or cause of action arising under the ordinance repealed. 
Sec. 1-9. - Severability of parts of Code. 
    The sections, paragraphs, sentences, clauses and phrases of this Code are severable, and if any phrase, clause, sentence, paragraph or section of this Code shall be declared unconstitutional, invalid or unenforceable by the valid judgment or decree of a court of competent jurisdiction, such unconstitutionality, invalidity or unenforceability shall not affect any of the remaining phrases, clauses, sentences, paragraphs and sections of this Code. 
(Code 1956, § 1.05) 
Sec. 1-10. - General penalty and collection of fines, charges, penalties or payments. 
(a)  Any person convicted of a violation of any section or provision of this Code, where no other penalty is set forth, shall be punished by a fine not to exceed one thousand five hundred dollars ($1,500.00) for any one (1) offense. 
(b)  Whenever any fine, charge, penalty or payment is due pursuant to any provision in this Code arid is not paid after the village sends, mails or otherwise delivers notice (unless a different period is stated elsewhere in this Code) to the person responsible for such fine, charge, penalty or payment (the "responsible person"), the village may transfer such fine, charge, penalty or payment to a collection agency of the village's choosing. Any such collection agency shall, for purposes of collection of such fine, charge, penalty or payment, be deemed an agent of the village. All costs incurred by the village for the collection of any fines, charges, penalties or payments transferred to any such collection agency shall be assessed against the responsible person as an additional fine, charge, penalty or payment, subject to any applicable statutory limits. 
(Ord. No. 08-2016, § 2, 7-26-16) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 08-2016, § 2, adopted July 26, 2016, repealed § 1-10, and reenacted a new § 1-10 as set out herein. Former § 1-10 pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Ord. No. 18-1981, § 1, adopted August 25, 2981; and Ord. No. 31-1995, § 1, adopted November 14, 1995. 
Cross reference- Offenses and miscellaneous provisions, Ch. 20; police, Ch. 24. 
State Law reference- Maximum punishments for ordinance violations, 65 ILCS 5/1-2-1. 
Sec. 1-11. - Recovery of fines. 
    All fines, forfeitures, penalties and costs imposed against any person by any of the ordinances of the village may be recovered before any judge of the county by action of debt in the name of the village, and judgment may be rendered thereon and collected by execution or other process as other judgments are rendered and collected. 
(Code 1956, § 17.07) 
Sec. 1-12. - Commitment for failure to pay fines. 
    In all cases where judgment is rendered as provided in section 1-11 in favor of the village, such person so convicted of a violation of any ordinance of the village shall be committed to the village jail or other place of imprisonment provided or authorized by the village and be imprisoned therein for failing to pay any fine, forfeiture, penalty or costs which may be adjudged against him where the defendant has waived a jury in writing or when such judgment was pursuant to the verdict of a jury, and may be required to work at such labor as his strength will permit, not to exceed eight (8) hours each day. For such work the prisoner shall be allowed, exclusive of his board, the sum of five dollars ($5.00) for each day's work or imprisonment on account of such fine, penalty or forfeiture and costs, until the same is fully satisfied; provided, no such imprisonment shall continue longer than six (6) months for any one offense. At the expiration of the term of confinement, the keeper of the place of confinement shall endorse the writ of commitment "satisfied in full by imprisonment," and discharge such person from his custody. Commitment of any person as provided in this section shall be by process, under the hand of the court which made the order for such commitment. 
(Code 1956, § 17.08) 
Sec. 1-13. - Recovery of damages for violation of ordinances. 
    Whenever in any ordinance the doing of any act or the omission to do any act or duty is declared to be a breach thereof, and damage, loss, expense or injury to the village or to any person is a result or consequence of such act or omission, compensation for such damage, loss, expense or injury may be recovered from the offender by the party aggrieved. 
Sec. 1-14. - Fee for returned checks. 
    A fee of thirty-five ($35.00) dollars shall be charged to any person or persons issuing checks to the Village of Hazel Crest which are returned for any reason to the village by a bank or other financial institution. 
(Ord. No. 48-1979, § 1, 11-13-79; Ord. No. 20-1985, § 1, 10-22-85; Ord. No. 11-1992, § 1, 8-11-92; Ord. No. 16-2003, 9-23-03) 
Chapter 2 - ADMINISTRATION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Civil defense and emergencies, Ch. 7; fire department, § 10-20 et seq.; health officer, § 13-17 et seq.; licenses and miscellaneous business regulations, Ch. 17; planning, Ch. 22; police, Ch. 24; taxation, Ch. 27; water and sewer department, § 29-22 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 2-1. - Corporate seal. 
    The corporate seal of the village shall be as established by the village board of trustees from time to time. 
(Code 1956, § 4.01) 
State Law reference- Authority to have corporate seal, 65 ILCS 5/2-2-12. 
Sec. 2-2. - Fiscal year. 
    The fiscal year of the village shall begin on the first day of May of each year and end on the last day of April of the year following. 
(Code 1956, § 4.02) 
State Law reference- Authority to establish fiscal year, 65 ILCS 5/1-1-2. 
Sec. 2-3. - Village datum. 
    The datum of the village is established and declared to be six hundred thirty-three and thirty-six thousandths (633.036) feet above sea level as indicated on a monument in front of the Municipal Center, outside the main entrance of 3000 W. 170th Place. The village datum was established April 27, 1993 at this location. 
(Code 1956, § 4.03) 
Sec. 2-4. - Required signatures on warrants. 
    All warrants drawn upon the treasury must be signed by the president of the village, the village clerk and treasurer. If any one of these three is unavailable, the chairman of the finance committee may sign in his place. The warrant must state the particular fund to which it is chargeable, the person to whom payable, and for what purpose it was drawn. No money shall be paid other than upon warrants so drawn. 
(Code 1956, § 4.04) 
Sec. 2-5. - Contracts for supplies exceeding ten thousand dollars. 
    All purchases of supplies of any kind or nature where the amount of such purchase shall exceed ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00), shall be furnished by contract let to the lowest responsible bidder after advertising thereof, unless the board of trustees specifically waives this provision before purchasing supplies. 
(Code 1956, § 4.05; Ord. No. 29-1977, § 1, 11-8-77; Ord. No. 7-1983, § 1, 5-10-83; Ord. No. 30-1997, § 1, 9-9-97) 
Sec. 2-6. - Surety bonds. 
    Whenever a surety bond to indemnify the village is required as a prerequisite to exercising the duties of any office or position, or to the issuance of a license or permit or the exercise of any special privilege, the surety on such bond shall be a corporation licensed and authorized to do business in this state as a surety company. 
(Code 1956, § 4.08) 
Sec. 2-7. - Disclosure of ownership or management interests in properties or developments required. 
(a)  For purposes of this section, a "multifamily residential development" means any building or structure or group of buildings or structures which contain two (2) or more dwellings under common management or ownership. 
(b)  The owners of all single-family rental properties, multifamily residential developments and all commercial properties in the village which require any type of permit, license, certificate or registration shall, within ninety (90) days from the date of Ordinance No. 24-1984 from which this section is derived, provide the village with the following information on a form made available by the village: 
(1)  The name and address of the property; 
(2)  The name, address and telephone number of the owner or owners of the property, or any interest therein; 
(3)  The name, address and telephone number of the managing agent or agents of the property; 
(4)  The name, address and telephone number of a responsible management agent who may receive telephone calls and inquiries from the village on a twenty-four-hour basis. 
(c)  Whenever the title to a single-family rental property, multifamily residential development or commercial property is held by a "land trust" as defined by 765 ILCS 405/1, the trustee shall, in addition to the information required hereinabove, identify each beneficiary of said land trust by name and address, and define his interest therein. 
(d)  Whenever there is a change in the ownership or management of a single-family rental property, a multifamily residential development or commercial business, the owner thereof shall, within thirty (30) days thereafter, so notify the village. 
(Ord. No. 24-1984, §§ 1-4, 7-10-84) 
Sec. 2-8. - Penalty on late payment on invoices for village services. 
    All invoices issued for village services, if not paid within thirty (30) days, will be subject to a ten (10) per cent late fee based on the total amount of the invoice. 
(Ord. No. 7-1998, § 1, 5-12-98) 
Secs. 2-9-2-18. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - LEGISLATIVE BODY 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 2-19. - Composition. 
(a)  The corporate authorities of the village shall consist of the president of the village, the village clerk, and six (6) trustees, who shall possess the legal qualifications for office and be elected by the persons qualified to vote for elective officers at municipal elections in the village. The president, village clerk and trustees shall take the oath of office and perform the duties provided by the Illinois Municipal Code, and shall perform such other duties as are required by law. 
(b)  Commencing with the municipal election held in and for the village on April 7, 1987, and continuing thereafter, the officers elected at such municipal elections provided such persons are otherwise qualified, shall be inaugurated immediately following the regular meeting of the president and board of trustees of the village held on the fourth Tuesday of April following such elections. 
(Code 1956, § 3.01; Ord. No. 10-1981, § 1, 3-24-81; Ord. No. 1-1987, § 1, 1-27-87) 
Sec. 2-20. - Regular meetings. 
    Meetings of the mayor and board of trustees shall be held on the second and fourth Tuesdays of each month at the village hall, unless otherwise established by consensus of the village board. The starting time for the meeting will be established by the agenda for the meeting and so posted. In case a board meeting falls on a legal holiday, such meeting may be rescheduled at the pleasure of the mayor and board of trustees. 
(Code 1956, § 3.02; Ord. No. 16-2008, § 1, 7-8-08; Ord. No. 03-2011, § 1, 5-24-11) 
Editor's note- Sections 2 and 3 of Ord. No. 03-2011 state the following: "Section 2: No meetings will be held in the month of August. 
 Section 3: The Village Board will only meet on the second Tuesday in the months of November and December." 
State Law reference- Authority to enact ordinance setting time and place of meetings, 65 ILCS 5/3-11-3. 
Sec. 2-21. - Special meetings. 
    Special meetings may be held at any time on call of the president or any two (2) or more trustees, which call shall be in writing, duly signed, and shall be presented to the clerk who shall proceed immediately to cause notice thereof to be served upon the president and trustees in person or by registered letter. Such notice shall describe in brief the nature or object of the call. Notice of any special meetings shall be given in accordance with the requirements of the Open Meetings Act. 
(Code 1956, § 3.03; Ord. No. 3-1989, § 1, 1-24-89) 
Sec. 2-22. - Quorum. 
    A majority of the board of trustees and village president shall constitute a quorum to do business, but a smaller number may convene from time to time, and may compel the attendance of absentees under such penalties as may be prescribed by ordinance. 
(Code 1956, § 3.04) 
Sec. 2-23. - Administrative meetings. 
    The president and board of trustees shall hold administrative workshop meetings on the first and third Tuesday of each month at 6:30 p.m. or such other time as the president and board of trustees may designate from time to time. 
(Ord. No. 08-2009, § 1, 6-9-09) 
Secs. 2-24-2-28. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - RULES AND ORDER OF BUSINESS 

Sec. 2-29. - Adopted. 
    The rules of order set forth in this division for the conduct of village business by the president and board of trustees are hereby adopted. 
(Code 1956, § 3.05) 
Sec. 2-30. - Assumption of chair; election of president pro tem. 
    The president shall, if present, take the chair at the hour appointed for the meeting of the board. The president and board of trustees may annually designate a trustee to serve as president pro tempore during specified periods in the event of the absence of the village president. If no president pro tem is designated, the board of trustees shall elect a president pro tem from among their members, who shall act in the president's place instead, and shall possess the powers of the president. 
(Code 1956, § 3.05, Rule 1; Ord. No. 3-1989, § 1, 1-24-89) 
Sec. 2-31. - Order of business. 
    After the meeting has been called to order, the order of business shall be as follows: 
(1)  Calling of the roll; 
(2)  Approval of the minutes of the last meeting; 
(3)  Consideration of accounts payable; 
(4)  Communications and petitions; 
(5)  Reports of committees and officers; 
(6)  Public participation; 
(7)  Pending (old) business. 
(8)  New business. 
    Absent an emergency, in order for new items of business to appear on the agenda at a village board meeting, it must first have been discussed by the board of trustees at an administrative meeting. The president and members of the board of trustees shall have the opportunity to submit new items to the village manager for placement on the administrative meeting agenda. The village manager will thereafter set the agenda for administrative meetings. Other items may be added to the agenda for the administrative meeting by a vote of a majority of all trustees then holding office. The village manager will ensure that all meetings, including without limitation administrative meetings, comply with the provisions of the Open Meetings Act. Nothing in this section shall be construed to give the village manager the authority to deny new items submitted by the corporate authorities from appearing on the administrative meeting agenda, except in the case where such items would be patently illegal or unconstitutional. 
(Code 1956, § 3.05, Rule 1; Ord. No. 20-2005, § 1, 7-26-05; Ord. No. 07-2013, § 3.0, 6-4-13) 
Editor's note- Section 2-31 was amended at the request of the village in June, 2002. 
Sec. 2-32. - Preservation of order; president's right to speak and decide points of order. 
    The president shall preserve order and decorum, may speak to points of order in preference to any member, and shall decide points of order subject to an appeal to the board of trustees by any two (2) members, on which appeal no member shall speak more than once unless by leave of the board. 
(Code 1956, § 3.05, Rule 2) 
Sec. 2-33. - Statement of question. 
    Every question shall be distinctly stated by the president before it is open for debate. Every motion shall be reduced to writing if the president or any member shall so demand. 
(Code 1956, § 3.05, Rule 3) 
Sec. 2-34. - President's right to call on others to act as chairman. 
    The president may call on any member to perform the duties of chairman, but no such substitution shall extend beyond the adjournment of the particular meeting. 
(Code 1956, § 3.05, Rule 4) 
Sec. 2-35. - Addressing chair prerequisite to speaking on question. 
    Every member, previous to speaking to any question, shall audibly address the presiding officer as "Mr. President." Such member shall not, however, speak further until he is recognized and named. 
(Code 1956, § 3.05, Rule 5) 
Sec. 2-36. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 9-1993, § 1, May 25, 1993, amended the Code by deleting provisions contained in § 2-36. Said provisions pertained to the reading of ordinances prerequisite to passage and derived from the Code of 1956, § 3.05, Rule 6. 
Sec. 2-37. - Certain ordinances to require absolute majority. 
    The passage of all ordinances for whatever purpose, and of any resolution or motion to create any liability against the village or for the expenditure or appropriation of its money, shall require the concurrence of a majority of all members elected to the village board, including the president. The yeas and nays shall be taken upon the question of passage of the designated ordinances, resolutions or motions and recorded in the journal of the village board. Likewise the yeas and nays shall be taken upon the passage of any other resolution or motion at the request of any trustee, and shall be recorded in the journal. Except where otherwise provided by state statute, the passage of all ordinances for whatever purpose, and of any resolutions for motion to create any liability against the village, or for the expenditure or appropriation of its monies, shall require the concurrence of majority of all members elected to the village board, including the president. 
(Code 1956, § 3.05, Rule 7; Ord. No. 3-1989, § 1, 1-24-89) 
Sec. 2-38. - President's right, duty to vote. 
(a)  The president may vote on any ordinance, resolution or motion and shall vote in the following instances: 
(1)  Where the vote of the trustees has resulted in a tie; 
(2)  Where one-half (1/2) of the trustees have voted in favor of an ordinance, resolution or motion even though there is no tie vote; 
(3)  Where a vote greater than a majority is required by this Code to adopt an ordinance, resolution or motion. 
(b)  Nothing in this section shall deprive a president pro tem from voting in his capacity as trustee, but he shall not be entitled to another vote in his capacity as president pro tem. 
(Code 1956, § 3.05, Rule 8) 
Sec. 2-39. - Voting prohibited where prohibited by statute. 
    Any member of the board of trustees is prohibited from voting in those instances where prohibited by statute, such as those set forth in the conflict of interest statute, 65 ILCS 5/3-14-4. 
(Code 1956, § 3.05, Rule 9; Ord. No. 3-1989, § 1, 1-24-89) 
Sec. 2-40. - President ex officio member of all committees. 
    The president of the village shall be an ex officio member of all committees. 
(Code 1956, § 3.05, Rule 10) 
Sec. 2-41. - Standing committees. 
    The standing committees of the village and interrelationships between such committees shall be as established from time to time by the board of trustees. 
(Code 1956, § 3.05, Rule 10) 
Sec. 2-42. - Special committees. 
    Special committees may be appointed for the consideration of any particular question or matter. Such special committees shall be appointed by the president with the advice and consent of the board of trustees. 
(Code 1956, § 3.05, Rule 11) 
Sec. 2-43. - Committee reports. 
    All committees to which any matter may be referred shall report in writing if requested by any member. Minority reports may be submitted signed by the dissenting member or members. 
(Code 1956, § 3.05, Rule 12) 
Sec. 2-44. - Discharge of special committees. 
    On the acceptance of a final report from a special committee, such committee shall stand discharged without vote unless it is otherwise ordered. 
(Code 1956, § 3.05, Rule 13) 
Sec. 2-45. - Reports, papers, etc., to be filed by clerk. 
    All reports made by committees or officers of the village, all resolutions adopted, all ordinances presented and passed, all communications, petitions and the like received, and generally all papers presented to be acted on shall be filed and carefully preserved by the clerk. 
(Code 1956, § 3.05, Rules 13, 14) 
Sec. 2-46. - Petitions, communications to be in writing. 
    All petitions or communications shall be addressed to the president and board of trustees, and shall be in writing. 
(Code 1956, § 3.05, Rule 14) 
Sec. 2-47. - Statement of nature of communication prior to presentation. 
    When a member wishes to present a communication, petition, order, resolution or other original matter, he shall briefly state its nature before presenting it. 
(Code 1956, § 3.05, Rule 15) 
Sec. 2-48. - Consent of president prerequisite to address by nonmember. 
    No person, except a member of the board, shall be permitted to address the president or the board without the consent of the president. 
(Code 1956, § 3.05, Rule 16) 
Sec. 2-49. - Robert's Rules of Order to govern questions not covered by division. 
    The president shall decide all questions of order, and in all cases not covered by the rules set forth in this division, or where they are not applicable, the board shall be governed by parliamentary law as laid down in Robert's Rules of Order. 
(Code 1956, § 3.05, Rule 18) 
Sec. 2-50. - Motions in order when question before the board. 
    When a question is before the board, no motions shall be in order but to adjourn, lay on the table, previous question, postpone indefinitely, postpone to a certain time, to commit, and amend. These motions shall be privileged and have precedence in the order named. 
(Code 1956, § 3.05, Rule 19) 
Sec. 2-51. - Compensation. 
(a)  All members of the board of trustees elected at the April 2009 election and elected or appointed thereafter shall receive an annual salary of fifteen thousand dollars ($15,000.00) payable monthly with a three (3) per cent annual increase thereafter beginning May 1, 2010. 
(b)  In the event a trustee is absent for more than four (4) regularly scheduled board meetings or administrative meetings in a calendar year, thirty dollars ($30.00) shall be deducted from the trustee's salary for each absence following the fourth absence. 
(Code 1956, § 3.06; Ord. No. 25-1972, § 2, 12-26-72; Ord. No. 2-1987, § 1, 1-27-87; Ord. No. 4-1989, § 1, 1-24-89; Ord. No. 2-1995, § 1, 1-24-95; Ord. No. 24-1998, § 1, 9-22-98; Ord. No. 7-1999, § 1, 4-27-99; Ord. No. 15-2008, § 1, 7-8-08; Ord. No. 13-2010, § 1, 9-28-10; Ord. No. 05-2011, § 3, 5-2-11) 
Editor's note- Section 2-51 was amended at the request of the village in June 2002 to remove expired provisions. 
State Law reference- Power to establish compensation, 65 ILCS 5/3-13-7. 
Sec. 2-52. - Limited public forum. 
    The following procedures regarding the conduct of regular and special meetings where public participation is granted for the village are hereby adopted: 
(a)  No person shall speak unless and until recognized by the chairman, consistent with section 2-48 of this Code. The chairman shall preserve order and decorum at the meeting. 
(b)  Any person recognized by the chairman may speak or provide remarks for a maximum of three (3) minutes in total. The three-minute time allotment may not be assigned (in whole or in part) to another speaker. Time shall be kept by the clerk. The clerk shall notify the board of trustees and the speaker when the speaker's time has expired. 
(c)  All persons speaking shall address the chairman and the remaining members of the board of trustees and do so with decorum, courtesy and not in a violent manner. Any person speaking shall upon recognition by the chairman immediately identify himself or herself by name and business or home address. 
(d)  All persons speaking shall address the chairman and the remaining members of the board of trustees only once, unless granted an additional opportunity to speak by the board of trustees participating in the meeting. 
(Ord. No. 18-2011, § 3, 12-13-11) 
Secs. 2-53-2-61. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - OFFICERS AND EMPLOYEES[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Power to provide for appointment of officers, 65 ILCS 5/3-8-1. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 2-62. - Appointive officers-Designated. 
(a)  Among the officers of the village to be appointed by the president and board of trustees, whose offices are hereby created and established, are the following: 
(1)  Village treasurer. 
(2)  Village manager. 
(3)  Village attorney. 
(b)  All appointees may be suspended or removed from office from time to time by the president and board of trustees, and all vacancies may be filled in like manner. 
(Code 1956, § 5.01; Ord. No. 4-1979, § 1, 2-13-79; Ord. No. 3-1989, § 1, 1-24-89; Ord. No. 10-2010, § 1, 5-25-10; Ord. No. 04-2011, § 3, 5-24-11) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 10-2010, § 1, adopted May 25, 2010, repealed section 2-62 in its entirety. Inasmuch as Ord. No. 10-2010 was subsequently repealed, revoked and vacated by Ord. No. 04-2011, § 3, adopted May 24, 2011, section 2-62 remains as previously enacted. The historical notation has been preserved for reference purposes. 
Sec. 2-63. - Same-Term. 
    All appointive officers of the village shall hold their offices until their successors have been appointed and qualified; subject, however, to removal at any time by the president and board of trustees, with or without specification of cause therefor. 
(Code 1956, § 5.02) 
Sec. 2-64. - Officer's oath. 
    All officers of the village, whether elected or appointed, before entering upon the duties of their respective offices, shall take and subscribe to the oath or affirmation as provided by the Illinois Revised Statutes for village officers, which oath or affirmation, so subscribed, shall be filed in the office of the clerk. 
(Code 1956, § 5.03) 
Sec. 2-65. - Bonds-Required. 
    In all cases not specifically provided for elsewhere in this Code, the officers of the village shall give such bonds and within such time as the president and board of trustees may require, or as may be required by law. Should good cause exist, in the judgment and discretion of the board of trustees, any officer may be required from time to time to give additional bonds in such sum and within such time as the board may by resolution direct. 
(Code 1956, § 5.04) 
State Law reference- Bonds of officers, 65 ILCS 5/3-14-3. 
Sec. 2-66. - Same-Execution. 
    The bond of each officer shall be executed to the village with two (2) or more sureties conditioned for the faithful performance of the duties of his office and the payment to the proper officer of all moneys coming into his hands by virtue of his office. Each of such sureties shall be freeholders of Cook County, and shall schedule real estate herein, clear of all encumbrances and other legal obligations, in value not less than the penal sum of such bond, which schedule shall be made separately by such sureties and sworn to before some officer authorized to administer oaths, and attached to such bond; provided, that any officer of the village may procure as surety upon any bond he may be required to give any responsible surety company or corporation. No member of the board of trustees shall sign any bond in any case wherein the village is interested. 
(Code 1956, § 5.05) 
Sec. 2-67. - Same-Approval; filing. 
    The bonds of all village officers shall be subject to the approval of the president and board of trustees. After such approval, the clerk shall endorse thereon the date thereof and file the same in his office, except the bond of the clerk, which shall be filed with the treasurer. 
(Code 1956, § 5.06) 
Sec. 2-68. - Effect of failure of officers-elect to qualify. 
    If any person who has been elected or appointed to any office of the village fails to qualify by taking, subscribing and filing the oath of office, and making, executing and filing his official bond as provided in this article, within ten (10) days after he is officially notified of his election or appointment, the office shall become vacant. 
(Code 1956, § 5.07) 
Sec. 2-69. - Payment of salaries. 
    Unless otherwise specified in this Code, the salary and pay of all employees shall be paid semimonthly to each person entitled thereto. The village president, village clerk and village treasurer shall be paid monthly and the board of trustees shall be paid quarterly. 
(Code 1956, § 5.08; Ord. No. § 36-1988, 9-27-88) 
Sec. 2-70. - Retention of village receipts prohibited. 
    No officer, deputy to an officer, employee, inspector or person acting as a representative of the village shall retain any license fee, permit fee, inspection fee or compensation for any service in his capacity as such, for any thing, act or service required to be done or authorized by this Code, but all such fees shall be turned over to the village collector. 
(Code 1956, § 5.08) 
Sec. 2-71. - Officers and employees to surrender village property at end of terms. 
    Any person who has been an officer or employee of the village, whose term has expired or who has resigned or been removed from office, within ten (10) days after notification and request therefor shall deliver to his successor in office all property, books and effects of every description in his possession belonging to the village or appertaining to his office. 
(Code 1956, § 5.09) 
Sec. 2-72. - Officer's duties generally. 
    In addition to the specific duties which may be required of any officer of the village by virtue of his office, each officer shall perform such other and further duties and be subject to such rules and regulations as the president and board of trustees may require from time to time, or may provide and establish by ordinance. 
(Code 1956, § 5.10) 
Sec. 2-73. - Books, papers subject to examination. 
    All books, papers, vouchers, warrants, entries, accounts and memoranda of each and every officer and employee of the village may be examined at any time by the president, and the president and board of trustees may call upon any officer to make a report in writing of any subject matter which the board may designate. 
(Code 1956, § 5.11) 
Sec. 2-74. - Office hours. 
    Unless otherwise provided, the offices of the respective village officers which are located in the village shall be opened for business from 8:00 a.m. to 5:00 p.m. Monday through Friday. Such offices shall be closed Saturdays, Sundays and all legal holidays, unless special hours are established by the village manager or village board. 
(Code 1956, § 5.12; Ord. No. 36-1988, 9-27-88) 
Sec. 2-75. - Participation in state municipal retirement fund. 
    The village does hereby elect to participate in the Illinois Municipal Retirement Fund, effective January 1, 1965. 
(Ord. No. 12-1964, 7-14-64) 
Sec. 2-76. - Residence of employees. 
(a)  There is hereby established a residence zone comprised of all of the territory of the village and those portions of other municipalities and the unincorporated territory of Cook County outside of but adjacent to the corporate limits of the Village of Hazel Crest, but within the boundaries of such residence zone. 
(b)  The boundaries of such residence zone are as follows: 
To the north: 95th Street. 
To the east: The Indiana border. 
To the south: 25000 south. 
To the west: Wolf Road. 
(c)  All employees of the village shall within six (6) months after completion of their probationary period, establish residence within the residency zone and shall maintain their residences within the residency zone as long as they remain employees of the village. 
The village manager shall establish residence within the corporate limits of the Village of Hazel Crest within twelve (12) months after his/her initial appointment and shall maintain such residence within the village as long as he/she remains so employed. The village manager, police chief, fire chief, and director of public works shall reside with the following residence zone within twelve (12) months of their appointment: 
Cook/Will Boundary on the south. 
State Line on the east. 
Harlem on the west. 
87 th Street on the north. 
(d)  It shall be considered cause for discharge of an employee who, within a reasonable time, fails to establish residence within the residence zone, or, after having established such residence, fails to maintain a residence within the residence zone. 
(e)  For purposes of this section the following terms shall have the following meanings: 
(1)  Employee means a full-time employee of the village or an officer or member of the police or fire departments of the village. 
(2)  Residence means the actual and principal place of abode of the employee from which he is registered to vote, or if not so registered, could register to vote if qualified to do so. 
(3)  Residence zone means that territory lying within the boundaries described in subparagraph (b) of this section. 
(4)  Establish means the moving by the employee of his household effects and personal belongings to living quarters located within the residence zone with the intent to make such living quarters his principal place of abode. 
(5)  Maintain means the actual use by such employee of an established residence, whether that be the initially established residence or at a subsequently established residence within the residence zone. 
(6)  Reasonable time means that period of time after initial appointment within which, taking all factors into consideration, an employee with a bona fide intent to comply with this section, could have established residence in the residence zone. Reasonable time shall be determined by the village manager. Reasonable time shall be determined by the board of fire and police commissioners for officers and members of the police and fire departments of the village. 
(7)  Exempt employee means those employees not in the classified civil service of the village or a regular member of the police or fire departments of the village. Exempt employee shall include manager, assistant manager, police chief, fire chief, director of public works, office administrator and such other employees as the president and board of trustees may, from time to time, designate. 
(f)  No employee shall change his or her residence without first advising the applicable department head of such change so that the department head may determine whether such move complies with this section. 
(Ord. No. 22-1975, § 1, 7-22-75; Ord. No. 36-1988, 9-27-88; Ord. No. 10-1993, §§ 1, 2, 6-8-93; Ord. No. 24-1994, § 1, 11-9-94; Ord. No. 28-1994, §§ 1, 2, 9-27-94; Ord. No. 23-1996, § 1, 12-17-96; Ord. No. 20-2001, § 1, 10-9-01; Ord. No. 02-2009, § 1, 4-14-09; Ord. No. 05-2010, § 2, 4-13-10; Ord. No. 15-2011, § 1, 10-25-11) 
Sec. 2-77. - Establishment of general prevailing rates of wages. 
    The village shall comply with the requirements of 820 ILCS 130/1 et seq., pertaining to the establishment of general prevailing rates of wages on an annual basis. 
(Ord. No. 22-1978, §§ 1-4, 6-27-78; Ord. No. 3-1989, § 1, 1-24-89) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 22-1978, §§ 1-4, was not amendatory of this Code and was codified as § 2-77 at the editor's discretion. 
State Law reference- Act regulating wages of laborers, mechanics and other workmen in any public works, 820 ILCS 130/1 through 130/12. 
Secs. 2-78-2-82. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - PRESIDENT[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference- Emergency powers of president, § 7-24 et seq. 
State Law reference- Village president's powers and duties, 65 ILCS 5/3-12-3. 

Sec. 2-83. - Election, qualifications. 
    The president of the village shall be elected every four (4) years at the regular village election, and shall hold such office for four (4) years and until his successor is elected and qualified. He shall be a citizen of the United States, a qualified elector, and shall have resided within the corporate limits of the village at least one (1) year next preceding the election at which he is a candidate. 
(Code 1956, § 5.13) 
Sec. 2-84. - Bond. 
    The president of the village shall, before he enters upon the duties of his office, execute a bond to the village in the penal sum of three thousand dollars ($3,000.00) with sureties to be approved by the board of trustees, conditioned as prescribed by 65 ILCS 5/3-14-30. 
(Code 1956, 5.14) 
Sec. 2-85. - Executive duties; compensation; veto power. 
(a)  The president of the village shall perform the duties and exercise the powers conferred upon the mayor of a city. 
(b)  The president shall devote such time to the duties of his office as the faithful discharge thereof may require. The village president elected at the April 2001 election and elected or appointed thereafter shall receive an annual salary of eight thousand dollars ($8,000.00) for service as president payable in equal monthly installments with a three (3) per cent annual increase thereafter beginning May 1, 2002. In the event the president is absent for more than four (4) regularly scheduled board meetings or administrative meetings in a calendar year, thirty dollars ($30.00) shall be deducted from the president's salary for each absence following the fourth absence. The village mayor elected at the April 2009 election and elected or appointed thereafter shall receive an annual salary of thirty thousand dollars ($30,000.00) for service as mayor payable in equal monthly installments with a three (3) per cent annual increase thereafter beginning May 1, 2010. 
(c)  The president of the village may exercise the same veto powers, and with like effect, as the mayor of a city; and the board of trustees may pass ordinances over such veto in like manner as a city council. 
(Code 1956, § 5.15; Ord. No. 5-1965, 4-13-65; Ord. No. 25-1972, § 1, 12-20-72; Ord. No. 5-1989, § 1, 1-24-89; Ord. No. 24-1998, § 2, 9-22-98; Ord. No. 15-2008, § 2, 7-8-08; Ord. No. 10-2010, §§ 2, 3, 5-25-10; Ord. No. 13-2010, § 2, 9-28-10; Ord. No. 04-2011, § 3, 5-24-11; Ord. No. 05-2011, § 3, 5-2-11) 
Editor's note- Section 2-85 was amended in June 2002 at the request of the village to remove expired provisions. 
Sec. 2-86. - Reserved. 
Sec. 2-87. - Appointments. 
    The president and board of trustees shall appoint all officers of the village whose appointments are not otherwise provided for by statute. Whenever a vacancy shall occur in any office which by statute or ordinance the president is authorized to fill, at the next regular meeting of the board of trustees, he shall communicate to the board of trustees his choice of an appointee to such office, and, pending the approval or rejection thereof by the board of trustees, he may designate some suitable person to discharge the duties of such office. 
(Code 1956, § 5.17) 
Sec. 2-88. - General duties. 
    The president of the village shall supervise the conduct of all appointed officers and see that they faithfully and efficiently discharge the duties of their respective offices; he shall inquire into all reasonable complaints made against them and cause any neglect or violation of duties to be promptly corrected; from time to time he shall give the board of trustees such information relative to the affairs of the village as he may deem proper; and he shall recommend for its consideration any measure he may deem expedient and tending to the well-being, security and improvement of the village. 
(Code 1956, § 5.18; Ord. No. 10-2010, § 4, 5-25-10; Ord. No. 04-2011, § 3, 5-24-11) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 10-2010, § 4, adopted May 25, 2010, repealed section 2-88 in its entirety. Inasmuch as Ord. No. 10-2010 was subsequently repealed, revoked and vacated by Ord. No. 04-2011, § 3, adopted May 24, 2011, section 2-88 remains as previously enacted. The historical notation has been preserved for reference purposes. 
Sec. 2-89. - Approval, veto of ordinances. 
    The president of the village shall carefully inspect all ordinances passed by the board of trustees, affix his official signature to such as he may approve, and return them to the village clerk. Such ordinances as he shall not approve shall be returned to the board of trustees, with his written objections, at the next regular meeting of the board occurring not less than five (5) days after their passage. Such veto may extend to any one or more items or appropriation contained in any ordinance making an appropriation, and if so, the remainder shall be effective. However, the president may disapprove entirely an ordinance, resolution or motion making an appropriation. If the president fails to return any ordinance with his written objections within the designated time, it shall become effective despite the absence of his signature. 
(Code 1956, § 5.19; Ord. No. 3-1989, § 1, 1-24-89) 
Sec. 2-90. - Signing of licenses, permits, commissions and warrants. 
    The president of the village shall sign all commissions, licenses, permits and warrants as provided by state statute or authorized by the ordinances of the village, except for those permits, licenses, and warrants provided to be issued by or under the signature of the village manager, health officer, building inspector, or fire chief, and may revoke any such license for cause. 
(Code 1956, § 5.20; Ord. No. 3-1989, § 1, 1-24-89) 
Sec. 2-91. - Release of prisoners. 
    The president of the village, for good and sufficient reasons, may release any person imprisoned for violation of any village ordinance. The president shall cause a proper record thereof to be made, and shall report such release with the reason therefor to the board of trustees at its first session thereafter. 
(Code 1956, § 5.21; Ord. No. 10-2010, § 5, 5-25-10; Ord. No. 04-2011, § 3, 5-24-11) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 10-2010, § 5, adopted May 25, 2010, repealed section 2-91 in its entirety. Inasmuch as Ord. No. 10-2010 was subsequently repealed, revoked and vacated by Ord. No. 04-2011, § 3, adopted May 24, 2011, section 2-91 remains as previously enacted. The historical notation has been preserved for reference purposes. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 65 ILCS 5/3-11-12. 
Sec. 2-92. - Conveyance of tax titles. 
    Upon such terms as may be agreed upon, with the consent of the board of trustees, the village president may sell and convey any and all lots and parcels of land to which a title is held by the village pursuant to sale and conveyance for the village taxes or assessments. 
(Code 1956, § 5.22) 
Sec. 2-93. - Litigation powers. 
    After approval by the village board of trustees, the president of the village shall sign, and is hereby authorized to sign in behalf of the village, all instruments necessary to the prompt prosecution or defense of any or all actions brought by or against the village, including bonds for injunction. 
(Code 1956, § 5.23; Ord. No. 10-2010, § 6, 5-25-10; Ord. No. 04-2011, § 3, 5-24-11) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 10-2010, § 6, adopted May 25, 2010, repealed section 2-93 in its entirety. Inasmuch as Ord. No. 10-2010 was subsequently repealed, revoked and vacated by Ord. No. 04-2011, § 3, adopted May 24, 2011, section 2-93 remains as previously enacted. The historical notation has been preserved for reference purposes. 
Secs. 2-94-2-99. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 11-2010, §§ 1, 2, adopted May 25, 2010, repealed the former sections 2-94 and 2-95 in their entirety, which pertained to liaison to village president; duties, and director of neighborhood affairs and special events; duties, respectively, and derived from Ord. No. 17-2005, §§ 1, 2, adopted May 24, 2005. 
DIVISION 3. - VILLAGE ATTORNEY[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 10-2010, § 7, adopted May 25, 2010, repealed division 3, sections 2-100-2-102 in its entirety. Inasmuch as Ord. No. 10-2010 was subsequently repealed, revoked and vacated by Ord. No. 04-2011, § 3, adopted May 24, 2011, division 3, sections 2-100-2-102 remains as previously enacted. The historical notation has been preserved for reference purposes. 

Sec. 2-100. - Duties. 
    The village attorney shall conduct all the law business of the village and draw up such ordinances, deeds, leases and other papers as may be required of him by the president and board of trustees, or any committee thereof. 
(Code 1956, § 5.34; Ord. No. 10-2010, § 7, 5-25-10; Ord. No. 04-2011, § 3, 5-24-11) 
Sec. 2-101. - Opinions. 
    The village attorney shall give his opinion, in writing, to the board of trustees or village manager, or to the village president, when requested, on legal questions arising under and concerning any ordinance of the village, and on questions and subjects in which the village shall be legally interested. 
(Code 1956, § 5.35; Ord. No. 36-1988, 9-27-88; Ord. No. 10-2010, § 7, 5-25-10; Ord. No. 04-2011, § 3, 5-24-11) 
Sec. 2-102. - Compensation. 
    The village attorney shall receive such compensation which will be set from time to time by the president and the board of trustees. 
(Code 1956, § 5.37; Ord. No. 6-1959, § I, 5-12-59; Ord. No. 36-1988, 9-27-88; Ord. No. 10-2010, § 7, 5-25-10; Ord. No. 04-2011, § 3, 5-24-11) 
Secs. 2-103-2-108. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - VILLAGE CLERK[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
State Law reference- Election and term of clerk, 65 ILCS 5/3-5-9; functions and duties of clerk, 65 ILCS 5/3-5-9. 

Sec. 2-109. - Election, qualifications. 
    The village clerk shall be elected when the village president is elected, and shall hold office for four (4) years and until a successor is elected and qualified; he shall be a citizen of the United States, a qualified elector, and shall have resided within the corporate limits of the village at least one (1) year next preceding the election at which he is a candidate. 
Sec. 2-110. - Bond. 
    The village clerk, before entering upon the duties of his office, shall extend to the village a bond in the penal sum of three thousand dollars ($3,000.00) with sureties to be approved by the board of trustees, conditioned as provided by law. 
(Code 1956, § 5.24) 
Sec. 2-111. - Duties. 
    In addition to the duties now imposed upon the village clerk by statute, he shall perform the following duties: 
(1)  Keep his office in the village offices in the administration building open for the transaction of village business during usual daily business hours, or at such other place as the village president shall direct. 
(2)  Issue notices of meetings to the president and members of the village board, and when directed by that body, to the members of the different committees of that body and all persons whose attendance will be required before the board or any committee thereof, when so directed; and issue and cause to be served notice of such meetings. 
(3)  Attest all the licenses granted by the village president or board of trustees under the ordinances of the village. 
(4)  Without delay deliver to the officers of the village and to the various committees, all bills, resolutions, communications and other documents referring to such officers and committees. 
(5)  Without delay deliver to the president of the village all ordinances or resolutions under his charge which may require approval or other action by the president, with all papers and information on which the same were founded. 
(6)  Reserved. 
(7)  Perform such other duties as may be required of him by the village president and board of trustees and the ordinances of the village. 
(Code 1956, § 5.25; Ord. No. 3-1989, § 1, 1-24-89) 
Sec. 2-112. - Keeper of seal and records. 
    The village clerk shall keep the corporate seal and all records and papers belonging to the village, the custody and control of which are not given to other officers, and shall attend all meetings of the president and board of trustees and keep a full record of its proceedings in the journal. He shall prepare all warrants for the payment of money and shall sign and deliver them when called for, after they have been countersigned by the president of the village. He shall make proper copies of all papers duly filed in his office and make transcripts from the journal and other records and files of his office, certified by him under the corporate seal. 
(Code 1956, § 5.26) 
Sec. 2-113. - Recording and publication of ordinances. 
    All ordinances passed by the village president and board of trustees shall be recorded after they go into effect by the clerk in a book kept for that purpose, before the next regular meeting, and if the ordinance requires publication, he shall cause it to be duly published. The clerk shall note at the foot of the record of each ordinance a memorandum of the date of its passage and approval or otherwise becoming effective, and if published, the date of the publication. The original shall be filed in the office of the clerk with a certificate of publication or posting attached to any ordinance requiring publication. 
(Code 1956, § 5.27) 
Sec. 2-114. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 3-1989, § 1, adopted Jan. 24, 1989, repealed former § 2-114, which pertained to notification of persons elected or appointed to office, former § 2-116, which pertained to records of expenses and payments, and former § 2-117, which pertained to report of village expenses, which sections derived from the 1956 Code, §§ 5.28, 5.30 and 5.31. 
Sec. 2-115. - Filing of tax levy. 
    It shall be the duty of the village clerk, on or before the second Tuesday in December, each year, to file with the county clerk a certified copy of the ordinance in which the total amount of appropriations for all corporate purposes of the village, legally made, are levied and assessed for the current fiscal year. 
(Code 1956, § 5.29; Ord. No. 3-1989, § 1, 1-24-89) 
Secs. 2-116, 2-117. - Reserved. 
Note- See the editor's note to § 2-114. 
Sec. 2-118. - Petitions, communications. 
    All petitions, remonstrances, bids, bills or other communications addressed to the village or board of trustees shall be received by the clerk and read by him at the board meeting next succeeding their receipt, unless otherwise ordered by the village board. 
(Code 1956, § 5.32) 
Sec. 2-119. - Compensation. 
    The village clerk elected at the April 2001 election and elected or appointed thereafter shall receive an annual salary of three thousand dollars ($3,000.00) payable monthly, with a three (3) per cent annual increase thereafter beginning May 1, 2002; provided further that in the event the clerk is absent for more than four (4) regularly scheduled board meetings or administrative meetings in a calendar year, thirty dollars ($30.00) shall be deducted from the clerk's salary for each absence following the fourth absence. The clerk shall have such other clerical and stenographic assistance as shall be approved by the president and board of trustees. 
    The village clerk elected at the April 2009 election and elected or appointed thereafter shall receive an annual salary of fifteen thousand dollars ($15,000.00) payable monthly with a three (3) per cent annual increase thereafter beginning on May 1, 2010. 
(Code 1956, § 5.33; Ord. No. 6-1989, § 1, 1-24-89; Ord. No. 24-1998, § 3, 9-22-98; Ord. No. 15-2008, § 3, 7-8-08; Ord. No. 13-2010, § 3, 9-28-10; Ord. No. 05-2011, § 3, 5-2-11) 
Editor's note- Section 2-119 was amended at the request of the village in June 2002 to remove expired provisions. 
Secs. 2-120-2-125. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 5. - VILLAGE TREASURER[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
State Law reference- Authority to appoint, 65 ILCS 5/3-10-5.1; duties generally, 65 ILCS 5/3-10-5.1. 

Sec. 2-126. - Appointment. 
    The village treasurer shall be appointed by the president with the consent of the board of trustees. 
Sec. 2-127. - Bond. 
    The village treasurer, before entering upon the duties of this office, shall execute to the village a bond conditioned for the faithful discharge of his duties and sureties to be provided by the president and the board of trustees in the amount of money that is not less than three (3) times the latest federal census population or any subsequent census figure used for motor fuel tax purposes. 
(Code 1956, § 5.38; Ord. No. 3-1989, § 1, 1-24-89) 
Sec. 2-128. - General duties. 
(a)  The village treasurer shall receive all moneys belonging to the village and shall render at the end of each and every month and more often, if required, a statement to the board of trustees showing the state of the treasury at the date of such account, and the balance of money therein. Such statement shall set forth all the moneys received by him, from whom and on what account, and all moneys paid out by him and on what account. 
(b)  The village treasurer shall keep by double entry a full detailed account of village funds, general tax receipts, and receipts from other sources, and shall also keep such funds as required by generally accepted accounting principles in a manner consistent with good accounting procedures and internal controls. He shall keep a ledger in which all special funds shall be listed, showing the total amount of each fund and the installment thereof to be collected; each amount shall show the total collections and disbursements on account of same. 
(c)  The village treasurer shall work with the village accounting staff regarding keeping of account books. He shall sign all checks and warrants, along with the president and village manager, issued by the village. Each warrant, as soon as it is issued by the village manager and signed by the president, shall be registered by the village treasurer in the warrant account with each fund, showing under separate headings the dates and amounts of payment made thereon and when cancelled. The village treasurer shall exercise other duties as shall be established by state law, local ordinance or local village policy. 
(Code 1956, §§ 5.39, 5.41; Ord. No. 3-1989, § 1, 1-24-89) 
Editor's note- Section 2-128 was amended in June 2002 at the request of the village to remove obsolete provisions pertaining the former office of village collector. 
Sec. 2-129. - Annual treasurer's report. 
    The village treasurer shall file an annual treasurer's report as required by 65 ILCS 5/3-10-5.1. 
(Ord. No. 3-1989, § 1, 1-24-89) 
Sec. 2-130. - To keep books of account. 
    The village treasurer shall cause to be kept books of account in such manner as to accurately show all moneys received by him, from whom and on what account they have been received; also all moneys paid out by him and on what account they have been paid. Such books shall be kept in such a manner as to be readily understood and investigated; and all such books, papers and files of his office shall be open to the examination of the president and board of trustees or any member thereof at any time. 
(Code 1956, § 5.40) 
Sec. 2-131. - Compensation. 
    The village treasurer shall receive such compensation as set from time to time by the board of trustees. 
(Code 1956, § 5.42; Ord. No. 3-1989, § 1, 1-24-89) 
Sec. 2-132. - Deposit of funds, designation of bank. 
(a)  All funds and moneys belonging to the village, in the custody of the village treasurer, may be kept on deposit in approved banks as directed by the board of trustees. Such banks shall not be qualified to receive funds or moneys of the village until they have furnished the corporate authorities with two (2) copies of the last two (2) sworn statements of resources and liabilities which the banks are required to furnish to the auditor of public accounts or to the comptroller of currency, and such banks, while acting as such depositories, shall furnish the corporate authorities with a copy of all statements of resources and liabilities which they are required to furnish to the auditor of public accounts or to the comptroller of currency. The village treasurer shall be discharged from responsibility for all funds or moneys which he deposits in such banks while the funds and moneys are so deposited; provided, however, the amount of such deposits shall not exceed seventy-five (75) per cent of any such bank's capital stock and surplus, and the village treasurer shall be responsible for funds or moneys deposited in any such bank in excess of that limitation. 
(b)  Such funds or moneys shall be subject to withdrawal from time to time upon checks or combination voucher-checks signed by the village treasurer, the president of the board of trustees and the village clerk. 
(Code 1956, § 5.43) 
Secs. 2-133-2-139. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 6. - ADMINISTRATIVE ADJUDICATION HEARING OFFICERS 

Sec. 2-140. - Administrative adjudication hearing officers. 
    The village mayor with the advice and consent of the board of trustees may appoint five (5) individuals to serve as hearing officers with respect to the village's administrative adjudication system for parking, standing and compliance violations within the Village of Hazel Crest. 
(1)  Each hearing officer shall be appointed for a two-year term. The terms will be staggered. 
(2)  The compensation for the hearing officer shall be established by the board of trustees from time to time. 
(Ord. No. 19-2001, § 1(2-29), 10-9-01; Ord. No. 19-2007, § 1(2-29), 11-13-07)
