Editor's note- Ord. No. 19-2001, § 1, adopted Oct. 9, 2001, added provisions designated as section 2-29. In order to keep related subject matter together, the editor has redesignated the provisions of Ord. No. 19-2001 as Div. 6 of Art. III, section 2-140. 
Secs. 2-141-2-150. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 7. - VILLAGE MANAGER 

Sec. 2-151. - Office established. 
    There is hereby established the office of village manager for the Village of Hazel Crest. 
(Ord. No. 26-1974, § 1, 9-24-74) 
Sec. 2-152. - Appointment and term of office. 
(a)  The village manager shall be appointed by the board of trustees. The appointment shall be made without regard to political beliefs. Notwithstanding section 2-76 of the Village Code, the village manager need not be a resident of the village when appointed but, within a reasonable time as determined by the village board, will establish residence within the corporate limits of Hazel Crest. 
(b)  The manager shall serve for an indefinite term. 
(Ord. No. 26-1974, § 2, 9-24-74; Ord. No. 22-1979, § 1, 5-8-79; Ord. No. 25-1979, § 1, 5-22-79) 
Sec. 2-153. - Qualifications. 
    The village manager shall be appointed solely on the basis of his proven education, training, knowledge, and ability in the field of municipal administration, and shall hold an M.A. degree in public administration or related field. 
(Ord. No. 26-1974, § 3, 9-24-74) 
Sec. 2-154. - Powers and duties generally. 
    The village manager shall be the chief administrative officer of the government of the village and he shall be responsible for the efficient administration of all departments of the village. 
    The powers and duties of the village manager shall be to: 
(a)  Enforce this Code and other ordinances within the village including applicable state statutes. 
(b)  Have all the powers and exercise all the duties granted in the Illinois Municipal Code to municipal clerks and comptrollers with respect to the preparation of a report of the estimated funds necessary to defray the expenses of the village for the fiscal year for the consideration of the president and board of trustees prior to the preparation of the annual appropriation ordinance. 
(c)  Prepare the budget annually and submit it to the board of trustees together with a message describing the important features and be responsible for its administration after adoption. 
(d)  Prepare and submit to the board of trustees as of the end of the fiscal year, a complete report on the finances and administrative activities of the village for the preceding year. 
(e)  Keep the board of trustees advised of the financial condition and future needs of the village, and make such recommendations as he may deem necessary. 
(f)  Exercise control of all departments and divisions thereof created by the Illinois Municipal Code and by any ordinance of the village and by this Code and all amendments thereto. 
(g)  Direct any department or division to perform work for any other department or division. 
(h)  Recommend to the board of trustees the appointment, removal or suspension of all appointed officers who are required by law to be appointed by the board of trustees. No recommendation for appointment shall be made upon any basis other than that of merit or fitness. 
(i)  Administer the employment and personnel policies of the village as approved by the village president and board of trustees. Recruit, interview and employ necessary personnel for the several village departments and offices as required. 
(j)  Consolidate or combine offices, positions, departments, or units under his jurisdiction, with the approval of the board of trustees. 
(k)  Recommend to the board of trustees a standard schedule of pay for each appointive office and position in the village service, including minimum, intermediate, and maximum rates. 
(l)  Recommend all salaries or wages of village employees not fixed by the village board or not required to be fixed by the village board pursuant to ordinance. 
(m)  Administer the participation of eligible village employees in the Illinois Municipal Retirement Fund, and in the hospitalization and medical care plans. 
(n)  Make, or cause to be made, monthly and annual reports to the president and village board of the activities of all departments. 
(o)  See that all terms and conditions imposed in favor of the village or its' inhabitants in any contract or public utility franchise are faithfully kept and performed. 
(p)  Issue all licenses and permits not otherwise provided for by the Illinois Revised Statutes. 
(q)  Act as agent for the local liquor control commissioner in all matters pertaining to the administration of the licensing and control of the sale of alcoholic liquors within the village and the administration of the Illinois Revised Statutes and the provisions of this Code pertaining thereto. 
(r)  Make, in the ordinary course of business, all purchases of materials and supplies necessary for the village as provided for in the annual appropriation ordinance and, in all cases, he shall comply with the provisions of this Code or statutory provisions as to solicitations of bids. 
(s)  Attend all meetings of the board of trustees with the right to take part in the discussion but with no right to vote. 
(t)  Recommend to the board of trustees (from time to time) adoption of such measures as he may deem necessary or expedient for the health, safety, or welfare of the community or for the improvement of administrative services. 
(u)  Meet the public in behalf of the president and village board, receive suggestions, hear and investigate complaints in relation to all matters concerning the administration of the government of the village and in regard to services rendered by the village, and see that all franchises, permits and privileges granted by the village are faithfully observed. 
(v)  Inform succeeding presidents and village boards of the general principles of administrative programs and policies of previous administrations so that a continuity of programs and policies may be possible. 
(w)  Perform such other duties, consistent with the Illinois Municipal Code, the ordinances of the village and the laws of the State of Illinois, and any other such duties as the president and village board may direct or delegate from time to time. 
(x)  Appoint and remove the heads of all departments of the Village of Hazel Crest. 
(Ord. No. 26-1974, § 4, 9-24-74; Ord. No. 22-1979, §§ 2, 3, 5-8-79; Ord. No. 10-2010, § 8, 5-25-10; Ord. No. 04-2011, § 3, 5-24-11) 
Sec. 2-154.1. - Duties of village collector assigned to manager. 
(a)  The duties of village collector are hereby assigned to the village manager. 
(b)  The village manager as village collector shall post a surety bond in the sum of five thousand dollars ($5,000.00) in favor of the Village of Hazel Crest to insure faithful performance of such duties. 
(c)  The bond premium for such bond shall be assumed by the Village of Hazel Crest. 
(Ord. No. 8-1975, §§ 1-3, 3-25-75) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 8-1975, §§ 1-3, being nonamendatory of this Code, has been included herein as § 2-154.1 at the discretion of the editors. Ord. No. 9-1975, enacted March 25, 1975, provided that "the ordinance creating the office of village manager be and the same is hereby amended to include the position of village collector." See Div. 6, §§ 2-140-2-150, of this chapter. 
Sec. 2-154.2. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 10-2010, § 9, adopted May 25, 2010, added section 2-154.2, "Duties of village treasurer assigned to manager." Inasmuch as Ord. No. 10-2010 was subsequently repealed, revoked and vacated by Ord. No. 04-2011, § 3, adopted May 24, 2011, section 2-154.2 has been removed from the Code. 
Sec. 2-155. - Removal from office. 
    The village manager may at any time be removed from office by a majority vote of the board of trustees. 
(Ord. No. 26-1974, § 5, 9-24-74; Ord. No. 27-1989, § 1, 11-28-89) 
State Law reference- Removal of manager by majority vote of council or board, 65 ILCS 5/5-3-7. 
Sec. 2-156. - Conflict of interest prohibited. 
    The village manager shall not be interested directly or indirectly in any contract, work or business of the village, or in the sale of any article to the village, or in the purchase of any property belonging to the village, or sold for taxes or assessments, or sold by virtue of legal process at the suit of the village. 
(Ord. No. 26-1974, § 6, 9-24-74) 
Sec. 2-157. - Designation of acting manager during absence, disability of manager. 
    In the case of the absence or the disability of the village manager, the president and board of trustees may designate a qualified administrative officer of the village to perform the duties of the manager during such absence or disability. 
(Ord. No. 26-1974, § 7, 9-24-74) 
Sec. 2-158. - Assistance from village board committees; meetings between manager and committee chairman. 
    The village manager may ask for a standing committee of the village board to assist him in matters of concern to that committee. Committee chairmen may call for a meeting with the village manager to discuss recommendations that will require full board approval. 
(Ord. No. 26-1974, § 8, 9-24-74) 
Sec. 2-159. - Interference with appointments or removals. 
    Neither the president nor the board of trustees shall direct or request the appointment of any person to, or his removal from, office by the manager or any of his subordinates, or in any manner take part in the appointment or removal of officers and employees in the administrative services of the village, except as otherwise provided by law or elsewhere in this division or this Code. Except for the purpose of inquiry, the board of trustees shall deal with the administrative service solely through the manager and neither the board not any member thereof, shall give orders to any subordinates of the manager, either publicly or privately. 
(Ord. No. 26-1974, § 9, 9-24-74) 
Sec. 2-160. - Emergencies. 
    In case of accident, disaster, or other circumstances creating a public emergency, the manager may award contracts and make purchases for the purpose of meeting said emergency; but he shall file promptly with the board of trustees, a certificate showing such emergency and the necessity for such action, together with an itemized account of all expenditures. Under no circumstance shall the manager's power described above extend beyond a twenty-four-hour period. 
(Ord. No. 26-1974, § 10, 9-24-74) 
Sec. 2-161. - Bond 
    The manager shall furnish a surety bond in such sum and form as approved by the board of trustees, said bond to be conditioned on the faithful performance of his duties. The premium of the bond shall be paid by the village. 
(Ord. No. 26-1974, § 11, 9-24-74) 
Sec. 2-162. - Compensation. 
    The manager shall receive such compensation as the board of trustees shall fix from time to time by ordinance or resolution. 
(Ord. No. 26-1974, § 12, 9-24-74) 
Sec. 2-162.01. - Financial audit. 
    The village board shall provide for an independent audit of all accounts of the village, as required by the statutes of the State of Illinois, the provisions of this Code and otherwise as required by law. Said audits shall be conducted independently of the village manager by some person or firm selected by the board of trustees. Full reports of such audits shall be filed in the public records of the village. The power of the board of trustees with respect to such audits shall not be construed to limit the responsibility of the manager for the proper expenditure of village funds. 
(Ord. No. 22-1979, § 4, 5-8-79) 
Sec. 2-162.02. - Conflicting ordinances. 
    All ordinances of the Village of Hazel Crest (a) defining the scope of each department of the village and of each division thereunder, (b) defining and prescribing the powers and duties of appointive officers and employees and (c) fixing the salary for all appointive officers and employees shall remain in full force and effect except insofar as they conflict with the provisions of this Division 7, Article III, Chapter 2 of the Village Code, in which case, the provisions of this Division 7, Article III, Chapter 2 shall govern. 
(Ord. No. 22-1979, § 5, 5-8-79)

ARTICLE IV. - BOARD OF FIRE AND POLICE COMMISSIONERS[8] 

Footnotes: 
--- (8) --- 
Cross reference- Subsidiary boards and commissions generally, § 2-220 et seq.; fire prevention and protection, Ch. 10; police, Ch. 24. 
State Law reference- Boards or fire and police commissioners, 65 ILCS 5/10-2.1-1 et seq. 

Sec. 2-163. - Created. 
    Pursuant to the authority and direction contained in 65 ILCS 5/10-2.1-1 et seq., there is hereby created and established a board of fire and police commissioners, consisting of five (5) members. 
(Ord. No. 16-1962, § 1, 7-10-62; Ord. No. 10-2017, § 1, 10-10-17) 
Sec. 2-164. - Appointment, terms. 
    Appointment of the members of the board of fire and police commissioners shall be made by the village president, with the consent of the board of trustees. Each member shall serve three (3) years, and until his successor is appointed and has qualified. 
    The terms of all commissioners appointed prior to May 1, 2008, shall expire on May 1, 2008. Thereafter, all commissioners shall serve one-year terms for a term of May 1 through the following April 30. All commissioners shall be appointed by the mayor with the advice and consent of the village board of trustees. 
(Ord. No. 16-1962, § 2, 7-10-62; Ord. No. 01-2008, § 2, 1-22-08) 
Sec. 2-165. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 12-1992, § 3, adopted Aug. 25, 1992, repealed former section 2-165 which pertained to qualifications of the board of fire and police commissioners and derived from Ord. No. 16-1962, §§ 3, 15, adopted July 10, 1962. 
Sec. 2-166. - Duties, powers relating to appointment of officers and departmental members. 
    The board of fire and police commissioners shall appoint all officers and members of the fire and police department with the exceptions of: (i) the fire chief and police chief, who shall be appointed by the village manager, in accordance with section 2-154(x) of the Village Code; deputy police chiefs, who shall be appointed by the police chief in accordance with section 24-14.1 of the Village Code; and (iii) the assistant (deputy) fire chief, who shall be appointed by the fire chief, in accordance with section 10-34 of the Hazel Crest Village Code. 
(Ord. No. 16-1962, § 4, 7-10-62; Ord. No. 5-1963, § 1, 5-28-63; Ord. No. 10-1985, § 1, 4-23-85; Ord. No. 14-2009, § 3, 10-13-09) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 65 ILCS 5/10-21-4. 
Sec. 2-167. - Rules. 
(a)  The board of fire and police commissioners shall make rules to carry out the purposes of this article, and for appointments and removals in accordance with the provisions of this article, which rules may be changed from time to time by the board. 
(b)  All such rules and changes therein shall be printed immediately for distribution. The board shall give notice of the places where the printed rules may be obtained, and of the date, not less than ten (10) days subsequent to the time of publication, when the rules or changes therein shall go into operation, which notice shall be published in one or more newspapers published in the village, or, if no newspaper is published therein, then in one or more newspapers with a general circulation within the village. 
(Ord. No. 16-1962, § 5, 7-10-62) 
Sec. 2-168. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 12-1992, § 3, adopted Aug. 25, 1992, repealed former section 2-168 which pertained to qualifications and examinations of applicants to the police and fire departments and derived from Ord. No. 16-1962, § 6, adopted July 10, 1962. 
Sec. 2-169. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 12-1992, § 3, adopted Aug. 25, 1992, repealed former section 2-169 which pertained to veteran's preference and derived from Ord. No. 16-1962, § 7, adopted July 10, 1962. 
Sec. 2-170. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 12-1992, § 3, adopted Aug. 25, 1992, repealed former section 2-170 which pertained to notice of examination and derived from Ord. No. 16-1962, § 8, adopted July 10, 1962. 
Sec. 2-171. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 12-1992, § 3, adopted Aug. 25, 1992, repealed former section 2-171 which pertained to a register of candidates for police and fire positions and derived from Ord. No. 16-1962, § 9, adopted July 10, 1962. 
Sec. 2-172. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 12-1992, § 3, adopted Aug. 25, 1992, repealed former section 2-172 which pertained to fire and police promotions and derived from Ord. No. 16-1962, § 10, adopted July 10, 1962. 
Sec. 2-173. - Temporary appointments. 
    In order to prevent a stoppage of public business, to meet extraordinary exigencies, or to prevent material impairment of either the police or fire department, the board of fire and police commissioners may make temporary appointments to remain in force until regular appointments may be made under the provisions of this article, but never to exceed sixty (60) days. 
(Ord. No. 16-1962, § 11, 7-10-62) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 65 ILCS 5/10-2.1-16. 
Sec. 2-174. - Alternate procedure for hiring fully qualified officers. 
(a)  For purposes of this section "fully qualified officer" shall mean: 
(1)  In the case of the police department, (a) an individual possessing all certifications and qualifications required by the Illinois Law Enforcement Training and Standards Board, or (b) an individual with equivalent qualifications from another agency who is able to obtain a waiver from the Illinois Law Enforcement Training and Standards Board to serve as a full-time police officer, and who is presently or who has previously been employed as a full-time certified police officer. 
(2)  In the case of the department of fire rescue and inspectional services, an individual who possesses all certifications required by Illinois law to be employed as a firefighter/paramedic (EMT) and who is or who has previously been employed as a full-time firefighter/paramedic in the State of Illinois. 
(b)  Whenever the police chief or fire chief certifies in writing to the mayor and board of trustees and village manager that there is a present need to hire a fully qualified officer to fill a vacancy, the village manager is authorized to hire a fully qualified officer for such vacancy. The manager and chiefs shall develop advertising and interviewing procedures in order to secure applicants. The manager shall advise the board of fire and police commissioners when this process is invoked and shall keep the commission apprised of interviewing and hiring progress. 
(c)  The hiring established pursuant to this section shall take precedence over any names appearing on an eligibility list developed by the board of fire and police commissioners. 
(d)  In order to be eligible for hiring a fully qualified officer, an applicant must meet all other eligibility criteria established by the board of fire and police commissioners or this Code for newly hired employees. 
(e)  Nothing in this section authorizes the village manager to hire any employees over and above the number of employees authorized and budgeted by the mayor and board of trustees from time to time. 
(f)  Any firefighter/paramedic or police officer hired under this section shall be placed at entry level on the salary scale pursuant to the applicable collective bargaining agreement. 
(Ord. No. 18-2006, § 1, 6-13-06; Ord. No. 04-2017, § 1, 4-25-17) 
Sec. 2-175. - Annual report. 
    Annually on or before the second Monday of May of each year and at such other times as the president and board of trustees may provide, the board of fire and police commissioners shall submit to the village president a report of its activities, and of the rules in force and the practical effect thereof. In such report the board may make suggestions which it believes would result in greater efficiency in the fire or police department. The village president shall transmit the report to the board of trustees. 
(Ord. No. 16-1962, § 13, 7-10-62) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 65 ILCS 5/10-2.1-19. 
Sec. 2-176. - Secretary. 
    The board of fire and police commissioners may employ a secretary, or may designate one of its own members to act as secretary. The secretary shall keep the minutes of the board's proceedings, shall be the custodian of all papers pertaining to the business of the board, shall keep a record of all examinations held, and shall perform all other duties the board may prescribe. 
(Ord. No. 16-1962, § 14, 7-10-62) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 65 ILCS 5/10-2.1-20. 
Sec. 2-177. - Examination rooms. 
    The president and board of trustees shall provide suitable rooms in which the board of fire and police commissioners may transact official business, and shall allow reasonable use of public buildings for the examinations held by the board. 
(Ord. No. 16-1962, § 16, 7-10-62) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 65 ILCS 5/10-2.1-21. 
Sec. 2-178. - Compensation for members, secretary. 
    The secretary of the board created by this article shall be paid a reasonable compensation for his services, to be fixed by the president and board of trustees. The president and board of trustees may also fix the compensation to be paid to the members of the board of fire and police commissioners, but until the president and board of trustees make provisions therefor, the members of the board shall serve without compensation. 
(Ord. No. 16-1962, § 17, 7-10-62) 
Secs. 2-179-2-188. - Reserved.

    The membership of the board of local improvements shall consist of the president and board of trustees and the director of public works. 
(Code 1956, § 4.09) 
Sec. 2-190. - Meetings. 
    The board of local improvements shall meet upon the call of the village president or of any two (2) members. Twenty-four (24) hours' notice of such call shall be given each member, provided that a meeting may be held when all members are present, without notice. 
(Code 1956, § 4.09) 
Sec. 2-191. - Officers. 
    The president of the village shall be president of the board of local improvements, and the secretary shall be appointed from the members of the board. 
(Code 1956, § 4.09)

ARTICLE VI. - PUBLIC WORKS[10] 

Footnotes: 
--- (10) --- 
Editor's note- Section 2 of Ord. No. 4-1979, adopted February 13, 1979, added provisions designated as §§ 2-203.1-2-203.8, which provisions have been redesignated as Art. VI, §§ 2-203-2-209. 

Sec. 2-203. - Department created; structure. 
(a)  There is hereby created and established an executive department of the municipal government of the village which shall be known as the Hazel Crest Department of Public Works. 
(b)  The department of public works shall consist of the director of public works, the assistant to the director of public works, the public works administrator, and all officers and employees assigned to the department. All officers and employees of the department of public works shall perform their duties under the supervision of the director of public works, who shall be responsible to the village manager and the board of trustees. 
(Ord. No. 4-1979, § 2, 2-13-79) 
Sec. 2-204. - Jurisdiction of department. 
(a)  The department of public works shall have charge of supervision, within the Village of Hazel Crest, over the care, maintenance and construction of all streets, sidewalks, alleys, public ways, street gutters and drains and appurtenances thereto, and the construction, operation and maintenance of all storm sewers and sanitary sewers. The department of public works shall also have charge of all street lighting systems, within the Village of Hazel Crest, and shall be responsible for the maintenance, repair and extension thereof. 
(b)  All physical properties of the village, including the water distribution, parks, playgrounds, and all municipal utilities not assigned to some other department or officer shall be and are hereby assigned to the department of public works. 
(Ord. No. 4-1979, § 2, 2-13-79) 
Cross reference- Streets, sidewalks and public places, Ch. 25; water and sewers, Ch. 29. 
Sec. 2-205. - Change of title of director. 
    After the effective date of this section, any reference in this Code or in any village ordinance to the "director of public works and buildings" shall mean the director of public works. 
(Ord. No. 4-1979, § 2, 2-13-79) 
Sec. 2-206. - Duties of the director of public works. 
    The director of public works shall be the head of the department of public works. He shall have charge and custody of all physical property of the village, other than records, not assigned to some other officer or employee, and shall perform all duties 
assigned to him or to the department of public works by the board of trustees. The director of public works shall have care and custody of all village-owned buildings and shall retain and perform any other duties of his office as established by this Code or by ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 4-1979, § 2, 2-13-79) 
Sec. 2-207. - Previously conferred duties and/or responsibilities still in effect. 
    All village Code provisions and all village ordinances conferring duties and/or responsibilities on the director of public works and buildings shall remain in full force and effect after the approval of sections 2-203-2-209 of this Code, except as modified by section 2-205. 
(Ord. No. 4-1979, § 2, 2-13-79) 
Sec. 2-208. - Duties of the assistant director of public works. 
    There is hereby created the position of assistant director of public works. The assistant director of public works shall assist the director of public works in all aspects relating to the administration of the department. The assistant director of public works shall also serve as acting director of public works in the absence of the director: assist in the preparation and the administration of the department's annual budget; make necessary studies and prepare reports on various operations and programs of the department as assigned by the director; coordinate the work of the public works administrative assistant based on directions given by the director; assist in long-range planning of capital improvement projects; assist in administering the state motor fuel tax program; perform other work as requested by the director of the department of public works. 
(Ord. No. 4-1979, § 2, 2-13-79; Ord. No. 24-2006, § 1, 10-10-06; Ord. No. 05-2010, § 2, 4-13-10) 
Sec. 2-209. - Duties of the administrative assistant. 
    The assistant director of public works shall be appointed by the village manager based on the recommendation of the director of public works. The public works administrative assistant shall coordinate the field operations of the department of public works by providing administrative support services for such operations. In addition, the administrative assistant shall perform the following duties subject to the review of the director; coordinate purchasing of all public works equipment and materials; maintain necessary records relating to all field operations of the department; provide direct supervision to water meter repairmen, mechanics, building custodian(s), and water plant operator(s); maintain a preventive maintenance program for all village equipment and vehicles; develop and maintain training schedules for all phases of public works operations; respond to citizen requests for service and coordinate work necessary to act on such requests; coordinate the village's safety program; prepare timesheets and attend to personnel matters relating to the department of public works employees; serve as liaison to the citizens' traffic commission; such other duties as assigned by the director of public works or the assistant director of public works. 
(Ord. No. 4-1979, § 2, 2-13-79) 
ARTICLE VII. - MUNICIPAL BUDGET ACT[11] 

Footnotes: 
--- (11) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 3-1976, § 2, adopted Feb. 10, 1976, specifically amended the Code by adding Art. VII, §§ 2-210-2-214 as herein set out. 

Sec. 2-210. - Adopted. 
    The Village of Hazel Crest hereby adopts the Municipal Budget Act. 
(Ord. No. 3-1976, § 2, 2-10-76) 
Sec. 2-211. - Budget officer. 
    The village manager shall serve as the budget officer and shall have the powers, duties and responsibilities enumerated in 65 ILCS 5/8-2-9.1 through 8-2-9.10 as they now are or may hereafter be amended. 
(Ord. No. 3-1976, § 2, 2-10-76) 
Sec. 2-212. - Budget officer to prepare budget. 
    The budget officer shall prepare an annual budget containing estimates of the revenues available before the beginning of the fiscal year to which it applies together with recommended expenditures for the municipality and all of its departments. Said budget shall be adopted prior to May first of each fiscal year. 
(Ord. No. 3-1976, § 2, 2-10-76) 
Sec. 2-213. - Budget to be available for public inspection; public hearing. 
    Copies of the tentative annual budget shall be made available for public inspection in typewritten form in the office of the village clerk for at least ten (10) days prior to the passage of the annual budget. Not less than one week after the budget is available for inspection, and prior to final action on the budget, at least one public hearing shall be held on the budget by the village board. Notice of this hearing shall be given by publication in a newspaper having general circulation in the village at least one (1) week prior to the time of hearing. 
(Ord. No. 3-1976, § 2, 2-10-76) 
Sec. 2-214. - Revision of budget. 
(a)  The village manager as designated budget officer shall have authority to approve increases or decreases within individual line items of the department's budget; however, no revision of the budget shall be made which would increase the total departmental budget to an amount greater than originally approved by the village president and board of trustees. 
(b)  All changes in the budget approved by the village manager shall be reported to the village board in a timely fashion indicating the amount of such change and reason for each change. 
(c)  The maximum amount of any one budget adjustment approved by the village manager shall be limited to two thousand five hundred dollars ($2,500.00). 
(d)  The village board may amend the budget at any time by ordinance adopted by a simple majority of the board of trustees. 
(Ord. No. 3-1976, § 2, 2-10-76; Ord. No. 3-1980, §§ 1-3, 3-25-80; Ord. No. 07-2010, § 1, 5-25-10) 
Secs. 2-215-2-219. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VIII. - SUBSIDIARY BOARDS AND COMMISSIONS[12] 
Footnotes: 
--- (12) --- 
Cross reference- Community relations commission, § 14-41 et seq.; citizen's traffic commission, § 19-175 et seq.; plan commission, § 22-13 et seq.; beautification commission, § 22-50 et seq. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 2-220. - Terms of office of members. 
    The terms of office of all members of advisory boards and commissions shall be three (3) years, except that those terms of office established by state statute, fire pension board, police pension board, board of police and fire and the zoning board of appeals, shall be in accord with Illinois State Statutes. 
(Ord. No. 24-1980, § 1, 9-23-80; Ord. No. 05-2010, § 2, 4-13-10) 
Sec. 2-221. - Appointment of members to boards and commissions. 
(a)  The village president shall make all appointments to boards and commissions except as provided by law. All appointments shall be subject to approval of a majority of village board members. 
(b)  The village president and board of trustees may request interviews with individuals prior to appointment to boards and commissions. 
(c)  No person shall be eligible for appointment to any board or commission unless he or she has been a bona fide resident of the Village of Hazel Crest for at least one (1) year prior to appointment. Consideration for appointment shall be based on the individual's experience, interest and commitment to the welfare of the village. 
(Ord. No. 24-1980, § 1, 9-23-80; Ord. No. 20-1994, § 11, 9-13-94) 
Sec. 2-222. - Removal of members from office. 
(a)  The village resident and board of trustees shall have the right to remove from office any member of a board or commission for cause. 
(b)  Cause for removal from office shall include but not be limited to the following: 
(1)  Failure to attend seventy-five (75) percent of meetings of the board or commission in any twelve-month period. 
(2)  Failure to adhere to rules of procedure which may be adopted by the board or commission. 
(3)  The village manager shall report to the village president and board of trustees the name of any commissioner or board member who has engaged in conduct which may be considered cause for removal from office. 
(4)  The president and board of trustees shall consider any extenuating circumstances prior to removing any member from office. 
(Ord. No. 24-1980, § 1, 9-23-80; Ord. No. 20-1994, §§ 12, 13, 9-13-94; Ord. No. 15-2004, § 1, 4-13-04) 
Sec. 2-223. - Administrative procedures. 
    All boards and commissions shall adopt administrative procedures which shall include but not be limited to the following items: 
(a)  Scheduled meeting dates, times and places. 
(b)  Procedures for calling a special meeting. 
(c)  Manner of placing items of business on the agenda. 
(d)  Method of determination of quorum to conduct business. 
(e)  Transcription, adoption and distribution of minutes. 
(f)  Rules regulating audience participation. 
(g)  Method of adopting recommendations. 
(h)  Commission and board representation at public meetings. 
(Ord. No. 24-1980, § 1, 9-23-80) 
Sec. 2-224. - Public hearings. 
    Any board or commission charged with the responsibility of conducting a public hearing shall conform to the requirements as provided by the village attorney. 
(Ord. No. 24-1980, § 1, 9-23-80) 
Sec. 2-225. - Annual report. 
    Each board and commission shall file an annual written report with the village manager detailing the past year's activities thirty (30) days prior to it presentation to the board. The report shall be presented to the village board at least thirty (30) days prior to an annual meeting with the village board to discuss board or commission concerns in accord with the following schedule: 
(a)  Zoning board of appeals and plan commission, in January. 
(b)  Board of fire and police, in February. 
(c)  Emergency services disaster agency, in April. 
(d)  Community relations commission, in June. 
(e)  Traffic commission, in September. 
(f)  Beautification commission, in December. 
(Ord. No. 24-1980, § 1, 9-23-80; Ord. No. 20-1994, §§ 14, 15, 9-13-94; Ord. No. 05-2010, § 2, 4-13-10) 
Sec. 2-226. - Orientation to commission. 
    Each commission or board chairman shall be responsible for providing the village manager with a list of relevant materials which shall be provided to new commission or board members. 
(Ord. No. 24-1980, § 1, 9-23-80) 
Sec. 2-227. - Community relations commission-Created; composition. 
    There is hereby created a Hazel Crest Community Relations Commission consisting of seven (7) members appointed by the village president with the advice and consent of the board of trustees. 
(Ord. No. 32-1997, § 3, 9-9-97) 
Sec. 2-228. - Duties of community relations commission. 
    The community relations commission shall have the following duties and responsibilities: 
(1)  To develop strategies and programs to promote a strong community identity for the Village of Hazel Crest. 
(2)  To actively encourage, promote, and support positive neighborhood activities. 
(3)  To assist the village by suggesting and promoting positive community events. 
(4)  To welcome newcomers to the village and from time to time to survey citizens who leave or move from the village. 
(5)  To promote the availability of neighbor mediation services and similar conflict resolution approaches. 
(6)  To report to the president and board of trustees from time to time as to suggestions for improving a sense of community within the village. 
(Ord. No. 32-1997, § 3, 9-9-97) 
Sec. 2-229. - Committee on board and commission appointments. 
    There is hereby created a committee on board and commission appointments. The purpose of this committee is advise the village president on appointments to boards and commissions. 
(Ord. No. 14-2004, § 1, 4-13-04) 
Secs. 2-230-2-240. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - FINANCE COMMITTEE[13] 

Footnotes: 
--- (13) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 06-2017, §§ 1-5, adopted June 13, 2017, added provisions to the Code, but did not specify manner of inclusion. Therefore, at the discretion of the editor, said provisions have been included as §§ 2-241-2-245 herein. 

Sec. 2-241. - Finance committee created. 
    There is hereby created for the Village of Hazel Crest the finance committee, a standing advisory committee of the village. 
(Ord. No. 06-2017, § 1, 6-13-17) 
Sec. 2-242. - Membership. 
    The finance committee will be composed of the following members: 
(1)  Four (4) members of the public to be appointed by the president with the advice and consent of the board of trustees. Two (2) of the four (4) initial appointees shall serve a term of two (2) years; two (2) initial appointees will serve a term of one (1) year and until their successors are appointed; thereafter, all public members will serve two (2) year terms. 
(2)  Three (3) members of the committee shall be appointed by the president from members of the board of trustees subject to advice and consent of the board of trustees. 
(Ord. No. 06-2017, § 2, 6-13-17) 
Sec. 2-243. - Open Meetings Act; chairperson. 
    All meetings of the finance committee shall be conducted in accordance with the terms of the Illinois Open Meetings Act. At the first meeting, the committee shall choose a chairperson from among their members. 
(Ord. No. 06-2017, § 3, 6-13-17) 
Sec. 2-244. - Powers and duties. 
    The finance committee shall have the following powers and duties: 
(1)  To generally review the financial condition of the village. 
(2)  To discuss and make recommendations to the board of trustees on short and long-term strategies for revenue enhancements and cost savings. 
(3)  To review and make recommendations to the board of trustees regarding investment policies. 
(4)  To recommend to the board of trustees availability of state, federal and local grants, loans, guarantees or other forms of assistance. 
(5)  To study and make general recommendations regarding the village's financial position, policies and practices. 
(6)  To study and make recommendations to the board of trustees on any proposals regarding long-term financing or bond issues. 
(Ord. No. 06-2017, § 4, 6-13-17) 
Sec. 2-245. - Regular and special meetings. 
    At its first meeting, the finance committee shall establish a schedule for regular meetings, which shall be at least one (1) meeting per calendar quarter. 
(Ord. No. 06-2017, § 5, 6-13-17) 
DIVISION 3. - PERSONNEL COMMITTEE[14] 

Footnotes: 
--- (14) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 11-2017, §§ 1-5, adopted November 27, 2017, added provisions to the Code, but did not specify manner of inclusion. Therefore, at the discretion of the editor, said provisions have been included as §§ 2-246-2-250 herein. 

Sec. 2-246. - Personnel committee created. 
    There is hereby created for the Village of Hazel Crest a personnel committee, a standing advisory committee of the village. 
(Ord. No. 11-2017, § 1, 11-27-17) 
Sec. 2-247. - Membership. 
    The personnel committee will be composed of three (3) members appointed by the president from members of the board of trustees subject to advice and consent of the board of trustees. 
(Ord. No. 11-2017, § 2, 11-27-17) 
Sec. 2-248. - Open Meetings Act; chairperson. 
    All meetings of the personnel committee shall be conducted in accordance with the terms of the Illinois Open Meetings Act. At the first meeting, the committee shall choose a chairperson from among their members. 
(Ord. No. 11-2017, § 3, 11-27-17) 
Sec. 2-249. - Powers and duties. 
    The personnel committee shall have the following powers and duties: 
(1)  To review current HR policies and recommend changes to the full board. 
(2)  To review staffing levels and to make recommendations to the entire board of trustees regarding the filling of positions. 
(3)  To review and make recommendations on matters relating to employees benefits such as health insurance. 
(4)  To review and make recommendations on matters relating to the status and administration of the village's collective bargaining agreements. 
(5)  To examine other personnel matters referred to the committee from time to time by the entire board of trustees and make recommendations. 
(Ord. No. 11-2017, § 4, 11-27-17) 
Sec. 2-250. - Regular and special meetings. 
    At its first meeting the personnel committee shall establish a schedule for regular meetings, which shall be at least one (1) meeting per calendar quarter. 
(Ord. No. 11-2017, § 5, 11-27-17) 
Secs. 2-251-2-256. - Reserved.

ARTICLE X. - ETHICS[16] 
Footnotes: 
--- (16) --- 
Editor's note- Section 1 of Ord. No. 13-2004, adopted May 11, 2004, amended Art. X, Gifts to Officers and Employees, in its entirety to read as herein set out. Section 2 of said ordinance repealed Ord. No. 11-1999, adopted June 22, 1999, from which former Art. X, § 2-262, derived. 
Cross reference- Acceptance of gifts, gratuities, contributions, etc., § 2-282. 

DIVISION 1. - DEFINITIONS 

Sec. 2-262. - Definitions. 
    As used in this article the following terms shall be given these definitions: 
    Campaign for elective office means any activity in furtherance of an effort to influence the selection, nomination, election, or appointment of any individual to any federal, state, or local public office or office in a political organization, or the selection, nomination, or election of presidential or vice-presidential electors, but does not include activities: 
(1)  Relating to the support or opposition of any executive, legislative, or administrative action; 
(2)  Relating to collective bargaining; or 
(3)  That are otherwise in furtherance of the person's official duties. 
    Candidate means a person who has filed nominating papers or petitions for nomination or election to an elected office, or who has been appointed to fill a vacancy in nomination, and who remains eligible for placement on the ballot at a regular election, as defined in section 1-3 of the Election Code (10 ILCS 5/1-3). 
    Collective bargaining has the same meaning as that term is defined in section 3 of the Illinois Public Labor Relations Act (5 ILCS 315/3). 
    Compensated time means, with respect to an employee, any time worked by or credited to the employee that counts toward any minimum work time requirement imposed as a condition of his or her employment, but for purposes of this article, does not include any designated holidays, vacation periods, personal time, compensatory time off or any period when the employee is on a leave of absence. With respect to officers or employees whose hours are not fixed, compensated time includes any period of time when the officer is on premises under the control of the employer and any other time when the officer or employee is executing his or her official duties, regardless of location. 
    Compensatory time off means authorized time off earned by or awarded to an employee to compensate in whole or in part for time worked in excess of the minimum work time required of that employee as a condition of his or her employment. 
    Contribution has the same meaning as that term is defined in section 9-1.4 of the Election Code (10 ILCS 5/9-1.4). 
    Employee means a person employed by the village, whether on a full-time or part-time basis or pursuant to a contract, whose duties are subject to the direction and control of an employer with regard to the material details of how the work is to be performed, but does not include an independent contractor. 
    Employer means the village. 
    Gift means any gratuity, discount, entertainment, hospitality, loan, forbearance, or other tangible or intangible item having monetary value including, but not limited to, cash, food and drink, and honoraria for speaking engagements related to or attributable to government employment or the official position of an officer or employee. 
    Immediate family member means parents, spouse, brothers, sisters, children, grandparents, grandchildren, parents-in-law, brothers-in-law, sisters-in-law, and legal guardians. 
    Leave of absence means any period during which an employee does not receive: 
(1)  Compensation for employment; 
(2)  Service credit towards pension benefits; and 
(3)  Health insurance benefits paid for by the employer. 
    Officer means a person who holds, by election or appointment, an office created by statute or ordinance, regardless of whether the officer is compensated for service in his or her official capacity. 
    Political activity means any activity in support of or in connection with any campaign for elective office or any political organization, but does not include activities: 
(1)  Relating to the support or opposition of any executive, legislative, or administrative action; 
(2)  Relating to collective bargaining; or 
(3)  That are otherwise in furtherance of the person's official duties. 
    Political organization means a party, committee, association, fund, or other organization (whether or not incorporated) that is required to file a statement of organization with the state board of elections or a county clerk under section 9-3 of the Election Code (10 ILCS 5/9-3), but only with regard to those activities that require filing with the state board of elections or a county clerk. 
    Prohibited political activity means: 
(1)  Preparing for, organizing, or participating in any political meeting, political rally, political demonstration, or other political event. 
(2)  Soliciting contributions, including but not limited to the purchase of, selling, distributing, or receiving payment for tickets for any political fundraiser, political meeting, or other political event. 
(3)  Soliciting, planning the solicitation of, or preparing any document or report regarding anything of value intended as a campaign contribution. 
(4)  Planning, conducting, or participating in a public opinion poll in connection with a campaign for elective office or on behalf of a political organization for political purposes or for or against any referendum question. 
(5)  Surveying or gathering information from potential or actual voters in an election to determine probable vote outcome in connection with a campaign for elective office or on behalf of a political organization for political purposes or for or against any referendum question. 
(6)  Assisting at the polls on election day on behalf of any political organization or candidate for elective office or for or against any referendum question. 
(7)  Soliciting votes on behalf of a candidate for elective office or a political organization or for or against any referendum question or helping in an effort to get voters to the polls. 
(8)  Initiating for circulation, preparing, circulating, reviewing, or filing any petition on behalf of a candidate for elective office or for or against any referendum question. 
(9)  Making contributions on behalf of any candidate for elective office in that capacity or in connection with a campaign for elective office. 
(10)  Preparing or reviewing responses to candidate questionnaires. 
(11)  Distributing, preparing for distribution, or mailing campaign literature, campaign signs, or other campaign material on behalf of any candidate for elective office or for or against any referendum question. 
(12)  Campaigning for any elective office or for or against any referendum question. 
(13)  Managing or working on a campaign for elective office or for or against any referendum question. 
(14)  Serving as a delegate, alternate, or proxy to a political party convention. 
(15)  Participating in any recount or challenge to the outcome of any election. 
    Prohibited source means any person or entity who: 
(1)  Is seeking official action (i) by an officer or (ii) by an employee, or by the officer or another employee directing that employee; 
(2)  Does business or seeks to do business (i) with the officer or (ii) with an employee, or with the officer or another employee directing that employee; 
(3)  Conducts activities regulated (i) by the officer or (ii) by an employee, or by the officer or another employee directing that employee; or 
(4)  Has interests that may be substantially affected by the performance or non-performance of the official duties of the officer or employee. 
(Ord. No. 13-2004, § 1, 5-11-04) 
DIVISION 2. - PROHIBITED POLITICAL ACTIVITIES 

Sec. 2-263. - Prohibited political activities. 
(a)  No officer or employee shall intentionally perform any prohibited political activity during any compensated time. No officer or employee shall intentionally use any property or resources of the village in connection with any prohibited political activity. 
(b)  At no time shall any officer or employee intentionally require any other officer or employee to perform any prohibited political activity: 
(1)  As part of that officer or employee's duties; 
(2)  As a condition of employment; or 
(3)  During any compensated time off (such as holidays, vacation or personal time off). 
(c)  No officer or employee shall be required at any time to participate in any prohibited political activity in consideration for that officer or employee being awarded additional compensation or any benefit, whether in the form of a salary adjustment, bonus, compensatory time off, continued employment or otherwise, nor shall any officer or employee be awarded additional compensation or any benefit in consideration for his or her participation in any prohibited political activity. 
(d)  Nothing in this section prohibits activities that are permissible for an officer or employee to engage in as part of his or her official duties, or activities that are undertaken by an officer or employee on a voluntary basis which are not prohibited by this Ordinance. 
(e)  No person either (i) in a position that is subject to recognized merit principles of public employment or (ii) in a position the salary for which is paid in whole or in part by federal funds and that is subject to the federal standards for a merit system of personnel administration applicable to grant-in-aid programs, shall be denied or deprived of employment or tenure solely because he or she is a member or an officer of a political committee, of a political party, or of a political organization or club. 
(Ord. No. 13-2004, § 1, 5-11-04) 
DIVISION 3. - GIFT BAN 

Sec. 2-264. - Gift ban. 
    Except as permitted by section 2-265 or 2-266, no officer or employee, and no spouse of or immediate family member living with any officer or employee (collectively referred to herein as "recipients"), shall intentionally solicit or accept any gift from any prohibited source, as defined herein, or which is otherwise prohibited by law or ordinance. No prohibited source shall intentionally offer or make a gift that violates this section. 
(Ord. No. 13-2004, § 1, 5-11-04) 
Sec. 2-265. - Exceptions. 
    The above section 2-264 is not applicable to the following: 
(1)  Opportunities, benefits, and services that are available on the same conditions as for the general public. 
(2)  Anything for which the officer or employee, or his or her spouse or immediate family member, pays the fair market value. 
(3)  Any (i) contribution that is lawfully made under the Election Code or (ii) activities associated with a fundraising event in support of a political organization or candidate. 
(4)  Educational materials and missions. 
(5)  Travel expenses for a meeting to discuss business. 
(6)  A gift from a relative, meaning those people related to the individual as father, mother, son, daughter, brother, sister, uncle, aunt, great aunt, great uncle, first cousin, nephew, niece, husband, wife, grandfather, grandmother, grandson, granddaughter, father-in-law, mother-in-law, son-in-law, daughter-in-law, brother-in-law, sister-in-law, stepfather, stepmother, stepson, stepdaughter, stepbrother, stepsister, half brother, half sister, and including the father, mother, grandfather, or grandmother of the individual's spouse and the individual's fiance or fiancee. 
(7)  Anything provided by an individual on the basis of a personal friendship unless the recipient has reason to believe that, under the circumstances, the gift was provided because of the official position or employment of the recipient or his or her spouse or immediate family member and not because of the personal friendship. In determining whether a gift is provided on the basis of personal friendship, the recipient shall consider the circumstances under which the gift was offered, such as: 
a.  The history of the relationship between the individual giving the gift and the recipient of the gift, including any previous exchange of gifts between those individuals; 
b.  Whether to the actual knowledge of the recipient the individual who gave the gift personally paid for the gift or sought a tax deduction or business reimbursement for the gift; and 
c.  Whether to the actual knowledge of the recipient the individual who gave the gift also at the same time gave the same or similar gifts to other officers or employees, or their spouses or immediate family members. 
(8)  Food or refreshments not exceeding seventy-five dollars ($75.00) per person in value on a single calendar day; provided that the food or refreshments are (i) consumed on the premises from which they were purchased or prepared or (ii) catered. For the purposes of this section, "catered" means food or refreshments that are purchased ready to consume which are delivered by any means. 
(9)  Food, refreshments, lodging, transportation, and other benefits resulting from outside business or employment activities (or outside activities that are not connected to the official duties of an officer or employee), if the benefits have not been offered or enhanced because of the official position or employment of the officer or employee, and are customarily provided to others in similar circumstances. 
(10)  Intra-governmental and inter-governmental gifts. For the purpose of this article, "intra-governmental gift" means any gift given to an officer or employee from another officer or employee, and "inter-governmental gift" means any gift given to an officer or employee by an officer or employee of another governmental entity. 
(11)  Bequests, inheritances, and other transfers at death. 
(12)  Any item or items from any one prohibited source during any calendar year having a cumulative total value of less than one hundred dollars ($100.00). 
    Each of the exceptions listed in this section is mutually exclusive and independent of every other. 
(Ord. No. 13-2004, § 1, 5-11-04) 
Sec. 2-266. - Disposition of gifts. 
    An officer or employee, his or her spouse or an immediate family member living with the officer or employee, does not violate this article if the recipient promptly takes reasonable action to return a gift from a prohibited source to its source or gives the gift or an amount equal to its value to an appropriate charity that is exempt from income taxation under Section 501(c)(3) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, as now or hereafter amended, renumbered, or succeeded. 
(Ord. No. 13-2004, § 1, 5-11-04) 
DIVISION 4. - ETHICS ADVISOR 

Sec. 2-267. - Position created. 
    The municipal attorney, with the advice and consent of the board of trustees shall serve as an ethics advisor for the village. The duties of the ethics advisor may be delegated to an officer or employee of the village unless the position has been created as an office by the village. 
(Ord. No. 13-2004, § 1, 5-11-04) 
Sec. 2-268. - Duties. 
    The ethics advisor shall provide guidance to the officers and employees of the village concerning the interpretation of and compliance with the provisions of this article and state ethics laws. The ethics advisor shall perform such other duties as may be delegated by the village. 
(Ord. No. 13-2004, § 1, 5-11-04) 
DIVISION 5. - PENALTIES 

Sec. 2-269. - Penalties. 
(a)  A person who intentionally violates any provision of section 2-263 of this article may be punished by a term of incarceration in a penal institution other than a penitentiary for a period of not more than three hundred sixty-four (364) days, and may be fined in an amount not to exceed two thousand five hundred dollars ($2,500.00). 
(b)  A person who intentionally violates any provision of section 2-264 or 2-266 of this article is subject to a fine in an amount of not less than one thousand one dollars ($1,001.00) and not more than five thousand dollars ($5,000.00). 
(c)  Any person who intentionally makes a false report alleging a violation of any provision of this article to the local enforcement authorities, the state's attorney or any other law enforcement official may be punished by a term of incarceration in a penal institution other than a penitentiary for a period of not more than three hundred sixty-four (364) days, and may be fined in an amount not to exceed two thousand five hundred dollars ($2,500.00). 
(d)  A violation of section 2-263 of this article shall be prosecuted as a criminal offense by an attorney for the village by filing in the circuit court an information, or sworn complaint, charging such offense. The prosecution shall be under and conform to the rules of criminal procedure. Conviction shall require the establishment of the guilt of the defendant beyond a reasonable doubt. A violation of section 2-264 or 2-266 of this article may be prosecuted as a quasi-criminal offense by an attorney for the village, or, if an ethics commission has been created, by the commission through the designated administrative procedure. 
(e)  In addition to any other penalty that may be applicable, whether criminal or civil, an officer or employee who intentionally violates any provision of section 2-263, 2-264 or 2-266 of this article is subject to discipline or discharge. 
(Ord. No. 13-2004, § 1, 5-11-04) 
Sec. 2-270. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XI. - CONFLICT OF INTEREST AND ETHICS 

Sec. 2-271. - Policy statement and definition. 
(a)  Policy statement: It is the policy of the village that its elected and appointed officials and all department heads should, in all cases, exercise their judgment and perform their official duties for the sole benefit of the village and its citizens. All such persons should avoid any situation where their private pecuniary interests would impair or may tend to impair the exercise of their independent judgment for the benefit of the village and its citizens. It is further the policy of the village that even the appearance of impropriety created by any conflict between official duties and an apparent pecuniary interest should be avoided. 
(b)  Definition of "interest": For purposes of this article, "interest" shall mean a direct or indirect pecuniary interest accruing to a "person affected" as defined in section 2-272 whether in that person's own name or the name of any person, firm, corporation, association or trust from which the person is entitled to receive any financial benefit as a result of a contract or transaction which is or will become the subject of an official act by the affected person with the village. 
"Interest" shall not include any such benefit accruing as a result of any such contracts or transactions that by their terms and substance confer on all other citizens of the village the opportunity and right to realize similar benefits. 
(Ord. No. 3-1993, § 1-11-1, 4-13-93) 
Sec. 2-272. - Affected persons. 
    All of the provisions of this article, except as may otherwise be indicated, apply to all elected village officials, all appointed village officials and members of boards and commissions, the village manager and department heads who are hereinafter referred to as "affected persons." Other employees shall be governed by applicable state law, personnel policies or personnel manuals, if any; provided, however, that section 2-272 shall be applicable to all village employees. 
(Ord. No. 3-1993, § 1-11-2, 4-13-93) 
Sec. 2-273. - Statutes not affected. 
    This article is intended to be declaratory of and consistent with the substantive ethical requirements of Illinois common and statutory law. This article shall not be construed as creating any ethical duty less restrictive than that contained in applicable common and statutory law. 
(Ord. No. 3-1993, § 1-11-3, 4-13-93) 
Sec. 2-274. - Standards of conduct. 
    No affected person shall have any interest in any contract, work or business of the village, except as permitted by 65 ILCS 5/3-14-4 of the Illinois Municipal Code as it now exists or may hereafter be amended. 
(Ord. No. 3-1993, § 1-11-4, 4-13-93) 
Sec. 2-275. - Disclosure of real estate. 
(a)  Each affected person shall file with the village clerk a statement disclosing direct or indirect ownership of any real property located within the corporate limits of the village, owned by the person required to file or by the spouse of such person. Such statement shall include the legal description and common address of the real estate and shall indicate the ownership interest held in such real estate. 
(b)  For the purpose of this section, the ownership of a beneficial interest in real estate held in land trust, real property being purchased by contract or real property held by a corporation, an investment group or partnership in which the person filing shall own more than a five (5) per cent interest, shall be considered real property. 
(c)  The property in which the affected person resides shall be exempt from the provisions of this section, unless said property contains more than three (3) residential units. 
(Ord. No. 3-1993, § 1-11-5, 4-13-93) 
Sec. 2-276. - Disclosure of business interests. 
    Each affected person shall file, with the village clerk, a statement disclosing any ownership interest of greater than five (5) per cent, either direct or indirect, which the affected person or his or her spouse has in any business, firm or corporation. 
(Ord. No. 3-1993, § 1-11-6, 4-13-93) 
Sec. 2-277. - Disclosure of other employment. 
(a)  Each affected person shall file with the village clerk, a statement indicating all current employment and all employment for the previous calendar year of the affected person and his or her spouse. Said statement shall include the name of the employing entity and the nature of the service rendered in the course of such employment. 
(b)  The statement shall further disclose whether the affected person directly or indirectly performed any service for compensation for the village other than that performed in his official capacity with the village, or was associated with or employed by a corporation or partnership which received compensation for services performed for the village. 
(Ord. No. 3-1993, § 1-11-7, 4-13-93) 
Sec. 2-278. - Filing and disclosure. 
(a)  All disclosure statements described in sections 2-274 through 2-277 of this chapter shall be filed with the village clerk on or before May 1 of each calendar year, except as hereinafter set forth, or within sixty (60) days after the affected person first assumed his or her office, position or employment with the village. 
(b)  Persons already obligated to file disclosure statements pursuant to the laws of the State of Illinois may file copies of said statements with the village clerk in satisfaction of the requirements of this article, except that any information required by this article and not contained on other filed statements, must be separately filed herein. 
(c)  The disclosure statements described herein shall be kept for five (5) years, from the date of filing, by the village clerk. Said records shall be considered public records. A request to view records shall be made in writing, with a copy of said request given to the individual whose records are to be viewed. Nothing herein shall prevent the village clerk from establishing reasonable rules and regulations governing when the records may be viewed and from requiring a reasonable charge for copying any of said records. 
(Ord. No. 3-1993, § 1-11-8, 4-13-93) 
Sec. 2-279. - Disclosure and abstention by village board members. 
(a)  Any affected person who is an elected or appointed member of the village board, and who has an interest in any proposed contract, work, business or land use application with the village shall publicly declare the nature and extent of such interest at the first village board meeting at which the proposed contract, work or business or application is first called on the agenda for consideration. 
(b)  In the event such member's interest is permitted under paragraph 65 ILCS 5/3-14-4 of the Illinois Municipal Code, such member shall not deliberate on the matter in his official capacity on the proposed contract, work or business, and such member shall not vote on said matter. 
(c)  In the event such members interest is determined not to be permitted under paragraph 65 ILCS 5/3-14-4 of the Illinois Municipal Code, no such contract, work or business shall be awarded, granted or entered into. 
(Ord. No. 3-1993, § 1-11-9, 4-13-93) 
Sec. 2-280. - Disclosure and abstention by appointed officials. 
(a)  Any affected person who is an appointed member of the several boards and commissions of the village having an interest in any actual or proposed contract, work, business or land use application of the village, shall disclose the nature and extent of such interest in writing to the village manager immediately upon learning of such contract, work or business. 
(b)  In the event such member's own board or commission is required to review or recommend such contract, work or business, such person shall publicly disclose the nature and extent of such interest at the first meeting at which the contract, work or business is first called for consideration. Such person shall not participate in his official capacity during discussion, deliberation and vote on the contract, work or business, and such person shall not vote on said matter. 
(c)  In the event such interest is determined not to be permitted under 65 ILCS 5/3-14-4 of the Illinois Municipal Code, such officer shall, prior to final board action on the contract under consideration, either tender his resignation or notify the board of his intent not to resign, in which case no contract, work or business shall be awarded to the officer. Any appointed member of a board or commission of the village who knowingly fails to disclose any such interest shall be subject to reprimand, or removal from office, as determined by majority vote of the village board. 
(Ord. No. 3-1993, § 1-11-10, 4-13-93) 
Sec. 2-281. - Disclosure by department heads. 
(a)  In the event that the village manager or any department head of the village should have an interest in any actual or proposed contract, work, business or land use application in the village, such affected person shall disclose the nature and extent of such interest in writing to the village clerk immediately upon learning of such contract, work or business. Such disclosure shall be referred to the village board. 
(b)  The village board shall reject any proposed contract, work or business which directly affects such person's department or where such person is in a position to recommend, as part of his official duties, any such contract, work or business. 
(c)  In the event such interest in any actual contract, work or business is determined not to be permitted under 65 ILCS 5/3-14-4 of the Illinois Municipal Code, or such person fails to disclose any such interest as required herein, such person shall be subject to remedial action as provided in this article. 
(Ord. No. 3-1993, § 1-11-11, 4-13-93) 
Sec. 2-282. - Acceptance of gifts, gratuities, contributions or other valuable items. 
(a)  No affected person or employee shall take or receive, or offer to take or receive, either directly or indirectly, any money or other thing of value as an inducement for, or compensation for, an official act or action. Any money or thing so received shall be promptly surrendered to the village for the sole use and benefit of the village. 
(b)  In addition, no affected person or employee shall take or receive any village property, funds or the services of any village employee for anything other than a proper public purpose. 
(Ord. No. 3-1993, § 1-11-12, 4-13-93) 
Cross reference- Adoption of state gift ban act, § 2-262. 
Sec. 2-283. - Ethical rulings. 
    Any affected person who has a question as to the applicability of this article in a particular situation may apply, in writing, to the village board for a ruling. Such a ruling shall be provided by the village board. 
(Ord. No. 3-1993, § 1-11-13, 4-13-93) 
Sec. 2-284. - Complaints. 
    Complaints that an affected person has violated its provisions shall be made in writing and signed by the complainant. Complaints shall be filed with: 
(1)  The village manager in the case of village employees or the village clerk; 
(2)  The village clerk for referral to the village board in all other cases. 
(Ord. No. 3-1993, § 1-11-14, 4-13-93) 
Sec. 2-285. - Complaint procedures. 
(a)  Any person against whom a complaint has been filed shall be heard by the village manager in the case of village employees or by a committee of the village board in all other cases. Any such person shall have the right to be represented by counsel, to confront and cross-examine all witnesses and to compel the appearance of any Village officers or employees who have knowledge of the allegations contained in the complaint. 
(b)  In the event that the village manager or the committee of the village board find a complaint has been sustained, in whole or in part, by a preponderance of the evidence, the village manager, in the case of village employees, shall take appropriate remedial action. In all other cases, the committee shall recommend remedial action to the full village board which shall take final action. Remedial action may consist of a reprimand, suspension without pay or removal from employment or office where permitted by law. 
(Ord. No. 3-1993, § 1-11-15, 4-13-93) 
Sec. 2-286. - Alternative remedial proceedings. 
    In addition to, or in lieu of, the complaint procedures set forth in sections 2-284 and 2-285 of this article, the village board or the village manager may refer any possible violation of this article to the village attorney for prosecution under the general penalty provisions of this Code, to the state's attorney's office for prosecution or to the board of fire and police commissioners where appropriate. 
(Ord. No. 3-1993, § 1-11-16, 4-13-93) 
Chapter 3 - ADVERTISING[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Licenses and miscellaneous business regulations, Ch. 17; peddlers, solicitors and vendors, Ch. 21; attaching notices, etc., to trees and shrubs prohibited, § 28-4. 

Sec. 3-1. - Billposting restricted. 
    No person shall paste, post, paint, print, nail or otherwise fasten any handbill, sign, poster, advertisement or notice of any kind whatsoever, or cause the same to be done, on any curbstone, flagstone or any portion or part of any sidewalk or street, lamppost, telegraph pole, hydrant, bridge, pier or any structure within the limits of any street in the village, except as may be required by the ordinances of the village, without the express consent of the village authorities. 
(Ord. No. 3-1957, § 1, 5-14-57) 
Sec. 3-2. - Distribution of samples of medicine. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to distribute, cast, throw or place in or along any of the streets, alleys or other public places of the village, or upon the porches or yards of private residences therein, or within any dwelling or building in the village, any samples of medicinal preparations for the purpose or with the intent of advertising or making known in a general or promiscuous manner any medical treatment or medicine whatsoever. 
Sec. 3-3. - Advertising unlawful articles and businesses. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to advertise any unlawful business or article in the village. 
Sec. 3-4. - Injuring advertisements and notices. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to injure or deface any lawful advertisement or notice. 
(Code 1956, § 17.29) 
Chapter 4 - ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Licenses and business operation regulations, Ch. 17. 
State Law reference- Liquor Control Act, 235 ILCS; local control, 235 ILCS 5/4-1. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- In June 2002, the village deleted former section 4-8 which pertained to minors handling alcoholic liquor as employees of retail licensees. Remaining sections of this article have been renumbered consecutively. 

Sec. 4-1. - Definitions. 
    Unless the context requires otherwise, the terms used in this chapter shall have the meanings ascribed to them in article I of the Liquor Control Act of 1934 (235 ILCS 5/1-1 et seq.), as amended from time to time. Where not otherwise qualified, the term "license" or "licensee", wherever used in this chapter, shall mean a license or licensee of the village under this chapter. 
    Private information means unique identifiers, including a person's social security number, driver's license number, employee identification number, biometric identifiers, personal financial information, passwords or other access codes, medical records, home or personal telephone numbers, and personal email addresses. Private information may also include home addresses and personal license plates, except as otherwise provided by law or when compiled without possibility of attribution to any person. 
(Code 1956, § 20.01; Ord. No. 11-1994, § 1, 5-10-94; Ord. No. 10-2013, § 3.00, 10-17-13) 
Cross reference- Rules of construction and definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 4-2. - Consumption on premises. 
    It shall be unlawful for anyone to sell or offer to sell any alcoholic liquor for consumption on the premises where sold, or permit the same to be consumed on the premises where sold, unless such person has a license issued under this code authorizing such sale and consumption. 
(Code 1956, § 20.07, Ord. No. 9-1957, § 1, 7-23-57; Ord. No. 11-1994, § 2, 5-10-94) 
Sec. 4-3. - Local liquor control commissioner-Designated; assistants; compensation. 
    The village president shall be the local liquor control commissioner and shall be charged with the administration of the provisions of this chapter and the appropriate provisions of the Liquor Control Act of the state, and may appoint any person to assist him in the exercise of such responsibilities. The village president elected at the April 2001 election and elected or appointed thereafter shall receive two thousand dollars ($2,000.00) annually for service as commissioner, with a three (3) per cent annual increase thereafter beginning May 1, 2002, such compensation to be paid as provided in section 2-85 of the Municipal Code. 
(Code 1956, § 20.08; Ord. No. 9-1957, § 1, 7-23-57; Ord. No. 24-1998, § 4, 9-22-98) 
Editor's note- Section 4-3 was amended in June 2002 at the request of the village. 
Cross reference- Administration generally, Ch. 2. 
Sec. 4-4. - Same-Powers, duties. 
    The local liquor control commissioner shall have the following powers, functions and duties: 
(1)  To grant and suspend, or both, for not more than thirty (30) days, or revoke for cause, all local licenses issued to persons for premises within the village; 
(2)  To enter or to authorize any law enforcing officer to enter upon the premises licensed under this chapter to determine whether any of the provisions of this chapter or of the Liquor Control Act of the state have been or are being violated; 
(3)  To receive or cause to be received all local license fees and pay them forthwith to the village treasurer; 
(4)  To receive complaints from any citizen of the village that any provision of this chapter or the Liquor Control Act has been or is being violated, and to act upon such complaint in the manner provided by law; 
(5)  To examine or cause to be examined under oath any applicant for a village license, or for renewal thereof, or any licensee upon whom notice of revocation has been served, all as provided in 235 ILCS 5/4-5, as amended from time to time. 
(6)  To require employees within licensed premises who serve alcohol to attend a certified training program for intervention procedures by servers of alcohol. 
(7)  To require employees within licensed premises who sell or serve alcohol to attend an Illinois Liquor Control Commission certified beverage alcohol sellers and servers education and training (BASSET) program. 
(Code 1956, § 20-08; Ord. No. 9-1957, § 1, 7-23-57; Ord. No. 3-1995, § 1, 2-14-95; Ord. No. 07-2002, § 1, 2-26-02) 
Sec. 4-5. - Peddling prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful to peddle alcoholic liquor in the village. 
(Code 1956, § 20.11; Ord. No. 9-1957, § 1, 7-23-57) 
Cross reference- Peddlers, solicitors and vendors, Ch. 21. 
Sec. 4-6. - Sanitary conditions. 
    All premises used for the retail sale of alcoholic liquor or for the storage thereof shall be kept in a clean and sanitary condition, and shall be governed by the ordinances of the village regulating the condition of premises used for the storage or sale of food for human consumption. 
(Code 1956, § 20.13; Ord, No. 9-1957, § 1, 7-23-57) 
Cross reference- Health and sanitation, Ch. 13. 
Sec. 4-7. - Employees. 
    It shall he unlawful to employ in any premises used for retail sale of alcoholic liquor any person who is afflicted with or who is a carrier of any contagious, infectious or venereal disease; and it shall be unlawful for any person who is afflicted with or a carrier of any such disease to work in or about any premises or to engage in any way in the handling, preparation or distribution of such liquor. 
(Code 1956, § 20.14; Ord. No. 9-1957, § 1, 7-23-57) 
Sec. 4-8. - Purchase, possession and consumption by persons under age. 
    No person under the age of twenty-one (21) years shall consume, purchase or accept delivery of alcohol liquor or have alcohol liquor in his or her possession within the Village of Hazel Crest; provided the possession and dispensing or consumption by any person under the age of twenty-one (21) years of alcoholic liquor in a performance of a religious service or ceremony, the consumption by a person under the age of twenty-one (21) years under the direct supervision and approval of parent(s) or guardian(s) of such under-age person in the privacy of the parent(s) or guardian(s) home is not prohibited. No person after purchasing or otherwise obtaining alcohol liquor shall sell, give or deliver such alcohol liquor to another person under the age of twenty-one (21) years. 
(Ord. No. 19-1982, § 1, 8-24-82) 
Sec. 4-9. - Liquor in vehicles.
