    General contractors or subcontractors engaged in making specific minor repairs not exceeding two hundred dollars ($200.00) are exempt from the requirements of this article. 
(Ord. No. 17-1967, § 4, 9-26-67) 
Secs. 6-24-6-34. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - FENCES AND SWALES 

Sec. 6-35. - Scope. 
    The regulations of this article shall control all matters concerning the construction, location and maintenance of all fences and swales in the village. 
(Ord. No. 22-1972, § 1, 11-28-72) 
Sec. 6-36. - Permit-Required; application. 
    It shall be unlawful to construct or erect a fence without first securing a building permit therefor by application filed at the office of the fire chief on a form prescribed and furnished for such purpose. Each application shall be accompanied by a plat of survey and a sketch or diagram of the proposed fence structure, indicating all dimensions and materials thereon, and its location on the property. 
(Ord. No. 22-1972, § 2, 11-28-72; Ord. No. 22-1992, § 2, 10-27-92) 
Sec. 6-37. - Same-Fee. 
    A fee of fifty dollars ($50.00) shall be deposited with the fire chief at the time the application for a fence or swale construction permit is filed. 
(Ord. No. 22-1972, § 2, 11-28-72; Ord. No. 22-1992, § 2, 10-27-92; Ord. No. 7-1995, § 8, 2-28-95; Ord. No. 05-2007, § 5, 3-27-07) 
Sec. 6-38. - Same-Approval or denial of application. 
    The village fire chief shall examine the application of each applicant for a fence or swale construction permit to determine whether or not the specifications, exhibits and information contained therein conform with the provisions of this article. He shall mark each application "approved" or "denied," with the reasons therefor. 
(Ord. No. 22-1972, § 6, 11-28-72; Ord. No. 22-1992, § 2, 10-27-92) 
Sec. 6-38.1. - Appeals from decisions of building inspector. 
    The owner of a fence or any other person may appeal from a decision of the building inspector refusing to grant a permit for the construction of a fence, to approve a fence or other decision arising from application of this article to a committee of village trustees as established by the village president. The fire chief or his designated representative shall take such action as recommended by this committee. 
(Ord. No. 32-1974, 11-12-74; Ord. No. 22-1992, § 2, 10-27-92) 
Sec. 6-39. - Registration of contractors. 
    All fence contractors shall be registered with the village upon payment of an annual fee of five dollars ($5.00), due on the first day of May of each year. 
(Ord. No. 22-1972, § 2, 11-28-72) 
Sec. 6-40. - Fences on residentially zoned property. 
(a)  Definitions. For the purposes of this section, a "boundary line fence" is a fence erected on and parallel to a lot line, and a "nonboundary line fence" is any fence which is not a boundary line fence. 
A "fence" is any structure made of wood, stone, concrete, metal or other material so as to create a sufficient obstruction around a lot or other space intended to prevent straying from within or intrusion from without certain property. 
(b)  Location. Fences shall not be permitted in the front yard. The definition of front yard (as defined in Section 3.2 of the Zoning Ordinance). A nonboundary line fence or fenced-in enclosure may be erected in the rear yard, provided the fence is erected at a distance not less than eight (8) feet from all lot lines. The following restrictions as to location shall also be complied with: 
(1)  A boundary line fence must be so constructed as to present its finished side to the adjacent property owner or owners. 
(2)  A fence shall not be constructed, placed, or maintained in any public right-of-way. Any fence existing, constructed, placed or maintained on an easement will be removed by the owner when work in such easement is necessary by public utility companies or agents authorized by the village. 
(3)  Fences on swales will be removed by the owner when work is necessary in swales by agents authorized by the village. 
(4)  Corner lots. A fence may be constructed in the side yard on the street side of the lot, but the fence cannot be located in any right-of-way or closer than ten (10 ) feet from the curb line of the street, which ever is more, and the fence cannot create a sight obstruction for traffic using the intersection. In the event that the above referenced set back of ten (10) feet is not adequate to avoid a sight obstruction, then the distance from the curb line shall be increased to eliminate the sight obstruction. 
(c)  Replacement. Replacement of a fence shall be the responsibility of the property owner and must conform with this article. 
(d)  Materials. Fences shall not be constructed either wholly or partially of barbed wire or carry an electrical charge. 
(e)  Height. Fences located in rear and side yards shall not exceed six (6) feet in height. The definition of the rear and side yards is found in Section 3.2 of the Zoning Ordinance. In determining the maximum height of any fence, the standard yard grade level will be used for measurement. The use of artificially installed landscape materials will not be included in the height calculation. 
(f)  Maintenance. When a property owner is installing a fences that is adjacent to an existing fence, and leaving space between the two fences, the fence must be installed in such a manner that the property owner can access the space between the fences in order to maintain the area including the cutting of grass and weeds and the removal of debris. Access could be by a gate or some other common access component. 
(Ord. No. 22-1972, § 3, 11-28-72; Ord. No. 32-1974, 11-12-74; Ord. No. 16-1982, §§ 1, 2, 7-13-82; Ord. No. 18-1999, §§ 1-5, 10-26-99) 
Sec. 6-41. - Fences on other than residentially zoned property. 
(a)  Location. Fences on other than residentially zoned property shall not be obstruct the view of vehicular traffic on any public right-of-way or access thereto. 
(b)  Height. Such fences shall not exceed eight (8) feet in height. 
(c)  Material. The top two (2) feet of such fences may be finished in barbed-wire type material only if so approved, and such fences shall not be constructed to carry an electrical charge. 
(d)  Advertising. General advertising on fences is prohibited unless it pertains to the operation of the business itself for identification purposes and complies with all village ordinances pertaining to signs. 
(Ord. No. 22-1972, § 4, 11-28-72) 
Sec. 6-42. - Maintenance of swales. 
    It shall be the responsibility of the property owner to maintain all swales on his property in a clean and effective condition, without obstruction to the normal water flow in the swale. 
(Ord. No. 22-1972, § 5, 11-28-72) 
Sec. 6-43. - Inspections. 
    The fire chief or his designated representative is hereby authorized and instructed to make an inspection of all swales and fence construction at such time as they are completed by the builder to ascertain and determine the applicant's compliances with the detailed representations he has made in the body of his application, and it shall be the fire chief or his designated representative's duty to inform the applicant of any violations of this article. Should the applicant fail to comply after such notice, the fire chief or his designated representative shall report the violations in writing and deposit the same with the owner and the village attorney for such further action as may be necessary. 
(Ord. No. 22-1972, § 6, 11-28-72; Ord. No. 22-1992, § 2, 10-27-92) 
ARTICLE IV. - SECURITY/FIRE ALARM SYSTEMS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Fire prevention and protection, Ch. 10, licenses and miscellaneous business regulations, Ch. 17; offenses and miscellaneous provisions, Ch. 20; police, Ch. 24. 

Sec. 6-44. - Definitions. 
    For the purposes of this article, the following words as used herein shall be construed to have the meaning herein ascribed to them: 
    Alarm subscriber shall mean the owner, tenant or other agents of the property where an alarm system is installed. 
    Alarm system shall mean any equipment or device initiating a request for emergency response. 
    Central station shall mean an independent alarm monitoring location which is regulated by the state and which relays requests for emergency response to the police or fire departments. 
    False alarm shall mean an activation of an alarm system due to mechanical failure, malfunction, improper installation, improper operation, or negligence of an alarm subscriber which causes an alarm signal to be received and responded to by either the police or fire departments, other than a noncontrollable alarm. 
    Local alarm shall mean any alarm system that activates an audible or visual display without transmitting the alarm to a central station or to the police or fire departments. 
    Noncontrollable alarm shall mean an activation of alarm system caused by adverse weather conditions, telephone line problems, or any other events over which the alarm company and its subscribers have no control. 
(Ord. No. 11-1990, § 1, 7-24-90) 
Sec. 6-45. - Permit requirement. 
(a)  All alarm systems operating within the village must have an annual alarm permit issued by the village. 
(b)  Application for initial alarm permit shall be on the form prescribed by the chief of police and billing department and shall include all information deemed necessary for the administration of this article. A forty dollar ($40.00) processing fee will be charged for the initial permit. A fifteen dollar ($15.00) annual renewal fee shall be payable on or before every May 1 thereafter. A penalty fee shall be added to the cost of the renewal permit in the amount equal to fifty (50) per cent of the original permit fee for renewal of the permit after May 1. 
(c)  Upon initial application, the proposed alarm system shall be inspected by the fire department and electrical inspector. In addition to the alarm permit fee, the applicant shall be responsible for any electrical inspection fees. 
(d)  All properties in the village which have alarm systems as of the effective date of this article, shall have one hundred eighty (180) days from the effective date hereof within which to obtain inspection of their alarm systems. 
(e)  A new permit shall be required upon a change of owner or tenant of the property within which the alarm system has been installed. 
(f)  Any change to the information listed on the original application for alarm permit shall be reported in writing to the police department within five (5) working days. 
(Ord. No. 11-1990, § 1, 7-24-90; Ord. No. 22-1992, § 2, 10-27-92; Ord. No. 11-1998, § 1, 6-9-98; Ord. No. 05-2007, § 6, 3-27-07) 
Sec. 6-46. - General requirements and prohibitions. 
(a)  All alarm system equipment must be approved by a nationally recognized testing or certifying laboratory or agency. 
(b)  All alarm systems may be connected to a central station or, in the case of commercial or bank alarms, may be connected directly to the police department alarm board, or else they may function as a local alarm. Any alarm system having an outside ringer, siren, buzzer or similar noisemaking device or any visual signal, either of which is designed to be detected by the public outside of the structure where the alarm is installed, must be equipped with an automatic shutoff device which will cause the alarm to shut off no later than thirty (30) minutes after it activates. This restriction shall not apply to fire alarm systems. 
(c)  No alarm system utilizing signaling devices that automatically select a telephone line of the police or fire departments, and then reproduce any prerecorded message which initiates a request for emergency response from the police or fire departments, shall be permitted. 
(d)  No alarm system may utilize the emergency 9-1-1 telephone lines into the police and fire departments. 
(e)  No alarm shall be manually activated for reasons other than a robbery or burglary in progress or having just occurred, a medical or fire emergency, or circumstances indicating a likelihood of death or great bodily harm. 
(Ord. No. 11-1990, § 1, 7-24-90) 
Sec. 6-47. - Service charges for false alarms. 
(a)  Each alarm system shall be allowed three (3) false alarms in the first month after installation or upgrading without the levy of a service charge. Thereafter, each alarm system will be allowed one (1) false alarm per calendar quarter without service charge. 
(b)  The owner of any system registering false alarms in excess of the allowances listed above, shall be assessed a twenty-five dollar ($25.00) service fee payable to the village. 
(Ord. No. 11-1990, § 1, 7-24-90) 
Sec. 6-48. - Suspension of alarm permits and disconnection of alarm systems. 
(a)  The following constitute grounds for suspension of alarm permits: 
(1)  More than three (3) false alarms in any calendar quarter; 
(2)  Installation, maintenance, or operation of an alarm system in violation of this article, or any term or condition of the owner's alarm permit; 
(3)  False information on the permit application; 
(4)  Failure to pay alarm service charges assessed under the terms of this article. 
(b)  Notice of revocation of alarm permit: 
(1)  When either the chief of police or the chief of the fire department determines that there are reasonable grounds for revocation of an alarm permit, the chief will have a notice of intent to revoke said permit sent to the alarm subscriber via certified mail. The notice will include the specific grounds for the intended revocation and will allow seven (7) days to correct the problem; 
(2)  If no corrective action has been taken by the alarm subscriber at the end of the seven-day period, the police or fire chief shall revoke the alarm permit, and so notify the owner. 
(c)  Upon revocation of an alarm permit, the alarm subscriber will disconnect the alarm system within twenty-four (24) hours after receipt of a written notice, via certified mail, of revocation. Any alarm remaining operational after this twenty-four hour period would be deemed prima facie evidence of a violation of this article and the permit holder subject to the penalties described in section 6-50 of this article. 
(Ord. No. 11-1990, § 1, 7-24-90) 
Sec. 6-49. - Limitation of village's responsibility. 
    Nothing in this article shall be construed as imposing any obligation or responsibility on the village with respect to the functioning of any alarm system. Nothing herein shall be construed as imposing on the village any obligation to provide any particular level of police or fire protection service to the owner of a system beyond that which the village provides for all of its citizens. 
(Ord. No. 11-1990, § 1, 7-24-90) 
Sec. 6-50. - Penalty. 
    Any person violating any of the provisions of sections 6-45 through 6-48 hereof shall, upon conviction thereof, be subject to a fine of not less than fifty dollars ($50.00) nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) for each offense. 
(Ord. No. 11-1990, § 1, 7- 24-90) 
ARTICLE V. - ADDITIONAL REQUIREMENTS FOR CERTAIN MULTIFAMILY PROPERTIES 

Sec. 6-51. - Applicability. 
    This article shall apply to owners and occupants of all multifamily dwellings containing in excess of seventy-five (75) separate residential units. 
(Ord. No. 15-1992, § 1, 9-8-92) 
Sec. 6-52. - Definitions. 
    For the purposes of this article, "owner" shall mean any individual, firm, corporation, land trust or other entity owning or operating a multifamily dwelling, subject to the terms of this article. "Tenant" shall mean any tenant residing within the property, subject to the terms of this article, regardless of whether the tenant occupies by way of oral or written lease, or similar agreement, or is a unit owner of a multifamily condominium or cooperative dwelling, which is subject to the terms of this article. 
(Ord. No. 15-1992, § 1, 9-8-92) 
Sec. 6-53. - Owner responsibilities. 
    Each owner shall have the following responsibilities with respect to the dwelling units: 
(a)  Property standards. Each owner shall: 
(1)  Provide drainage to prevent standing water and flooding on the land; 
(2)  Remove dead trees and tree limbs that are reasonably capable of causing injury to a person; 
(3)  Keep the doors and windows of a vacant dwelling unit or vacant portion of an apartment building securely closed to prevent unauthorized entry; 
(4)  Keep all areas of the building, grounds, facilities and appurtenances in a clean and sanitary condition; 
(5)  Maintain lighting of exterior parking areas according to existing Village Code requirements; 
(6)  Maintain at least two (2) private security officers on duty between 6:00 p.m. and 2:00 a.m. seven (7) days a week; 
(7)  Ensure that swimming pools on the premises will be operated in conformance to all state and local requirements. In addition, 
a.  The pool area is to be fenced in; 
b.  A pool attendant is to be on duty at all times the pool is scheduled for use; 
c.  The pool is to be used only be residents of said rental units and their guests and not be operated as a public facility; 
d.  Residents utilizing the pool are to be provided with or be required to produce identification indicating residency at the property; 
e.  Guests are to be issued a pass to gain entrance; 
f.  Records are to be made and kept of those attending the pool, their guests and place of residence within the complex. 
(8)  Require that parking stickers or similar forms of identification be issued by the management of said units to residents, and to be displayed on the vehicle to indicate that the vehicle's owner is a resident of the apartment complex; 
(9)  Required that visitor parking areas be designated for visitor parking only, with appropriate signage posted to indicate said use; 
(10)  Require that visitors intending to remain in a unit in excess of forty-eight (48) hours, register with premises management. At the time of visitor registration, owner must issue a parking pass to such visitor for a period of up to fourteen (14) days, said pass to be displayed in the right lower portion of the windshield of the visitor's vehicle. Following that fourteen-day period, a new parking pass may be issued. The owner shall transmit the names and vehicles of all such extended visitors to the village police department. 
(11)  Prohibit tenants from installing window coverings consisting of blankets, sheets, towels, newspapers or other paper and cloth products that would be affixed, tacked, nailed or glued to the window surface. Window coverings should allow the occupant to facilitate the entrance of light into the dwelling unit in a convenient manner utilizing a draw string, rope or mechanical device. 
(12)  Secure all exterior wires, service lines, cable TV or telephone connections to the exterior of the building so none of these "utility" lines are draped or otherwise hanging with "slack" created. 
(13)  Require that any garbage receptacle areas will be fully enclosed and maintained to their existing design. 
(14)  Shall maintain landscaping in conformance to its originally approved design plan. If a landscaping plan did not exist at the time of development, such plan is to be submitted within one hundred twenty (120) days of the passage of this article. A landscape design plan submitted under this article is subject to review and recommendation of the village plan commission, beautification commission, and village board. Upon approval of the landscape plan, the landscape plan is to be subject to annual review by the village to ensure adherence to the approved plan. 
(b)  Structural standards. An owner shall: 
(1)  Protect the exterior surfaces of a structure which are subject to decay by application of paint or other protective coating; 
(2)  Provide and maintain railings for stairs, steps, balconies, porches and elsewhere as specified in the Village of Hazel Crest Building Code; 
(3)  Provide and maintain in working order connections and pipes to supply potable water at adequate pressure, a minimum of fifty (50) PSI, to a dwelling unit; 
(4)  Provide and maintain a device to supply hot water of a constant minimum temperature of one hundred twenty (120) degrees Fahrenheit within each dwelling unit; 
(5)  Provide, connect and maintain in working order all provided kitchen sinks, bathtubs or showers and lavatories in a dwelling unit to a cold and hot water source; 
(6)  Connect all owner provided plumbing fixtures and heating equipment in accordance with the Village of Hazel Crest Plumbing Code and Village of Hazel Crest Mechanical Code; 
(7)  Provide heating equipment capable of maintaining a minimum inside temperature of sixty-eight (68) degrees Fahrenheit in each room of a dwelling unit; 
(8)  Maintain and repair air conditioning equipment provided with a unit capable of maintaining a maximum inside temperature of seventy-eight (78) degrees Fahrenheit; 
(9)  Provide and maintain in a satisfactory operating condition all supply lines for electrical service to each dwelling unit; 
(10)  Provide and maintain in a satisfactory operating condition all electrical circuits and outlets sufficient to safely carry a load imposed by normal use of appliances and fixtures; 
(11)  Maintain all electrical, plumbing, heating and other facilities supplied by owner in conformance with Village Codes, in good working condition at all times; and 
(12)  Promptly pay all utility bills in order to prevent all utility cut-offs by utility companies. 
(d)  Health standards. An owner shall: 
(1)  Eliminate rodents and vermin in all units and buildings as well as on the land; 
(2)  Maintain the interior of a vacant structure or vacant portion of a structure free from rubbish and garbage; 
(3)  Keep the interior of a vacant structure or vacant portion of a structure free from insects, rodents and vermin; 
(4)  Provide and maintain appropriate receptacles and conveniences for the removal of ashes, rubbish, garbage and any other waste material, and to arrange for the frequent, periodic removal of such waste materials; and 
(5)  Establish a regular program whereby each unit is treated by an exterminator at least twice per year. 
Sec. 6-54. - Tenant responsibilities. 
(a)  A tenant shall: 
(1)  Maintain the interior of said dwelling unit free from rubbish and garbage; 
(2)  Reserved. 
(3)  Connect plumbing fixtures and heating equipment that the tenant supplies in accordance with the village plumbing code and the village mechanical code; 
(4)  Place all ashes, rubbish, garbage and any other waste material in the appropriate receptacles provided for same by said owner; 
(5)  Not alter a structure or its facilities so as to create a nonconformity with section 6-53, "owner responsibilities" of this article; 
(6)  Use in a reasonable manner all electrical, plumbing, sanitary, heating, ventilating, air conditioning, and other facilities and appliance on the premises. 
(7)  Not deliberately or intentionally destroy, deface, damage, impair, or remove any part of the premises or knowingly permit any person to do so; 
(8)  Install, operate and maintain window coverings designed for such purpose, and shall not use covering material prohibited by section 6-53A.(11) of this article; 
(9)  Display the vehicle parking sticker issued by the management; 
(10)  Refrain from barbecuing or outdoor cooking on any balconies. 
(Ord. No. 15-1992, § 1, 9-8-92) 
Sec. 6-55. - Owner's repair duties. 
(a)  The owner shall provide to all tenants an emergency telephone number which is answered at all times during night or day. 
(b)  Upon notice by the tenant in writing of any defective condition in the premises or dwelling unit in noncompliance with the standards stated in section 6-53, the owner shall repair such condition within a reasonable period of time. If the owner fails to complete such repairs within seven (7) days, the tenant may file a complaint in writing to the fire chief or his designated representative for enforcement of the article. The fire chief or his designated representative shall cause an inspection, and establish a time by which the repair must be completed and shall issue a citation if the defect is not corrected by the specified date. 
(c)  In the event the repairs are not completed by the date specified by the fire chief or his designated representative, and the reasonable cost of the repair does not exceed the greater of five hundred dollars ($500.00) or one-half (1/2) of the monthly rent, the tenant may notify the landlord of his intention to correct the condition at the landlord's expense. If the landlord fails to correct the defect within seven (7) days after being notified by the tenant, or as promptly as conditions require in the case of an emergency, the tenant may have the work done in a workmanlike manner and in compliance with existing ordinances and regulations of the village, and after submitting to the owner a paid bill from an appropriate tradesman, supplier or contractor, deduct from his or her rent the amount thereof not to exceed the limits specified hereinabove, and not to exceed the reasonable price then customarily charged for the work. A tenant shall not repair at owner's expense if the condition was caused by the deliberate or negligent act or omission of the tenant, a member of the tenant's family, or other person on the premises with the tenant's consent. Before correcting a condition affecting facilities shared by more than one (1) dwelling unit, the tenant shall notify all other affected tenants and shall cause the work to be done so as to create the least practical inconvenience to the other tenants. Nothing herein shall be deemed to grant any tenant any right to repair any common element. 
(d)  In emergency situations, tenant shall notify the owner immediately by way of the emergency telephone number. For purposes of this article, "emergency situations" are defined as a stopped-up commode (when there is only one commode in a unit), overflowing bathtub or sink, broken pipes, leaking roof, emergency electrical malfunction or other situations having immediate adverse effects on the health or safety of the tenant or his/her property. Upon notification, the owner shall respond immediately and furnish assistance to the tenant within two (2) hours from such notification. 
(Ord. No. 15-1992, § 1, 9-8-92) 
Sec. 6-56. - Notice requirements. 
(a)  A person "notifies" or "gives a notice" or notification to another person by taking steps reasonably calculated to inform the other in ordinary course, whether or not the other actually comes to know of it. A person "receives" a notice or notification when (1) it comes to his attention, or (2) in case of the owner, it is delivered at the place of business of the owner through which the rental agreement was made or at any place held out by him as the place for receipt of the communication. In the case of the tenant, it is delivered in hand to the tenant or mailed by registered or certified mail to him at the place held out by him as the place for receipt of the communication or, in the absence of such designation to his last known place of residence. 
(b)  A tenant may not file a complaint with the fire chief or his designated representative under the terms of this article until seven (7) days have elapsed following written notice to the manager. 
(Ord. No. 15-1992, § 1, 9-8-92) 
Sec. 6-57. - Affirmative defenses. 
    Notwithstanding all other sections of this article, it will be an affirmative defense to a complaint if the defendant owner or tenant is able to establish that: 
(a)  The noncomplying condition described in the complaint was repaired within the prescribed time limits set forth in section 6-55 of this article; 
(b)  The noncomplying conditions were repaired within the time limits established by the fire chief or his designated representative; 
(c)  The required notice in section 6-56 of this article was not provided; 
(d)  The noncomplying condition was caused by the deliberate or intentional conduct of the complaining party; 
(e)  The noncomplying condition could have been corrected but for the tenant's refusal to permit access to his apartment. 
(Ord. No. 15-1992, § 1, 9-8-92) 
Sec. 6-58. - Rental agreement, disclosure, administrative responsibilities. 
(a)  An owner shall disclose to the tenant by properly posting in the office the name, address and telephone number of: 
(1)  Each property manager and resident manager; 
(2)  The management company responsible for the operation of the company. 
(b)  An owner shall leave notice of entry whenever it is necessary to enter an apartment without the specific permission of the tenant. Such notice shall include date, time, purpose and the person who has entered the apartment unit. 
(c)  An owner shall distribute to all tenants a copy of this ordinance describing the rights and responsibilities of the tenants. 
(Ord. No. 15-1992, § 1, 9-8-92) 
Sec. 6-59. - Conflicts. 
    In case of any conflicts between the provisions of this article and other provisions of the Village Code, the more restrictive provision shall apply. 
(Ord. No. 15-1992, § 1, 9-8-92) 
Sec. 6-60. - Penalties. 
(a)  Any person violating any provision of this article shall, upon conviction thereof, be subject to a fine of not less than fifty dollars ($50.00) and not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00). 
(b)  After notice, a person who knowingly continues to violate a provision of this article, or fails to perform an act required of him by this article, commits an offense, and upon conviction thereof, shall be fined not less than fifty dollars ($50.00) and not to exceed two hundred dollars ($200.00). A person commits a separate offense each day or portion of a day during which a violation occurs or continues. 
(Ord. No. 15-1992, § 1, 9-8-92) 
Sec. 6-61. - Severability. 
    If any section, paragraph, subdivision, clause or phrase of this article shall be adjudged invalid or held unconstitutional, the same shall not effect the validity of this article as a whole or any part of any provision thereof; other than the part so decided to be invalid or unconstitutional. 
(Ord. No. 15-1992, § 1, 9-8-92) 
ARTICLE VI. - MAINTENANCE AND OCCUPANCY COMMERCIAL BUILDING AND RESIDENTIAL RENTAL UNITS 

Sec. 6-62. - Definitions. 
    The following definitions shall apply in the interpretation and enforcement of this article: 
    Apartment shall mean a dwelling unit having both bathroom, and kitchen facilities. 
    Appropriate authority shall mean that person within the governmental structure of the corporate unit who is charged with the administration of the appropriate code. 
    Approved shall mean approved by the local or state authority having such administrative authority. 
    Attic shall mean any story situated wholly or partly within the roof, and so designed, arranged or built as to be used for business, storage, or habitation. 
    Basement shall mean a portion of a building located partly or wholly below grade and having half or more than half of its clear floor-to-ceiling height above the average grade of the adjoining ground. 
    Building shall mean a fixed structure with walls, foundation and roof, such as a house, factory, garage, etc. 
    Cellar shall mean a portion of a building located partly or wholly below grade and having half or more than half of its clear floor-to-ceiling height below the average grade of the adjoining ground. 
    Certificate of occupancy shall mean a document issued by the village after inspections performed either pursuant to this title or other provisions of the ordinances of the village showing that the premises conform to the ordinances of the village. 
    Commercial building shall mean any building or premises used to conduct a business or manufacture or to store goods or merchandise. 
    Dilapidated shall mean no longer adequate for the purpose or use for which it was originally intended. 
    Dwelling shall mean any enclosed space wholly or partly used or intended to be used for living, sleeping, cooking and eating. 
    Dwelling unit shall mean a room or group of rooms located within a dwelling forming a single habitable unit with facilities used or intended to be used by a single family for living, sleeping, cooking and eating purposes, including one- and two-family rental units and multiple-family dwelling units. 
    Enforcement authority shall mean the village manager or the village manager's designee is assigned to administer enforcement of this article. 
    Family shall mean one (1) or more individuals occupying a single dwelling unit; provided that unless all members who are related by blood, marriage, legal adoption or are foster children; and not more than two (2) guests or roomers whether gratuitous or nongratuitous may be housed; except for state licensed community integrated living arrangements (CILA) homes upon written notification to the Village of Hazel Crest. The term "family," as regards the number of persons residing within a dwelling unit, shall be further regulated by the necessary minimum requirement of the zoning ordinance of the Village of Hazel Crest, and the adopted codes herein referenced. 
    Grade shall mean the finished ground level adjacent to a required window. 
    Habitable room shall mean a room or enclosed floor space used or intended to be used for living, sleeping, cooking, or eating purposes, excluding bathrooms, water closet compartments, laundries, furnace rooms, pantries, kitchenettes and utility rooms with less than fifty (50) square feet of floor space, foyers or communicating corridors, stairways, closets, storage spaces and workshops, hobby and recreation areas or other areas that clearly cannot be used or intended to be used for living, sleeping, cooking, or eating purposes. 
    Household shall mean one (1) or more individuals living together in a single dwelling unit and sharing common living, sleeping, cooking and eating facilities, (see also "Family"). 
    Housing inspector shall mean the person who is acting as an inspector for the enforcement of this article of the Village of Hazel Crest or a fire department employee assigned as a fire inspector by the fire chief, and any other persons assigned code enforcement inspection duties by their supervisors. Said housing inspector shall be certified by the ICC, International Code Council. 
    Multiple-family dwelling shall mean any dwelling containing more than one (1) dwelling unit, including a lodging house. 
    Occupant shall mean any individual, over one (1) year of age, living, sleeping, cooking, or eating in, or having possession of, a dwelling unit or a rooming unit; except that in dwelling units a guest shall not be considered an occupant. 
    Operator shall mean any individual, over one (1) year of age, living, sleeping, cooking, or eating in, or having possession of, a dwelling unit or a rooming unit; except that in dwelling units a guest shall not be considered an occupant. 
    Owner shall mean any person who, alone or jointly or severally with others: 
(1)  Shall have legal title to any premises, dwelling or dwelling unit, with or without accompanying actual possession thereof; or 
(2)  Shall have charge, care, or control of any premises, dwelling or dwelling unit, as owner or agent of the owner, or an executor, administrator, manager, trustee, or guardian of the estate of the owner. 
Any such person thus representing the actual owner shall be found to comply with the provisions of this chapter and of rules and regulations adopted pursuant thereto, to the same extent as if he were the owner. 
    Permissible occupancy shall mean the maximum number of individuals permitted to reside in a dwelling unit, rooming unit or dormitory. 
    Person shall mean and include any individual, firm, corporation, association, and partnership, cooperative or governmental agency. 
    Premises shall mean a platted lot or part thereof or unplatted lot or parcel of land or plot of land, either occupied or unoccupied by any dwelling or nondwelling structure, and includes any such building, accessory structure or other structure thereon. 
    Rental shall mean any structure owned by another and occupied or used for a fee or without a fee by: 
(1)  Any person unrelated to the owner (as defined in "Owner") by blood, marriage or legal adoption; 
(2)  Any copartnership, firm, or corporation; or 
(3)  Any other entity. 
    Rooming unit shall mean any room or group of rooms forming a single habitable unit used or intended to be used for living and sleeping, but not for cooking purposes. 
    Short term shall mean a period of time of a short duration such as a visitor visiting for a week, but not to exceed thirty (30) days. 
    Tenant shall mean a person, persons, copartnership, firm, corporation or other entity occupying or using a building premises or any part or parts thereof owned by another for a fee or without a fee. 
(Ord. No. 14-2008, § 1, 6-10-08) 
Sec. 6-63. - Plans for inspections; certificate of compliance issued. 
    Each commercial and residential rental property shall be inspected in accordance with the provisions of section 6-64 once each year for the purpose of determining compliance with the Building and Building Regulation Codes of the Village of Hazel Crest and this annual inspection shall serve as the occupancy compliance and licensing inspection. 
(1)  On first application, each rental unit requiring inspection under this article shall be inspected as soon as possible and the compliance inspection and license required under this article shall be active until the period for inspection in which the building or premises is located, or for six (6) months, whichever is greater. Every relicensing or compliance inspection following such inspection shall be annually thereafter. 
(2)  Inspections may be made by the housing inspector when there is valid reason or probable cause to believe that a violation of this article has been or is being committed, upon the request of the owner, or receipt of a documented complaint as to a condition not compliant to the property maintenance standards. 
(Ord. No. 14-2008, § 1, 6-10-08) 
Sec. 6-64. - Powers and duties of housing inspector. 
(a)  Notice to public. Before making inspections, the housing inspector shall advise the owner and/or tenant of the plan to inspect. 
(b)  Inspection. The housing inspector, or an authorized representative, shall enforce the provisions of this article and is hereby authorized and directed to make inspections upon request of the owner, or in response to a complaint that an alleged violation of the provisions of this article or of the applicable rules or regulations adopted pursuant thereto may exist, or when the housing inspector has valid reason or probable cause to believe that a violation of this chapter or any rules and regulations adopted has been or is being committed. 
(c)  Time of inspections. The housing inspector is hereby authorized to enter and inspect between 9:00 a.m. and 5:00 p.m., or other hours as agreed upon between the housing inspector with the owner and/or tenant, all dwellings and commercial buildings subject to the provisions of this article for the purpose of determining whether or not there is compliance with its provisions. 
(d)  Premises inspection. The housing inspector is hereby authorized to inspect rental dwelling units and commercial buildings subject to this article, for the purpose of enforcing the specific minimum standards of the Building and Property Maintenance Codes of the Village of Hazel Crest (chapter 6 and chapter 14, article II). 
(e)  Appointments. The housing inspector and the owner, occupant or other person in charge of a dwelling or commercial building subject to this article may agree to an inspection by appointment at a time other than the hours provided in subsection (c) of this article. 
(f)  Access. The owner, occupant or other person in charge of the dwelling or commercial building upon presentation of proper identification by the housing inspector, a copy of any relevant plan of inspection pursuant to which entry is sought, and a schedule of the specific areas and facilities to be inspected, shall give the housing inspector entry and free access to every part of the dwelling or commercial building or to the surrounding premises. 
(g)  Compliance with article required. No premises covered by this article shall be occupied in violation of this article. 
(h)  Petition to court. If any owner, occupant, or other person in charge of a dwelling, dwelling unit, rooming unit, multiple-dwelling, or commercial buildings licensed as such, fails to refuse to permit free access and entry to the structure or premises under his control, or any part thereof, with respect to which an inspection authorized by this chapter is sought to be made, the housing inspector may, upon a showing to the court that probable cause exists for the inspection and for the issuance of an order directing compliance with the inspection requirements of this chapter with respect to such dwelling, dwelling units, multiple dwelling, or commercial buildings petition and obtain such order from a court of competent jurisdiction. 
(Ord. No. 14-2008, § 1, 6-10-08) 
Sec. 6-65. - Notice of violation. 
(a)  Contents of and specifications for notice. Whenever the housing inspector determines that any dwelling, dwelling unit, rooming unit, or the premises surrounding any of these, fails to meet the requirements set forth in this article or in applicable rules and regulations issued pursuant thereto, the housing inspector in accordance with existing legislation and the inspection plan, shall issue a notice setting forth alleged violations, and advising the owner, occupant, operator, or agent that such violations must be corrected. The notice shall: 
(1)  Be in writing; 
(2)  Set forth the alleged violations of this article or of the applicable rules and regulations issued pursuant thereto and include the specific provision by number; 
(3)  Describe the dwelling, dwelling unit, or rooming unit or commercial building where the violations are alleged to exist or to have been committed; 
(4)  Specify an appropriate or acceptable method of correction; 
(5)  Specify a date for the correction of any violation alleged; and 
(6)  Be served upon the owner, occupant, operator, or agent of the dwelling, dwelling unit or rooming unit or commercial building: 
a.  Personally; 
b.  By registered mail, return receipt requested, addressed to the owner, occupant, operator or agent at his last known address; 
c.  By posting the notice in or about the dwelling, dwelling unit, rooming unit, or commercial buildings described in the notice; or 
d.  Upon a resident agent for the receipt of such service of notice designated pursuant to this chapter. 
(b)  Reinspection. At the end of the period of time allowed for the correction of any violation alleged, the housing inspector shall reinspect the dwelling, dwelling unit, rooming unit, or commercial building described in the notice. 
(c)  Legal proceedings or vacation of order. If upon reinspection, the violations are determined by the housing inspector not to have been corrected, the housing inspector shall initiate legal proceedings for the immediate correction of the alleged violations and/or shall order the dwelling, dwelling unit, rooming unit, or commercial buildings vacated within thirty (30) days. 
(Ord. No. 14-2008, § 1, 6-10-08; Ord. No. 20-2008, § 1, 8-12-08) 
Sec. 6-66. - Penalties. 
    Any owner, occupant, operator, or agent of a dwelling, dwelling unit, rooming unit, or commercial building who has received a notice of an alleged violation of this article shall be subject to a penalty of not less than five hundred dollars ($500.00) per day nor more than the maximum amount allowed by state statute for ordinance violations. 
(Ord. No. 14-2008, § 1, 6-10-08) 
Sec. 6-67. - Emergencies. 
    Wherever in the judgment of the housing inspector an emergency exists which requires immediate action to protect the public health, safety, or welfare, an order may be issued, without a hearing or appeal, directing the owner, occupant, operator or agent to take such action as is appropriate to correct or abate the emergency. If circumstances warrant, the housing inspector may act to correct or abate the emergency. 
(1)  Notice served. Immediately after the violation is corrected by the housing inspector under the procedure described in the above paragraph, the inspector's supervising authority, or their designee shall serve or cause to be served a copy of the order on the owner or manager pursuant to the procedures outlined in this article. 
(2)  Order. The order issued under this section of the article shall: 
a.  Contain a description of the dwelling sufficient to identify and locate it; 
b.  Set out the particulars of the violation and the reasons why such violation constituted an urgent hazard to the health and safety of any person; 
c.  Have appended thereto a statement from the inspector setting out the measures taken by the village and the amount expended by the village in so doing; and 
d.  Contain notice of the appellate procedures outlined in this article. 
(3)  Recovery of costs. When repairs are made or other corrective action taken at the direction of the housing inspector, the cost of such repairs and corrective action shall constitute a debt in favor of the Village of Hazel Crest against the owner of the repaired structure. In the event such owner fails, neglects or refuses to pay the Village of Hazel Crest the amount of this debt, it shall be recoverable in a civil action against the owner or his successor, brought in a court of competent jurisdiction by the Village of Hazel Crest which shall possess all rights of a private creditor, or any other means of collection available to municipal corporations as set forth in the Illinois State Statutes. 
(4)  Liens. In addition to other methods of recovery, the cost of repair or other corrective action incurred by the village is recoverable from the owner or owners of such real estate and is a lien thereon, which lien is superior to all prior existing liens and encumbrances, except taxes; provided that within sixty (60) days after such repair or corrective action, the village shall file notice of lien of such costs and expenses incurred in the office of the recorder of deeds. The notice of lien must consist of a supporting statement setting out: 
a.  A description of the real estate sufficient for identification thereof; 
b.  The amount of money representing the cost; and 
c.  The date or dates when the cost and expense were incurred by the village. 
Upon payment of the cost and expense by the owner of or persons interested in the property after notice of lien has been filed, the lien shall be released by the village and the release may be filed of record as in the case of filing notice of lien. The lien may be enforced by proceedings to foreclosure as in the case of mortgages or mechanic's liens. Suit to foreclosure such lien must be commenced within three (3) years after the date of filing notice of lien. 
(Ord. No. 14-2008, § 1, 6-10-08) 
Sec. 6-68. - Appellate procedures. 
(a)  Appeal to enforcement authority. Any person aggrieved by a notice issued by the housing inspector, in connection with any alleged violation of this article or of any applicable rule or regulation issued pursuant thereto, or by any order requiring repair or demolition, may apply to the enforcement authority or his/her authorized representative for an administrative hearing for reconsideration of such notice or order provided such an application is made within ten (10) working days of the date the notice or order was issued. If the enforcement authority holds an administrative hearing for reconsideration of the notice or order, the enforcement authority shall prepare a summary of the conference and shall state the decision reached; each summary and statement shall become part of the public record. 
(b)  Action of enforcement authority. After such hearing, the enforcement authority shall sustain, modify or withdraw the notice or order, pursuant to his/her findings as to the compliance of the aggrieved person with the provisions of this article and of the rules and regulations adopted pursuant thereto. If the enforcement authority sustains or modifies such notice, it shall be deemed to be an order. 
(Ord. No. 14-2008, § 1, 6-10-08) 
Sec. 6-69. - Licensing of rental dwelling units. 
(a)  License required. 
(1)  No person, corporation or other entity shall operate rental dwelling units unless he or she or it holds a current, unrevoked operating license issued by the enforcement authority of the Village of Hazel Crest, in his or her or its name for the specifically named rental dwelling units. 
(2)  An operating license shall not be issued until the landlord, or designated agent, has attended and successfully completed the Village of Hazel Crest's crime free housing informational training within sixty (60) days of an operator's license application and fee of twenty-five dollars ($25.00) being submitted to the village. Licenses shall be null and void if the landlord, or designated agent, fails to comply with the village's crime free housing informational training requirement. 
(b)  Period of license. Every operating license shall be issued for a period of one (1) year or three hundred sixty-five (365) days after its date of issue, unless sooner revoked and may be renewed for successive periods not to exceed one (1) year or three hundred sixty-five (365) days. Said license is transferable to a new person, corporation or other entity on notification to the enforcement authority of intent to transfer, prior to the actual transfer and any such license so transferred shall remain in effect until its renewal or termination date provided the transferee meets the requirements of this article. 
(c)  Licensing authorized. The village enforcement authority is hereby authorized, upon application on forms provided by the enforcement authority, to issue a new operating license or to renew an existing operating license, in the name of the owner, operator or agent thereof, for the operation of one- and two-family dwelling units or multiple family dwelling units, on presentation by the applicant of a certificate of compliance issued by the enforcement authority, showing compliance to the health, safety and maintenance standards set forth in the article, and dated less than one hundred eighty (180) days prior to the date of application. 
(d)  Inspection and application fees. A fee of one hundred dollars ($100.00) per unit must be paid in full at time of request for inspection. In the event more than one (1) reinspection is required, there will be an additional fee of thirty-five dollars ($35.00) per reinspection. In multifamily buildings with multiple units to inspect, the first unit is one-hundred dollars ($100.00). Additional units inspected on the same day are thirty-five dollars ($35.00) each. An additional fee of fifty dollars ($50.00) per unit is assessed when the unit is occupied prior to a certificate of occupancy being issued. 
(e)  Renewal of existing license. All operating licenses will expire on April 30 of each year. Renewal of existing operating licenses must take place at least sixty (60) days prior to the expiration date of said license and all inspection and application fees paid. Renewal application made after the expiration date shall be charged a late fee of one hundred dollars ($100.00). Any renewal application without the required certificate of compliance shall be charged a fifteen ($15.00) per unit expediting fee in addition to the regular inspection and application fee. Renewed operating licenses will be issued as May 1 to April 30 of each year. 
(f)  A residency/registered agent. No license shall be issued or renewed for a nonresident applicant unless such applicants designates in writing, on the application form, the name of a registered agent in the State of Illinois, County of Cook for the receipt of service of any notices or correspondence issued pursuant to the enforcement of this article and for service of process pursuant to this article. An applicant shall be considered to be nonresident when absent from the Village of Hazel Crest for thirty (30) days or more. 
(g)  Display of license. Each license issued under this chapter must be available for inspection on request, by any officer of the Village of Hazel Crest, tenant or renter, or potential renter or tenant. 
(h)  Record of repair or changes. Any holder of an operating license issued pursuant to this article shall keep or cause to be kept a written record in the form of a list showing date and nature of all repairs, alterations or changes in equipment or systems related to the provisions of this article or to any rules or regulations pertaining thereto, and of all corrections made as a result of inspections made by the housing inspector. Such record shall be made available to the enforcement authority on request to the holder of license or their registered agent. Notice is hereby given that such record may be used in administrative or judicial proceedings pursuant to this article. 
(i)  Notice of violation. Whenever, upon inspection of any licensed premises or the records required to be kept under this article, a determination by the housing inspector or the enforcement authority indicates a violation of the provisions of this article occurs, a notice of violation shall be served in accordance with the requirements of this article. The notice of violation shall contain a statement of the specific requirement violated and a provision for the licensee to correct the violation or violations in a reasonable time as determined by the enforcement authority, and a statement that the license is subject to revocation if the corrections do not take place in the time limit stated. 
(j)  Reinspection and suspension of license. At the end of the time allowed for correction of the violation notice or earlier if requested by the license holder, a reinspection of the premises shall take place to determine if the corrections have taken place. If on inspection, the violations have not taken place, the enforcement authority shall issue an order suspending the operating license. 
(k)  Appeal of suspension order. An appeal to the enforcement authority appealing the suspension of an operating license must be in writing and submitted to the enforcement authority by the license holder or their agent, within ten (10) days of the issue of the suspension order. Failure to correct violations and failure to appeal the suspension as provided herein shall result in the revocation of said license. 
(l)  Reinstatement of suspended or revoked license. Suspended or revoked operator's license for the operation of one- and two-family rental dwelling units or multiple-family dwelling units shall be reinstated only on reinspection showing all cited violations have been corrected. 
(m)  Conviction. If a license holder or occupant or tenant is found guilty in a court of competent jurisdiction of any violation of the ordinances of the Village of Hazel Crest or the Laws of the United States or the State of Illinois in connection with the licensed premises, then the license shall be subject to revocation without further notice. 
(n)  Extremely hazardous conditions. In the event a condition of extreme hazard or imminent danger to the occupants or general public is found to exist on or in licensed premises, the housing inspector of the enforcement authority may immediately revoke the license and issue a notice of violation without a time limit to correct the hazardous condition; and order evacuation of the premises if, in the inspector's opinion, evacuation is necessary to protect the occupants. 
(o)  Separate violation. Each item contained in a notice of violation may be considered a separate violation of this article and each day that a violation exists from the date of discovery and the date of correction shall be considered a separate violation of the article and subject to the fines set herein. 
(p)  Transfer of cited property. It is unlawful for the owner of any premises who has received compliance orders or upon whom a notice of violation has been served, to sell, transfer, mortgage, lease or otherwise dispose of to another party, the so cited property until the provisions of the compliance order or notice of violation have been complied with, or until such owner shall furnish to the grantee, mortgagor or lessee, a true copy of any compliance or notice of violation, issued by the enforcement authority, or shall furnish to the enforcement authority a signed and notarized statement from grantees, transferee, mortgagor, or lessee, acknowledging the receipt of such compliance order or notice of violation and fully accepting the responsibility without condition for making the corrections or repairs required by such compliance order or notice of violation. 
(q)  Any owner, agent or designee of rented property is required to utilize a nuisance-free lease addendum or have a clause in the lease similar to a nuisance-free lease addendum for any leases executed after the effective date of this article. The village manager, or the village manager's designee, shall provide at no cost samples of the nuisance-free lease addendum and shall review any clauses within actual leases with the village attorney to determine if the clause if similar to the nuisance-free lease addendum. The clause is to make criminal activity (not limited to violent criminal activity or drug-related criminal activity engaged by, facilitated by or permitted by the renter, a member of the household, guest or other party under the control of the renter) a lease violation. The landlord shall have authority under that clause to initiate an eviction proceeding as specified in the Illinois Compiled Statues Forcible Entry and Detainer statutes. Proof of criminal violation shall be by a preponderance of the evidence. 
(Ord. No. 14-2008, § 1, 6-10-08; Ord. No. 20-2008, § 1, 8-12-08) 
Sec. 6-70. - Nuisance residential rental property. 
(a)  It is hereby declared a nuisance and to be declared against the health, peace and comfort of the village for any property owner, agent, or manager to allow or permit the following: 
(1)  Rental of a residential unit, or residential building within an apartment community, or governed by a homeowner's association to a tenant who has any involvement in any of the following offenses relating to the tenant, a member of the tenant's household, guest or other party under control of the tenant to occur: murder, kidnapping, aggravated kidnapping, prostitution, solicitation of prostitution, pandering, obscenity, sale or possession of child pornography, sale of obscene publication, possession of explosives, unlawful use of weapons, sale of firearms, gambling, keeping a gambling place, concealing a fugitive, violation of the Illinois Controlled Substances Act, violation of the Cannabis Control Act, or commission of any two (2) or more of any other offenses under the State of Illinois or under the federal government not specifically listed above. 
(2)  Rental of a residential unit or residential building within an apartment community, or governed by a homeowner's association to a tenant who has any involvement in any of the following offenses relating to the tenant, members of the tenant's household, guest or other party under control of the tenant to occur: commission of four (4) or more village ordinance violations in a six-month period or an unreasonably high number of calls for police service including, but not limited to, calls that may fall within the descriptions listed above that when compared to other properties in the Village of Hazel Crest of similar type, reasonably indicate that the activity at this property is out of character for the area and is impacting the quality of life of those in the area. 
(b)  The village administrator may suspend and/or recommend revocation of the license issued pursuant to section 6-69 if it appears to his satisfaction from the report of any village officer or village employee making an inspection, or any other available information, that the licensee is violating any law or ordinance, or is in violation of the nuisance section or is operating in a manner not conducive to the public health, morals or safety. Any suspension of a license may be appealed directly to the mayor and board of trustees within fifteen (15) days of rendering his decision by the village manager. In the event the village manager determines the revocation of the license is appropriate, he shall so forward his recommendation to the mayor and board of trustees for their review and determination. 
(Ord. No. 14-2008, § 1, 6-10-08) 
Secs. 6-71-6-80. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - HEARING PROCEEDINGS AND ENFORCEMENT OF BUILDING, HOUSING AND ZONING ORDINANCE VIOLATIONS[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note- Section 2 of Ord. No. 14-2008, adopted June 10, 2008, renumbered former art. VI as art. VII. 

Sec. 6-81. - Adoption of state statute. 
    Hereby adopted is 65 ILCS 5/11-31.1-1 et seq. as it may be amended from time-to-time and as allowed by said statute. 
(Ord. No. 26-2002, Art. I, 9-24-02) 
Sec. 6-82. - Definitions. 
    As used in this article, unless context requires otherwise: 
    Building inspector means a full-time municipal employee whose duties include the inspection or examination of structures or property in the Village of Hazel Crest in the State of Illinois, to determine if zoning or other code violation exist. 
    Code means any village ordinance, law, housing, building code or zoning ordinance that establishes construction, plumbing, heating, electrical, fire prevention, sanitation or other health and safety standards that are applicable to structures in the village. 
    Hearing officer means a village employee or an officer or agent of Village of Hazel Crest, other than a property inspector or law enforcement officer, whose duty it is to: 
(1)  Preside at an administrative hearing called to determine whether or not a code violation exists; 
(2)  Hear testimony and accept evidence from the property inspector, the building owner and all interested parties relevant to the existence of a Code violation; 
(3)  Preserve and authenticate the record of the hearing and all exhibits and evidence introduced at the hearing; 
(4)  Issue and sign a written finding, decision and order stating whether a Code violation exists; 
(5)  Administer oaths; and 
(6)  Hold conferences for the settlement or simplification of issues. 
    Property owner means the legal or beneficial owner of a structure. 
(Ord. No. 26-2002, Art. II, 9-24-02) 
Sec. 6-83. - Code hearing department. 
(a)  There is hereby established a Code Hearing Department the function of which is to expedite the presentation and correction of Code violations in the manner set out in 65 ILCS 5/11-31.1 et seq and this article. 
(b)  The adoption of this article does not preclude the village from using other lawful methods to enforce the provisions of its Code. 
(Ord. No. 26-2002, Art. III, 9-24-02) 
Sec. 6-84. - Code hearing procedure. 
(a)  When a building inspector finds a code violation while inspecting a property, he shall note the violation on a multiple copy violation notice and report form, indicating the name and address of the property owner, the type and nature of the violation, the date and time the violation was observed, the names of witnesses to the violation, and the address of the property where the violation is observed. 
(b)  The violation report form shall be forwarded by the building inspector to the code hearing department where a docket number shall be stamped on all copies of the report, and a hearing date noted in the blank spaces provided for that purpose on the form. The hearing date shall not be less than fifteen (15) days after the violation is reported by the building inspector. 
(c)  One (1) copy of the violation report form shall be maintained in the files of the code hearing department and shall be part of the record of hearing, one (1) copy of the report form shall be returned to the building inspector so that he may prepare evidence of the code violation for presentation at the hearing on the date indicated, and one (1) copy of the report form shall be served by first class mail on the property owner along with a summons commanding the property owner to appear at the hearing. [If the municipality in which the property is situated has an ordinance requiring property owners to register with the municipality, service may be made on the property owner by mailing the report and summons to the property owner's address registered with the municipality.] If the name of the property owner of the structure cannot be ascertained or if service on the property owner cannot be made by mail, service may be made on the property owner by posting or nailing a copy of the violation report form on the front door of the structure where the violation is found, not less than twenty (20) days before the hearing is scheduled. 
(Ord. No. 26-2002, Art. IV, 9-24-02; Ord. No. 16-2011, § 3, 11-8-11) 
Sec. 6-85. - Subpoenas. 
    At any time prior to the hearing date the hearing officer assigned to hear the case may, at the request of the building inspector or the attorney for Village of Hazel Crest, or the property owner or his attorney, issue subpoenas directing witnesses to appear and give testimony and/or submit document at the hearing. 
(Ord. No. 26-2002, Art. V, 9-24-02) 
Sec. 6-86. - Default. 
    If on the date set for hearing the property owner or his attorney fails to appear, the hearing officer may find the property owner in default and shall proceed with the hearing and accept evidence relevant to the existence of a code violation. 
(Ord. No. 26-2002, Art. VI, 9-24-02) 
Sec. 6-87. - Continuances and representation at code hearings. 
    No continuances shall be authorized by the hearing officer in proceedings under this article except in cases where a continuance is absolutely necessary to protect the rights of the owner. Lack of preparation shall not be grounds for a continuance. Any continuance authorized by a hearing officer under this article shall not exceed twenty-five (25) days. The case for the village may be presented by the building inspector, by any other village employee or by an attorney designated by the village. However, in no event shall the case for the village be presented by an employee of the code hearing department. The case for the property owner may be presented by the owner, his attorney, or any other agent or representative. 
(Ord. No. 26-2002, Art. VII, 9-24-02) 
Sec. 6-88. - Evidence at hearing. 
    At the hearing, a hearing officer shall preside and shall hear testimony and accept and evidence relevant to the existence or non-existence of a code violation relating to a property or structure indicated. The strict rules of evidence applicable to judicial proceedings shall not apply to hearings authorized by this article. The hearing officer shall determine the weight, if any, to be afforded documents received into evidence. 
(Ord. No. 26-2002, Art. VIII, 9-24-02) 
Sec. 6-89. - Transcripts of proceedings. 
    The village shall determine the manner in which the transcript of proceedings shall occur. Either party may request the proceedings be taken and transcribed by a certified court reporter. The cost of the reporter shall be borne by the party requesting the court reporter. The village may at its own costs, record the proceedings. If a recording is made, a respondent may obtain a transcript at the respondent's costs. 
(Ord. No. 26-2002, Art. IX, 9-24-02) 
Sec. 6-90. - Retaliatory action against occupants prohibited . 
    No action for eviction, abatement of a nuisance, forcible entry and detainer or other similar proceeding shall be threatened or instituted against an occupant of a dwelling solely because such occupant agrees to testify or testifies at a code violation hearing. 
(Ord. No. 26-2002, Art. X, 9-24-02) 
Sec. 6-91. - Defenses to code violations. 
    It shall be a defense to a code violation charge under this article if the property owner, his attorney, or any other agent or representative proves to the hearing officer's satisfaction that: 
(1)  The code violation alleged in the notice does not in fact exist, or at the time of the hearing the violation has been remedied or removed; 
(2)  The code violation has been caused by the current property occupants and that in spite of reasonable attempts by the property owner to maintain the dwelling free of such violations, the current occupants continue to cause the violations; or 
(3)  An occupant or resident of the dwelling has refused entry to the property owner or his agent to all or a part of the dwelling for the purpose of correcting the code violation. 
(Ord. No. 26-2002, Art. XI, 9-24-02) 
Sec. 6-92. - Findings, decision, order of hearing officer. 
(a)  At the conclusion of the hearing the hearing officer shall make a determination on the basis of the evidence presented at the hearing whether or not a code violation exists. The determination shall be in writing and shall be designated as findings, decision and order. The findings, decision and order shall include the hearing officer's finding of fact, a decision whether or not a code violation exists based upon the findings of facts, and an order ordering the property owner to correct the violation or dismissing the case in the event a violation is not proved. 
(b)  If a code violation is proved, the order may also impose the sanctions that are provided in the code for the violation proved. A copy of the findings, decision, and order shall be served on the property owner within five (5) days after they are issued; service shall be in the same manner as the report form and summons are served pursuant to section 4-84(c). Payment of any penalty or fine and the disposition of fine money shall be in the same manner as set forth in this code, unless otherwise provided. 
(Ord. No. 26-2002, Art. XII, 9-24-02) 
Sec. 6-93. - Fines and sanctions. 
    The municipality adopts by reference all current and future local ordinances, and those provisions of Illinois Complied Statues 65 ILCS 5/11-31.1-1 et seq, governing property or zoning codes applicable to structures or properties relative to construction, plumbing, heating, electrical, fire prevention, sanitation and other health and safety standards in village, for its enforcement and adjudication within the geographical boundaries of the village. 
(Ord. No. 26-2002, Art. XIII, 9-24-02) 
Sec. 6-94. - Incorporation of laws. 
    The findings, decision and order of the hearing officer shall be subject to review in the Circuit Court of Cook County, and the provisions of the administrative review law (735 ILCS 5/3-101 et seq), and all amendments and modifications thereto, and the rules adopted pursuant thereto are adopted and shall apply to and govern every action for the judicial review of the final findings, decision and order of a hearing officer under this article. 
(Ord. No. 26-2002, Art. XIV, 9-24-02) 
Sec. 6-95. - Disposition of violations. 
(a)  Any fine, other sanction or costs imposed, or part of any fine, other sanction or costs imposed remaining unpaid after the exhaustion of, or the failure to exhaust, judicial review procedures under the administrative review law shall be a debt due and owing the Village of Hazel Crest and, as such, may be collected in accordance with applicable law. 
(b)  After expiration of the period within judicial review under the administrative review law may be sought for a final determination of the code violation, the village may commence a proceeding in the Circuit Court of Cook County for purposes of obtaining a judgment on the findings, decision and order. Nothing in this section shall prevent the village from consolidating multiple findings, decisions and orders against a person in such a proceeding. Upon commencement of the action, the village shall file a certified copy of the findings, decision and order, which shall be accompanied by a certification that recites facts sufficient to show that the findings, decision and order was issued in accordance with this article and applicable state law. Service of the summons and a copy of the petition may be by any method provided by Section 2-203 of the Code of Civil Procedure or by certified mail. return receipt requested, provided that the total amounts of fines, other sanctions and costs imposed by the findings, decision and order does not exceed two thousand five hundred dollars ($2,500.00). 
(Ord. No. 26-2002, Art. XV, 9-24-02) 
Sec. 6-96. - Sanctions and findings to run with property. 
    The order to correct a code violation and the sanctions imposed by the village as the result of a finding of a code violation under this article shall attach to the property as well as to the property owner so that a finding of a code violation against one owner cannot be avoided by conveying or transferring the property to another owner. Any subsequent transferee or owner of property takes subject to the findings, decision and order of a hearing officer under this article. 
(Ord. No. 26-2002, Art. XVI, 9-24-02) 
Chapter 7 - CIVIL DEFENSE AND EMERGENCIES[1]

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL[2]
