ARTICLE II. - EMERGENCY POWERS OF PRESIDENT[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference- President, 2-83 et seq. 

Sec. 7-24. - Definitions. 
    For the purposes of this article, the following terms shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section: 
    A civil emergency shall be: 
(1)  A riot or unlawful assembly characterized by the use of actual force or violence or any threat to use force if accompanied by immediate power to execute by three (3) or more persons acting together without authority of law; or 
(2)  Any natural disaster or man-made calamity, including flood, conflagration, cyclone, tornado, earthquake or explosion within the corporate limits of the village, resulting in the death or injury of persons or the destruction of property to such an extent that extraordinary measures must be taken to protect the public health, safety and welfare. 
    Curfew: A prohibition against any person walking, running, loitering, standing or riding upon any alley, street, highway, public property or vacant premises within the corporate limits of the village, except officials of any governmental unit and persons officially designated to duty with reference to the civil emergency. 
(Ord. No. 18-1968, § 1, 9-24-68) 
Cross reference- Rules of construction and definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 7-25. - Proclamation of emergency. 
    Whenever the president of the board of trustees finds that a civil emergency exists, he shall set forth the facts, by means of a written statement signed by him under oath, to substantiate such findings, describing the emergency and declaring that such an emergency exists. Such statement shall be filed with the clerk of the village as soon as practicable. 
(Ord. No. 18-1968, § 2, 9-24-68) 
Sec. 7-26. - Duration of emergency. 
    After a state of emergency has been declared as provided in this article, it shall expire not later than the adjournment of the first regular meeting of the village board after the state of emergency has been declared. The village board may by its action extend the state of emergency if, in the opinion of the board, such emergency still exists. 
(Ord. No. 18-1968, § 3, 9-24-68) 
Sec. 7-27. - Curfew. 
    After the proclamation of a civil emergency by the president of the village, he may order a general curfew applicable to such geographical areas of the village or to the village as a whole as he may deem advisable and applicable during such hours of the day or night as he deems necessary in the interests of the public safety and welfare. In the event the president is absent from the village, or for some reason is unable to act, the president pro tem or the oldest ranking member of the village board is authorized to proclaim such an emergency. 
(Ord. No. 18-1968, § 4, 9-24-68) 
Cross reference- Curfew for minors, Ch. 20, Art. VI. 
Sec. 7-28. - Time period for proclamation. 
    The proclamation authorized in this article shall be effective for a period of forty-eight (48) hours, unless sooner terminated by a proclamation of the president of the board of trustees indicating that the civil emergency no longer exists. The president shall have the power to reproclaim the existence of a civil emergency at the end of each forty-eight (48) hour period during the time such civil emergency exists. 
(Ord. No. 18-1968, § 5, 9-24-68) 
Sec. 7-29. - Notification to news media of emergency. 
    Upon issuing the proclamation authorized in this article, the chief of police shall notify the news media serving the village or situated within the village, and shall cause three (3) copies of the proclamation declaring the existence of the emergency to be posted in the village at the village hall, the police station and the post office. 
(Ord. No. 18-1968, § 6, 9-24-68) 
Sec. 7-30. - Violations. 
    Any person violating the provisions of this article, or an executive order issued pursuant thereto, shall be guilty of an offense against the village. 
(Ord. No. 18-1968, § 7, 9-24-68) 
Sec. 7-31. - Construction of article. 
    Nothing contained in this article shall be construed to impair the powers given to the police and fire departments in other provisions of this Code, but shall be construed together with existing ordinances now in effect for the safety and welfare of the citizens of the village. 
(Ord. No. 18-1968, § 9, 9-24-68) 
Secs. 7-32-7-42. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - DISASTER COORDINATION[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Cross reference- Planning generally, Ch. 22. 

Sec. 7-43. - Coordinator of emergency services and disaster agency for the village charged with coordination. 
    As soon as a state of emergency has been declared by the village president, or by the elected official acting in the president's absence, the director of civil defense will be so informed and will be charged with all coordinating responsibilities. Such responsibilities shall include directing all the disaster activities of the police, fire, public works, civil defense and office personnel 
(Ord. No. 22-1992, § 2, 10-27-92) 
Sec. 7-44. - Notice to department heads; cooperation of personnel in absence of department heads. 
    In order for the director of civil defense to successfully direct and coordinate the activities described in section 7-43, he shall contact the various department heads and announce that the state of emergency has been declared by the proper elected official, and that he needs department cooperation. If the department head is not immediately available, all personnel of each department shall follow the directions of the director. 
Sec. 7-45. - Duty of departments whose assistance is not requested. 
    If the director of civil defense does not solicit assistance from a department head or other department personnel during a state of emergency, the department must continue to function in the most effective manner possible under direction of the department's normal supervisory personnel. 
Sec. 7-46. - Notice upon cessation of emergency. 
    When a state of emergency has ceased, the director of civil defense will so notify all department heads and advise them that their operations should return to normal. 
Secs. 7-47-7-56. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - EMERGENCY SERVICES AND DISASTER AGENCIES[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2-1976, §§ 1-12, adopted Jan. 27, 1976 did not specifically amend the Code, hence codification herein as Art. IV, §§ 7-57-7-68 was at the discretion of the editor. 

Sec. 7-57. - Establishment. 
    There is hereby created the Village of Hazel Crest, Illinois ESDA to prevent, minimize, repair and alleviate injury or damage resulting from disaster caused by enemy attack, sabotage or other hostile action, or from natural or manmade disaster, in accordance with the Illinois Emergency Services and Disaster Act of 1975. This ESDA shall consist of the coordinator and such additional members as may be selected by the coordinator. 
(Ord. No. 2-1976, § 1, 1-27-76) 
Sec. 7-58. - Coordinator. 
(a)  The coordinator of the village ESDA shall be appointed by the president and board of trustees and shall serve until removed by same. 
(b)  The coordinator shall have direct responsibility for the organization, administration, training and operation of the ESDA, subject to the direction and control of the village president as provided by statute. 
(c)  In the event of the absence, resignation, death or inability to serve as the coordinator, the deputy coordinator shall be and act as coordinator until a new appointment is made as provided in this article. 
(Ord. No. 2-1976, § 2, 1-27-76) 
Sec. 7-59. - Functions. 
    The village ESDA shall perform such ESDA functions within the village as shall be prescribed in and by the state ESDA plan and program prepared by the governor, and such orders, rules and regulations as may be promulgated by the governor, and in addition shall perform such duties outside the corporate limits as may be required pursuant to any mutual aid agreement with any other political subdivision, municipality or quasi-municipality entered into as provided in the state ESDA Act of 1975. 
(Ord. No. 2-1976, § 3, 1-27-76) 
Sec. 7-60. - Service as mobile support team. 
(a)  All or any members of the village ESDA organization may be designated as members of a mobile support team created by the director of the state ESDA as provided by law. 
(b)  The leader of such mobile support team shall be designated by the coordinator of the Village ESDA organization. 
(c)  Any member of a mobile support team who is a village employee or officer while serving on call to duty by the governor, or the state director, shall receive the compensation and have the powers, duties, rights and immunities incident to such employment or office. Any such member who is not a paid officer or employee of the city, while so serving, shall receive from the state reasonable compensation as provided by law. 
(Ord. No. 2-1976, § 4, 1-27-76) 
Sec. 7-61. - Agreements with other political subdivisions. 
    The coordinator of ESDA may negotiate mutual aid agreements with other villages or political subdivisions of the state, but no such agreement shall be effective until it has been approved by the board of trustees and by the state director of ESDA. 
(Ord. No. 2-1976, § 5, 1-27-76) 
Sec. 7-62. - Emergency action. 
    If the governor proclaims that a disaster emergency exists in the event of actual enemy attack upon the United States or the occurrence within the State of Illinois of a major disaster resulting from enemy sabotage or other hostile action, or from man-made or natural disaster, it shall be the duty of the village ESDA to cooperate fully with the state ESDA and with the governor in the exercise of emergency powers as provided by law. 
(Ord. No. 2-1976, § 6, 1-27-76) 
Sec. 7-63. - Compensation. 
    Members of the ESDA who are paid employees or officers of the village, if called for training by the state director of ESDA, shall receive for the time spent in such training the same rate of pay as is attached to the position held; members who are not such village employees or officers shall receive for such training time such compensation as may be established by the president and board of trustees. 
(Ord. No. 2-1976, § 7, 1-27-76) 
Sec. 7-64. - Reimbursement by state. 
    The state treasurer may receive and allocate to the appropriate fund, any reimbursement by the state to the village for expenses incident to training members of the ESDA as prescribed by the state director of ESDA, compensation for services and expenses of members of a mobile support team while serving outside the village in response to a call by the governor or state director of ESDA, as provided by law, and any other reimbursement made by the state incident to ESDA activities as provided by law. 
(Ord. No. 2-1976, § 8, 1-27-76) 
Sec. 7-65. - Purchases and expenditures. 
(a)  The village president and board of trustees may, on recommendation of the village coordinator of ESDA, authorize any purchase of contracts necessary to place the village in a position to combat effectively any disaster resulting from the explosion of any nuclear or other bomb or missile, and to protect the public health and safety, protect property, and provide emergency assistance to victims in the case of such disaster, or from man-made or natural disaster. 
(b)  In the event of enemy-caused or other disaster, the village coordinator of ESDA is authorized, on behalf of the village, to procure such services, supplies, equipment or material as may be necessary for such purposes, in view of the exigency without regard to the statutory procedures or formalities normally prescribed by law pertaining to city contracts or obligations, as authorized by the state ESDA Act of 1975, provided that if the president and board of trustees meets at such time he shall act subject to the directions and restrictions imposed by that body. 
(Ord. No. 2-1976, § 9, 1-27-76) 
Sec. 7-66. - Oath. 
    Every person appointed to serve in any capacity in the village ESDA organization shall, before entering upon his duties, subscribe to the following oath, which shall be filed with the coordinator: 
"I, ____________ , do solemnly swear (or affirm) that I will support and defend and bear true faith and allegiance to the Constitution of the United States and the Constitution of the State of Illinois, and the territory, institutions and facilities thereof, both public and private, against all enemies, foreign and domestic; that I take this obligation freely, without any mental reservation or purpose of evasion; and that I will well and faithfully discharge the duties upon which I am about to enter. And I do further swear (or affirm) that I do not advocate, nor am I nor have I been a member of any political party or organization that advocates the overthrow of the government of the United States or of this state by force or violence; and that during such time as I am affiliated with the Village of Hazel Crest ESDA organization, I will not advocate nor become a member of any political party or organization that advocates the overthrow of the government of the United States or of this state by force or violence." 
(Ord. No. 2-1976, § 10, 1-27-76) 
Sec. 7-67. - Office space. 
    The village president is authorized to designate space in a village building, or elsewhere, as may be provided for by the village board for the ESDA as its office. 
(Ord. No. 2-1976, § 11, 1-27-76) 
Sec. 7-68. - Funding; tax levy. 
    The village board may make an appropriation for ESDA purposes in the manner provided by law and may levy in addition for ESDA purposes only, a tax not to exceed five cents ($0.05) per one hundred dollars ($100.00) of the assessed value of all taxable property in addition to all other taxes, as provided by the state ESDA Act of 1975; however, that amount collectable under such levy shall in no event exceed twenty-five cents ($0.25) per capita. 
(Ord. No. 2-1976, § 12, 1-27-76) 
Chapter 8 - ELECTIONS[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Administration generally, Ch. 2. 
State Law reference- Elections generally, 10 ILCS. 

Sec. 8-1. - Procedure. 
    Elections for municipal offices shall be held as and at the time prescribed by statute. 
(Code 1956, § 4.07) 
Chapter 9 - ELECTRICITY 
ARTICLE I. - ELECTRICAL CODE, 2000 

Sec. 9-1. - Adoption of electrical code. 
    That a certain document, three (3) copies of which are on file in the Office of the Village Clerk of the Village of Hazel Crest, and have been on file there, and made available for public use, inspection, and examination for at least thirty (30) days prior to the enactment of this section, being marked and designated as the ICC Electrical Code, 2000, Administrative Procedures, and the National Electrical Code, 1999, are hereby adopted as the Electrical Code of the Village of Hazel Crest in the State of Illinois, for the control of all electrical wiring and electrical equipment, and each and all of the regulations, provisions, penalties, conditions and terms of the ICC Electrical Code, 2000, Administrative Procedures, and the National Electrical Code, 1999, are hereby referred to, adopted and made part hereof, as if fully set out in this chapter with the insertion prescribed in Section 9-1.1. 
(Ord. No. 8-1976, § 1, 3-9-76; Ord. No. 12-1979, § 1, 3-27-79; Ord. No. 20-1981, § 1, 9-22-81; Ord. No. 24-185, § 1, 11-12-85; Ord. No. 3-1991, § 1, 3-26-91; Ord. No. 22-1992, § 2, 10-27-92; Ord. No. 8-1995, § 1, 2-28-95; Ord. No. 23-2002, § 24, 8-13-02) 
Sec. 9-1.1. - Code revisions [ICC Electrical Code 2000]. 
    The following sections of the ICC Electrical Code, 2000, Administrative Procedures, are hereby revised as follows: 
(1)  Section 1101.1, Membership of Board: The Board of Appeals shall consist of the Village Board of Trustees. The Village President shall act as Chairman of this Board. The Chairman will vote on the case under appeal only if there is a tie vote. 
(2)  Section 1102: Delete. 
(3)  Section 1103: Delete. 
(Ord. No. 8-1976, § 3, 3-9-76; Ord. No. 12-1979, § 2, 3-27-79; Ord. No. 20-1981, § 2, 9-22-81; Ord. No. 24-185, § 2, 11-12-85; Ord. No. 3-1991, § 2, 3-26-91; Ord. No. 8-1995, § 2, 2-28-95; Ord. No. 23-2002, § 25, 8-13-02) 
Sec. 9-1.2. - Code revisions [National Electrical Code, 1999]. 
    The following sections of the National Electrical Code, 1999, are hereby revised as follows: 
(1)  Article 210-8 is hereby amended to read as follows: All 125-volt, single-phase 15- and 20-amp receptacles installed in bathrooms, garages, outdoors, or within six (6) feet of any plumbing fixture shall be provided with ground-fault circuit interrupter protection for personnel. (Exception: sump and ejector pits) 
(2)  Delete in its entirety the following: 
Article 324 (concealed knob and tube); 
Article 331 (electrical nonmetallic tubing); 
Article 336 (nonmetallic-sheathed cable); 
Article 347 (rigid nonmetallic conduit); 
Article 545; 
Article 604 (manufactured wiring systems). 
(3)  Add the following: 
Article 385: all conductors shall be installed in approved metallic raceways. 
Article 386: aluminum conductors shall not be allowed in residential or commercial construction 
(4)  Additional changes: 
Article 410-8, add to section: 
(a2)  All closets as defined above shall be completed with an approved light fixture 
Article 410-8E, add new section: all fixtures located inside closets shall be controlled by an approved general use wall switch. 
(Ord. No. 23-2002, § 26, 8-13-02) 
Sec. 9-1.3. - Penalty for violation of sections 9-1, 9-1.1 [and 9-1.2.] 
    Any person who shall violate a provision of sections 9-1 or 9-1.1 [and 9.1.2] or shall fail to comply with any of the requirements thereof or who shall perform any electrical work in violation of an approved plan or directive of the fire chief or his designated representative, or of a permit or certificate issued under the provisions of sections 9-1 or 9-1.1 [and 9.1.2], shall be guilty of an offense against the village, punishable by a fine of not less than fifty dollars ($50.00), nor more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00). Each day that a violation continues shall be deemed a separate offence. 
(Ord. No. 12-1979, § 3, 3-27-79; Ord. No. 20-1981, § 3, 9-22-81; Ord. No. 22-1992, § 2, 10-27-92; Ord. No. 23-2002, § 27, 8-13-02) 
Sec. 9-2. - Installation in accord with regulations. 
    The installation of all electric wiring and electric equipment provided for shall be in strict accordance with the electrical regulations of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 8-1976, § 2(2.1), 3-9-76) 
Sec. 9-3. - Enforcement. 
    The fire chief or his designated representative shall enforce the electrical regulations of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 8-1976, § 2(2.2), 3-9-76; Ord. No. 22-1992, § 2, 10-27-92) 
Sec. 9-4. - Village not liable for damages. 
    The electrical regulations of this chapter shall not be construed to relieve from or lessen the responsibility of any person owning, operating, selling, offering for sale or installing any electrical wires, appliances, apparatus, construction or equipment, for damages to anyone injured by any defect therein by reason of the inspection authorized herein or the certificate of inspection issued by the electrical inspector; nor shall the municipality be held liable for any damages resulting from the enforcement of the electrical regulations of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 8-1976, § 2(2.3), 3-9-76) 
Sec. 9-5. - Action by inspector on behalf of municipality. 
    In all cases where any action is taken by the electrical inspector to enforce the provisions of any of the sections contained in the electrical regulations of this chapter, such acts shall be done in the name of and on behalf of the municipality, and the said electrical inspector in so acting for the municipality shall not render himself liable for any damage that may accrue to persons or property as a result of any such act committed in good faith in the discharge of his duties, and any suit brought against said electrical inspector by reason thereof, shall be defended by the corporation counsel of said municipality until final termination of the proceedings contained therein. 
(Ord. No. 8-1976, § 2(2.4), 3-9-76) 
Sec. 9-6. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 8-1995, § 3, adopted Feb. 28, 1995, repealed former section 9-6 in its entirety which pertained to modification of the regulations of this chapter and derived from Ord. No. 8-1976, § 2(2.5), adopted March 9, 1976. 
Sec. 9-7. - Inspector authorized to enter any premises. 
    The electrical inspector is authorized to enter any building or premises at any reasonable hour in the discharge of his duties. If the owner, occupant or other person in charge of a structure subject to the provisions of this chapter refuses, impedes, inhibits, interferes with, restricts or obstructs entry and free access to every part of the structure or premises where inspection authorized by this chapter is sought, the administrative authority may seek, in a court of competent jurisdiction, an order that such owner, occupant or other person in charge cease and desist with such interference. 
(Ord. No. 8-1976, § 2(2.6), 3-9-76) 
Sec. 9-8. - Authority of inspector to call upon police. 
    Wherever, in the opinion of the electrical inspector, it shall be necessary to call upon the department of police for aid and assistance in carrying out or enforcing any of the provisions of this chapter governing the inspection of electrical equipment, he shall have the authority to do so, and it shall be the duty of any member of the department of police when called upon by said electrical inspector, to act according to the instructions of and to perform such duties as may be required by such electrical inspector in order to enforce or put into effect the provisions of this chapter relating to the inspection of electrical equipment. 
(Ord. No. 8-1976, § 2(2.7), 3-9-76) 
Sec. 9-9. - Permit required; authority of inspector to stop work begun without permit. 
    No registered electrical contractor shall install any electrical conduits, electrical wires, equipment or apparatus in any building or structure, for which a permit is required, until such permit shall have been secured. In case any work is begun on the installation of electrical conduits, raceways, or the installation, alteration or repair of electrical wires or apparatus in any building or structure without a permit authorizing the same being first issued therefor, the aforesaid installations made in violation of the electrical regulations of this chapter, the electrical inspector shall have the power to stop such work at once and to order any and all persons engaged therein, to stop and desist therefrom until the proper permit is secured. Such stop work order shall be in compliance with appropriate section of the Village of Hazel Crest building code. 
(Ord. No. 8-1976, § 2(2.8), 3-9-76; Ord. No. 8-1995, § 3, 2-28-95) 
Sec. 9-10. - Compliance with code standards; definitions; examples. 
    It shall be unlawful for any individual, company or corporation to sell, offer for sale, give away gratis, install, alter, repair or use any electrical equipment or appliance intended for use in the municipality which does not conform to the standards set forth in this chapter. 
(a)  The term "electrical equipment" as used in the electrical regulations of this chapter is hereby defined as meaning conductors and apparatus installed for the utilization of electricity for light, heat, power, aural or visual communication or signal transmission or convenience. 
(b)  The term "appliance" as used in the electrical regulations of this chapter is hereby defined as meaning any device, machine, piece of apparatus or tool which utilizes of transmits electrical current or energy. 
(c)  Examples of electrical equipment are as follows: Conduit, wire ways, trough, duct, switchboards, panelboards, distribution centers, motor control centers, conductors, cables, cords, junction boxes, cabinets, connectors, couplings, tape, fittings, switches, circuit breakers, fuses, meter fittings, combinations of any of the foregoing and, in general, anything that would be utilized in making an electrical installation. 
(d)  Examples of appliances are as follows: All electrical tools, toasters, irons, hair dryers, washers, dryers, dishwashers, stoves, ranges, ovens, rotisseries, fry pans; radios and television sets not specifically excluded by this section of the code; amplifiers, speakers, phonographs, recorders, office machines, electrical toys, cords and cord sets, signs, points of display, fixtures, decorations and, in general, any and all electrical appliances or devices or machines intended by their nature and construction to utilize or transform electrical current in their normal usage. 
(Ord. No. 8-1976, § 2(2.9), 3-9-76) 
Sec. 9-11. - "Electrical contractor" defined. 
    The term "electrical contractor" as used in this chapter shall be understood to mean any person engaged in the business of installing or altering by contract electrical equipment for the utilization of electricity supplied for light, heat or power, not including radio apparatus or equipment for wireless reception of sounds and signals, conductors and other equipment installed for or by public utilities including common carriers which are under the jurisdiction of the Illinois Commerce Commission, for use in their operation as public utilities; but the term "electrical contractor" does not include employees employed by such contractor to do or supervise such work. 
(Ord. No. 8-1976, § 2(2.10), 3-9-76) 
Sec. 9-12. - Authority of inspector to attach notice to prevent electricity usage. 
    The fire chief or his designated representative is hereby empowered to attach to electrical cabinets and equipment any official notice or seal to prevent use of electricity, and it shall be unlawful for any other person to put or attach such seal, or to break, change, destroy, tear, mutilate, cover or otherwise deface or injure any such official notice or seal posted by the inspector. 
(Ord. No. 8-1976, § 2(2.11), 3-9-76; Ord. No. 22-1992, § 2, 10-27-92) 
Sec. 9-13. - Conformity with code required when tampering with wiring. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person in any way to cut, disturb, alter or change any electrical wiring or to permit such electrical wiring to be cut, disturbed, altered or changed, unless done in conformity with the electrical regulations of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 8-1976, § 2(2.12), 3-9-76) 
Sec. 9-14. - Overfusing prohibited; overcurrent devices; violation. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to overfuse any conductor, motor or apparatus, or to install any substitute in lieu of an approved fuse or device so as to remove or reduce the factor of safety of the same. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to sell or offer for sale any tool or device especially made or intended for the purpose of defeating the noninterchangeability feature of overcurrent protective devices. Nor shall any individual, company or corporation sell, offer for sale or give away gratis any tool or device which by its very nature defeats the intent of those sections of this chapter relating to the noninterchangeability of overcurrent devices. 
(c)  This section is not intended to prohibit the use of devices which are made available by manufacturers in order to accomplish the permitted interchange of overcurrent protective devices, which such devices are made available only by the manufacturer of the overcurrent protective devices to be changed. 
(d)  Each such device sold, offered for sale or given away gratis shall constitute a separate violation of this section and shall be so prosecuted. 
(Ord. No. 8-1976, § 2(2.13), 3-9-76) 
Sec. 9-15. - Installations by nonregistered contractors. 
    When contracts to install electrical work have been obtained by persons who are not registered as electrical contractors, as provided for in this chapter basis, the name of such registered electrical contractor shall immediately be disclosed by the registered electrical contractor to the other party to the contract in writing. 
(Ord. No. 8-1976, § 2(2.14), 3-9-76) 
Secs. 9-16-9-24. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 23-2002, § 28, adopted Aug. 13, 2002, repealed former sections 9-16-9-19 in their entirety which pertained to the registration of electrical contractors and derived from Ord. No. 8-1976, §§ 2(2.15)-2(2.18). 
 Ord. No. 8-1995, § 3, adopted Feb. 28, 1995, repealed former sections 9-20-9-24 in their entirety which derived from Ord. No. 8-1976, § 2(2.19-2.23), adopted March 9, 1976. Former sections 9-20-9-24, respectively pertained to the appointment of a supervising electrician, application for supervising electrician, applicant qualifications and examination, certification, and duties of supervising electrician. 
Sec. 9-25. - Penalty and hearing for electrical work without a permit. 
(a)  No electrical equipment shall be installed or altered except upon the issuance of a permit. 
(b)  Where an electrical installation has been started prior to the issuance of a permit for such work, the normal permit fee as required by this chapter shall be increased by the amount of fifteen dollars ($15.00). 
(Ord. No. 8-1976, § 2(2.24), 3-9-76; Ord. No. 8-1995, § 3, 2-28-95) 
Sec. 9-26. - Issuance of permit required for applicants in compliance with rules and regulations; exception. 
    The fire department shall issue permits for such installation and alteration of electrical equipment in all cases where application for such permit shall be made in accordance with the rules and regulations applicable thereto; provided however, that no permit shall be issued for installing or altering by contract, electrical equipment, unless the person applying for such permit is registered as an electrical contractor as required in section 9-16 of this chapter, and further provided, that the inspection fee as provided for in this chapter shall have been paid in advance upon filing the application. 
(Ord. No. 8-1976, § 2(2.25), 3-9-76; Ord. No. 22-1992, § 2, 10-27-92) 
Sec. 9-27. - Inspection by electrical inspector. 
    The fire chief or his designated representative shall inspect all electrical equipment installed or altered, except such electrical equipment as may be lawfully exempt, and shall require that it conform to the electrical regulations of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 8-1976, § 2(2.26), 3-9-76; Ord. No. 22-1992, § 2, 10-27-92) 
Sec. 9-28. - Issuance of certificate of inspection. 
    Upon completion of such installation or alteration in compliance with the electrical regulations of this chapter, the building department shall, on request made by a registered electrical contractor, issue a certificate of inspection covering such installation or alteration; provided however, that no such certificate shall be issued until all inspection fees for such installation have been paid. 
(Ord. No. 8-1976, § 2(2.27), 3-9-76) 
Sec. 9-29. - Reinspection; notification by inspector. 
    The fire chief or his designated representative is hereby empowered to reinspect any electrical equipment within the scope of the electrical regulations of this chapter, and when said electrical equipment is found to be unsafe to life or property, shall notify in writing either the owner, his agent for the purpose of managing, controlling or collecting rents or any other person managing, controlling, using or operating the same to place such electrical equipment in a safe and secure condition in compliance with the electrical regulations of this chapter within such time as the fire chief or his designated representative shall consider just and reasonable, but in no event shall this time exceed fifteen (15) days from the date of such notice. Refusal to comply with the requirements of such notice shall subject the person owning, managing, operating or using such electrical equipment to the penalties provided for in section 9-100 of this chapter. The fire chief or his designated representative is hereby empowered to cut off and stop current to any electrical equipment found to be unsafe to life or property. 
(Ord. No. 8-1976, § 2(2.29), 3-9-76; Ord. No. 22-1992, § 2, 10-27-92) 
Sec. 9-30. - Fire department records. 
    The fire department shall keep complete records of all permits issued and inspections made and other official work performed under the electrical regulations of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 8-1976, § 2(2.29), 3-9-76; Ord. No. 8-1995, § 3, 2-28-95) 
Sec. 9-31. - Electrical current usage prohibited on building sites until approved by inspector; exception; notice. 
    Whenever any electrical equipment has been installed or altered, no electrical current shall be used on such equipment, except as hereinafter provided, previous to the inspection of such equipment by the fire chief or his designated representative and the issuance of a temporary current permit covering designated portions or the entirety of such installation or alteration; provided however, that in the case of any installation or alteration, covered by permit authorizing such installation or alteration, the portion of such equipment comprising the service entrance equipment and wiring, the meter and meter connection cabinet and the meter wiring up to but not beyond the customer's disconnecting switch or other disconnecting device may be made electrically alive prior to inspection and the issuance of a temporary current permit, and provided further that, in such case, the fire chief or his designated representative shall be notified of the intention to make such portion of the equipment electrically alive and that the customer's disconnecting switch or other disconnecting device shall be sealed in the "off" position and tagged with a warning notice reading as follows: 
    "It shall be unlawful for any person to place this switch in the `on' or `closed' position or to use electricity on any wiring beyond this switch previous to the issuance, by the fire chief or his designated representative, of a temporary current permit or a certificate of inspection authorizing the use of current on this installation." 
(Ord. No. 8-1976, § 2(2.30), 3-9-76; Ord. No. 22-1992, § 2, 10-27-92) 
Sec. 9-32. - Failure by contractor to correct defect noticed by inspector; penalty. 
(a)  Failure on the part of any registered electrical contractor to correct any defect, error or deficiency in any work installed under the authority of a permit issued to him by the fire department within ten (10) calendar days after written notification thereof by the said bureau or within such further reasonable time as may, upon request, be prescribed, the fire chief or his designated representative shall, without further notice, stop the issuance of permits to such registered electrical contractor until such corrections have been made, inspected and approved. In addition thereto, the penalty provided in this section may be enforced. 
(b)  The fire chief or his designated representative shall recommend suspension of permit privileges of any registered electrical contractor who shall fail to pay any just indebtedness for inspection fees for electrical wires and apparatus as fixed by that part of this chapter dealing therewith, until such registered electrical contractor shall discharge and pay to the municipality all just indebtedness then due and owing from such registered electrician. 
(Ord. No. 8-1976, § 2(2.31), 3-9-76; Ord. No. 22-1992, § 2, 10-27-92) 
Sec. 9-33. - Inspector authorized to recommend revocation. 
    The fire chief or his designated representative is authorized to recommend revocation of any permit or certificate obtained by fraud, misrepresentation, or in any way contrary to the provisions of the electrical regulations of this chapter, for the installation, alteration, repair and use of any electrical equipment. 
(Ord. No. 8-1976, § 2(2.32), 3-9-76; Ord. No. 22-1992, § 2, 10-27-92) 
Sec. 9-34. - Unlawful to use another's permit. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to install, alter or repair any electrical wires or apparatus by authority of a permit issued to and for the use of some other person. 
(Ord. No. 8-1976, § 2(2.33), 3-9-76) 
Sec. 9-35. - Unlawful for contractor to secure permit for person not entitled. 
    It shall be unlawful for any registered electrical contractor to secure or furnish a permit or the installation, alteration and repair of electrical wires and apparatus to any person not entitled to such permit under the electrical regulations of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 8-1976, § 2(2.34), 3-9-76) 
Sec. 9-36. - Unlawful to tamper with forms issued to contractors by building department. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to change, add to or mutilate so as to change the original wording, of any written or printed form issued to registered electrical contractors by the building department. 
(Ord. No. 8-1976, § 2(2.35), 3-9-76) 
Sec. 9-37. - Violation of sections 9-32 through 9-36. 
    Any person violating any of sections 9-32 to 9-36, inclusive, shall be subject to the penalties provided or in section 9-100, and in addition thereto the permit, certificate or any printed form issued to a registered electrical contractor shall be revoked by the fire department. Notice of revocation shall be in writing to the person violating any of those sections. 
(Ord. No. 8-1976, § 2(2.36), 3-9-76; Ord. No. 8-1995, § 3, 2-28-95) 
Sec. 9-38. - Monthly permits-Generally. 
    Where due to the nature of their business it is necessary to make frequent alterations and changes to their electrical equipment, a monthly permit may be obtained each and every month of the year to cover all of the electrical work installed, altered or repaired during the previous month by persons who have a maintenance supervisor registered as per section 9-40 of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 8-1976, § 2(2.37), 3-9-76) 
Sec. 9-39. - Same-Application. 
    Before such a permit shall be issued to any person, he shall fill out an affidavit form of application to be furnished by the fire department. 
(Ord. No. 8-1976, § 2(2.38), 3-9-76; Ord. No. 22-1992, § 2, 10-27-92) 
Secs. 9-40-9-43. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 8-1995, § 3, adopted Feb. 28, 1995, repealed former sections 9-40-9-43 in their entirety and which respectively pertained to the employment of a supervising electrician, recommendation of supervising electrician by the electrical inspector, records to be kept by the supervising electrician, and penalties for violation. These former sections derived from Ord. No. 9-1976, § 2(2.39-2.42), 3-9-76; Ord. No. 22-1992, § 2, 10-27-92. 
Sec. 9-44. - Maintenance listing for permit privileges-Generally. 
    Maintenance listing for permit privileges may be extended to persons for the installation, alteration, repair and maintenance of electrical wires and equipment under the conditions in sections 9-45 to 9-50 inclusive, of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 8-1976, § 2(2.43), 3-9-76) 
Sec. 9-45. - Same-Application. 
    Application for maintenance listing for permit privileges shall be made in writing on affidavit form to be furnished by the fire department. 
(Ord. No. 8-1976, § 2(2.44), 3-9-76; Ord. No. 22-1992, § 2, 10-27-92) 
Sec. 9-46. - Same-Conditions for permit issuance. 
    Permits for the installation, alteration, repair and maintenance of electric wires and apparatus shall be issued under the authority of this chapter applicable to maintenance permits to a person only where such electrical work is to be performed in or on the premises or property owned or controlled by the said person and used exclusively by them to conduct their business. 
(Ord. No. 8-1976, § 2(2.45), 3-9-76) 
Sec. 9-47. - Same-Unlawful to obtain permit when work performed by written or oral contractor. 
    It shall be unlawful to obtain a permit under the provisions of this chapter dealing with maintenance permits for the installation, alteration, repair or maintenance of electrical wires or apparatus where such electrical work is performed under or by contract either verbal or written. 
(Ord. No. 8-1976, § 2(2.46), 3-9-76) 
Sec. 9-48. - Same-Location of work site to be recorded with fire department. 
    The location of all buildings, premises or property, where electrical work is to be installed, altered, repaired or maintained, under authority of permits issued under the provisions of this chapter dealing with maintenance permits, shall be recorded with the building department. 
(Ord. No. 8-1976, § 2(2.47), 3-9-76; Ord. No. 8-1995, § 3, 2-28-95) 
Secs. 9-49-9-51. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 8-1995, § 3, adopted Feb. 28, 1995, repealed former sections 9-49-9-51 in their entirety which respectively pertained to the appointment and employment of a supervising electrician, recommendation of supervising electricians by the inspector, and penalties for violation. These former sections derived from Ord. No. 8-1972, § 2(2.48-2.50), 3-9-76; Ord. No. 22-1992, § 2, 10-27-92. 
Sec. 9-52. - Commercial electric lamp posts-Defined. 
    For the purpose of the electrical regulations of this electrical code, commercial electric lamp posts shall be deemed street lamp posts on public property not owned, operated or maintained by the municipality. 
(Ord. No. 8-1976, § 2(2.51), 3-9-76) 
Sec. 9-53. - Same-Nonapplicability of provisions to equipment owned by municipality. 
    The following sections of this chapter [sections 9-54 through 9-61] on commercial electric lamp posts shall not be construed as applying in any way to street lighting posts or equipment erected, owned or maintained by the municipality. 
(Ord. No. 8-1976, § 2(2.52), 3-9-76) 
Sec. 9-54. - Same-Application for installation or repair. 
    Any person desiring to install, alter or repair any commercial electric lamp post on any public way in the municipality shall make an application to the fire department for that purpose on a form furnished therefor by the fire department, setting forth therein such information as is required by such bureau. Such application when made shall be submitted to the director of public works for his approval and when the same shall be approved by the director of public works, a permit in writing authorizing such applicant, providing such applicant is a registered electrical contractor as required by section 9-16, to install, alter, repair and maintain commercial electrical lamp post or posts at the location or locations designated in such application, shall thereupon be issued. No work of any kind shall be started until such permit has been obtained. 
(Ord. No. 8-1976, § 2(2.53), 3-9-76; Ord. No. 22-1992, § 2, 10-27-92) 
Sec. 9-55. - Same-Issuance of permit contingent upon approval of post type, design, etc. 
    No permit shall be issued for the erection of any commercial electric lamp posts, under the provisions of this chapter, until the director of public works shall have approved the type and design of such posts and the locations of such posts on the public way. All commercial electric lamp posts erected shall conform to the standards and specifications as prescribed in that part of section 9-1.1 dealing with outside wiring. 
(Ord. No. 8-1976, § 2 (2.54), 3-9-76) 
Sec. 9-56. - Same-Revocation of maintenance permits. 
    Permits for the maintenance of commercial electric lamp posts may be revoked at any time. 
(Ord. No. 8-1976, § 2 (2.55), 3-9-76) 
Sec. 9-57. - Same-Removal due to interference. 
    The fire department shall remove or cause to be removed any commercial electric lamp post that interferes with the proper installation or operation of any equipment for any purpose whatsoever that the village has or may install or maintain on or over any public way. 
(Ord. No. 8-1976, § 2(2.56), 3-9-76; Ord. No. 22-1992, § 2, 10-27-92) 
Sec. 9-58. - Same-Removal due to abandonment. 
    Any commercial electric lamp post not maintained in strict conformity with all the electrical regulations of this chapter, shall be declared to be abandoned and an obstruction upon public property. The fire department is hereby empowered to remove or cause to be removed any such abandoned commercial electric lamp post or posts. 
(Ord. No. 8-1976, § 2(2.57), 3-9-76; Ord. No. 22-1922, § 2, 10-27-92) 
Sec. 9-59. - Same-Bond required. 
    No permit shall be issued to install, alter, repair or maintain any electric lamp post until the person making an application for such permit shall have filed with the building department an indemnifying bond with good and sufficient sureties approved by the director of public works equal to the sum of five hundred dollars ($500.00) for each electric lamp post installed or maintained. The aforesaid bond shall guarantee the installation and maintenance of any and all electric lamp posts specified in the application for a permit in accordance with the provision, standards and specifications of the electrical regulations of this code applicable thereto. The aforesaid bond shall further guarantee the removal from the public way in a manner satisfactory to the director of public works of any and all abandoned electric lamp posts, specified in any permit, within a period of thirty (30) days after having received notice thereof. In the event of the failure of any person to comply with any of the electrical regulations of this code applicable thereto, the director of public works shall notify the guarantors and should any violation continue for a period of more than thirty (30) days, he shall declare the bond applying to the electric lamp post in violation forfeited, and the director of public works is hereby authorized to collect the full amount of such bond. 
(Ord. No. 8-1976, § 2 (2.58), 3-9-76) 
Sec. 9-60. - Same-Inspection. 
    All commercial electric lamp posts installed on public property shall be inspected by the fire chief or his designated representative after installation. 
(Ord. No. 8-1976, § 2(2.59), 3-9-76; Ord. No. 22-1992, § 2, 10-27-92) 
Sec. 9-61. - Same-Attachment of signs. 
    Any department of the municipality is hereby empowered to attach any sign or signs deemed necessary to any commercial electric lamp post erected and maintained under the authority of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 8-1976, § 2 (2.60), 3-9-76) 
Sec. 9-62. - Festoons and decorative lighting equipment-Defined. 
    Festoons and decorative lighting equipment shall be deemed to be lamps attached to wires or structures which extend over any public property and shall not apply to lamps attached to commercial electric lamp posts as defined in section 9-52 or to any sign, canopy or structure authorized by this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 8-1976, § 2 (2.61), 3-9-76) 
Sec. 9-63. - Same-Permit application for installation, repair, etc.; revocation. 
(a)  Any person desiring to install, alter or repair any festoons or commercial street lighting equipment on or over any public way shall make an application to the fire department for that purpose on a form furnished therefor by the building department setting forth therein such information as is required by such department. Such application when made shall be submitted to the fire chief or his designated representative for his review and when the same shall be approved by the fire department, a permit in writing authorizing such applicant, providing such applicant is a registered electrical contractor as provided for in sections 9-16 and 9-17, to install, alter, repair and maintain festoons or decorative lighting equipment at the location or locations designated in such application, shall thereupon be issued by the director of public works and no work of any kind shall be started until such permit has been obtained. 
(b)  No permit shall be issued under the authority of this code for the installation of any festoons or decorative street lighting equipment other than such as conform to the standards and specifications for outside wiring prescribed in this code. 
(c)  Permits for the maintenance of festoons or decorative street lighting equipment may be revoked at any time. 
(Ord. No. 8-1976, § 2(2.62), 3-9-76; Ord. No. 22-1992, § 2, 10-27-92) 
Sec. 9-64. - Same-Removal due to interference. 
    The fire department shall remove or cause to be removed any festoon or decorative street lighting equipment for interference with the proper installation or operation of any equipment for any purpose whatsoever that the municipality has or may install or maintain on or over any public way. 
(Ord. No. 8-1976, § 2(2.63), 3-9-76; Ord. No. 22-1992, § 2, 10-27-92) 
Sec. 9-65. - Same-Removal due to abandonment. 
    Any festoon or decorative street lighting equipment not maintained in strict conformity with all the electrical regulations of this code shall be declared to be abandoned or a hazard over the public way, and the fire department is hereby empowered to remove or cause to be removed any such abandoned hazardous festoon or decorative street lighting equipment. 
(Ord. No. 8-1976, § 2(2.64), 3-9-76; Ord. No. 22-1992, § 2, 10-27-92) 
Sec. 9-66. - Same-Bond required. 
    No permit shall be issued to install, alter, repair or maintain any festoon or decorative lighting equipment until the person making an application for such permit shall have filed with the director of public works an indemnifying bond with good and sufficient sureties approved by the said director equal to the sum of five hundred dollars ($500.00) for each electric festoon or branch circuit for decorative lighting equipment installed or maintained. The aforesaid bond shall guarantee the installation and maintenance of any and all festoons or decorative lighting equipment specified in the application for a permit in accordance with the provisions, standards and specifications of the electrical regulations of this chapter applicable thereto. The aforesaid bond shall further guarantee the removal from the public way in a manner satisfactory to the director of public works of any and all abandoned festoons or decorative street lighting equipment specified in any permit within a period of thirty (30) days after having received notice thereof. In the event of the failure of any person to comply with any of the electrical regulations of this chapter applicable thereto, the director of public works shall notify the guarantors and should any violation continue for a period of more than thirty (30) days, he shall declare the bond applying to the festoon or decorative lighting equipment in violation forfeited and the director of public works is hereby authorized to collect the full amount of such bond. 
(Ord. No. 8-1976, § 2 (2.65), 3-9-76) 
Sec. 9-67. - Same-Inspection. 
    All electric festoons or decorative lighting equipment installed on public property shall be inspected by the fire chief or his designated representative after installation. 
(Ord. No. 8-1976, § 2(2.66), 3-9-76; Ord. No. 22-1992, § 2, 10-27-92) 
Sec. 9-68. - Same-Attachment of equipment to municipal poles prohibited without written permission. 
    No electrical equipment used as a part of any festoon or decorative street lighting equipment shall be attached to any municipal poles unless permission in writing has been obtained from the director of public works. 
(Ord. No. 8-1976, § 2 (2.67), 3-9-76) 
Sec. 9-69. - Work performed on, over or under public way-Permit required. 
    No person shall erect, construct, maintain, use, alter or repair any pole, line or wire, underground conductors or electric conductors of any description whatever on, over or under any public way or public place, without first having obtained a permit therefor from the director of public works. 
(Ord. No. 8-1976, § 2 (2.68), 3-9-76) 
Sec. 9-70. - Same-Application for permit. 
(a)  Applications for permits shall be made in duplicate on a form to be approved by the building department. 
(b)  Applications shall be submitted to the director of public works who shall cause the necessary inspection to be made. 
(c)  All applications for permits to erect poles in the streets and alleys shall provide that the municipality may use the poles to be so erected and may attach thereto such necessary cross arms, wires or other electrical appliances as may be deemed necessary for the electrical service of the municipality, and no permit shall be issued by the director of public works for the erection of such poles in which the application and permit does not provide for the privileges required as herein contained. 
(Ord. No. 8-1976, § 2 (2.69), 3-9-76) 
Sec. 9-71. - Same-Inspection of all apparatus. 
    All apparatus installed under authority of a permit issued in accordance with section 9-70 dealing with poles, wires and conductors shall be inspected by the building department. The fee for such inspection shall be in conformity with sections 9-76 through 9-85. Said fees shall be paid before any such permit is issued. 
(Ord. No. 8-1976, § 2 (2.70), 3-9-76) 
Sec. 9-72. - Same-Subject to removal. 
    No permission or authority shall be given to any person to erect any pole or poles for telegraph, telephone or electric light or power purposes or for the purpose of stringing thereon wires, cables or conveyors for the transmission of sounds or signals, or of heat, light or power, upon or along any public way, except upon the express provision that such poles and conductors are to be and will be removed forthwith whenever the board of trustees shall order such removal; provided however, that nothing in sections 9-70 and 9-71 concerning poles, wires and conductors shall apply to any pole or poles used solely for the carrying and support of its overhead contact trolley wires by any street railway company where it is claimed by such company that it is operating its cars under the authority of any ordinance of the municipality. 
(Ord. No. 8-1976, § 2 (2.71), 3-9-76) 
Sec. 9-73. - Same-Specifications. 
    Such wires or conductors shall in no case be placed at a greater distance from the curbstone separating sidewalk from carriageway than four (4) feet, except in crossing streets running transversely to the direction of said lines when such crossing shall be made in the shortest straight line, or in making necessary connections with buildings and stations. 
(Ord. No. 8-1976, § 2 (2.72), 3-9-76) 
Sec. 9-74. - Same-Method of laying conductors. 
    The method employed of laying said conductors shall be such that it will at no time be necessary to remove so much of the pavement, or to make such excavation, as to materially impede traffic or passage upon sidewalk or street during the operation of laying or repairing said conductors, except when crossing streets transversely, where authority may be granted to remove the pavement for a width not exceeding two (2) feet in the nearest straight line from corner to corner. In no case during the general hours of passage and traffic shall passage be interrupted thereby for a period longer than one hour. 
(Ord. No. 8-1976, § 2 (2.73), 3-9-76) 
Sec. 9-75. - Same-Subject to control of director of public works. 
    The work of removal and replacement of the pavements in any and all of the public ways and public places in and through which the wires of any company shall be laid, shall be subject to the control and supervision of the director of public works; excavations in any and all of the unpaved public ways or public places shall also be subject to like control and supervision. The space selected for placing said wires, the same in every case being limited as to direction and general position by the foregoing provisions, shall be of sufficient size to permit the installation of the necessary conductors and equipment. 
(Ord. No. 8-1976, § 2 (2.74), 3-9-76) 
Sec. 9-76. - Circuits-Defined. 
    The term circuit as used in section 9-77 shall mean any set of branch lighting conductors which have been extended from a distribution center, and which may be utilized for the transmission of electrical energy. 
(Ord. No. 8-1976, § 2 (2.75), 3-9-76)

(a)  Electric signs shall be charged at a rate of twenty-five cents ($0.25) per square foot of area of each face. The area of skeleton letters shall be computed as that area within the perimeter design of the letters. No fee shall be less than ten dollars ($10.00). 
(b)  Permits issued for the re-erection or alteration of any electric sign, illumination of signboards or illumination of flat or wall signs shall be ten dollars ($10.00). The fees for permits issued for illuminated signs to be erected for a period not to exceed thirty (30) days shall be one-quarter (1/4) the sign fee. No fee shall be less than ten dollars ($10.00). The fee for cancellation of any permit shall be ten dollars ($10.00) and shall be deducted before the remaining amount is refunded.

Sec. 9-99. - Rehabilitation. 
    Buildings existing prior to March 26, 1991, in which there is work involving electrical repairs, alterations, additions or changes of use, shall be made to conform to the provisions of this code. 
(Ord. No. 3-1991, § 4, 3-26-91)
