Sec. 9-100. - Penalty for violations. 
    Any person who shall violate a provision of this article or shall fail to comply with any of the requirements thereof, or who shall perform any electrical work in violation of an approved plan or directive of the fire chief or his designated representative, or of a permit or certificate issued under the provisions of this article, shall be guilty of an offense against the village, punishable by a fine of not less than fifty dollars ($50.00), nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00). Each day that a violation continues shall be deemed a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 8-1976, § 2(2.100), 3-9-76; Ord. No. 24-1985, § 4, 11-12-85; Ord. No. 3-1991, § 5, 3-26-91; Ord. No. 22-1992, § 2, 10-27-92) 
Secs. 9-101-9-110. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - EMERGENCY ENERGY PLAN 

Sec. 9-111. - Definitions. 
    As used in this article, unless the context otherwise requires: 
(a)  Control area means an electrical system bounded by interconnection (tie-line) metering and telemetry. It controls generation directly to maintain its interchange schedule with other control areas and contributes to frequency regulation of the interconnection. 
(b)  Control area emergency means that control area is at risk of having to shed firm load, having taken or committed to take all feasible mitigating action short of shedding firm load and firm sales. 
(c)  Controlled rotating interruptions of electrical service means the implementation of a plan to curtail electric service to firm load customers for a short period of time and rotating this curtailment of electric service through different areas within the electric utility's service territory in a situation where the demand has exceeded or is at significant risk of exceeding the supply of electricity available to the electric utility. The action of an electric utility to interrupt or curtail electric service to a customer participating in or taking service under an interruptible or curtailable rate is not included in this definition of a controlled rotating interruption of electric service. 
(d)  Emergency energy plan means the portions of the emergency load conservation procedures, which immediately precede and include the controlled rotating interruption of electrical service to firm load customers within the village. The emergency energy plan shall include the following steps: 
(1)  A request for emergency help from neighboring utilities; 
(2)  A declaration of a control area emergency; 
(3)  A public appeal for voluntary curtailment of electricity use; and 
(4)  Implementation of the plan for controlled rotating interruptions of electrical service. 
(e)  Emergency load conservation procedures means a planned course of action developed by an electric utility company to be implemented in emergency situations when the demand for electricity exceeds, or is at significant risk of exceeding the supply of electricity available to the electric utility. 
(f)  Electric utility company or electric utility means any person or entity engaged in the business of distributing, transmitting, or otherwise delivering electricity regardless of its source, for use or consumption within the village. This term shall not include any person or entity that delivers electricity to fewer than fifty (50) customers within the village. 
(Ord. No. 15-1999, § 2, 8-24-99) 
Sec. 9-112. - Submittal of emergency energy plan. 
(a)  Every electric utility company must have adopted an emergency energy plan no later than thirty (30) days after the effective date of this chapter, or within thirty (30) days after becoming an electric utility company, whichever is later. Every such electric utility company shall submit to the Village of Hazel Crest an emergency energy plan adopted by the company no later than thirty (30) days after the effective date of this article, or within twenty-four (24) hours of the time the plan is adopted, whichever is later. The electric utility company shall be required to examine and update as needed its emergency energy plan at least annually. The electric utility company shall notify the foregoing public official(s) in writing of any material revisions to its plan and the rationale for said revisions within five (5) business days of the time said revisions are made. 
(b)  The emergency energy plan shall include, at a minimum, information detailing: 
(1)  Circumstances that would require the implementation of the emergency energy plan; 
(2)  Stages of the emergency energy plan; 
(3)  The approximate geographic limits of each outage area provided for in the emergency energy plan; 
(4)  The approximate number of customers within each outage area provided for in the emergency energy plan; 
(5)  The police facilities, fire stations, hospitals, nursing homes, schools, day care centers, senior citizen centers, community health centers, dialysis centers, community mental health centers, correctional facilities, stormwater and wastewater treatment or pumping facilities, and water-pumping stations that have been identified by the village and persons on life-support systems that are known to the company, and that could be affected by controlled rotating interruptions of electric service under the emergency energy plan; and 
(6)  The anticipated sequence and duration of intentional interruptions of electric service to each outage area under the emergency energy plan. 
(Ord. No. 15-1999, § 2, 8-24-99) 
Sec. 9-113. - Review of plan. 
(a)  Upon submittal of the emergency energy plan to the village, the village shall review the emergency energy plan in order to determine if the emergency energy plan is complete and to assure appropriate coordination with public health and safety agencies. The village may reject the emergency energy plan if it does not contain all the information required under section 9-112(b) in which case the village shall notify the electric utility company in writing of said rejection and the reasons therefor. The electric utility company shall thereafter submit a complete emergency energy plan to the village no later than thirty (30) days after such notices are sent by the village. 
(b)  The village and the electric utility shall work cooperatively to: 
(1)  Identify customers and facilities for which a controlled rotating interruption of electric service would require heightened response by village public health and safety agencies; 
(2)  Mitigate the potential impact of the plan on public health and safety; and 
(3)  Mitigate the potential impact of the plan on the duties of the village's public health and safety agencies. 
(Ord. No. 15-1999, § 2, 8-24-99) 
Sec. 9-114. - Implementation of emergency energy plan. 
(a)  Whenever an electric utility company determines that it may be necessary to implement a controlled rotating interruption of electrical service due to the demand for electricity exceeding, or being at significant risk of exceeding, the supply of electricity available to the electric utility company, the electric utility company shall do the following: 
(1)  Take appropriate action in preparation for implementing a controlled rotating interruption of electric service and notifying the appropriate electric utility company personnel; and 
(2)  Notify the Village of Hazel Crest that the electric utility company will be implementing its emergency energy plan. The notification shall be made pursuant to a notification procedure approved by the village after consultation with the village president and board of trustees. The village may waive the notice requirement to accommodate exigent circumstances. 
(b)  Reserved. 
(c)  Subsequent to providing the notice as required above, an electric utility company shall reasonably and separately advise the designated village officials when it implements each step of the emergency energy plan. Such steps shall include the following: 
(1)  A request for emergency help from neighboring utilities; 
(2)  A declaration of a control area emergency; 
(3)  A public appeal for voluntary curtailment of electricity use. 
(d)  The electric utility company shall give a separate notice to the village, immediately upon the determination that there will be a controlled rotating interruption of electric service pursuant to the emergency energy plan. The notification shall include the areas to be interrupted; the sequence and estimated duration of the service outage for each area; and the affected feeders and number of affected customers in each area. Whenever practical, the notification shall be made at least two (2) hours prior to the time of the outages, and in no case shall the notification be made less than (30) minutes prior to the outages, if the company is aware that controlled rotating interruptions may be required. 
(e)  Notification required by this section shall be in addition to any notification requirements set forth in any applicable franchise agreement or franchise ordinance, or as may be required by applicable federal or state law or regulation. 
(Ord. No. 15-1999, § 2, 8-24-99) 
Sec. 9-115. - Violations; enforcement. 
    Any electric utility company that knowingly violates this article or any rules promulgated thereunder shall be subject to a fine of not less than two thousand five hundred dollars ($2,500.00) and not more than ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00) for each offense. Each day that a violation continues shall constitute a separate and distinct offense. 
    The village may apply to any court of competent jurisdiction for an injunction or order to compel the other party to comply with the provisions of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 15-1999, § 2, 8-24-99) 
Sec. 9-116. - Construction. 
    Nothing in this article shall be construed to preclude or interfere with the implementation by an electric utility company of measures necessary to assure the provision of adequate, efficient, reliable and environmentally safe service, as required by the Illinois Public Utilities Act (220 ILCS 5/1-101 et seq.). Nothing set forth in this article shall be deemed to modify the terms of any existing franchise agreement or franchise ordinance otherwise applicable to any electric utility company, or to excuse any performance required by such agreement or ordinance or to limit any authority that may be exercised pursuant to such agreement or ordinance, or to limit any remedy that may be available under such agreement or ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 15-1999, § 2, 8-24-99) 
Sec. 9-117. - Severability. 
    Should any section, paragraph, sentence, clause, phrase or word of this article be declared invalid or unconstitutional by a court or agency of competent jurisdiction, such invalidity or unconstitutionality shall not affect any of the remaining words, phrases, clauses, sentences, paragraphs or sections of the article, since the same would have been enacted by the board of trustees without the incorporation of this article of any such invalid or unconstitutional word, phase, clause, sentence, paragraph, or section. 
(Ord. No. 15-1999, § 2, 8-24-99) 
Chapter 10 - FIRE PREVENTION AND PROTECTION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- The words, "fire department" have been changed to "fire, rescue and inspectional services department" throughout this chapter to reflect the current name of this village department. 
Cross reference- Buildings and building regulations, Ch. 6; electrical regulations, Ch. 9; floodplain management, Ch. 11; housing, Ch. 14; plumbing, Ch. 23; subdivision regulations, App. A. 
State Law reference- Authority of village to provide fire protection, 65 ILCS 5/11-6-1 et seq.; incorporation of technical codes by reference, 65 ILCS 5/1-3-1. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 10-1. - Driving vehicles over fire hose. 
    No wagon, railroad car or other vehicle shall be driven over any unprotected hose of the fire, rescue and inspectional services department of the village when laid down on any street or alley by order of the chief of the fire, rescue and inspectional services department or other proper officer, without the consent of the chief of the fire, rescue and inspectional services department or officers or members in charge of such hose. 
(Code 1956, § 10.12) 
Cross reference- Operation of vehicles generally, Ch. 19, Art. II. 
Sec. 10-2. - Tampering with signal boxes; false alarms. 
    No person, except those connected with the management of the fire, rescue and inspectional services department, shall open any signal box unless it is to communicate an alarm of fire; nor shall any person break, cut, deface, derange or in any manner meddle or interfere with any signal box, or fire alarm, telegraph or telephone wires; nor shall any person knowingly communicate any false information to the fire, rescue and inspectional services department regarding the existence of a fire. 
(Code 1956, § 10.13) 
Sec. 10-3. - Reimbursement to village for expense incurred in emergency response due to hazardous substance and material incident. 
(a)  Definitions: 
(1)  Costs: All expenses incurred by the Hazel Crest Dept. of Fire, Rescue, and Inspectional Services or any other public agency assisting the Hazel Crest Dept. of Fire, Rescue, and Inspectional Services as a result of any removal or remedial action, whether assumed by the village directly, by way of intergovernmental agreement, or by way of contracted services. 
(2)  Facility: Any building, structure, installation, equipment pipe or pipeline including but not limited to any pipe into a sewer or publicly owned treatment works, well, pond, lagoon, impoundment, ditch, landfill, storage container, tank, motor vehicle, truck trailer, rolling stock, or aircraft. Also, any site or area where a hazardous material has been deposited, stored, disposed of, or otherwise managed. 
(3)  Hazardous materials or substances: Any material, substance, or mixture of materials or substances which are toxic, flammable, corrosive, explosive, carcinogenic, or radioactive including but not limited to any substance or material which is designated as a hazardous material pursuant to the "Hazardous Materials Transportation Act" (49 U.S.C.A., sections 1801, et seq.) in a quantity and form which may pose a substantial present or potential hazard to human health, property, or the environment when improperly released, treated, stored, transported, disposed of, or otherwise managed. 
(4)  Emergency response agency: A unit of local government or volunteer fire protection organization that provide: 
a.  Fire fighting services. 
b.  Emergency rescue services. 
c.  Emergency medical services. 
d.  Hazardous materials response teams. 
e.  Emergency service and disaster agency/civil defense. 
f.  Public works departments and/or maintenance departments. 
(5)  Mutual aid: Any action taken by the Hazel Crest Dept. of Fire, Rescue, and Inspectional Services or any public agency pursuant to an intergovernmental agreement, including but not limited to any agreement that is part of the mutual aid box alarm system ("MABAS"). 
(6)  Responsible party: Any persons, company, firm, corporation, business, partnership, an unincorporated association, association, estate, trust, joint venture, or legal entity, or their legal representative, agent, or assign. Also any unit of federal, state, or local government. 
(7)  Release: Any spilling, leaking, pumping, puring, emitting, escaping, discharging, injecting, leaching, dumping, or disposing of a hazardous material into or on any land, air, water, well, stream, sewer or pipe so that such hazardous material or any constituent thereof may enter the environment. 
(8)  Remedial action: Any action consistent with permanent remedy taken instead of or in addition to removal actions in the event of a release or threatened release of a hazardous material into the environment, to prevent or minimize the release of a hazardous material so that they do not migrate to cause a substantial present or potential hazard to human health, property, or the environment. The term includes but is not limited to, such actions at the location of release as storage, confinement, perimeter protection, using dikes, trenches, or ditches, clay cover, neutralization, clean-up of released hazardous materials or contaminated materials, recycling or reuse, diversion, destruction, segregation, or reactive wastes, repair or replacement of leaking containers, collection of leachate and runoff, on-site treatment or incineration, provision of alternate waste supplies, and any monitoring reasonably required to assure that such actions protect the public health and welfare and the environment. 
(9)  Removal: The clean-up or removal of released hazardous materials from the environment; such actions as may be necessary or appropriate to monitor, assess, and evaluate the release or threat of release of hazardous materials, the disposal of removed material, or the taking of such action as may be necessary to prevent, minimize, or mitigate damage to the public health or welfare of the environment. 
(10)  Response: Any removal or remedial action. 
(b)  Prohibited acts: No person shall cause, threaten or allow the release of hazardous materials into the environment unless such release is in accordance with an appropriate permit granted by the Illinois Environmental Protection Agency or other state of federal agency having primary jurisdiction over the release and such release is in such place and manner as will not create a substantial present or potential hazard to human health, property, or the environment. 
(c)  Response authority: 
(1)  The fire chief or designee shall have authority to respond to any release or threatened release of hazardous materials within the village or affecting the public water supply, wells, or sewage treatment works located within the village or pursuant to any lawful intergovernmental agreement of which the Hazel Crest Dept. of Fire, Rescue, and Inspectional Services is a party. This authority includes, but is not limited to, remedial action and removal. 
(2)  The fire chief or designee shall have primary authority to respond to any release or threatened release of hazardous materials as described above. The fire chief or designee shall ensure the reporting of any release or threatened release of hazardous materials to appropriate federal, state, and local public health, safety, and emergency agencies within twenty-four (24) hours of any substantial release of hazardous materials. The fire chief shall relinquish response authority at such time, if any, as the federal, state, or local public health, safety or emergency agency having primary jurisdiction over the release or threatened release has assumed responsibility for response to the release or threatened release. 
(3)  The fire chief or designee shall be authorized to utilize all department personnel and equipment and has sole discretion to take such remedial or removal action as may be deemed necessary or appropriate to respond to the release of hazardous material. 
(4)  All responding personnel shall cooperate with and operate under the direction of the fire chief or other person then exercising response authority under this section until such time as the person exercising such response authority has determined that the response is complete or responsibility for response is assumed by the federal, state, or local public health, safety, or emergency agency having primary jurisdiction over the release or threatened release. 
(5)  The person exercising response authority under this ordinance shall coordinate and/or cooperate with other federal, state, or local public health, safety, or emergency response agencies involved in response to the release or threatened release of hazardous materials. 
(d)  Liability for costs: 
(1)  Notwithstanding any other provision or rule of law, and subject only to the defenses set forth in subsection 10-3(e) hereof, the following persons shall be jointly and severally liable for all costs of removal and remedial action incurred by the village, including but not limited to the village's fire department, police department, and public works department, as a result of a release or threatened release of a hazardous material: 
a.  The owner or operator of a facility or vessel from which there was a release or substantial threat of release of a hazardous material. 
b.  Any person who, at the time of disposal, transport, storage or treatment of a hazardous material, owned or operated the facility or vessel used for such disposal, transport, treatment, or storage from which there was a release or substantial threat of a release of any such hazardous material. 
c.  Any person who by contract, agreement, or otherwise has arranged with another party or entity for transport, storage, disposal, or treatment of hazardous materials owned, controlled, or possessed by such person at a facility owned or operated by another party or entity from which facility there is a release or substantial threat of a release of such hazardous materials. 
d.  Any person who accepts or accepted any hazardous materials for transport to disposal, storage, or treatment facilities from which there is a release or substantial threat of a release of hazardous substances. 
(e)  Defenses: There will be no liability under subsection 10-3(d) thereof for a person otherwise liable who can establish by a preponderance of the evidence that the release or substantial threat of release of a hazardous material and the damages resulting therefrom occurred in accordance with any of the permitted defenses enumerated in 415 ILCS 5/22-2. 
(f)  Penalty for violations: 
(1)  Any person who is liable for the release or threatened release of a hazardous material who fails without sufficient cause to pay for or provide removal or remedial action upon or in accordance with a notice and request of the Hazel Crest Dept. of Fire, Rescue, and Inspectional Services, or in accordance with any order of any court having jurisdiction of the matter, shall be liable to the village for any costs incurred by the department of fire, rescue, and inspectional services as a result of such failure to provide or take such removal or remedial action, together with the cost of any removal or remedial action taken by the department of fire, rescue, and inspection services in accordance with this section, and all attorneys' fees and related legal costs incurred in connection therewith. 
(2)  In addition, any such person shall be guilty of a violation of this section and shall be fined not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) nor more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for each offense. A separate offense shall be deemed committed for each day on which a violation occurs or continues. 
(3)  Charges for removal or remedial action when rendered by the department of fire, rescue, and inspectional services or any other responding agency rendering mutual aid or assistance to the department of fire, rescue, and inspectional services shall include but not be limited to: 
a.  The reasonable cost of each vehicle responding as determined by the responding agency; and 
b.  The cost of all personnel including any overtime costs to the Village of Hazel Crest or to any responding agency, incurred as a result of the removal or remedial action; and 
c.  The cost of all materials and equipment used, expended, depleted, destroyed or removed from service in accordance with federal, state, or local ordinance as a result of the mitigation or containment operations if or at the request of the department of fire, rescue, and inspectional services or any responding agency. 
(Ord. No. 46-1997, § 1, 12-23-97) 
Sec. 10-4. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 9-1995, § 1, adopted Feb. 28, 1995, repealed former section 10-4 in its entirety which pertained to the applicability of the fire prevention code to flammable liquids and derived from Ord. Note- See editor's note at Ch. 10. 
Sec. 10-9. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 22-1992, § 2, adopted Oct. 27, 1992, repealed former § 10-9 which pertained to the position of fire inspector and derived from Ord. No. 28-1974, §§ 1-3, adopted Oct. 8, 1974. 
Sec. 10-10. - Ambulance service fees. 
(a)  Definitions. 
(1)  Advanced life support. Advanced life support shall be defined as use of advanced paramedic equipment for life threatening injuries and/or sickness including heart monitoring equipment and the administering of intravenous fluid and medications. This also includes the prescribed medications carried by the paramedical team for symptomatic injuries and/or illnesses and the use of telemetry for the notification of the resource hospital or the use of specific airway maintenance materials and the application of antishock devices. 
(2)  Basic life support. Basic life support shall be defined as any call which is not advanced life support. These include response for first aid and transport for victims who are sick and/or injured. 
(3)  Resident. An individual whose principal residence is within the corporate limits of the Village of Hazel Crest. 
(4)  Nonresident. An individual whose principal residence is not within the corporate limits of the Village of Hazel Crest. 
(b)  Amount of fees. 
(1)  The fee for a resident for basic life support services shall be three hundred forty-two dollars and seventy-three cents ($342.73). Such fee shall be charged only when ambulance service includes transportation to a hospital, clinic or other health care facility for purposes of medical treatment. 
(2)  The fee for a resident for advanced life support 1 services shall be four hundred six dollars and ninety-nine cents ($406.99) and for advanced life support 2 services it shall be five hundred eighty-nine dollars and seven cents ($589.07). Such fee shall be charged only when ambulance service includes transportation to a hospital, clinic or other health care facility for purposes of medical treatment. 
The village will accept medicare assignment and direct insurance payments with no additional cost to be born by a resident. 
(3)  The fee for a nonresident for basic life support services shall be five hundred dollars ($500.00). Such fee shall be charged only when ambulance service includes transportation to a hospital, clinic or other health care facility for purposes of medical treatment. 
(4)  The fee for a nonresident for advanced life support services 1 and 2 shall be seven hundred dollars ($700.00). Such fee shall be charged only when ambulance service includes transportation to a hospital, clinic or other health care facility for purposes of medical treatment. 
(5)  The fee for resident and nonresident nontransport services shall be twenty-five dollars ($25.00). This fee will be charged when services are requested, but no transportation occurred at the patient's request. 
(c)  Payment of fees. Said fees shall be paid to the Village of Hazel Crest by the individual receiving such ambulance service within thirty (30) days after such service is provided except that when such service is provided to a minor, such fees shall be paid by parent or legal guardian. 
(Ord. No. 40-1979, § 1, 9-25-79; Ord. No. 16-1980, § 1, 7-22-80; Ord. No. 9-1984, § 1, 4-10-84; Ord. No. 9-1986, § 1, 4-22-86; Ord. No. 14-1989, § 1, 4-27-89; Ord. No. 4-1993, § 1, 4-27-93; Ord. No. 5-2008, 2-26-08) 
Cross reference- Ambulances, mobile intensive care units, ambulance services and mobile intensive care unit services, § 17-65 et seq. 
State Law reference- Authority to operate municipal ambulance service, 65 ILCS 5/11-5-7. 
Secs. 10-11-10-19. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - FIRE, RESCUE AND INSPECTIONAL SERVICES DEPARTMENT[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- See the editor's note at the beginning of this chapter. 
Cross reference- Administration generally, Ch. 2. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 10-20. - Established. 
(a)  There is hereby established a department of the village government which shall be known as the fire, rescue and inspectional services department, and which shall consist of a chief of fire, rescue and inspectional services, and as many officers, firefighter/paramedics, firefighters, inspectors, and clerical staff as may be deemed necessary to perform the requirements set forth by the village board. 
(b)  The fire, rescue and inspectional services department shall be responsible for providing fire suppression, emergency medical services, inspectional services, code enforcement, fire prevention, public education and training within the village. 
(c)  No individual shall be eligible for full-time employment as a full-time firefighter/paramedic unless he or she is a fully certified firefighter/paramedic (EMT) in accordance with applicable Illinois certification standards as of the date of that individual's hire. 
(Code 1956, § 10.01; Ord. No. 9-1995, § 1, 2-28-95; Ord. No. 19-2006, § 1, 6-13-06) 
Sec. 10-21. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 22-1992, § 2, adopted Oct. 27, 1992, repealed former § 10-21 in its entirety. Former § 10-21 pertained to the division of fire protection and public education and derived from Ord. No. 7-1979, § 2, 2-22-79; Ord. No. 21-1981, § 2, 9-22-81; Ord. No. 23-1985, § 2, 11-12-85. 
Sec. 10-22. - Foreign fire insurance companies. 
(a)  Compliance required. No corporation, company or association not incorporated under the law of the State of Illinois, shall engage in effecting fire insurance, or transact any business of fire insurance, in the village, which corporation, company or association has failed to comply with any of the provisions of this section, without fully complying with such provisions. 
(b)  Payments to village. 
(1)  Any fire insurance corporation, company or association, not incorporated under the law of the State of Illinois, which is engaged in the village in effecting fire insurance, shall pay the village treasurer, for the maintenance, use and benefit of the village fire rescue and inspectional services department, a sum equal to two percent of the gross receipts received as premiums upon fire insurance policies by any and all agents of such corporation, company or association, during the year ending July 1 in each year, for any insurance effected or agreed to be effected, on property located within the village by or with any such corporation, company or association during the year. 
(2)  Time of payment: All payments required by this section shall be made on or before the fifteenth day of July following the termination of the year for which such payments are due. Said payments shall be paid to the village treasurer at the same time the annual report, required pursuant to subsection 10-22(c) below, is rendered to the village clerk. 
(3)  The sum of money for which a foreign fire insurance corporation, company or association is chargeable may be recovered from it or its agent by an action for money had and received in the name of and for the use of the village. 
(c)  Annual report to village. 
(1)  Each person acting in the village as an agent or otherwise for or on behalf of any such corporation, company or association required under subsection 10-22(b) to make payments to the village, shall, on or before the fifteenth day of July of each year, render to the village clerk a full, true and just account, verified by his or her oath, of all premiums which, during the year ending July 1 preceding said report, have been received by him or her, or by another person acting on the behalf of such corporation, company or association on such fire insurance policies for property located within the village. 
(2)  Such agent, corporation, company or association shall have available original books of entry, records, papers or other documents adequate for verification of the correctness of such report of the amount received for fire insurance, which shall be open for examination by the village treasurer or his/her designated representative during office hours. 
(d)  Placement of insurance restricted. 
(1)  No insurance shall be placed with any corporation, company or association not incorporated under the laws of the State of Illinois which are in default for not reporting or making payment as required by this section as of the fifteenth day of July, until such corporation, company or association shall have complied with the reporting requirements set forth herein and the sum due under this section has been fully paid. 
(2)  Nothing in this section shall relieve any corporation, company or association from the payment of any loss upon any risk that may be taken in violation of this requirement. 
(Code 1956, § 10.03; Ord. No. 9-1995, § 1, 2-28-95; Ord. No. 21-2002, § 2, 6-11-02) 
Sec. 10-23. - Foreign fire insurance board. 
(a)  Establishment. There is hereby established, by and for the Village of Hazel Crest, a foreign fire insurance board comprised of officers elected as set forth below, whose purpose is to establish rules and regulations with respect to the management of funds received by the village as foreign fire insurance tax receipts. 
(b)  Definitions. As used in this section, the following terms shall be given the meanings herein ascribed to them. 
(1)  Board means the foreign fire insurance board created by this section. 
(2)  Department means the Village of Hazel Crest Fire Rescue and Inspectional Services Department. 
(3)  Fund means the foreign fire insurance tax fund, pursuant to Section 5/11-10-1 of the Illinois Municipal Code, 65 ILCS 5/11-10-1, and sec. 10-22 of the village's Municipal Code. 
(4)  Members of the department mean all fire-fighters employed by the Village of Hazel Crest, whether full-time or part-time. All members of the Hazel Crest Fire Rescue and Inspectional Services Department shall be eligible to be elected as officers of the Board except those members who have not completed the applicable probationary period or who are not in good standing in accordance with the rules and regulations of the department. 
(5)  Temporary election committee means the Temporary Hazel Crest Fire Rescue and Inspectional Services Election Committee. 
(c)  Membership; compensation. The board shall consist of the chief of fire rescue and inspectional services, at the discretion of the chief, one (1) commanding officer appointed by the chief, and three (3) officers elected by the members of the department. The fire chief and the appointed commanding officer shall be ex officio voting members of the board. The chief shall attend all meetings, or may send a designee in his/her place if unable to attend a board meeting. All elected members of the board shall be members of the hazel crest fire rescue and inspectional services department at the time of their election and during their entire terms of office. No more than two (2) members may be full-time firefighters and no more than two (2) members may be part-time firefighters. All members of the board shall serve without compensation. 
(d)  Organization; terms of office; vacancies. 
(1)  The first election of officers shall take place within sixty (60) days of the passage of this section, and the officers then elected shall serve until June 30, 2004. The initial term of office of the three (3) elected members shall begin ten (10) days after the completion of the election, to be conducted by the temporary election committee. elections thereafter shall take place during the month of June of every even-numbered year. 
(2)  The terms of office for each elected officer shall be from July 1 of an even-numbered year to June 30 of the next even-numbered year, or until such time as a successor has been elected and qualified. 
(3)  Any member who resigns, retires or is discharged from the Hazel Crest Fire Rescue and Inspectional Services department, or who leaves active duty for any reason, shall automatically be removed from the board and his/her position shall be deemed vacant. 
(4)  Vacancies on the board shall be filled for the balance of the unexpired term by the remaining officers of the board. The remaining officers shall appoint a member of the Hazel Crest Fire Rescue and Inspectional Services department to fill the office until the expiration of the term and the election and qualification of a successor. 
(5)  No officer shall serve for more than two (2) consecutive terms. 
(e)  Temporary election committee. 
(1)  There is hereby established a temporary election committee, to be known as the Temporary Hazel Crest Fire Rescue and Inspectional Services Election Committee. The temporary election committee shall consist of three (3) members. The fire chief shall serve, ex-officio, as chairperson of the committee. The chief shall appoint two (2) members of the Hazel Crest Fire Rescue and Inspectional Services department, one (1) full-time firefighter and one (1) part-time firefighter to serve on the committee, one of whom shall be from the classified ranks. 
(2)  The temporary election committee shall be responsible for organizing, conducting and supervising the initial election of department members to serve on the foreign fire insurance board. The temporary election committee shall establish procedures consistent with this section. 
(3)  Notice of the initial election and the nomination procedures shall be posted throughout the department not less than thirty (30) days before the election. Notice of the initial election procedures shall be posted throughout the department not less than fifteen (15) days before the election. Thereafter, the elected board shall establish its own election procedures consistent with this section. 
(4)  Any eligible person who desires to run for the board shall submit a written letter to the temporary election committee advising the committee that he/she wishes to be placed on the ballot as a candidate for board member. 
(5)  In the initial election and all elections held thereafter, each eligible member may vote for three (3) individuals on the ballot. The winners of the election in the initial election and all subsequent elections shall be determined as follows: 
a.  The two (2) candidates with the most votes shall be declared winners and take their seats on the board. 
b.  The third elected board member must meet the following: If the two (2) candidates with the most votes are full-time members, the third elected board member shall be the part-time member receiving the most votes. If the two (2) candidates with the most votes are part-time members, the third elected board member shall be the full-time member receiving the most votes. If the two (2) candidates with the most votes are one full-time member and one (1) part-time member, the third elected board member shall be the candidate who comes in third in the amount of votes recorded. If there is a tie, the third member shall be determined by lottery. 
(f)  Elections. The board shall adopt rules and regulations establishing procedures for the nomination and election of department members to serve on the board. All rules and regulations with respect to the election process shall be consistent with the procedures set forth in this section and shall be adopted and posted throughout the department not less than thirty (30) days prior to the date of the election. 
All elections, subsequent to the initial election, shall be organized, conducted and supervised by the village manager or his/her designee, and consistent with the rules and regulations of the board and the provisions of this section. Notice of the election shall be posted throughout the department at least twenty-one (21) days prior to the date of the election. Eligible members wishing to be placed on the ballot must notify the village manager of that fact in writing at least seven (7) days prior to the election. The written notice must identify the member by name and his/her category, either full-time or part-time member of the fire rescue and inspectional services department. no member may appear on the ballot under more than one (1) category. Only eligible members who have submitted written notices shall be placed on the ballot. 
(g)  Officers-Powers and duties. At the first meeting of a newly elected board, the members of the board shall elect from among their members, a president, a secretary and treasurer, who shall have the following powers and duties. No member may hold more than one (1) position on the board at any one time. 
(1)  President. The president shall preside over all meetings of the board. The president shall have such other powers as he/she may be given from time to time by action of the village president and the board of trustees, consistent with state statute and village ordinances. 
(2)  Secretary. The secretary shall keep an accurate record of all resolutions, proceedings, minutes and actions of the board and shall attest all official documents with his/her signature. The secretary shall keep these minutes in a manner identical to the manner in which the village board minutes are kept and shall present all minutes for review and approval by the board. The secretary shall have custody of all documents, records, books and papers belonging to the board, except as provided by statute or ordinance. The secretary shall also perform such other duties and functions as are assigned from time to time by the president of the board, the village president and the board of trustees. 
(3)  Treasurer. The treasurer shall: 
a.  Have charge of the receipt, custody and disbursement of all funds received by the village from the foreign fire insurance tax, as described in section 10-22 of this article, and deposited in a special fund called the foreign fire insurance tax fund ("fund"); 
b.  Deposit all monies in the fund in the name of the Village of Hazel Crest Fire Rescue and Inspectional Department in such banks, savings and loan associations or other federally insured depositories as shall be approved by the village president and the board of trustees; 
c.  Invest said funds not immediately required in such securities as the village treasurer shall specifically or generally select from time to time, provided, however, that all investments shall be made only in accordance with the village's current investment policy and in only those securities which may be purchased under Illinois law; 
d.  Maintain the financial books and records of the board, keep a current record of all financial transactions affecting the fund and countersign all checks involving the expenditures of monies of the fund; 
e.  Receive all funds appropriated by the village board and pay out money and otherwise make expenditures upon the order of the board for the maintenance, use and benefit of the fire rescue and inspectional services department; 
f.  Perform all duties incident to the office of treasurer and such other duties as from time to time may be required by law; and 
g.  Give a sufficient bond to the Village of Hazel Crest, which shall be approved by the village manager, conditioned upon the faithful performance of the treasurer of his/her duties under state statutes, village ordinances and the rules and regulations adopted by the board. Said bond shall be paid for from the fund. 
(h)  Meetings; quorums; minutes. the board shall be subject to the Open Meetings Act. In accordance with the Act, the board shall establish a regular time and place for its meetings and shall publish all required notices. Three (3) members of the board shall constitute a quorum for the transaction of business. each member, including the fire chief and the appointed commanding officer, shall be entitled to one (1) vote on every matter brought to a vote. The affirmative vote of three (3) members of the board shall constitute approval of the business before it. The president of the board may call a special meeting at any time. The president shall call a special meeting upon the written request of three (3) members of the board. The request shall include a description of the subject matter of the special meeting and shall be signed by all of the requesting members. Any person shall be entitled to appear and be heard on any matter before the board. a copy of minutes of all meetings shall be filed with the village clerk. 
(i)  Powers and duties. The foreign fire insurance board shall have the following powers and duties: 
(1)  The board shall adopt all rules and regulations required by this section and such other rules and regulations necessary and appropriate to carry out the board's statutory and ordinance powers, including the management of the funds appropriated to the Board, provided, however, that no such rule shall be made to govern the operation of the Hazel Crest Fire Rescue and Inspectional Department or the conduct of its members. All rules and regulations promulgated by the board must be passed by the affirmative vote of all members of the board. Said rules and regulations shall then be subject to approval by the village president and the board of trustees. The board may only amend or revoke the rules and regulations so adopted by an affirmative vote of all the members of the board. 
(2)  All of the money paid to the village treasurer, as provided by section 10-22 of this article, shall be set apart and shall be appropriated annually by the village president and the board of trustees to the board. 
(3)  Prior to the appropriation of funds to the board by the village president and the board of trustees, the board shall develop and maintain a list of those items the board feels are appropriate expenditures under applicable state statutes and village ordinances. The board shall, by March 1 of each fiscal year, approve a preliminary budget for the upcoming fiscal year. The budget shall prescribe the purposes for which funds may be expended for the next fiscal year (May 1 through April 30). By May 1 of each fiscal year, prior to the start of the village's fiscal year, the Board shall adopt a final budget for the expenditure of funds for the maintenance, use and benefit of the fire rescue and inspectional services department as herein below provided. The final budget shall be adopted in accordance with the rules and regulations of the board. A copy of the preliminary and final budgets shall be furnished to the village president and the board of trustees. The board's final budget shall be included as part of the village's annual budget and shall be approved by the village president and the board of trustees. 
(4)  All expenditures of funds appropriated to the board by the village president and the board of trustees shall be for the maintenance, use and benefit of the fire rescue and inspectional services department. Such expenditures shall include the operating expenses of the board and the treasurer's bond. Expenditures may also be for items such as household goods; fire apparatus; office equipment; small tools; hoses; hose appliances; safety equipment and materials; fitness equipment; ambulance and rescue equipment; training equipment and materials; station furniture and appliances; purchase of the fire and emergency television network; attendance at training schools, as approved by the fire chief; and emergency medical and fire suppression equipment. No expenditures shall be made for any item that is not used in or directly relates to department operations. 
(5)  All expenditures of the board shall be made in accordance with the ordinances, rules, procedures and policies of the village regarding the holding and expenditure of public funds. 
(j)  Annual audit. The funds of the board shall be reviewed annually as part of the village's annual audit. The audit shall verify that purchases of the board are for the maintenance, use and benefit of the department, as provided by applicable state statutes and village ordinances, and that investments have been made in accordance with the village's current investment policy. 
(Code 1956, 10.04; Ord. No. 9-1995, § 1, 2-28-95; Ord. No. 21-2002, § 3, 6-11-02) 
Sec. 10-24. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 21-2002, § 1, adopted June 6, 2002, repealed former section 10-24 in its entirety which pertained to the duties of the treasurer fire, rescue and inspectional services department regarding the fire insurance tax and derived from the Code of 1956 and Ord. No. 9-1995, § 1, 2-28-95. 
Sec. 10-25. - Violations. 
    Every person present at a fire shall be subject to and obedient to the orders of the chief of the fire, rescue and inspectional services department and other officers of the fire, rescue and inspectional services department engaged in extinguishing the fire, implementing a rescue, or removing or protecting property. In case any person shall refuse to obey such orders, or shall willfully offer any hinderance to any officer or fire fighter in the performance of his duty at a fire or rescue, or shall willfully in any manner destroy, injure or deface any hose cart, hose or other fire apparatus belonging to the village, he shall be punished as provided in section 1-10 of this Code. 
Editor's note- At the request of the village in June 2002 former section 10-25 was deleted and former section 10-26 was renumbered as section 10-25. Former section 10-25 pertained to removal of members of the fire department and derived from the Code of 1956. 
(Code 1956, §§ 10.01, 10.11; Ord. No. 9-1995, § 1, 2-28-95) 
Secs. 10-26-10-32. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - CHIEF 

Sec. 10-33. - Office created. 
    There is hereby created the office of the chief of the fire, rescue and inspectional services department of the village. The fire chief shall be appointed by the village manager in accordance with section 2-154(x) of the village Code. 
(Code 1956, § 10.02, Ord. No. 10-1985, § 2, 4-23-85) 
Sec. 10-34. - Duties; appointment of assistant chief. 
    The chief of the fire, rescue and inspectional services department shall report to the village manager, and shall have command and control of the department and all members thereof. The chief may appoint one assistant chief who shall perform such duties as prescribed by the chief. He shall have the general care and custody of the engines, hose carts, hose, trucks, hooks, ladders and all other property and equipment of the department, and shall personally attend to or provide for all repairs required to be made upon same. 
(Code 1956, § 10.06; Ord. No. 23-2006, § 1, 10-10-06; Ord. No. 14-2009, § 2, 10-13-09) 
Sec. 10-35. - Command at fires. 
    The chief of the Hazel Crest Department of Fire, Rescue and Inspectional Services or his designated representative shall attend all fires and rescues occurring within the village, take command of the organization and see that the members of the department faithfully perform their respective duties. The chief of the department of fire, rescue and inspectional services may order the tearing down of any building when, in any case, it shall be deemed necessary to check the progress of a fire. 
(Code 1956, § 10.07) 
Editor's note- Amended by request of the village in June 2002. 
Sec. 10-36. - Records; reports. 
    The chief of the department shall keep records that provide a full, true and complete record of all property and equipment of the fire, rescue and inspectional services department, together with a record of all transactions of the fire, rescue and inspectional services department and of all the property placed in his charge and custody. He shall annually, at the close of each calendar year, make a written report to the president and board of trustees showing the condition of the department under his management. 
(Code 1956, § 10.08; Ord. No. 9-1995, § 1, 2-28-95) 
Sec. 10-37. - To prescribe limits at fires. 
    The chief of the fire, rescue and inspectional services department or other officer of the fire, rescue and inspectional services department in command may prescribe limits in the vicinity of any fire, within which no persons except those who reside therein, fire fighters, police officers and those admitted by order of any officer of the fire, rescue and inspectional services department shall be permitted to go. He shall also have power to cause the removal of any property whenever it shall become necessary for the preservation of such property from fire, to prevent the spreading of fire, or to protect adjoining property. 
(Code 1956, § 10.09; Ord. No. 9-1995, § 1, 2-28-95) 
Sec. 10-38. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 9-1995, § 1, adopted Feb. 28, 1995, repealed former section 10-38 in its entirety which pertained to the delivery of books and equipment to the successor of the chief of the fire department and derived from the Code of 1956, § 10-15. 
Secs. 10-39-10-42. - Reserved.

ARTICLE III. - FIRE PREVENTION CODE, 2000[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Cross reference- Regulation of flammable liquids and liquefied petroleum gas by fire prevention code and state law, §§ 10-4 and 10-5; enforcement of fire prevention code, § 10-21. 

Sec. 10-50. - Adoption of fire prevention code. 
    There is hereby adopted by the Village Board of Trustees of the Village of Hazel Crest, Cook County, Illinois, for the purpose of prescribing regulations governing conditions hazardous to life and property from fire or explosion, that certain code known as the International Fire Prevention Code, 2000, save and except such portions as are hereinafter deleted, modified or amended by this article. Three (3) copies of such document are now on file in the office of the village clerk, and have been on file there, and made available for public use, inspection and examination for at least thirty (30) days prior to the enactment of this section. The same are hereby adopted and incorporated as fully as if set out at length herein, and from the date of which this section shall take effect, the provisions thereof shall be controlling within the limits of the Village of Hazel Crest, Cook County, Illinois. 
(Ord. No. 9-1995, § 1, 2-28-95; Ord. No. 23-2002, § 12, 8-13-02) 
Sec. 10-51. - Definitions. 
(a)  Wherever the "village" is used in the fire prevention code, it shall be held to mean the Village of Hazel Crest, Cook County, Illinois. 
(b)  Wherever the term "legal counsel" is used in the fire prevention code, it shall be held to mean the attorney for the Village of Hazel Crest, Cook County, Illinois. 
(c)  Whenever the words "chief of the bureau of fire prevention" are used in the fire prevention code, they shall mean the fire chief of the Village of Hazel Crest, Illinois, or his authorized representatives. 
(Ord. No. 9-1995, § 1, 2-28-95; Ord. No. 23-2002, § 13, 8-13-02) 
Sec. 10-52. - Amendments made in the Boca National Fire Prevention Code/2000. 
    Section F-101.1, Insert: "Village of Hazel Crest." 
    Section 108.1 is revised to read as follows: 
Membership of Board: The Board of Appeals shall consist of the Village Board of Trustees. The Village President shall act as Chairman of this Board. The Chairman will vote on the case under appeal only if there is a tie vote. 
Section 3301.2.4.2 is revised to read as follows: The permit holder shall furnish a bond in the amount of not less than $2,000,000 for the payment of all potential damage caused either to the person or property due to the permitted display, and arising from the act of the permit holder or the agent of the permit holder. 
(Ord. No. 9-1995, § 1, 2-28-95; Ord. No. 23-2002, § 14, 8-13-02) 
Sec. 10-53. - Maintenance of free access to fire department. 
    Off-street parking areas, private roads, and walkways shall be maintained and free of obstructions which would impede the operations of the fire department. After snow begins to fall and during the time snow continues to fall; if the snow exceeds two (2) inches in depth, all areas in this section as well as all fire lanes as designated in the International Fire Prevention Code, 2000, Section F-311.1 shall be cleaned of snow. 
(Ord. No. 9-1995, § 1, 2-28-95; Ord. No. 23-2002, § 15, 8-13-02) 
Sec. 10-54. - Fire hydrants. 
    All fire hydrants on private property shall be kept free of all obstructions at all times; these hydrants shall be marked and protected in a manner prescribed by the fire official. 
(Ord. No. 9-1995, § 1, 2-28-95; Ord. No. 23-2002, § 17, 8-13-02) 
Sec. 10-55. - Violation; penalties. 
    Any person who shall violate a provision of this article or shall fail to comply with any of the requirements thereof, shall be guilty of an offense against the village, punishable by a fine of not less than fifty dollars ($50.00), nor more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00). Each day that a violation continues shall be deemed a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 9-1995, § 1, 2-28-95; Ord. No. 23-2002, § 18, 8-13-02) 
Secs. 10-56-10-59. - Reserved. 
Chapter 11 - FLOODPLAIN MANAGEMENT[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 13-2008, § 1, adopted June 10, 2008, amended ch. 11 in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former ch. 11, §§ 11-1-11-17, pertained to similar subject matter, and derived from Ord. No. 27-2000, adopted Oct. 24, 2000 and Ord. No. 21-1992, adopted Oct. 10, 1992. 

Sec. 11-1. - Short title. 
    This chapter shall be known and may be cited and referred to as the "Floodplain Management Ordinance for the Village of Hazel Crest, Illinois." 
(Ord. No. 13-2008, § 1, 6-10-08) 
Sec. 11-2. - Purpose. 
    This chapter is enacted pursuant to the police powers granted to this village by 65 ILCS 5/1-2-1, 5/11-12-12, 5/11-30-2, 5/11-30-8, and 5/11-31-2(1994). The purpose of this chapter is to maintain the Village of Hazel Crest's eligibility in the National Flood Insurance Program; to minimize potential losses due to periodic flooding including loss of life, loss of property, health and safety hazards, disruption of commerce and governmental services, extraordinary public expenditures for flood protection and relief, and impairment of the tax base, all of which adversely affect the public health, safety and general welfare; and to preserve and enhance the quality of surface waters, conserve economic and natural values and provide for the wise utilization of water and related land resources. This chapter is adopted in order to accomplish the following specific purposes: 
(1)  To meet the requirements of 615 ILCS 5/1/g River, Lakes and Streams Act. 
(2)  To assure that new development does not increase the flood or drainage hazards to others, or creating unstable conditions susceptible to erosion; 
(3)  To protect new buildings and major improvements to buildings from flood damage; 
(4)  To protect human life and health from the hazards of flooding; 
(5)  To lessen the burden on the taxpayer for flood control projects, repairs to flood-damaged public facilities and utilities, and flood rescue and relief operations; and 
(6)  To make federally subsidized flood insurance available for property in the Village of Hazel by fulfilling the requirements of the National Flood Insurance Program; 
(7)  To comply with rules and regulations of the National Flood Insurance Program codified as 44 CFR 59-79, as amended; 
(8)  To protect, conserve, and promote the orderly development of land and water resources; 
(9)  To preserve the natural characteristics and functions of watercourses and floodplains in order to moderate flood and stormwater impacts, improve water quality, reduce soil erosion, protect aquatic and riparian habitat, provide recreational opportunities, provide aesthetic benefits and enhance community and economic development. 
(Ord. No. 13-2008, § 1, 6-10-08) 
Sec. 11-3. - Definitions. 
    For the purposes of this chapter, the following definitions are adopted: 
    Act: An act in relation to the regulation of the rivers, lakes and streams of the State of Illinois, 615 ILCS 5/5 et seq. 
    Applicant: Any person, firm, corporation or agency which submits an application. 
    Appropriate use: Only uses of the designated floodway that are permissible and will be considered for permit issuance. The only uses that will be allowed are as specified in Section 802.0. 
    Base flood: The flood having a one-per cent probability of being equaled or exceeded in any given year. The base flood is also known as the 100-year frequency flood event. Application of the base flood elevation at any location is as defined in section 11-6 of this chapter. 
    Building: A structure that is principally above ground and is enclosed by walls and a roof. The term includes a gas or liquid storage tank, a manufactured home, mobile home or a prefabricated building. 
    Channel: Any river, stream, creek, brook, branch, natural or artificial depression, ponded area, flowage, slough, ditch, conduit, culvert, gully, ravine, wash, or natural or manmade drainageway, which has a definite bed and banks or shoreline, in or into which surface or groundwater flows, either perennially or intermittently. 
    Channel modification: Alteration of a channel by changing the physical dimensions or materials of its bed or banks. Channel modification includes damming, rip-rapping (or other armoring), widening, deepening, straightening, relocation, lining and significant removal of native vegetation from the bottom or banks channel modification does not include the clearing of dead or dying vegetation, debris, or trash form the channel. Channelization is a server form of channel modification involving a significant change in the channel cross-section and typically involving relocation of the existing channel (e.g., straightening). 
    Compensatory storage: An artificially excavated, hydraulically equivalent volume of storage within the SFHA used to balance the loss of natural flood storage capacity when artificial fill or structures are placed within the floodplain. The uncompensated loss of natural floodplain storage can increase off-site floodwater elevations and flows. 
    Conditional approval of a designated floodway map change: Preconstruction approval by IDNR/OWR and FEMA of a proposed change to the floodway map. This preconstruction approval, pursuant to (this part, gives assurances to the property owner that once an appropriate use is constructed according to permitted plans, the floodway map can be changed, as previously agreed, upon review and acceptance of as-built plans. 
    Conditional letter of map revision (CLOMR): A letter which indicates that the Federal Emergency Management Agency will revise base flood elevations, flood insurance rate zones, flood boundaries or floodways as shown on the effective flood hazard boundary map or flood insurance rate map, once the as-built plans are submitted and approved. 
    Control structure: A structure designed to control the rate of flow that passes through the structure, given a specific upstream and downstream water surface elevation. 
    Dam: All obstructions, wall embankments or barriers, together with their abutments and appurtenant works, if any, constructed for the purpose of storing or diverting water or creating a pool underground storage tanks are not included. 
    Designated floodway: The channel, including on-stream lakes, and that portion of the floodplain adjacent to a stream or watercourse as designated by IDNR/OWR, which is needed to store and convey the existing ten-year frequency flood discharge with no more than a one-tenth (0.1) foot increase in stage due to the loss of flood conveyance or storage, and no more than a ten (10) per cent increase in velocities. 
(1)  The floodways are designated for the Calumet Union drainage ditch southwest branch, Cherry Creek east branch and Cherry Creek west branch (map number 17031C0729J, map number 17031C0733J, map number 17031C0734J and map number 17031C0737J) on the Countywide Flood Insurance Rate Map of Cook County prepared by FEMA and dated August 19, 2008. 
(2)  The floodways for those parts of unincorporated Cook County that are within the extraterritorial jurisdiction of the Village of Hazel Crest that may be annexed into the village are designated for the Calumet Union drainage ditch southwest branch, Cherry Creek east branch and Cherry Creek west branch, (map number 17031C0729J map number 17031C0733J, map number 17031C0734J and map number 17031C0737J) on the Countywide Flood Insurance Rate Map of Cook County prepared by FEMA and dated August 19, 2008. 
(3)  To locate the designated floodway boundary on any site, the designated floodway boundary should be scaled off the designated floodway map and located on a site plan, using reference marks common to both maps. Where interpretation is needed to determine the exact location of the designated floodway boundary, IDNR/OWR should be contacted for the interpretation. 
    Development: Any manmade change to real estate, including: 
(1)  Construction, reconstruction, repair, or replacement of a building or any addition to a building. 
(2)  Installing a manufactured home on a site, preparing a site for a manufactured home, or installing a travel trailer on a site for more than one hundred eighty (180) days. If a travel trailer or recreational vehicle is on site for less than one hundred eighty (180) days, it must be fully licensed and ready for highway use. 
(3)  Drilling, mining, installing utilities, construction of roads, bridges, storage of equipment or other materials, or similar projects. 
(4)  Demolition of a structure or redevelopment of a site. 
(5)  Clearing of land as an adjunct of construction. 
(6)  Construction or erection of levees, walls, fences, dams, or culverts; channel modification; filling, dredging, grading, excavating, paving, or other nonagricultural alterations of the ground surface; storage of materials; deposit of solid or liquid waste; 
(7)  Any other activity of man that might change the direction, height, or velocity of flood or surface water, including extensive vegetation removal. 
Development does not include maintenance of existing buildings and facilities such as re-roofing or resurfacing of roads when there is no increase in elevation, or gardening, plowing, and similar agricultural practices that do not involve filling, grading, or construction of levees. 
    Director of Public Works (director): The director of public works for the Village of Hazel Crest, Illinois. 
    DWR: Illinois Department of Natural Resources, Office of Water Resources. 
    Elevation certificate: A form published by the Federal Emergency Management Agency that is used to certify the elevation to which a building has been elevated. 
    Erosion: The general process whereby soils are moved by flowing water or wave action. 
    Exempt organizations: Organizations which are exempt from this chapter per Illinois Compiled Statutes (ILCS) including state, federal or local units of government. 
    Existing manufactured home park or subdivision: A manufactured home park or subdivision for which the construction of facilities for servicing the lots on which the manufactured homes are to be affixed (including, at a minimum, the installation of utilities, the construction of streets, and either final site grading or pouring of concrete pads) is completed before April 1, 1990. 
    Expansion to an existing manufactured home park or subdivision: The preparation of additional sites by the construction of facilities for servicing the lots on which the manufactured homes are to be affixed (including the installation of utilities, the construction of streets, and either final site grading or pouring of concrete pads.) 
    FEMA: Federal Emergency Management Agency and its regulations at 44 CFR 59-79 effective as of September 29, 1989. This incorporation does not include any later editions or amendments. 
    Flood: A general and temporary condition of partial or complete inundation of normally dry land areas from overflow of inland or tidal waves, or unusual and rapid accumulation or runoff of surface waters from any source. 
    Flood frequency: A period of years, based on a statistical analysis, during which a flood of a stated magnitude may be expected to be equaled or exceeded. 
    Flood fringe: That portion of the floodplain outside of the designated floodway. 
    Flood insurance rate maps (FIRM): A map prepared by the Federal Emergency Management Agency that depicts the special flood hazard areas (SFHA's) within the Village of Hazel Crest. This map includes insurance rate zones and floodplains and may or may not depict floodways. 
    Floodplain: That land typically adjacent to a body of water with ground surface elevations at or below the base flood or the 100-year frequency flood elevation. Floodplains may also include detached special flood hazard areas, ponding areas, etc. The floodplain is also known as the special flood hazard area (SFHA). 
(1)  The floodplains are those lands within the jurisdiction of the Village of Hazel Crest, (map number 17031C0729J, map number 17031C0733J, map number 17031C0734J, map number 17031C0737J) that are subject to inundation by the base flood or 100-year frequency flood. The SFHA's of the Village of Hazel Crest are generally identified as such on the Countywide Flood Insurance Rate Map of Cook County prepared by the Federal Emergency Management Agency and dated August 19, 2008. 
(2)  The SFHA's of those parts of unincorporated Cook County that are within the extraterritorial jurisdiction of the Village of Hazel Crest, (map number 17031C0729J, map number 17031C0733J, map number 17031C0734J and map number 17031C0737J) or that may be annexed into the Village of Hazel Crest are generally identified as such on the Flood Insurance Rate Map prepared for Cook County by the Federal Emergency Management Agency and dated August 19, 2008. 
    Floodproofing: Any combination of structural and nonstructural additions, changes or adjustments to structures which reduce or eliminate flood damage to real estate or improved real property, water and sanitary facilities, structures and their contents. 
    Floodproofing certificate: A form published by the Federal Emergency Management Agency that is used to certify that a building has been designed and constructed to be structurally dry floodproofed to the flood protection elevation. 
    Flood protection elevation (FPE): The elevation of the base flood or 100-year frequency flood plus one (1) foot of freeboard at any given location in the SFHA. 
    Freeboard: An increment of elevation added to the base flood elevation to provide a factor of safety for uncertainties in calculations, future watershed development, unknown localized conditions, wave actions and unpredictable effects such as those caused by ice or debris jams. 
    Historic structure: Any structure that is: 
(1)  Listed individually in the National Register of Historic Places or preliminary determined by the Secretary of the Interior as meeting the requirements for the individual listing on the National Register; 
(2)  Certified or preliminary determined by the Secretary of the Interior as contributing to the historic district or a district preliminary determined by the Secretary to qualify as a registered historic district; 
(3)  Individually listed on the state inventory of historic places by the Illinois Historic Preservation Agency; 
(4)  Individually listed on a local inventory of historic places that has been certified by the Illinois Historic Preservation Agency. 
    Hydrologic and hydraulic calculations: Engineering analysis which determine expected flood flows and flood elevations based on land characteristics and rainfall events. 
    IDNR/OWR: Illinois Department of Natural Resources, Office of Water Resources. 
    Letter of map amendment (LOMA): Official determination by FEMA that a specific structure is not in a 100-year flood zone; amends the effective flood hazard boundary map (FHBM) or FIRM. 
    Letter of map revision (LOMR): Letter that revises base flood or 100-year frequency flood elevations, flood insurance rate zones, flood boundaries or floodways as shown on an effective FHBM or FIRM. 
    Manufactured home: A structure, transportable in one (1) or more sections which is built on a permanent chassis and is designated for use with or without a permanent foundation when attached to the required utilities. The term "manufactured homes" also includes park trailer, travel trailers and other similar vehicles placed on site for more than one hundred eighty (180) consecutive days. The term "manufactured home" does not include a "recreational vehicle." 
    Manufactured home park or subdivision: A parcel (or contiguous parcels) of land divided into two (2) or more manufactured home lots for rent or sale. 
    Mitigation: Mitigation includes those measures necessary to minimize the negative effects which floodplain development activities might have on the public health, safety and welfare. Examples of mitigation include compensatory storage, soil erosion and sedimentation control, and channel restoration. Mitigation may also include those activities taken to reduce a structure's susceptibility to flooding. 
    New manufactured home park or subdivision: Manufactured home park or subdivision for which the construction of facilities for servicing the lots on which the manufactured homes are to be affixed (including at a minimum, the installation of utilities, the construction of streets, and either final site grading or the pouring of concrete pads) has been completed on or after April 1, 1990. 
    NGVD: National Geodetic Vertical Datum of 1929. Reference surface set by the National Geodetic Survey deduced from a continental adjustment of all existing adjustments in 1929. 
    Natural: When used in reference to channels means those channels formed by the existing surface topography of the earth prior to changes made by man. A natural stream tends to follow a meandering path; its floodplain is not constrained by levees; the area near the bank has not been cleared, mowed or cultivated; the stream flows over soil and geologic materials typical of the area with no substantial alteration of the course or cross-section of the stream caused by filling or excavating. A modified channel may regain some natural characteristics over time as the channel meanders and vegetation is reestablished. Similarly, a modified channel may be restored to more natural conditions by man through regrading and revegetation. 
    Ordinary high water mark (OHWM): The point on the bank or shore up to which the presence and action of surface water is so continuous so as to leave a distinctive mark such as by erosion, destruction or prevention of terrestrial vegetation, predominance of aquatic vegetation or other easily recognized characteristics. 
    Public flood control project: A flood control project which will be operated and maintained by a public agency to reduce flood damages to existing buildings and structures which includes a hydrologic and hydraulic study of the existing and proposed conditions of the watershed. Nothing in this definition shall preclude the design, engineering, construction or financing, in whole or in part, of a flood control project by person or parties who are not public agencies. 
    Public bodies of waters: All open public streams and lakes capable of being navigated by watercraft, in whole or in part, for commercial uses and purposes, and all lakes, rivers, and streams which in their natural condition were capable of being improved and made navigable, or that are connected with or discharge their waters into navigable lakes or rivers within, or upon the borders of the State of Illinois, together with all bayous, sloughs, backwaters, and submerged lands that are open to the main channel or body of water directly accessible thereto. 
    Recreational vehicle or travel trailer: A vehicle which is: 
(1)  Built on a single chassis; 
(2)  Four hundred (400) square feet or less when measured at the largest horizontal projection; 
(3)  Designed to be self-propelled or permanently towable by a light duty truck; and 
(4)  Designed primarily not for use as a permanent dwelling but as temporary living quarters for recreational, camping, travel, or seasonal use. 
    Registered land surveyor: A land surveyor registered in the State of Illinois, under The Illinois Land Surveyors Act (225 ILCS 330/1 et seq.). 
    Registered professional engineer: A engineer registered in the State of Illinois, under The Illinois Professional Engineering Practice Act (225 ILCS 325/1 et seq.). 
    Repair, remodeling or maintenance: Development activities which do not result in any increases in the outside dimensions of a building or any changes to the dimensions of a structure. 
    Repetitive loss: Flood-related damages sustained by a structure on two (2) separate occasions during a ten-year period for which the cost of repairs at the time of each such flood event on the average, equals or exceeds the twenty-five (25) per cent of the market value of the structure before the damage occurred. 
    Retention/detention facility: A retention facility stores stormwater runoff without a gravity release. A detention facility provides for storage of stormwater runoff and controlled release of this runoff during and after a flood or storm. 
    Riverine SFHA: Any SFHA subject to flooding from a river, creek, intermittent stream, ditch, on stream lake system or any other identified channel. This term does not include areas subject to flooding form lakes, ponding areas of sheet flow, or other areas not subject to overbank flooding. 
    Runoff: The water derived from melting snow or rain falling on the land surface, flowing over the surface of the ground or collected in channels or conduits. 
    Sedimentation: The processes that deposit soils, debris, and other materials either on other ground surfaces or in bodies of water or watercourses. 
    Special flood hazard area (SFHA): Any base flood area subject to flooding from a river, creek, intermittent stream, ditch, or any other identified channel or ponding and shown on a flood hazard boundary map or flood insurance rate map as zone A, AO, A1-30, AE, A99, AH, VO, V30, VE, V, M, E, D, or X. 
    Structure: The results of a manmade change to the land constructed on or below the ground, including the construction, reconstruction or placement of a building or an addition to a building; installing a manufactured home on a site; preparing a site for a manufactured home or installing a travel trailer on a site for more than one hundred eighty (180) days unless they are fully licensed and ready for highway use. 
    Substantial damage: A building is considered substantially damaged when it sustains damage from any cause (fire, flood, earthquake, etc.), whereby the cost of fully restoring the structure would equal or exceed fifty (50) per cent of the pre-damage market value of the structure, regardless of the actual repair work performed. 
    Substantial improvement: 
(1)  Any repair, reconstruction or improvement of a structure, the cost of which equals or exceeds fifty (50) per cent of the market value of the structure either, (1) before the improvement or repair is started, or (2) if the structure has been damaged, and is being restored, before the damage occurred. 
(2)  For the purposes of this definition "substantial improvement" is considered to occur when the first alteration of any wall, ceiling, floor, or other structural part of the building commences, whether or not that alteration affects the external dimensions of the structure.
