(1)  Whenever the standards of this chapter place undue hardship on a specific development proposal, the applicant may apply to the planning and zoning commission for a variance. 
(2)  The planning and zoning commission shall review the applicant's request for a variance and shall submit its recommendation to the village board of trustees. 
(b)  No variance shall be granted unless the applicant demonstrates that: 
(1)  The development activity cannot be located outside the SFHA; 
(2)  An exceptional hardship would result if the variance were not granted; 
(3)  The relief requested is the minimum necessary; 
(4)  There will be no additional threat to public health, safety, beneficial stream uses and functions, especially aquatic habitat, or creation of a nuisance; 
(5)  There will be no additional public expense for flood protection, lost environmental stream uses and functions, rescue or relief operations, policing, or repairs to streambeds and banks, roads, utilities, or other public facilities; 
(6)  The provisions of subsections 11-7(2) and 11-9(2) of this chapter shall still be met; 
(7)  The activity is not in a designated floodway; 
(8)  The applicant's circumstances are unique and do not represent a general problem; and 
(9)  The granting of the variance will not alter the essential character of the area involved including existing stream uses. 
(c)  The director of public works shall notify an applicant in writing that a variance from the requirements of section 11-10 that would lessen the degree of protection to a building will: 
(1)  Result in increased premium rates for flood insurance up to amounts as high as twenty-five dollars ($25.00) for one hundred dollars ($100.00) of insurance coverage; 
(2)  Increase the risks to life and property; and 
(3)  Require that the applicant proceed with knowledge of these risks and that he will acknowledge in writing that he assumes the risk and liability. 
(d)  Variances requested in connection with restoration of a historic site or historic structure as defined in [section] 11-3, "historic structures," may be granted using criteria more permissive than the requirements of subsections (a) and (b), subject to the conditions that: 
(1)  The repair or rehabilitation is the minimum necessary to preserve the historic character and design of the structure; and 
(2)  The repair or rehabilitation will not result in the structure being removed as a certified historic structure. 
(Ord. No. 13-2008, § 1, 6-10-08) 
Sec. 11-13. - Disclaimer of liability. 
(a)  The degree of flood protection required by this chapter is considered reasonable for regulatory purposes and is based on available information derived from engineering and scientific methods of study. 
(b)  Larger floods may occur or flood heights may be increased by manmade or natural causes. 
(c)  This chapter does not imply that development, either inside or outside of the SFHA, will be free from flooding or damage. 
(d)  This chapter does not create liability on the part of the Village of Hazel Crest or any officer or employee thereof for any flood damage that results from reliance on this chapter or any administrative decision made lawfully thereunder. 
(Ord. No. 13-2008, § 1, 6-10-08) 
Sec. 11-14. - Penalty. 
    Failure to comply with the requirements of a permit or conditions of a variance resolution shall be deemed to be a violation of this chapter. Upon due investigation, the director of public works may determine that a violation of the minimum standards of this chapter exist. The director of public works shall notify the owner in writing of such violation. 
(1)  If such owner fails after ten days' notice to correct the violation: 
a.  The Village of Hazel Crest may make application to the circuit court for an injunction requiring conformance with this chapter or make such other order as the court deems necessary to secure compliance with the chapter. 
b.  Any person who violates this chapter shall, upon conviction thereof, be fined not less than fifty dollars ($50.00) or more than one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) for each offense. 
c.  A separate offense shall be deemed committed upon each day during or on which a violation occurs or continues. 
d.  The Village of Hazel Crest may record a notice of violation on the title to the property. 
(2)  The director of public works shall inform the owner that any such violation is considered a willful act to increase flood damages and, therefore, may cause coverage by a standard flood insurance policy to be suspended. 
a.  The director of public works is authorized to issue an order requiring the suspension of the subject development. The stop-work order shall be in writing, shall indicate the reason for the issuance, and shall order the action, if necessary, to resolve the circumstances requiring the stop-work order. The stop-work order constitutes a suspension of the permit. 
b.  No site development permit shall be permanently suspended or revoked until a hearing is held by the planning and zoning commission. Written notice of such hearing shall be served on the permittee and shall state: (1) the grounds for compliant or reasons for suspension or revocation; and (2) the time and place of the hearing. At such hearing, the permittee shall be given an opportunity to present evidence on his/her behalf. At the conclusion of the hearing, the planning and zoning commission shall determine whether the permit shall be suspended or revoked. 
(3)  Nothing herein shall prevent the Village of Hazel Crest from taking such other lawful action to prevent or remedy any violations. All costs connected therewith shall accrue to the person or persons responsible. 
(Ord. No. 13-2008, § 1, 6-10-08) 
Sec. 11-15. - Abrogation and greater restrictions. 
(a)  This chapter is not intended to repeal abrogate or impair any existing easements, covenants, or deed restrictions. 
(b)  Where this chapter and other ordinances, easements, covenants, or deed restrictions conflict or overlap, whichever imposes the more stringent restrictions shall prevail. 
(c)  This chapter is intended to repeal the original ordinance or resolution which was adopted to meet the National Flood Insurance Program regulations, but is not intended to repeal the resolutions which the Village of Hazel Crest passed in order to establish initial eligibility for the program. 
(Ord. No. 13-2008, § 1, 6-10-08) 
Sec. 11-16. - Separability. 
    The provisions and sections of this chapter shall be deemed separable and the invalidity of any portion of this chapter shall not affect the validity of the remainder. 
(Ord. No. 13-2008, § 1, 6-10-08) 
Sec. 11-17. - Effective date. 
    This chapter shall be in full force from and after its passage and approval and publication as required by law. 
(Ord. No. 13-2008, § 1, 6-10-08) 
Chapter 12 - GARBAGE, TRASH AND REFUSE[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Health and sanitation, Ch. 13; water and sewers, Ch. 29. 
State Law reference- Disposal of refuse, garbage and ashes in municipalities, 65 ILCS 5/11-19-1 et seq.; authority to prohibit deposits in streets, alleys and other public property, 65 ILCS 5/11-80-10; Environmental Control Act, 415 ILCS 5/1 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 12-1. - Definitions. 
    For the purposes of this chapter, the following words shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section: 
    Burnable waste shall mean dry paper, dry cardboard, and leaves and shrub clippings. 
    Container shall mean any object that can be used to hold materials. 
    Dumpster shall mean a container, with or without wheels, designed to receive and transport construction materials, garbage, refuse, rubbish, waste, recyclable materials, or similar discarded materials in bulk. A dumpster is a large durable metal rust-resisting, nonabsorbent, watertight and easily washable boxlike object of standardized dimensions, which shall have close-fitting covers and adequate handles or bails to facilitate collection, that can be loaded from one form of transport to another and that is used by commercial and multi-family residential buildings. Dumpsters shall be located in and enclosed in surroundings of approved, substantial construction so as to blend with the prevailing construction and terrain. The dumpster surroundings shall be constructed at the expense of the property owner and shall comply with this Code. The health inspector shall approve all dumpsters. 
    Garbage shall mean rejected food wastes and shall include every waste accumulation of animal, fruit or vegetable matter used or intended for food, and such paper as may necessarily be used for wrapping thereof. 
    Refuse shall mean all solid wastes of a community, including garbage, ashes, rubbish, dead animals, sweepings, solid market and industrial wastes, and burnable waste. 
    Rubbish shall mean such matter as ashes, cans, metalware, broken glass, crockery, dirt, sweepings, boxes, wood, grass clippings or litter of any kind. 
(Ord. No. 8-1968, § 1, 6-11-68; Ord. No. 12-2012, § 3, 7-24-12) 
Cross reference- Rules of construction and definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 12-2. - Premises to be kept clean. 
    The owner, occupant or lessee of any premises in the village shall cause to be removed from such premises all refuse and shall keep such premises at all times free and clean from any accumulation of refuse. 
(Ord. No. 8-1968, § 2, 6-11-68; Ord. No. 8-1973, § 4, 3-27-73) 
Sec. 12-3. - Improper disposal of refuse. 
    It shall be unlawful to dispose of or place any refuse in any street, alley, or other public place within the village without consent, nor shall any person dispose of or place any refuse on the private property of other residents without consent. Individual property garbage disposal must follow all sections of Chapter 12. 
(Ord. No. 8-1968, § 3, 6-11-68; Ord. No. 4-1970, 6-9-70; Ord. No. 8-1973, § 5, 3-27-73; Ord. No. 22-1992, § 2, 10-27-92; Ord. No. 10-1995, § 1, 2-28-95) 
Sec. 12-4. - Refuse storage-Containers to be kept clean and in repair. 
    Containers as required by this chapter shall be kept clean and in good repair by the owner, occupant or lessee of any premises in the village. The village's waste hauler contractor shall provide containers for single-family residences only. All other owners, occupants or lessees of any premises in the village are required to provide their own containers. 
(Ord. No. 8-1968, § 4, 6-11-68; Ord. No. 01-2006, § 1, 1-17-06) 
Sec. 12-5. - Same-Placement of containers. 
(a)  No refuse or garbage containers may be placed in a front yard or parkway, except during the period from 7:00 p.m. on the evening prior to collection until the evening of collection day. No refuse or garbage container may be left in a front yard or on the parkway after 7:00 p.m. of collection day. 
(b)  No container used for the storage, collection and removal of garbage or other refuse shall be placed so as to constitute a nuisance to adjacent property or the occupants thereof. 
(c)  In all cases when a garbage or refuse container is placed on the rear of the lot for the purpose of having its contents removed, it shall be entirely within the lot line. 
(d)  Prior to the placement or deployment of any dumpster within the boundaries of the village, the person or business requesting the deployment or placement of the dumpster shall secure a permit to locate and deploy the dumpster in the village if so required by the village. The village manager, the health inspector or a designee of the aforesaid shall approve or deny all dumpster applications in accordance with all applicable laws and procedures. No person shall be permitted to place, deploy or otherwise use a dumpster without first securing a village permit to do so. Any violation of this section shall be subject to a fine of not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) nor more than seven hundred dollars ($700.00) per day. 
(e)  All dumpsters used for temporary purposes, such as the removal of the construction debris, ("temporary dumpsters") shall be used for a period of no longer than fourteen (14) days unless such time period is extended or otherwise renewed by the corporate authorities, village manager or health inspector, pursuant to the provisions below. The village manager, the health inspector, or his or her designee shall prepare a standard form permit application for the use of a temporary dumpster. The application shall minimally contain the address where the temporary dumpster is to be sited, the time frame for the siting of the temporary dumpster. Any extension of the 14-day time period shall be accompanied with an additional application for the same. The use of temporary dumpsters shall also be subject to all other provisions of the Village Code. 
(Ord. No. 8-1968, § 4, 6-11-68; Ord. No. 8-1973, § 6, 3-27-73; Ord. No. 12-2012, § 3, 7-24-12) 
Sec. 12-6. - Same-Container, wrapping and bundling specifications for household refuse. 
    Garbage shall not be buried. Appropriate containers for single-family residences shall be provided by the village's waste hauler contractor. All household garbage shall be drained, wrapped and stored in metal or plastic, nonabsorbent, watertight and easily washable containers with close-fitting covers and adequate handles or bails to facilitate collection, and shall not be less than twenty (20) gallons nor more than thirty (30) gallons in capacity. Household rubbish shall be stored in durable, metal or plastic containers with close-fitting covers except for bulky rubbish such as trees, branches and large cardboard boxes; provided, however, that newspapers and magazines, if not stored in containers, shall be bundled securely. Cardboard cartons shall be broken down and bundled or tied securely. Tree cuttings and branches shall be bundled securely in lengths not to exceed four (4) feet and in diameter not to exceed two (2) feet. The weight of any bundled refuse shall not exceed fifty (50) pounds. 
(Ord. No. 8-1968, § 4, 6-11-68; Ord. No. 8-1973, § 6, 3-27-73; Ord. No. 01-2006, § 2, 1-17-06) 
Sec. 12-7. - Same-Container specifications for institutional, commercial and industrial garbage. 
    All institutional, commercial and industrial garbage shall be stored in durable, metal, rust-resisting, nonabsorbent, watertight and easily washable containers, which shall have close-fitting covers and adequate handles or bails to facilitate collection. No more than four (4) thirty-gallon containers shall be allowed for each institution, commercial or industrial establishment. If more than four (4) containers are required to store garbage or refuse between collection periods, it will be necessary to provide one (1) Leach container, or the equivalent thereof, of at least one (1) cubic yard capacity or as many as is necessary to provide storage between collection periods. Such containers shall be located in and enclosed in surroundings of approved, substantial construction so as to blend with the prevailing construction and terrain. The container surroundings shall be constructed at the expense of the property owner and shall comply with this Code. 
(Ord. No. 8-1968, § 4, 6-11-68; Ord. No. 8-1973, § 6, 3-27-73; Ord. No. 16-1985, § 1, 9-10-85) 
Sec. 12-8. - Same-Container specifications for apartment houses, etc. 
    All owners, management or leasing agents of townhouses, apartments, trailer houses and mobile homes that are being leased or rented as single-family units must provide at least (1) Leach container, or the equivalent thereof, of one (1) cubic yard capacity for every seven (7) units or less, which shall be collected twice weekly. Such containers shall be located in and enclosed in surroundings of approved, substantial construction so as to blend with the prevailing construction and terrain. The container surroundings shall be constructed at the expense of the property owner and shall comply with this Code. 
(Ord. No. 8-1968, § 4, 6-11-68) 
Sec. 12-9. - Burnable waste. 
    No person shall set or maintain a fire of burnable waste, including leaves, in any public street, or on any public or private grounds. 
(Ord. No. 8-1968, § 5, 6-11-68; Ord. No. 4-1970, 6-9-70; Ord. No. 8-1973, § 7, 3-27-73) 
Sec. 12-10. - Refuse collection schedule. 
(a)  All household refuse shall be collected according to the following schedule: 
(1)  Garbage shall be collected at least once each week. 
(2)  Rubbish shall be collected at least once each week. 
(b)  All institutional, commercial and industrial refuse shall be collected according to the following schedule: 
(1)  Garbage shall be collected at least twice each week and more often if necessary to maintain proper disposal procedures. 
(2)  Rubbish shall be collected at least once each week. 
(Ord. No. 8-1968, § 6, 6-11-68; Ord. No. 8-1973, § 8, 3-27-73) 
Sec. 12-11. - Inspection of receptacles. 
    All refuse and garbage receptacles shall be subject to inspection an approval or condemnation by the fire chief or his designated representative. 
(Ord. No. 8-1968, § 7, 6-11-68; Ord. No. 22-1992, § 2, 10-27-92) 
Sec. 12-12. - Composting. 
(a)  Purpose and intent. The purpose of this section is to promote the recycling of yard waste through composting, and to establish minimum standards for proper compost maintenance. 
(b)  Definitions. Composting shall mean a controlled biological reduction of organic waste to humus. Yard waste shall mean leaves, grass clippings, garden debris and brush. 
(c)  Maintenance. All compost piles shall be maintained using approved composting procedures to comply with the following requirements: 
(1)  All compost piles shall be enclosed in a freestanding compost bin. Each compost bin shall be no larger in volume than one hundred (100) cubic feet, and shall be no taller than four (4) feet. 
(2)  All compost piles shall be so maintained as to prevent the attraction or harborage of rodents and pests. The presence of rodents in or near a compost pile shall be cause for the building department to proceed under section 20-107(12). 
(3)  All compost piles shall be so maintained as to prevent unpleasant odors. Compost piles containing horse manure or fruits shall be kept covered, except when turning. 
(4)  No compost pile shall be located in any yard except as follows: 
a.  In a rear yard not less than three (3) feet from all lot lines, nor closer than twenty (20) feet from any dwelling unit. 
(d)  Ingredients. 
(1)  No compost piles shall contain any of the following: 
a.  Lakeweeds; 
b.  Cook food scraps; 
c.  Fish, meat or other animal products; 
d.  Manures other than horse manure. 
(2)  Permitted ingredients shall include: 
a.  Yard waste; 
b.  Raw vegetables and fruit scrapes of four (4) inches in length or less; 
c.  Horse manure; 
d.  Commercial compost additives. 
(e)  Owner responsibility. Every owner or operator shall be responsible for maintaining all property under his or her control in accordance with the requirements of this subsection. 
(f)  Penalty. Any person violating section 12-12 shall be subject to a forfeiture of not less than twenty-five dollars ($25.00) or more than two hundred dollars ($200.00). Each day such violation continues shall be considered a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 12-1990, § 1, 7-24-90) 
Sec. 12-13. - Bills for services; payment of charges. 
    Charges for garbage collection and disposal services provided to single-family residential customers by the village's contracted waste hauler shall be included and billed as part of the village's periodic bill for water and sewer service to the subject property, and shall be paid to the village in accordance with Village Code section 29-43. The owner of the subject property, and any non-owner that is the occupant or the lessee thereof, shall be jointly and severally liable to pay for waste collection and disposal services provided to the premises. Any deposit made to the village pursuant to Village Code section 29-41 may be applied to the payment of the refuse bills. 
(Ord. No. 01-2006, § 3, 1-17-06) 
Secs. 12-14-12-22. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - SCAVENGERS 

Sec. 12-23. - License required. 
(a)  Generally. No person shall engage in the business of scavenger, garbage collection or refuse collection and disposal within the village limits without first securing a license to conduct such business pursuant to this article. 
(b)  Plan. Requirements for securing a scavenger license within the village shall include submission of a plan to collect and redistribute defined recyclable materials to recognized processing centers for recyclable material. 
(c)  Biannual reports. The scavenger shall report to the village on a biannual basis the amount of recyclable materials collected from village residents occupying single-family structures, the amount of recyclable material redistributed to recognized processing centers for recyclable material and the number of households actively participating with the scavenger's recycling service. 
(d)  Approval of plan. To secure and/or maintain a scavenger license the proposed recycling plan must be approved and accepted by the village. Furthermore, the collection and redistribution of recycled material must be maintained at a quantity level so as to meet at a minimum the state's requirement of fifteen (15) per cent of the waste stream being recycled by January 1, 1994. The scavenger would be further required to meet, at a minimum, any future recycling level set by the state after the January 1, 1994 date. 
(e)  Initiation of plan. The scavengers recycling plan, once approved, must be initiated by September 7, 1990. 
(f)  Elements of plan. The scavenger's plan for recycling must include the cost to the resident, how the resident is to be instructed to handle recyclable material and prepare it for scavenger pickup, the proposed facilities the recyclable material will be transferred to, and the frequency of pickup. The scavenger must also describe the pickup routes to be followed and if the route goes outside the village, how this material will not be included in the volume count for the village. 
(g)  Materials to be included in plan. The scavenger will address in the plan for recycling how the following material will be handled: Newspaper, other paper, corrugated, glass containers, plate glass, oil, batteries, bimetal cans, aluminum cans, ferrous cans, mixed cans and plastics. 
(h)  Amounts of materials to be described in plan. The biannual report to the village will detail the amounts of material, as well as the type as described above, delivered to the designated recycling facilities. Quantity will be expressed in tons, pounds or cubic yards. Documentation including receipts will be required to confirm delivery of material. In order to measure and meet state requirements for recycling, the scavenger will be required to submit documentation on the total amount of solid waste collected to determine the percentage recycled. 
(Ord. No. 8-1973, §§ 1, 11, 3-27-73; Ord. No. 6-1990, § 1, 5-8-90) 
Sec. 12-24. - Types, number of licenses. 
(a)  There shall be one type of scavenger license which permits the holder to service single-family dwellings on a route basis, and also permits the holder to service commercial, industrial and multifamily buildings on a contract basis. 
(b)  The maximum number of scavenger licenses to be issued by the village shall be limited to four (4). 
(Ord. No. 8-1973, § 2, 3-27-73; Ord. No. 1-1985, § 1, 1-8-85) 
Sec. 12-25. - License fee. 
    The annual fee for a scavenger license shall be four hundred fifty dollars ($450.00), payable on or before May 1 of each year. 
(Ord. No. 8-1973, § 9, 3-27-73; Ord. No. 15-1989, § 7, 4-25-89; Ord. No. 10-1995, § 1, 2-28-95) 
Cross reference- License fees, § 17-37 et seq. 
Sec. 12-26. - Insurance. 
    No license shall be issued under the provisions of this article unless the applicant has first submitted to the Village of Hazel Crest proof of public liability insurance covering operations within Hazel Crest in the amount of not less than five hundred thousand dollars ($500,000.00) for personal injuries, including accidental death to any one person; in the amount not less than one million dollars ($1,000,000.00) for each such occurrence; and, as to property damage, not less than twenty-five hundred thousand dollars ($250,000.00) for each occurrence. 
(Ord. No. 11-1979, § 1, 3-13-79) 
Chapter 13 - HEALTH AND SANITATION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Animals and fowl, Ch. 5; garbage, trash and refuse, Ch. 12; water and sewers, Ch. 29. 
State Law reference- Health powers generally, 65 ILCS 5/11-6-1; authority to promulgate health regulations, 65 ILCS 5/11-20-5. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 13-1. - Enforcement of health regulations. 
    It shall be the duty of every member of the police department to aid in the enforcement of any order issued by the authority of the board of health, the health officer, the president or board of trustees, or any member thereof. 
(Code 1956, § 7.03) 
Sec. 13-2. - Unhealthful acts. 
    It shall be unlawful to commit or do any act which endangers the public health in any way or results in discomfort to the public. 
(Code 1956, § 7.23) 
Sec. 13-3. - Common use towels in public places prohibited. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful to maintain in or about any public lavatory or washroom any towel for common use. 
(b)  The term "common use" as used in this section shall be construed to mean for use by more than one person. 
(Code 1956, § 7.21) 
Sec. 13-4. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 11-1995, § 1, adopted Feb. 28, 1995, repealed former section 13-4 in its entirety which pertained to the reporting and control of communicable diseases and derived from Ord. No. 20-1973, §§ 1.10, 1.11, adopted Nov. 13, 1973. 
Sec. 13-5. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 11-1995, § 1, adopted Feb. 28, 1995, repealed former section 13-5 in its entirety which pertained to the applicability of the Illinois Grade A Milk Law and other state law provisions to milk and milk products sold, handled or produced in the village. 
Sec. 13-6. - Accumulation, removal and disposal of waste. 
    Refer to existing Scavenger Ordinance No. 8-1973 [Chapter 12, Article II of this Code.] 
(Ord. No. 20-1973, 11-13-73) 
Sec. 13-7. - Nuisances. 
    Refer to current village ordinances [Chapter 20, Article VII of this Code.] 
(Ord. No. 20-1973, 11-13-73) 
Sec. 13-8. - Sanitary requirements of public places. 
    Every place wherein any business is carried on and all public premises, hotels, lodging houses, theatres, public halls or other places where public gatherings of any kind are held, shall be kept clean and in sanitary condition. All necessary measures shall be taken to safeguard the lives and health of all persons visiting or employed in such establishments, and adequate and convenient washing and toilet facilities shall be provided for the public and employees. No person suffering from active communicable disease shall be employed in any business. 
    All articles kept for sale or use in such establishments shall be kept free from vermin or any matter of a contagious or infectious nature. All decomposed matter and all refuse, waste and sweepings shall be removed and disposed of at least once each day, and in such a manner as not to cause a nuisance, and all cleaning shall be done as far as possible outside of working hours, but if done during working hours, it shall be done in such a manner as to avoid the unnecessary raising of dust or noxious material. 
(Ord. No. 20-1973, § 1.29, 11-13-73) 
Sec. 13-9. - Sanitary requirements of private buildings and premises. 
    When it comes to the attention of the health officer that the conditions of any building or premises is prejudicial to the health or dangerous to the lives of the occupants and the public, the health officer shall make a thorough examination of the building or premises and shall cause such building or premises to be put in a sanitary condition at the cost of the person who is responsible for causing such unsanitary or dangerous condition. 
    The health officer shall see that every dwelling shall be clean and free from any accumulation of dirt, filth, rubbish, garbage or other matter in or upon the same or in the courts, yards, passages or areas connected with or belonging to the same and that the owner of such building or in the case of a private building, the occupant thereof shall keep such parts in a clean condition at all times. 
(Ord. No. 20-1973, § 1.30, 11-13-73) 
Sec. 13-10. - Labeling poisonous seeds. 
    All vendors of garden seeds shall affix proper labels to each packet of seeds that are poisonous when eaten, with a special note of caution to keep them out of the reach of children, unless the original packet already carries sufficiently clear information to this effect. Among the poisonous seeds to be so labeled are Ricinus (castor bean), Digitalis (fox glove), Delphinium (larkspur), Henbane and Datura. 
(Ord. No. 20-1973, § 1.32, 11-13-73) 
Sec. 13-11. - Penalty; continuing violations. 
    Whenever in this chapter any act is prohibited or is made or declared to be unlawful or an offense, or whenever in this chapter, the doing of any act is required or the failure to do any act is declared to be unlawful, where no specific penalty is provided therefore, the violation of any such provision of this chapter shall be punished by a fine not less than fifty dollars ($50.00) and not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00). Each day any violation of any provision of this chapter shall continue shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 20-1973, § 1.33, 11-13-73; Ord. No. 11-1995, § 1, 2-28-95) 
Sec. 13-12. - Violation hearings. 
    When it appears that any state or county statute or provision of this Code relating to health or any rule or regulation of the board of health has been violated, the health officer shall cause notice of such fact to be given to the person concerned, who shall be given an opportunity to be heard before the board of health concerning such alleged violation. The notice shall specify the date, hour and place of hearing, which hearing shall be private. If, after such hearing, the board of health believes such statute or provision of this Code has been violated, it shall cause the violator to be prosecuted. 
Secs. 13-13-13-16. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - HEALTH OFFICER[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Administration generally, Ch. 2. 

Sec. 13-17. - Office created; appointment. 
    There is hereby created the office of health officer. The chief of the department of fire, rescue and inspectional services shall be the health officer. He shall have the management and control of all matters and things pertaining to health. 
(Ord. No. 20-1973, § 1.6, 1-13-73; Ord. No. 11-1995, § 1, 2-28-95) 
Editor's note- Amended by request of the village in June 2002. 
Sec. 13-18. - Duties. 
(a)  It shall be the duty of the health officer by and with the aid of his assistants in the fire department of the village: 
(1)  To enforce and observe all rules, regulations and orders of the village president and board of trustees pertaining to public health. 
(2)  To investigate the existence of any communicable disease within the village and to report the same promptly to the Cook County Department of Public Health, and to act without delay in carrying out such measures for arresting the progress of the same as that department shall recommend. 
(3)  To exercise a general supervision over the sanitary conditions of the village, including all persons and establishments handling, selling, manufacturing or processing any type of food or milk products. 
(4)  To make or cause to be made all necessary sanitary and health investigations and inspections within the village. 
(5)  To call upon the police of the village and such other authorities, state or municipal, as may be deemed by him to be necessary in the performance of his duties, and to cause the arrest and prosecution of offenders against any of the rules, regulations, any of the ordinances of the village relating to public health and sanitation. 
(6)  The furnish the village manager and the officers in charge of executive departments all such professional advice and information as they may require, with a view to preservation of the public health. 
(b)  For the purpose of carrying out the foregoing requirements, he or his representative shall be permitted at all reasonable hours, to enter into or upon any house, store or other building or unimproved lot, if he shall deem it necessary, in order to make a thorough examination of the sanitary conditions of the premises. 
(Code 1956, § 7.01; Ord. No. 20-1973, § 1.7, 11-13-73; Ord. No. 11-1995, § 2, 2-28-95) 
Sec. 13-19. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 11-1995, § 2, adopted Feb. 28, 1995, repealed former section 13-19 in its entirety which pertained to compensation of the health officer and derived from the Code of 1956, § 7.02.

ARTICLE V. - NURSING AND SHELTERED CARE HOMES, HOMES FOR THE AGED[5] 
Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 22-1977, § 1, adopted July 12, 1977, deleted former Div. 1, §§ 13-65-13-73, and enacted a new Div. 1 to read as herein set. Formerly Div. 1, §§ 13-65-13-73 had pertained to similar subject matter and had been derived from Ord. No. 13-1969, §§ III-VI, adopted April 8, 1969. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 13-65. - Definitions. 
    For the purposes of this article, the following terms are defined to mean: 
    Applicant: Any person making application for a license. 
    Controlled substance: A substance defined as such by the Illinois Controlled Substances Act (720 ILCS 570/100). 
    Cook County medical examiner ordinance: That ordinance enacted by the Cook County board, effective December 6, 1976, establishing the office of Cook County medical examiner, and the regulations promulgated by the Cook County medical examiner pursuant to such ordinance, dated April 6, 1977, and entitled "Guidelines for Hospitals and Physicians." 
    Home for the aged: Any home operated not for profit under the auspices of a religious, fraternal, charitable or other nonprofit organization, or operated not for profit under an endowment, which through its ownership or management, and as its principal objective provides maintenance, personal care, nursing or sheltered care to aged persons, and in the conduct of which provides such service or services to not less than three (3) persons over sixty (60) years of age. 
    Home regulated by this article: Every nursing home, sheltered care home and home for the aged, as such terms are defined by this article, located within the Village of Hazel Crest. 
    Maintenance: Food, shelter and laundry. 
    Nurse: A person licensed to practice nursing in the State of Illinois. 
    Nursing: Professional nursing or practical nursing, as these terms are defined in Section 3 of the Illinois Nursing Act of 1987 (225 ILCS 65/3), for sick or infirm persons who are under the care and supervision of licensed medical practitioners. 
    Nursing home: Private home, institution, building, residence or other place, whether operated for profit or not, for the infirm or chronically ill, which provides through its ownership or management, maintenance, personal care or nursing for three (3) or more persons, not related to the applicant or owner by blood or marriage; or any similar facility in which maintenance is provided to three (3) or more persons who, by reason of illness or physical infirmity, require personal care or nursing. 
    Home administrator: A person licensed as a nursing home administrator by the Illinois Department of Registration and Education, pursuant to the Nursing Home Care Act (210 ILCS 45/1-101 et seq.), and licensed by the village to operate and manage a nursing home, sheltered care home, or home for the aged. 
    Owner: In the case of a licensee who is an individual, "owner" means the licensee; and in the case of a licensee that is a firm, partnership, association, corporation, municipality, political subdivision, trust or estate, or any other entity whatsoever, "owner" means each member thereof, or the governing body thereof, whichever is applicable. 
    Person: Any individual, partnership, association, firm, corporation, municipality, political subdivision, trust or estate, or any other entity whatsoever. 
    Personal care: Assistance with meals, dressing, transportation, movement, bathing, or other personal needs; or general oversight of the physical and mental well-being of the residents, exclusive of nursing, as may be required by their condition. 
    Physician: A person licensed to practice medicine in all its branches in the State of Illinois. 
    Resident: Any person admitted as a patient to a nursing, sheltered care home, or home for the aged, for care. 
    Sheltered care: Maintenance and personal care. 
    Sheltered care home: A private boarding home, institution, building, residence or other place, whether operated for profit or not, which, through its ownership or management, provides sheltered care to three (3) or more persons who are not related to the applicant or owner by blood or marriage; or any similar facility in which maintenance is provided to three (3) or more persons who, by reason of physical infirmity, require personal care. 
(Ord. No. 22-1977, § 1, 7-12-77) 
Sec. 13-66. - Minimum standards. 
(a)  Village regulations. Each home regulated by this article shall comply with the building and zoning provisions and fire regulations of the village. 
(b)  Isolation rooms. Each home regulated by this article shall be provided with a suitable room or rooms, approved by the county and state health departments, to be used for cases of serious illness, terminal cases, and for the isolation of cases of contagious, infectious, epidemic or communicable diseases. Each room thus provided shall have a stationary washstand with a supply of hot and cold running water. 
(c)  Holding rooms or areas. Each home regulated by this article shall be provided with a suitable room or area, approved by the county and state health departments, for the proper care of deceased residents pending their removal, after the resident has been pronounced dead by a physician. 
(d)  Storage of narcotics and drugs. Each home regulated by this article shall be provided with secure storage, under lock and key, for all controlled substances in the possession of the home. Each such storage area shall have at least two (2) keys to be held by the shift supervisor. 
(e)  State health regulations. Each home regulated by this article shall comply with the minimum standards, rules, and regulations prescribed by the state department of public health, pursuant to its authority under Art. III of the Nursing Home Care Act (210 ILCS 45/3-101 et seq.). The following rules and regulations which were published by said department pursuant to this authority, are incorporated by reference: 
(1)  Minimum Standards, Rules and Regulations for License of Community Living Facilities, dated December 28, 1976; 
(2)  Minimum Standards, Rules and Regulations for License of Intermediate Care Facilities for the Developmentally Disabled, dated August 28, 1975; and 
(3)  Long-Term Care Facilities-Minimum Standards, Rules and Regulations, dated December 28, 1976. 
    Three (3) copies of such rules and regulations have been made available for public inspection at the village hall for at least thirty (30) days prior to the enactment of the comprehensive amendment. 
(f)  Controlled substances. No person who operates, manages or is employed by a home regulated by this article shall manufacture, distribute, or dispense any controlled substance unless such person is registered by the Illinois Department of Registration and Education pursuant to the provisions of Section 302 of the Illinois Controlled Substances Act (720 ILCS 570/302). 
(Ord. No. 22-1977, § 1, 7-12-77) 
Sec. 13-67. - Cooperation with village health officer in control of communicable disease. 
    It shall be the duty of every person conducting, operating, or employed by any home regulated by this article to cooperate with the village health officer to minimize the danger of the transmission of communicable diseases, in accordance with rules and regulations promulgated by the county health department. 
(Ord. No. 22-1977, § 1, 7-12-77) 
Sec. 13-68. - Compliance with the Cook County medical examiner ordinance. 
(a)  Notification of Cook County medical examiner when resident dies: Upon the death of a resident who was not attended by a physician within the thirty-day period immediately prior to death, or upon the death of a resident who was attended by a physician, but the death was due to unnatural causes, the home administrator shall notify the office of the Cook County medical examiner immediately. If the decedent was attended by a physician within the thirty-day period immediately prior to death, and the death was not due to unnatural causes, and such physician agrees to sign the death certificate, the home administrator need not notify the office of the Cook County medical examiner. 
(b)  Removal of dead in medical examiner cases: In the event that a resident dies in a home regulated by this article, under circumstances that require notification to be given to the Cook County medical examiner as provided in subsection (a) of this section 13-68, no person shall disturb the scene where the death of resident takes place, nor shall any person in any way disturb the body from the position in which it is found until expressly authorized to do so by the medical examiner or his appointed representative, unless the movement of the deceased or of his personal property is required for the purpose of preventing damage to or destruction of the decedent's body or his personal property, or is necessary to protect life, safety or health. Whenever the medical examiner has lawfully assumed jurisdiction of a body, such body shall not be removed or released from his jurisdiction without his express consent. If the medical examiner consents to the moving of the body, it may be moved from the place of death only to a mortuary within Cook County. 
(c)  Removal of dead in nonmedical examiner cases: 
(1)  Written permission for removal. In the event that a resident dies in a home regulated by this article, under circumstances that do not require notification to be given to the Cook County medical examiner as provided in subsection (a) of this section 13-68, no person acting as superintendent or manager, or who is otherwise in charge or control of any home regulated by this article, nor any person connected with any such home in any capacity whatsoever as nurse, physician, employee, or attendant, shall order, permit or allow the body of any resident who has died therein to be removed therefrom at any time within sixteen (16) hours after the hour of death, unless the removal of such body has been authorized in writing by some member of the immediate family of the deceased person, or by some other person legally authorized to order or permit such removal, or unless such removal is necessary to protect life, safety or health. 
(2)  Compliance with county regulations. No body of a deceased person shall be removed otherwise than in accordance with the provisions of the county health department concerning the removal of dead bodies. 
(3)  Permission of county required to keep bodies over twenty-four (24) hours. No body of a deceased person shall be kept in any home regulated by this article longer than twenty-four (24) hours after the hour of death without permission from the county health department. 
(Ord. No. 22-1977, § 1, 7-12-77) 
Sec. 13-69. - Records. 
(a)  Resident's records: 
(1)  Individual records. Each home regulated by this article shall maintain individual records for each resident and shall include the resident's admission record (which record shall show the name, address, age, sex, marital status, information required for the filling in of a death certificate, the date of admission and discharge or disposition of each resident in the home), a medical record, a physician's order record, nursing notes, and a list of the resident's belongings. 
(2)  Permanent residents' registry. Each home regulated by this article shall maintain a permanent residents' registry book in which the name of each resident shall be entered in the chronological order of admission, with the date and number of entry. 
(3)  Financial transactions with resident's funds. Each home regulated by this article shall maintain accurate records of financial transactions involving the use of each resident's funds. 
(4)  Death records. Each home regulated by this article shall maintain a record showing the name of each person who dies while a resident therein, the date of death, the name and address of the person to whom the body is released, the date of removal from the home, or if finally disposed by the home, the date, place and manner of disposition. 
(b)  Personnel files. Each home regulated by this article shall maintain accurate personnel files for all employees which shall include records of education, experience, findings of medical examinations as to physical and mental fitness, and showing freedom from any communicable disease. Daily work and time schedules of employees shall be maintained as part of such personnel files. 
(c)  Inventory of controlled substances. Each home regulated by this article which dispenses, administers or distributes any controlled substances shall maintain an inventory of such controlled substances in accordance with the laws of the United States and the State of Illinois, and rules promulgated by the Illinois Department of Registration and Education. 
(d)  Open to health officer. All records shall be open at all reasonable times to the inspection of the village health officer or his duly authorized representative. 
(Ord. No. 22-1977, § 1, 7-12-77) 
Sec. 13-70. - Daily reports. 
(a)  It shall be the duty of every person conducting or operating any home regulated by this article to make a report to the village health officer daily, by telephone and confirmed in writing immediately thereafter, of all epidemic, communicable or contagious diseases. Such daily reports shall contain the names and residences of all persons suffering from any such diseases, together with such other information as may be required by the health officer. A copy of all such reports shall also be mailed to the county and state health departments. 
(b)  It shall be the duty of every person conducting or operating any home regulated by this article to report to the village police department by telephone any unusual occurrences such as unaccounted for disappearance of controlled substances and syringes, accidents resulting in severe personal injury or death, attempted suicides, suicides, and sudden unexplained deaths. 
(Ord. No. 22-1977, § 1, 7-12-77) 
Sec. 13-71. - Inspections. 
    Every home regulated by this article shall be open at all reasonable times to inspection by the village health officer, building department, police department, and fire department, as often as is deemed necessary. 
(Ord. No. 22-1977, § 1, 7-12-77) 
Sec. 13-72. - Patients relying on prayer and spiritual treatment. 
    Nothing in the provisions of this article shall be construed as authorizing the medical supervision, regulation or control of the remedial care or treatment of residents or patients in any such home or institution conducted for those who rely upon treatment by prayer or spiritual means in accordance with the creed or tenets of any well-recognized church or religious denomination; provided, however, a license shall be required and all rules, regulations and minimum standards of this article shall apply thereto. 
(Ord. No. 22-1977, § 1, 7-12-77) 
Sec. 13-73-13-79. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - LICENSE[6] 

Footnotes:
