ARTICLE VI. - RODENT CONTROL 

Sec. 13-101. - Harborage of rodents prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful to willfully permit harborage of rats or other rodents within the village. 
(Ord. No. 14A-1966, 7-26-66) 
Sec. 13-102. - Right of entry for inspection. 
    Upon due notice access shall be granted to the health officer or other authorized official of the village to inspect private property for rodents. 
(Ord. No. 14A-1966, 7-26-66) 
Sec. 13-103. - Extermination by village upon owner's failure to comply with notice to exterminate; collection of costs. 
    Failure of a property owner to comply with written notice to exterminate existing rodents and remove their harborage before two (2) weeks shall have elapsed shall be evidence of willful noncompliance, and the village shall effect measures as are necessary at the expense of the owner who shall remit to the village an amount equal to the cost to the village of any expenses occasioned by the owner's noncompliance. If any such payment to the village is not remitted within thirty (30) days after submission of the bill, the village shall have the power to place a lien against the property in question. 
(Ord. No. 14A-1966, 7-26-66) 
Secs. 13-104-13-114. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - WATER POLLUTION 

Sec. 13-115. - Unlawful deposits. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to throw, dump or deposit, or cause to be thrown, dumped or deposited, garbage, grass cuttings, tree trimmings, etc., or large articles such as building material wastes, including broken concrete, bricks, etc., discarded articles of furniture and other kindred household articles, automobile parts, discarded refrigerators, washing machines, discarded mechanical articles such as appliances and garden tools of every kind and nature, in any watercourse (particularly Cherry Creek or South Drainage Ditch), pond, spring or well within the village. 
(Ord. No. 13-1970, § 1, 11-24-70) 
Sec. 13-116. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 11-1995, § 5, adopted Feb. 28, 1995, repealed former section 13-116 in its entirety which pertained to a reward for information leading to the arrest of a person violating section 13-116. Former section 3-116 derived from Ord. No. 13-1970, §§ 3-5, adopted Nov. 24, 1970. 
Secs. 13-117-13-120. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VIII. - FOOD HANDLING ESTABLISHMENTS[7] 

Footnotes: 
--- (7) --- 
Editor's note- Article VIII, §§ 13-121-13-129, is derived from Ord. No. 20-1973, §§ 1.14-1.22, enacted Nov. 13, 1973. 

Sec. 13-121. - Definitions. 
    The following definitions shall apply in the interpretations and the enforcement of this article: 
(1)  Restaurant. The term "restaurant" shall mean restaurant, coffee shop, cafeteria, short order cafe, luncheonette, tavern, sandwich stand, soda fountain, school lunch, mobile lunch trucks and all other establishments where food or drinks are sold, as well as kitchens or other places in which foods or drinks are prepared for sale elsewhere. 
(2)  Itinerant restaurant. The term "itinerant restaurant" shall mean a restaurant operating for a temporary period in connection with a fair, carnival, circus, public exhibition, or other similar gathering. 
(3)  Food store. The term "food store" shall mean grocery store, butcher store, delicatessen store, confectionery store, bakery store, milk store, butter and egg store, fruit and vegetable store, cheese store, fish store, drug store, ice cream store, or a combination of the foregoing, or any place where food and drink is prepared, handled, stored, offered for sale, or sold at wholesale or retail. 
(4)  Itinerant vendor. The term "itinerant vendor" shall mean any person traveling from place to place upon the public highways who shall deal in, sell, or offer for sale, any article of food or drink at wholesale or retail and who shall not operate a regular, established store or warehouse for the merchandising of foods. 
(Ord. No. 20-1973, § 1.14, 11-13-73) 
Sec. 13-122. - Permits and licenses required. 
(a)  Permits. It shall be unlawful for any person to operate a restaurant or food store in the Village of Hazel Crest who does not possess a permit from the village. Only persons who comply with the requirements of this article and rules and regulations adopted by the village shall be entitled to receive and retain such a permit. A person conducting an itinerant restaurant, or an itinerant vendor, shall also be required to secure a permit. Permits shall not be transferable. Such permit may be temporarily suspended by the health officer upon notice and opportunity to be heard upon the violation by the holder of any of the terms of this chapter or of the rules and regulations adopted by the village pursuant to the provisions of this chapter, or may be revoked after notice and an opportunity for a hearing by the health officer upon serious or repeated violations. 
(b)  Permit fee; renewal. Every person and/or corporation keeping, maintaining, or operating a restaurant or food store in the village, and each itinerant vendor, as defined in section 13-121, shall annually, on or before the first day of May of each year, obtain a permit issued by the health officer as provided in this section, and shall pay to the village for each such establishment or privilege, a permit fee in the amount of one hundred dollars ($100.00) per inspection. 
(Ord. No. 20-1973, § 1.15, 11-13-73; Ord. No. 11-1995, § 6, 2-28-95; Ord. No. 11-2015, § 1, 10-13-15) 
Sec. 13-123. - Examination and removal from sale of unwholesome or adulterated food or drink. 
    Samples of food, drink and other substances offered for human consumption in the village, may be taken and examined by the health officer as often as may be necessary for the detection of unwholesomeness or adulteration. The health officer shall forbid the sale of any food or drink or other substances found by him to be unwholesome, adulterated or unfit for human consumption, and shall cause the same to be forthwith removed from sale or destroyed. 
    The health officer shall forbid the sale of milk and milk products in containers bearing dates beyond which sale is prohibited by ordinance, if offered for sale after such date and he shall forthwith remove the same from sale. 
(Ord. No. 20-1973, § 1.16, 11-13-73) 
Sec. 13-124. - Inspection of restaurants and food stores. 
(a)  Frequency. At least once every six (6) months, the health officer shall inspect every restaurant, food store and other establishment in which food or drink is served or prepared, located within the village. 
(b)  Access. The health officer or his representative, after proper identification, shall be permitted to enter any food service establishment at any reasonable time for the purpose of making inspections to determine compliance with this section. The representative shall be permitted to examine the records of the establishment to obtain information pertaining to food and supplies purchased, received, or used. 
(c)  Report. Whenever an inspection of a restaurant, food store, and other establishment in which food or drink is served or prepared, located within the village is made, the findings shall be recorded on the Hazel Crest retail food sanitary inspection report. The inspection report form shall summarize the requirements of this section and shall set forth a weighted point value for each requirement. Inspectional remarks shall be written to reference, by section number, the section violated and shall state the correction to be made. The rating score of the establishment shall be the total of the weighted point values for all violations, subtracted from one hundred (100). A copy of the completed inspection report form shall be furnished to the person in charge of the establishment at the conclusion of the inspection. The completed inspection report form is a public document that shall be made available for public disclosure to any person who requests it according to law. 
(d)  Correction of violations: 
(1)  The completed inspection report form shall specify a reasonable period of time for the correction of the violations found; and correction of the violations shall be accomplished within the period specified, in accordance with the following provisions: 
a.  If an imminent health hazard exists, such as complete lack of refrigeration or sewage backup into the establishment, the establishment shall immediately cease food service operations. Operations shall not be resumed until authorized by the health officer. 
b.  All violations of four-or five-point weighted items shall be corrected as soon as possible, but in any event, within two (2) days following inspection. Within five (5) days after the inspection, the holder of the permit, license or certificate shall submit a written report to the health officer staging that the four-or five-point weighted violations have been corrected. A follow-up inspection shall be conducted to confirm correction. 
c.  All one-or two-point weighted items shall be corrected as soon as possible, but in any event, by the time of the next routine inspection. 
d.  When the rating score of the establishment is less than sixty (60), the establishment shall initiate corrective action on all identified violations within forty-eight (48) hours. One or more reinspections will be conducted at reasonable time intervals to assure correction. 
e.  In the case of temporary food service establishments, all violations shall be corrected within twenty-four (24) hours. If violations are not corrected within twenty-four (24) hours, the establishment shall immediately cease food service operations until authorized to resume by the health officer. 
(2)  The inspection report shall state that failure to comply with any time limits for corrections may result in cessation of food service operations. An opportunity for hearing on the inspection findings or the time limitations, or both, will be provided if a written request is filed with the health officer within five (5) days following cessation of operations. If a request for hearing is received, a hearing shall be held within twenty (20) days of receipt of the request. 
(3)  Whenever a food service establishment is required to cease operations, it shall not resume operations until it is shown on reinspection that conditions responsible for the order to cease operations no longer exist. Opportunity for reinspection shall be offered within a reasonable time. 
(e)  Service of notice. A notice provided for in this section is properly served when it is delivered to the holder of the permit, license or certificate, or the person in charge, or when it is sent by registered or certified mail, return receipt requested, to the last known address of the holder of the permit, license or certificate. A copy of the notice shall be filed in the records of the department of public health. 
(f)  Hearings. The hearings provided for in this section shall be conducted by the president and board of trustees for the village at a time and place designated by it. Any oral testimony given at a hearing shall be reported verbatim, and the presiding officer shall make provision for sufficient copies of the transcript. The president and board of trustees shall make a final finding based upon the complete hearing record and shall sustain, modify or rescind any notice or order considered in the hearing. A written report of the hearing decision shall be furnished to the holder of the permit, license or certificate by the health officer. 
(Ord. No. 20-1973, § 1.17, 11-13-73; Ord. No. 21-1987, § 1, 10-13-87) 
Sec. 13-125. - Food service establishment and retail food store sanitation requirements. 
    The village does hereby adopt as though fully set forth herein the rules and regulations on food service sanitation published by the State of Illinois, Department of Public Health, 1993, in their entirety, and where reference is made to the State of Illinois in such publication, the same shall mean the Village of Hazel Crest. The village does further adopt as though fully set forth herein the rules and regulations on retail food store sanitation published by the State of Illinois, Department of Health, 1992 Edition in their entirety, and where reference is made to the State of Illinois in such publication, the same shall mean the Village of Hazel Crest. For penalties, see Section 13-11 of this code. 
(Ord. No. 20-1973, § 1.18, 11-13-73; Ord. No. 2-1977, § 1, 1-25-77; Ord. No. 6-1985, § 1, 2-26-85; Ord. No. 21-1987, § 2, 10-13-87; Ord. No. 11-1995, § 6, 2-28-95) 
Sec. 13-126. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2-1977, § 2, adopted Jan. 25, 1977, repealed former § 13-126, relative to itinerant restaurants, derived from Ord. No. 20-1973, § 1.19, enacted Nov. 13, 1973. 
Sec. 13-127. - Restaurants and food stores to comply with article provisions; suspension of permit for noncompliance. 
    No restaurant or food store shall be operated within the village unless it conforms with the requirements of this article; provided, that when any restaurant or food store fails to qualify, the health officer is authorized to suspend the permit in lieu thereof and permit its operation during a temporary period not exceeding three (3) days. 
(Ord. No. 20-1973, § 1.20, 11-13-73) 
Sec. 13-128. - Reinstatement of permit. 
    Any restaurant or food store, the permit of which has been suspended, may at any time, make application for the reinstatement of the permit. Within one (1) week after the receipt of a satisfactory application, accompanied by a statement signed by the applicant to the effect that the violated provision or provisions of this article have been conformed to, the health officer shall make a reinspection, and thereafter as many additional reinspections as he may deem necessary to assure himself that the applicant is against complying with the requirements, and, in case the findings indicates compliance, shall reinstate the permit. 
(Ord. No. 20-1973, § 1.21, 11-13-73) 
Sec. 13-129. - Enforcement. 
(a)  Disease control. No person who is afflicted with any disease in a communicable form or is a carrier of such disease shall work in any food store and no food store shall employ any such person or any person suspected of being a carrier of such disease. If the operator of a food store suspects that any employee has contacted any disease in a communicable form or has become a carrier of such disease, he shall notify the health officer immediately. A placard containing this section shall be posted in all toilet areas. 
(b)  Procedure when infection is suspected. When suspicion arises as to the possibility of transmission of infection from any food store employee, the health officer is authorized to require any or all of the following measures: 
(1)  The immediate exclusion of the employee from all food stores; 
(2)  The immediate closing of the food store concerned until no further danger of disease outbreak exists, in the opinion of the health officer; 
(3)  Adequate medical examination of the employee and of his associates, with such laboratory examinations as may be indicated. 
(Ord. No. 20-1973, § 1.22, 11-13-73; Ord. No. 2-1977, § 3, 1-25-77) 
Sec. 13-130. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 11-1995, § 6, adopted Feb. 28, 1995, repealed former section 13-130 in its entirety which pertained to supplemental criteria regarding bulk food merchandising and derived from Ord. No. 6-1985, §§ 2, 3, adopted Feb. 26, 1985. 
Sec. 13-131. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 6-1985, § 2, adopted Feb. 26, 1985, repealed § 13-131 in its entirety, which section contained amendments to the food service sanitation regulations and was derived from Ord. No. 2-1977, § 5, adopted Jan. 25, 1977. 
ARTICLE IX. - DOMESTIC VIOLENCE SHELTER FACILITIES[8] 

Footnotes: 
--- (8) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2-1984, § 1, adopted Feb. 7, 1984, added new §§ 13-132-13-145 to the Code to read as herein set out with minor nonsubstantive changes made by the editor, including the redesignation of certain subsections to their alpha-numeric equivalent, for purposes of maintaining a uniform style within this chapter. 

Sec. 13-132. - Definitions. 
    For purposes of this article, the following terms are defined to mean: 
    Domestic violence: Attempting to cause or causing bodily injury to a family or household member or placing a family or household member in fear of imminent physical harm by threat or force. 
    Domestic violence shelter facility: A facility providing temporary residential facilities to family or household members who are victims of domestic violence, and their children. 
    Facility: A domestic violence shelter facility as defined herein. 
    Family or household member: A spouse, person living as a spouse, or parent who is residing or has resided with a person committing domestic violence. 
(Ord. No. 2-1984, § 1, 2-7-84) 
Sec. 13-133. - License required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person, association, partnership or corporation to conduct or operate any domestic violence shelter facility within the village without first obtaining a license therefor. No more than one licensed facility shall be permitted in the village. Such license shall be for a period of one year. 
(Ord. No. 2-1984, § 1, 2-7-84) 
Sec. 13-134. - Minimum standards. 
    Each facility regulated by this article shall comply with the following provisions and regulations: 
(1)  Each facility shall comply with all building, zoning and fire regulations of the village. However, in the event that a building or fire regulation provision contained in this article is more restrictive than that found in any other Code or ordinance of the village, then the more restrictive provisions of this article shall control. 
(2)  No more than fifteen (15) people shall be permitted by a licensee to reside at a facility. 
(3)  No family or household member shall be allowed to remain at a facility for more than thirty (30) consecutive days. 
(4)  Each facility shall be equipped and furnished as follows: 
a.  One bed per anticipated resident must be provided. Such bed shall be at least thirty-six (36) inches wide. 
b.  Adequate pillow and clothing storage areas two (2) feet by two (2) feet must be provided for each resident. 
c.  Each bedroom must contain a mirror, a window with shades, and a reading lamp. 
d.  Each facility must contain one (1) crib or similar infant's furnishing for every two (2) bedrooms therein. 
e.  Each facility must be designed in such a way that no people have to walk through one bedroom to reach another bedroom. 
f.  Only one family unit may occupy any one bedroom at any one time. However, two (2) unrelated family or household member without children may agree to occupy a single bedroom. 
g.  No smoking shall be allowed in any bedroom in a facility, and signs to that effect shall be posted. 
h.  No alcoholic beverages shall be served at the facility. 
i.  The total occupancy at the facility at any one time, including staff and other members, shall not exceed twenty-five (25) people. 
(5)  Any kitchens located within a facility must meet the requirements of Article VIII sections 13-130 and 13-131 of the Village Code. In addition, each facility must provide at least three (3) meals a day for its residents, and such meals shall be served only in the kitchen or dining area of the facility. A daily food allowance must meet the food pattern for general diet as recommended by the Food Nutrition Board of the National Research Council. 
(Ord. No. 2-1984, § 1, 2-7-84) 
Sec. 13-135. - Fire and health/safety requirements. 
    The fire and health/safety requirements shall be as follows for each family: 
(1)  A sprinkler system shall be installed in each such facility in accordance with the requirements of the village fire department. 
(2)  Single-station smoke detectors shall be located in all bedrooms and such other areas as may be designated by the village fire department. Such detectors shall be connected into the facility's electric system in a manner prescribed by the Village Code. 
(3)  Each facility shall have at least one fire extinguisher per floor, and each such extinguisher shall be rated at 2A-10 BC. 
(4)  Illuminated exit signs with a back-up power source shall be placed in such locations and in such manner as is directed by the village fire department. 
(5)  Adequate lighting shall be provided to illuminate all stairways leading to and from the facility. 
(6)  Each facility shall provide at least ten (10) off-street parking spaces in a lighted and screened area. This area shall be at least thirty (30) feet but not more than three hundred (300) feet from the main entrance to the facility. 
(7)  Each facility shall at all times be staffed by qualified individuals at least twenty-one (21) years of age. Each facility shall have a "house manager" or similar person so designated who manages the facility, is responsible for its operation and maintenance, and who is available and accessible to the village on a twenty-four-hour basis in case of emergencies. Children under the age of sixteen (16) must be under adult supervision at all times they are at the facility. 
(8)  Each facility shall have an outdoor fenced and screened play area for children. Such area shall be at least five hundred (500) square feet. 
(Ord. No. 2-1984, § 1, 2-7-84) 
Sec. 13-136. - Records. 
(a)  Each facility regulated by this article shall maintain individual records for each family or household member admitted to the facility, which shall include such person's admission record, including the resident's name, address, age, sex, marital status, family size staying at the facility, and a list of the person's personal property and other belongings brought to the facility. Such records shall also show the dates of admission and release of each such person. 
(b)  Each facility shall maintain a permanent residents' registry book in which the name of each resident shall be entered in the chronological order of admission and release, with the date and number of entry. 
(c)  Each facility shall maintain accurate personnel files of all employees working in such facility, which shall include records as to education, experience and similar background information. Daily work and time schedules of employees shall be maintained as part of such personnel files. 
(d)  All records required to be maintained by this article shall be open at all reasonable times for the inspection of the village manager or his designated representative for the sole purpose of ensuring compliance with the terms of this article and other applicable village ordinances. 
(Ord. No. 2-1984, § 1, 2-7-84) 
Sec. 13-137. - Inspections. 
    Every facility regulated by this article shall be open at all reasonable times to inspection by the village health officer, building department, police department and fire department as is deemed necessary by the village to ensure compliance with the terms of this article and other village ordinances. 
(Ord. No. 2-1984, § 1, 2-7-84) 
Sec. 13-138. - License applications. 
(a)  An application for a license to conduct and operate a facility regulated by this article shall be made in conformity with the general requirements of this code relating to applications for licenses. The application shall be under oath and contain: 
(1)  The name and address of the applicant, if an individual; if a firm, partnership or association, the name and address of every member thereof; and if a corporation, the names and addresses of its officers. 
(2)  The location of the proposed facility for which a license is sought. 
(3)  The name, address and home phone number of the person under whose management or supervision the home will be conducted. 
(4)  The number of residents anticipated to be accommodated at the facility. 
(5)  Such information relating to the number, experience and training of the employees of the facility as the village manager may deem necessary. 
(b)  Each application shall be accompanied by a statement relative to the financial status of the applicant. 
(c)  As a condition of the issuance or renewal of a license, the applicant shall file with the village a statement of ownership which the applicant or licensee shall update every six (6) months. The statement of ownership shall include: 
(1)  The name, address, telephone number, occupation or business activity, business address and business telephone number regarding every person who has entered into a contract to manage or operate or who owns or controls, directly or indirectly, any of the shares of stock of, or any other financial interest in, the facility which is the subject of the application or license, and the value and percentage of such interest. 
(2)  The names and addresses of the owners of the real estate where the facility is proposed to be located, and if the property is held in trust, the beneficiaries thereof shall be identified pursuant to "An Act to Require Disclosure, under Certification of Perjury, of All Beneficial Interests in Real Property Held in a Land Trust, in Certain Cases," 765 ILCS 405/1. 
(3)  The address of any other facility, wherever located, in which any financial interest is owned or controlled, directly or indirectly, by the applicant. 
(Ord. No. 2-1984, § 1, 2-7-84) 
Sec. 13-139. - Investigation of premises, applicant; issuance. 
    The village manager, upon the receipt of an application and fee for a license pursuant to this article, shall cause the health officer, and the fire and building departments to make a thorough investigation of the premises proposed to be licensed, and if satisfied that the required standards of the Village Code are met, and that the applicant is otherwise qualified, the village manager, pursuant to a favorable written report of findings from the above, shall issue a license to the applicant for a period of one year to conduct such facility at the location specified. The license shall state the maximum number of residents that may be accommodated at any one time. 
(Ord. No. 2-1984, § 1, 2-7-84) 
Sec. 13-140. - Fee. 
    The annual fee for a license to conduct a facility shall be one hundred dollars ($100.00). 
(Ord. No. 2-1984, § 1, 2-7-84) 
Sec. 13-141. - Display; transfer. 
    A license issued pursuant to this article shall be displayed in a conspicuous place in the hall or near the main entrance inside the facility. Such license shall be valid only in the hands of the person to whom it is issued, and it shall not be subject to sale, assignment or other transfer, voluntary or involuntary, nor shall it be valid for any premises other than those for which originally issued. In addition, the facility shall post a notice or otherwise notify residents of the existence of this ordinance and the regulations herein, and further notify said residents that any resident complaints regarding the operation or maintenance of the facility may be forwarded to the village. 
(Ord. No. 2-1984, § 1, 2-7-84) 
Sec. 13-142. - Grounds for denial. 
    An application for a license required by this article shall be denied for any of the following reasons: 
(1)  Failure to meet the minimum standards prescribed in this article. 
(2)  Conviction of the applicant, or if the applicant is a firm, partnership or association, of any of its members, or if a corporation, of any of its officers or directors, or of the person designated to manage or supervise the facility, of a felony or of two (2) or more misdemeanors involving moral turpitude as shown by a certified copy of the record of conviction, or in the case of a conviction of a misdemeanor by a court not of record, as shown by evidence, or other satisfactory evidence that the moral character of the applicant, manager or supervisor of the home is not reputable. 
(3)  Personnel insufficient in number or unqualified by training or experience to provide proper and adequate care for the number of residents anticipated to be accommodated. 
(4)  Insufficient financial or other resources to operate and conduct the facility in accordance with the requirements of this article and the minimum standards, rules and regulations promulgated thereunder. 
(Ord. No. 2-1984, § 1, 2-7-84) 
Sec. 13-143. - Revocation; denial of renewal. 
    A license may be revoked or a renewal thereof denied for any of the following reasons: 
(1)  Cruelty or indifference to the welfare of a resident. 
(2)  Misappropriation of the property of a resident. 
(3)  Conversion of the property of a resident. 
(4)  Violation of any provision of this article or of the minimum standards, rules and regulations promulgated thereunder. 
(5)  Violation of any ordinances of the village or violation of any laws of the state. 
(6)  Any grounds upon which an application for a license may be denied as prescribed in this section. 
(Ord. No. 2-1984, § 1, 2-7-84) 
Sec. 13-144. - Review of denial; revocation; procedures. 
    The procedures and remedies set forth in section 13-87 through section 13-89, inclusive, of the Village Code shall apply and govern the review of denial of a license application or renewal for a facility, and a proceeding to revoke the facility's license. 
(Ord. No. 2-1984, § 1, 2-7-84) 
Sec. 13-145. - Penalties. 
    The opening or operation of a facility without a license therefor, or in violation of any provision of this article, shall also be punishable by a fine of not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00), and each day's violation shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 2-1984, § 1, 2-7-84) 
ARTICLE X. - DAY CARE HOMES 

Sec. 13-146. - Definitions. 
    For purposes of this article, the following terms are defined to mean: 
    Certificate of compliance shall mean a certificate issued by the village evidencing that a day care home has been found to be in compliance with all applicable health and safety regulations of the village, including but not limited to the requirements of this Article X. 
    Day care home. A family home which receives more than three (3) or the maximum of twelve (12) children for less than twenty-four (24) hours per day. The maximum of twelve (12) children includes the family's natural, foster or adopted children and all other persons under the age of twelve (12). The term does not include facilities which receive only children from a single household. 
    Department means the Illinois Department of Children and Family Services. 
    Operator shall mean an individual or individuals operating a day care home from the family residence. 
(Ord. No. 20-1993, § 2, 12-14-93) 
Sec. 13-147. - Annual certificate of compliance required. 
    No person shall operate a day care home within the village unless the operator obtains an annual certificate of compliance by the village. 
(Ord. No. 20-1993, § 2, 12-14-93) 
Sec. 13-148. - Minimum standards; requirements. 
    No certificate of compliance shall be issued to a day care home unless the operator complies with the following regulations, restrictions and conditions: 
(1)  No day care home may be operated from a multi-family unit. 
(2)  Each day care home shall comply with all building, zoning, fire and other health and safety regulations of the village as they may be amended from time to time. 
(3)  No day care home may operate unless the operator possesses a valid day care home license issued by the department. 
(4)  No day care home may operate in violation of any regulation of the department. 
(5)  Each day care home shall be subject to at least quarterly inspections by the village to determine compliance with the provisions of this article, and the operator shall cooperate with authorized inspecting agents of the village. 
(6)  Each operator shall make available at all time to the village fire department, a list showing the names and addresses of all children being cared for in the day care home. 
(7)  Each operator shall annually furnish the village with evidence that the operator and all employees have submitted to at least fifteen (15) hours annually of training in child care, in addition to first aid and CPR administration, said training to be conducted by agencies such as a community college, YMCA or other agency regularly engaged in such training. 
(8)  Each operator shall maintain a working telephone at all times. 
(9)  The operator of each day care home shall provide a safe means of ingress and egress for children being transported to or from a day care home. In particular, an off-street drop-off/pickup area must be provided if a day care home is located on an arterial street, including but not limited to 167th, 175th, 183rd, Kedzie Avenue, Wood Street, Dixie Highway, and 170th Street. 
(Ord. No. 20-1993, § 2, 12-14-93) 
Sec. 13-149. - Application for certificate of compliance; requirements. 
    Each applicant for a certificate of compliance to operate a day care home in the village shall complete an application form provided and furnished by the village, which form shall require the operator to furnish the following: 
(1)  Name and address of the operator. 
(2)  Name and address of any employees of any individual over the age of sixteen (16) involved in the operation of the day care home. 
(3)  A copy of the operator's current valid day care home license issued by the department. 
(4)  Whether the operator or any employee has been, or is currently subject to any proceeding involving the suspension or revocation of the license issued by the department. 
(5)  The operator and employees shall be fingerprinted by the village police department, and shall pay the village an additional amount as may be required by the State of Illinois or Federal Bureau of Investigation to process such fingerprints. By making application for a certificate of compliance, the operator and employees authorize the village to forward the results of the fingerprint identification to the department. The processing of fingerprints shall not be cause for delay in the issuance of a certificate of compliance. 
(6)  Such other information relating to the terms and provisions of this article. 
    Upon receipt of a completed application and the fee as provided in section 13-150, the fire department shall inspect the premises of the day care home for purposes of determining compliance with this article. Upon such determination, a certificate of compliance shall be issued. Upon the issuance of such certificate of compliance the operator shall be authorized to operate a day care home within the village. 
(Ord. No. 20-1993, § 2, 12-14-93) 
Sec. 13-150. - Certificate of compliance fee; license year. 
    Each applicant for a certificate of compliance to operate a day care home shall pay an annual fee of one hundred ($100.00) to the village at the time of making application for such certificate of compliance. The certificate shall be issued on a May 1 fiscal year basis and there shall be no prorations of such fee in the event a day care home discontinues operation during the course of any license. 
(Ord. No. 20-1993, § 2, 12-14-93) 
Sec. 13-151. - Existing day care homes. 
    Any day care home licensed by the department which is operating as of the effective date of this article shall have an additional thirty (30) days thereafter to make application to the village for a certificate of compliance. No punitive action will be taken by the village against such facility during the pendency of the village's review in the event of a timely application. 
(Ord. No. 20-1993, § 2, 12-14-93) 
Sec. 13-152. - Penalties; reporting to the department. 
    Any person who shall violate a provision of this article shall be guilty of an offense against the village punishable by a fine of not less than fifty ($50.00) dollars nor more than five hundred ($500.00) dollars. Each day that a violation continues shall be deemed a separate offense. In addition, any violation of this article may be grounds for revocation of the certificate of compliance. All violations of this article shall be reported to the department. 
(Ord. No. 20-1993, § 2, 12-14-93) 
Chapter 14 - HOUSING[1] 
Footnotes:

Cross reference- Buildings and building regulations, Ch. 6; electrical regulations, Ch. 9; fire prevention and protection, Ch. 10; flood damage prevention, Ch. 11; planning, Ch. 22; plumbing, Ch. 23; subdivision regulations, App. A.

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 14-1-14-10. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - PROPERTY MAINTENANCE CODE, 2012 

Sec. 14-11. - Adopted. 
    A certain document, three (3) copies of which are on file in the offices of the village, and have been on file there, and made available for public use, inspection and examination for at least thirty (30) days prior to the enactment of this section being marked and designated as "International Property Maintenance Code, 2012," be and is hereby adopted as the property maintenance code of the village, for the control of buildings, structures and property as herein provided; and each and all of the regulations of the International Property Maintenance Code, 2012, are hereby referred to, adopted and made part thereof, as if fully set out in this section. 
(Ord. No. 9-1990, § 1, 5-22-90; Ord. No. 22-1992, § 2, 10-27-92; Ord. No. 12-1995, § 1, 2-28-95; Ord. No. 23-2002, § 8, 8-13-02; Ord. No. 13-2012, § 3, 7-24-12) 
Sec. 14-12. - Amendments. 
    The following sections of the International Property Maintenance Code, 2012, are hereby revised as follows: 
    Section PM-101.1, Add: "Village of Hazel Crest" 
    Section PM-104.3, Search Warrant in Absence of Consent: If the Building Official, after a reasonable attempt to obtain consent, does not receive consent to entry as described in Section PM-104.1 (Note, there is a strikethrough the second 4 here, once amended this section will read PM-104.1), the Building Official may seek, in the Circuit Court of Cook County, a search warrant. An owner, occupant or other person in charge of a dwelling or structure subject to the provisions of this Code, who is presented with a search warrant obtained pursuant to this Section, shall not refuse, impede, inhibit, interfere with, restrict or obstruct entry and free access to any part of the structure or premises where an inspection authorized by the search warrant is sought to be made. 
    Section PM-106.4, Violation Penalties: Any person, firm or corporation who shall violate a provision of this Article or shall fail to comply with any of the requirements thereof, shall be guilty of an offense against the Village, punishable by a fine of not less than Fifty Dollars ($50.00) nor more than Seven Hundred Fifty Dollars ($750.00). Each day that a violation continues shall be deemed a separate offense. 
    Section PM 111, Means of Appeal: Any person directly affected by a decision of the local adjudication official or a notice or order issued under this code shall have the right to file an appeal with the Clerk of the Circuit Court of Cook County, located at the 6th District, Cook County Courthouse, 16501 South Kedzie Ave, Markham, Illinois. 
    Section PM-302.4, Weeds: All premises and exterior property shall be maintained free from weed or plant growth in excess of eight (8) inches. All noxious weeds shall be prohibited. Weeds shall be defined as all grasses, annual plants and vegetation, other than trees and shrubs, provided, however, this term shall not include cultivated flowers and gardens. 
PM-302.4.1, Dead Material: All premises and exterior property shall be maintained free from dead or damaged trees, bushes, shrubs or other lifeless vegetation. This would include cut as well as in-ground vegetation. 
Section PM-304.1.1.14, Exterior Covering: No plastic sheeting may be installed, attached or maintained on the exterior of any structure for insulation, weatherproofing or other purposes, except in the case of emergency temporary weatherproofing approved by the Fire Chief. 
    Section PM-304.14, Add: "March 1st to October 1st." 
    Section PM-302.9, Graffiti: The property owner shall take all necessary steps to remove any and all graffiti, or graffiti-like markings, on the exterior surface of any building or other structure. 
    Section PM-602.3, Add: "September 1st to April 30th." 
    Section PM-602.4, Add: "September 1st; to April 30." 
    PM-605.5, Ground Fault Protection: Every habitable space in a dwelling shall contain at least two (2) separate and remote receptacle outlets. Every laundry area shall contain at least one (1) grounded type receptacle. Every bathroom shall contain at least one (1) receptacle. Every receptacle within six (6) feet of a plumbing fixture shall be provided with ground-fault protection. 
EXCEPTION: dedicated sump pump receptacles. 
(Ord. No. 9-1990, § 2, 5-22-90; Ord. No. 21-1991, § 1, 11-26-91; Ord. No. 12-1995, § 2, 2-28-95; Ord. No. 23-2002, § 9; Ord. No. 13-2012, § 3, 7-24-12) 
Sec. 14-13. - Inspection requirements. 
(a)  Notice of sale or lease. No owner, agent or person in charge of a one-family dwelling, two-family dwelling or multi-family apartment house, or any commercial or industrial structure, shall sell or allow any person to occupy the same as a tenant or lessee unless the owner, agent or person in charge of such dwelling or structure has notified the fire chief no less than eight (8) working days before the proposed sale or lease. The term eight (8) working days in this instance shall mean any eight (8) working days during a given week or part thereof, when normal business activities are carried on by the village. 
(b)  Attempted inspection by the fire chief. Upon receiving notice of intent to sell or lease a dwelling or structure as described in Section 308.1, the fire chief shall attempt to inspect such dwelling or structure to determine whether the dwelling or structure is in compliance with all of the provisions of this Code. The fire chief shall attempt to make the inspection no less than five (5) working days before the date of the proposed sale or lease. The term five (5) working days in this instance shall mean any five (5) days or part thereof, when normal business activities are carried on by the village. Failure to consent to an inspection under this section shall not constitute an offense against the village and shall not be punishable by fine or imprisonment. Nor shall such failure to consent prevent the sale or lease of a dwelling or structure. 
(c)  Inspection by warrant. If the owner, agent, occupant or person in charge of a dwelling or structure does not consent to the attempted inspection described in subsection 14-13(b), the fire chief shall seek, in the circuit court of Cook County, a search warrant. 
(d)  Certificate of occupancy requirement. If an inspection has been made pursuant to Section 111 of the International Building Code, 2012 no owner, agent, or person in charge of a one-family dwelling, two-family dwelling, or multifamily apartment house (as those terms are defined in PM-202.0 of the Property Maintenance Code) or any commercial or industrial structure, shall sell or allow any person to occupy the same as a tenant or lessee unless the fire chief has issued a certificate of occupancy for such dwelling or structure. A certificate of occupancy shall be issued only if: 
(1)  The fire chief has determined that the dwelling or structure is in compliance with all of the provisions of this code; or 
(2)  a.  The owner, agent, or person in charge of the dwelling or structure has deposited in escrow an amount of money determined by the fire chief to be sufficient to bring the dwelling or structure into compliance with all of the requirements of this code; and 
b.  The buyer or lessee has entered into an agreement with the village whereby the village agrees to issue a certificate of occupancy and the buyer or lessee agrees to apply the escrow fund to bring the dwelling or structure into compliance with this code within a time period determined by the fire chief. Failure of the buyer or lessees to fulfill the terms of the agreement described in paragraph (2)b. or to bring the dwelling or structure into compliance with all of the provisions of this code within the time period designated in the agreement shall constitute a violation of this section, such violation continuing until the dwelling or structure is in compliance with the provisions of this code. 
(e)  Sale or lease is absence of inspection. If an inspection is not made pursuant to subsection 14-13(b) or subsection 14-13(c), nothing herein shall prohibit the sale or lease of a one-family dwelling, two-family dwelling, or multifamily apartment house, or commercial or industrial structure unless an owner, agent or person in charge of such dwelling or structure is interfering with or impeding an inspection authorized by a search warrant obtained pursuant to Section 104.3 of the Property Maintenance Code or subsection 14-13(c). 
(f)  Procurement of search warrant. A search warrant sought pursuant to Section 104.3 of the Property Maintenance Code or subsection 14-13(c) shall be sought in the Circuit Court of Cook County. The court may consider any of the following factors along with such other matters as it deems pertinent in its decision as to whether a warrant shall issue: 
(1)  Eyewitness account of violations; 
(2)  Citizen complaints; 
(3)  Tenant complaints; 
(4)  Plain view violations; 
(5)  Violations apparent from village records; 
(6)  Property deterioration; 
(7)  Age of property; 
(8)  Nature of alleged violations; 
(9)  Similar properties in the area; 
(10)  Documented violations on similar properties in the area; 
(11)  Passage of time since last inspection; 
(12)  Previous violations on the property. 
(g)  Annual inspections. Annual inspections are required for all rental or leased dwelling units or dwelling structures. 
(h)  Fees. 
(1)  The fee for an inspection of a one-family dwelling shall be fifty dollars ($50.00). This fee includes one (1) re-inspection of the property. Additional inspections will be conducted at the rate of twenty-five dollars ($25.00) each. 
(2)  The fee for an inspection of a two-family dwelling or multifamily apartment house shall be fifty dollars ($50.00) for the first inspection of a dwelling unit and twenty-five dollars ($25.00) for each inspection of a dwelling unit thereafter, when the additional inspections take place at the same time as the primary inspection for which the fifty dollar ($50.00) fee is paid. This fee includes one (1) re-inspection of the property. Additional inspections will be conducted at the rate of twenty-five dollars ($25.00) each. 
(3)  When a single-family dwelling, two-family dwelling, a multifamily dwelling or any commercial or industrial structure is occupied prior to an inspection being requested and a certificate of compliance being issued by the village, the fee as set out in subsection 14-13(h) shall be increased by the amount of fifty dollars ($50.00). 
(4)  In the event an inspection is scheduled and the responsible party fails to keep the appointment, the visit by the inspector will be considered as one (1) inspection in the calculation of fees. 
(i)  Issuance of certificate shall not be construed as a warranty. In issuing a certificate of occupancy, the village does not intend to nor does it warrant, insure, or guarantee to the holder thereof, to his assignee or other interested party that there are no violations of the Codified Ordinances of the Village of Hazel Crest or laws of the State of Illinois or the United States of America. 
(Ord. No. 12-1995, § 2, 2-28-95; Ord. No. 23-2002, § 10, 8-13-02; Ord. No. 13-2012, § 3, 7-24-12) 
Secs. 14-14-14-23. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - FAIR HOUSING[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 9-1983, § 1, adopted May 24, 1983, repealed Ch. 4, Art. III, §§ 14-24-14-28, relative to fair housing, and in lieu thereof enacted a new Ch. 14, Art. III, relative to similar subject matter. The deleted provisions derived from Ord. No. 6-1983, adopted April 26, 1983. 
State Law reference- Authority to adopt fair housing ordinances, 65 ILCS 5/11-11-1.1. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 14-24. - Declaration of policy. 
(a)  It is hereby declared to be the policy of the village to provide, within constitutional limitations, for fair housing throughout the village, to assure that all persons have full and equal opportunity to consider all available housing and obtain fair and adequate housing for themselves and their families within the village without discrimination because of race, color, religion, sex or national origin, and to promote a stable, racially integrated community. 
(b)  It is hereby further declared to be the policy of the village to take all actions necessary and proper to achieve the policy expressed in part (a) of this section, and in accordance with the village policy of racial diversity, Resolution No. 7-1979. 
(Ord. No. 9-1983, § 1, 5-24-83) 
Sec. 14-25. - Construction. 
    This article shall be liberally construed to further the purposes and policies stated herein. 
(Ord. No. 9-1983, § 1, 5-24-83) 
Sec. 14-26. - Severability. 
    If any court of competent jurisdiction shall adjudge any section, subsection or provision of this article to be unconstitutional, void or ineffective, such judgment shall not affect any other section, subsection or provision of this ordinance not specifically included in said judgment. If any court of competent jurisdiction shall adjudge the application of any section, subsection or provision of this article to any person or circumstance to be unconstitutional, void or ineffective, such judgement shall not affect the application of said section, subsection or provision to any other person or circumstance not specifically included in said judgement. 
(Ord. No. 9-1983, § 1, 5-24-83) 
Sec. 14-27. - Definitions. 
    As used in this article: 
    Board means the fair housing review board. 
    Commission means the human relations commission, established by Ordinance No. 76-1968, as amended. 
    Discriminate or discrimination means to treat any person(s) in a particular manner solely or in part because of race, color, religion, sex or national origin, provided that "discriminate" or "discrimination" shall not include special outreach efforts conducted by or under the authority of units of local government (including agencies, departments and commissions thereof) or nonprofit fair housing agencies to ensure that persons of minority groups are fully informed of available dwelling opportunities in areas of present or prospective majority group concentration, or to ensure that persons of the majority group are fully informed of available dwelling opportunities in areas of present or prospective minority group concentration. 
    Dwelling means any building, structure or portion thereof which is occupied as, or designed or intended for occupancy as, a residence by one or more persons, and any vacant land which is offered for sale or rental and on which any such building, structure or portion thereof may be constructed or located. 
    Lending institution means any bank, savings and loan association, insurance company or other organization or person regularly engaged in the business of lending money, guaranteeing loans for profit or otherwise providing financial assistance or insurance in connection with the purchase, sale or rental of dwellings. 
    Multifamily residential development means any building or structure, or group of buildings or structures, which contains six (6) or more dwellings under common management or ownership. 
    Owner means any person who holds legal or equitable title to, or owns any beneficial interest in, a dwelling, or who holds legal or equitable title to, or shares of, or holds any beneficial interest in, any organization or person which owns a dwelling; and his or her agent(s). 
    Person means one or more individuals, corporations, partnerships, associations, labor organizations, legal representatives, mutual companies, joint-stock companies, trusts, unincorporated organizations, trustees, trustees in bankruptcy, receivers or fiduciaries. 
    Purchase means to obtain a dwelling through a sale. 
    Real estate agent means any person who for consideration negotiates or attempts to negotiate the purchase, sale, rental or listing of a dwelling or interest therein, or who acts as an employee or agent to manage a dwelling. "Real estate agent" includes, but is not limited to, all persons licensed, or required to be licensed, pursuant to the provisions of the Illinois Real Estate Brokers and Salesmen License Act, Illinois Revised Statutes, Chapter 111, Section 5701, et seq. 
    Rent or rental means to lease, sublease, assign or otherwise grant or obtain the right to occupy a dwelling not owned by the occupant in return for consideration, or a contract or option to do any of the foregoing. 
    Sale or sell means to convey, exchange, transfer or assign legal or equitable title to, or a beneficial interest in, a dwelling in return for consideration, or a contract or option to do any of the foregoing. 
    Solicit or solicitation means any communication by or on behalf of a real estate agent with the owner or occupant of a dwelling which is intended to induce the sale, rental or listing for sale or rental of such dwelling; which is intended to offer or promote services in connection with the sale, rental or listing of such dwelling; and which is carried out by means of: 
(a)  In-person contacts at the dwelling; 
(b)  Written material mailed or delivered directly to the dwelling, such as direct mail, leaflets or pamphlets; or 
(c)  Telephonic contacts with owners or occupants of the dwelling. 
For purposes of this article, the term "solicit" or "solicitation" shall not refer to communication carried out by means of print or electronic media of general circulation, such as a newspaper, radio, television or the yellow pages. 
(Ord. No. 9-1983, § 1, 5-24-83; Ord. No. 8-1986, § 1, 4-22-86) 
Sec. 14-28. - Exemptions. 
    Nothing in this article shall apply to: 
(a)  The rental of a room or rooms in an owner-occupied single-family dwelling; 
(b)  A religious organization or any nonprofit organization operated, supervised or controlled by or in conjunction with a religious organization, with respect to its limitation of the sale, rental or occupancy of dwellings which it owns or operates for other than a commercial purpose to persons of the same religion, or with respect to preference given to such persons, unless membership in such religion is restricted on account of race, color, sex or national origin; or 
(c)  A private club not in fact open to the public, which as an incident to its primary purpose(s) provides lodgings which it owns or operates for other than a commercial purpose, with respect to its limitations of the rental or occupancy of such lodgings to its members and their guests, or with respect to preference given to such persons. 
(Ord. No. 9-1983, § 1, 5-24-83) 
DIVISION 2. - PROHIBITED ACTS 

Sec. 14-29. - Enumerated. 
    In order to effectuate the policies set forth in section 14-24 as far as legislatively possible, it is hereby declared to be a discriminatory act, an unfair housing practice and unlawful for any real estate agent, lending institution or other person to: 
(a)  Discriminatory terms. Discriminate against any person in the price, terms, conditions or privileges relating to the sale or rental of any dwelling, or in the provision of facilities, repairs, improvements or services in connection therewith. 
(b)  Refusal to negotiate or deal. Discriminate against any person by refusing to sell or rent, or by refusing to negotiate for the sale or rental of, or by withdrawing from the market or otherwise making unavailable or denying, any dwelling. 
(c)  False representation. Discriminate against any person by making false representations, or by withholding material information, constructively or otherwise, with respect to the inspection, sale or rental of any dwelling, including, but not limited to; representing to any person that any dwelling is not available for inspection, sale or rental when such dwelling is in fact available. 
(d)  Advertisements, signs, notices. Make, publish, print, circulate, issue or display, or cause to be made, published, printed, circulated, issued or displayed, any communication, notice, advertisement, sign, symbol, listing or other writing of any kind, in connection with the sale or rental of any dwelling, or the financing thereof, that indicates or expresses any preference, limitation, reliance or discrimination based on race, color, religion, sex or national origin, or any intention to make any such preference, limitation, reliance or discrimination. 
(e)  Listing agreements. Enter into any listing agreement which sanctions discrimination against any person. 
(f)  Multiple-listing services. Discriminate against any person by denying access to, or membership or participation in, any multiple-listing service, real estate agents' organization, or other service, organization, or facility relating to the business of selling or renting dwellings; or discriminate against any person in the terms or conditions of such access, membership or participation. 
(g)  Steering. Use any word, phrase or action in rendering real estate agent services relating to the prospective sale or rental of a dwelling, which influences or is intended to influence the choice of any person in favor of any area because it is occupied, in whole or in part, by individuals of such person's own race or ethnic origin, or against any area because it is occupied, in whole or in part, by individuals of a race or ethnic origin different from such person. 
(h)  Panic peddling. For profit, induce or attempt to induce the sale, rental or listing for sale or rental of any dwelling by representations regarding the presence in, proximity to, or entry or prospective entry into, the block, neighborhood or area of a person or persons of a particular race, color, religion, sex or national origin. 
(i)  Coerce or interfere. Coerce, intimidate, threaten or interfere with any person in the exercise or enjoyment of, or on account of his having aided or encouraged any other person in the exercise or enjoyment of, any right granted or protected by this article. 
(j)  Aid or obstruct. Aid, abet, compel, coerce, or attempt the commission of any act declared to be unlawful under this article; or obstruct or prevent enforcement of, or compliance with, this article. 
(k)  Other discriminatory acts. Discriminate by engaging in any other action which makes unavailable, or restricts consideration of, the inspection, purchase, sale or rental of any dwelling. 
It is also hereby declared to be a discriminatory act, an unfair housing practice and unlawful for any lending institution to: 
(l)  Lending. Discriminate against any person in connection with borrowing or lending money, guaranteeing loans, accepting a deed of trust or mortgage, or otherwise obtaining or making available funds for the purchase, construction, improvement, repair or maintenance of any dwelling; or discriminate by delaying the processing of or denying such loan or other financial assistance; or discriminate in the fixing of the amount, interest rate, duration or other terms or conditions of such loan or other financial assistance. 
(m)  Appraisal. Discriminate against any person in appraising the value of any dwelling in connection with the sale or rental of such dwelling. 
Provided that nothing in this section shall be construed to prohibit special outreach efforts conducted by or under the authority of units of local government (including agencies, departments and commissions thereof) or nonprofit fair housing agencies to ensure that persons of minority groups are fully informed of available dwelling opportunities in areas of present or prospective majority group concentration, or to ensure that persons of the majority group are fully informed of available dwelling opportunities in areas of present or prospective minority group concentration. 
(Ord. No. 9-1983, § 1, 5-24-83; Ord. No. 27-1986, § 1, 12-23-86) 
DIVISION 3. - FAIR HOUSING PRACTICES 

Sec. 14-30. - Enumerated. 
    In order to effectuate the policies set forth in section 14-24 as far as legislatively possible, it is hereby declared to be a fair housing practice to: 
(a)  Solicitation. Conduct solicitation in accordance with the provisions of section 14-32. 
(b)  Affirmative marketing. Conduct affirmative marketing in accordance with the provisions of section 14-33. 
(Ord. No. 9-1983, § 1, 5-24-83) 
Sec. 14-31. - Compliance by real estate agents, etc. 
    It is hereby declared to be unlawful and an unfair housing practice for any real estate agent or other person to whom any of Divisions 4 through 6 apply to fail to comply therewith. 
(Ord. No. 9-1983, § 1, 5-24-83)

Sec. 14-32. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 5. - AFFIRMATIVE MARKETING PLANS 

Sec. 14-33. - Applicability; procedures. 
(a)  The provisions of this section shall apply to: 
(1)  Residential subdivision developments for which plans have not received final municipal approval or for which building permits have not been issued. 
(2)  Residential planned unit developments for which plans have not received final municipal approval or for which building permits have not been issued. 
(3)  Multifamily residential developments, to be newly constructed or substantially rehabilitated, for which building permits have not been issued. 
(b)  The owner of each such development shall prepare and file an affirmative marketing plan with the village manager, on a printed form made available by the village. Upon approval of the plan by the village manager pursuant to paragraph (c) of this section, the owner shall thereafter implement the plan. The plan shall be designed to attract purchasers and renters of majority and minority groups to such developments, and to provide for special outreach efforts to ensure that persons of the identified majority group are fully informed of available dwelling opportunities in areas of present and prospective minority group concentrations, and to ensure that persons of minority groups are fully informed of available dwelling opportunities in areas of present or prospective majority group concentrations. 
(c)  Within thirty (30) days of the filing of an affirmative marketing plan, the village manager shall either approve the plan, in writing, if it complies with the provisions of this section, or state, in writing, his reason(s) for failing to approve the plan if it does not so comply. No advertising, sale or rental of dwellings in developments subject to this section may be commenced, and no final municipal approvals or building permits may be issued for such developments, until the village managers grants such written approval. 
(d)  An affirmative marketing plan shall be in effect for one year after the date on which the village manager grants written approval of the plan pursuant to paragraph (c) of this section. Each year, the owner shall prepare and file a revised affirmative marketing plan with the village manager pursuant to paragraph (b) of this section, and the village manager shall thereupon review the plan pursuant to paragraph (c) of this section. No advertising, sale or rental of dwellings in developments subject to this section may be commenced or continued except in accordance with an affirmative marketing plan for which the village manager has granted written approval pursuant to paragraph (c) of this section. 
(e)  The owner shall provide monthly reports to the village manager, on a printed form made available by the village, concerning implementation of the approved affirmative marketing plan. Such reports shall state, with respect to the previous month, the race of the persons who inquired, at any time and place, as to the availability of dwellings in the development and the source of information leading to each such inquiry; the race of persons who applied to purchase or rent such dwellings and the source of information leading to each such application; the race of the persons currently residing in the dwellings in the development; and such other information related to the advertising, sale or rental of such dwellings as the village manager may determine is necessary to review and evaluate the effectiveness of the plan. 
(f)  The village manager and the owner shall evaluate the progress and effectiveness of the affirmative marketing plan at such times as the village manager may deem appropriate. Any approved affirmative marketing plan may be modified, amended or terminated at any time by written agreement between the village manager and the owner. 
(g)  This section shall not be construed in any manner to limit any applicable federal or state affirmative marketing requirements. 
(Ord. No. 9-1983, § 1, 5-24-83; Ord. No. 34-1997, §§ 1, 2, 10-14-97)

Footnotes:
