DIVISION 9. - IMPLEMENTATION 

Secs. 14-41-14-44. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 32-1997, § 1, adopted Sept. 9, 1997, repealed former sections 14-41-14-44 in their entirety which pertained to the community relations commission and derived from Ord. No. 9-1983, § 1, 5-24-83; Ord. No. 27-1986, § 2, 12-23-86; Ord. No. 12-1992, §§ 6-8, 8-25-92; Ord. No. 20-1994, § 2, 9-13-94. 
Sec. 14-45. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 12-1992, § 9, adopted Aug. 21, 1992, repealed former section 14-45 which pertained to the fair housing review board and derived from Ord. No. 9-1983, § 1, adopted May 24, 1983, and Ord. No. 27-1986, § 2, adopted Dec. 23, 1986. 
Sec. 14-46. - Adjudication of complaints. 
    A hearing officer appointed by the village manager shall have the responsibility of adjudicating complaints alleging violations of this article. The hearing officer shall have the following powers to implement the purposes of this article: 
(a)  To hold adjudicative hearings, make findings of fact, issue orders and seek judicial and/or administrative relief with respect to any such complaints and orders in accordance with the provisions of this article. 
(b)  To subpoena witnesses, compel their attendance, administer oaths, take sworn testimony and, in connection therewith, to require the production for examination of any documents relating to any other matter under investigation or in question before the board, and enforce such powers by proper petition to any court of competent jurisdiction. 
(c)  To render at least once a year to the village board a written report of the boards's activities and recommendations with respect to fair housing practices, which report shall be made public after submission to the village board. 
(d)  To adopt such rules and regulations as the board may deem necessary or desirable to conduct its business and to carry out the purposes of this article. 
(e)  To do such other acts as are necessary and proper to perform those duties with which the board is charged under this article. 
(Ord. No. 9-1983, § 1, 5-24-83; Ord. No. 6-1984, § 1, 3-27-84; Ord. No. 27-1986, § 2, 12-23-86; Ord. No. 12-1992, § 10, 8-25-92; Ord. No. 32-1997, § 1, 9-9-97) 
DIVISION 10. - ADMINISTRATION 

Sec. 14-47. - Appointment of administrator. 
    The village manager shall appoint an administrator. The administrator shall have such duties, responsibilities and powers as may be provided by the village manager, including, but not limited to, the initiation, receipt, conciliation and processing of complaints on behalf of the commission. 
(Ord. No. 9-1983, § 1, 5-24-83; Ord. No. 27-1986, § 3, 12-23-86) 
Sec. 14-48. - Complaints. 
    Any person aggrieved in any manner by a violation of this article may allege that a violation has occurred, or that a violation will occur and cause irrevocable injury, by filing with the commission, within one hundred eighty (180) days of the alleged violation, a written verified complaint setting forth his or her grievance. Any complaint initiated by the commission shall be signed by its chairperson. The complaint shall state, on a printer form made available by the commission, the name and address of the complainant, the name and address (if known) of the person(s) alleged to have committed a violation of this article and the particular facts thereof, and such other information as may be required by the commission. A complaint may be amended at any time. 
(Ord. No. 9-1983, § 1, 5-24-83; Ord. No. 27-1986, § 3, 12-23-86) 
Sec. 14-49. - Notice. 
    Within fifteen (15) calendar days after a complaint has been received or initiated by the commission, the administrator shall serve, or cause to be served, in person or by certified mail, a copy of the complaint on the person alleged to have violated this article (hereinafter referred to as "respondent"). 
(Ord. No. 9-1983, § 1, 5-24-83; Ord. No. 27-1986, § 3, 12-23-86) 
Sec. 14-50. - Investigation. 
    Within thirty (30) calendar days after a complaint has been received or initiated by the commission, the administrator shall conduct an investigation of the complaint and shall determine either that: 
(a)  There are reasonable grounds to believe that a violation of this article has occurred, in which case the administrator shall then initiate the conciliation process of section 14-51; or 
(b)  There are no reasonable grounds to believe that a violation of this article has occurred, in which case the administrator shall then dismiss the complaint by preparing a written notice of dismissal, including the reason therefor, and notify the parties of the dismissal, within five (5) days, by serving a copy of the notice of dismissal by certified mail on the parties. The notice of dismissal shall advise the complainant of his or her right to appeal under this section. Within fourteen (14) days of receipt of the notice of dismissal, the complainant may appeal by filing a written request with the commission for a review of the complaint. By a majority vote, the commission may overrule the dismissal and refer the complaint to the administrator for conciliation pursuant to section 14-51. 
(Ord. No. 9-1983, § 1, 5-24-83; Ord. No. 27-1986, § 3, 12-23-86) 
Sec. 14-51. - Conciliation. 
    If the administrator has made a determination pursuant to section 14-50(a) that there are reasonable grounds to believe that a violation of this article has occurred, the commission shall: 
(a)  Notify the complainant and respondent of the time, place and date of a conciliation conference at least ten (10) days prior thereto, and both parties shall appear at the conciliation conference in person or by attorney; and for such purposes the commission is authorized to hold closed meetings or sessions in accordance with the provisions of the Illinois Municipal Code and the Illinois Open Meetings Act; and 
(b)  Attempt to resolve the complaint by methods of conference, conciliation and persuasion with all interested parties and such representatives as the parties may choose to assist them. Conciliation conferences shall be informal and nothing said or done during such conferences shall be made public unless the parties agree thereto in writing. The terms of the conciliation agreed to by the parties shall be reduced to writing and incorporated into a consent agreement to be signed by the parties. Consent agreements shall be signed on behalf of the commission by its chairperson. 
    If the complaint has not been resolved by conciliation within sixty (60) calendar days after it has been received or initiated by the commission, the administrator shall so report to the commission and then refer the complaint to the fair housing review board for an adjudicative hearing. 
(Ord. No. 9-1983, § 1, 5-24-83; Ord. No. 6-1984, § 1, 3-27-84; Ord. No. 27-1986, § 3, 12-23-86) 
Sec. 14-52. - Injunctive relief. 
    At any time after the administrator has determined pursuant to section 14-50(a) that there are reasonable grounds to believe that a violation of this article has occurred, the administrator may petition the appropriate court for temporary relief pending final determination of the proceedings under this article, including an order or decree restraining the respondent from doing or causing any act which would render ineffectual any order or action by the fair housing review board. 
(Ord. No. 9-1983, § 1, 5-24-83; Ord. No. 27-1986, § 3, 12-23-86) 
Sec. 14-53. - Hearings. 
    Within forty (40) calendar days after the administrator refers a complaint to the fair housing review board pursuant to section 14-51, that agency shall, upon due and reasonable notice to all parties, conduct a hearing on the complaint. Parties to the hearing shall be the complainant and respondent, and such other persons as the fair housing review board may deem appropriate. The hearing shall be open to the public, or the board, either on its own motion or at the request of the parties, [shall] provide for a closed hearing pursuant to the provisions of the Illinois Municipal Code and the Illinois Open Meetings Act. At least ten (10) days before the hearing, the fair housing review board shall serve upon the respondent a statement of charges and a summons requiring the attendance of the named persons and the production of relevant documents and records. The parties may apply to the fair housing review board to have subpoenas issued in the fair housing review board's name, which subpoenas may be served by any police officer of the village or by any person authorized to serve a subpoena under Illinois law. Failure to comply with a summons or subpoena shall constitute a violation of this article. The parties may file such statements with the fair housing review board as they deem necessary. No fewer than three (3) of the same members of the fair housing review board must be present at all times during a hearing. The parties may appear before the fair housing review board in person or by a duly authorized representative, and may be represented by legal counsel. The parties shall have the right to present witnesses and cross-examine witnesses, and all testimony and evidence shall be given under oath or by affirmation. 
(Ord. No. 9-1983, § 1, 5-24-83; Ord. No. 6-1984, § 1, 3-27-84; Ord. No. 27-1986, § 3, 12-23-86) 
Sec. 14-54. - Hearing decisions. 
    Only those members of the fair housing review board who have attended all hearings on the complaint shall participate in the determination of the complaint. Within fifteen (15) days of the close of the hearing, the decision shall be rendered, at a meeting open to the public, in the form of a written order which shall include findings of fact, a statement of whether the respondent has violated this article, and such remedial actions as the fair housing review board may order pursuant to section 14-55. The order shall be served upon the parties by certified mail within fifteen (15) days of the public meeting. The order shall be available for public inspection, and a copy shall be provided to any person upon request and payment of reproduction costs. 
(Ord. No. 9-1983, § 1, 5-24-83; Ord. No. 27-1986, § 3, 12-23-86) 
Sec. 14-55. - Remedial actions. 
(a)  If the fair housing review board finds upon the preponderance of the evidence that the respondent has not violated this article, its order under section 14-54 shall dismiss the complaint. 
(b)  If the fair housing review board fins upon the preponderance of the evidence that the respondent has violated this article, its order under section 14-54 shall assess a fine pursuant to Division II and shall provide for the taking of such further remedial action(s) as it deems appropriate, which may include, but need not be limited to: 
(1)  Directing the respondent to cease and desist from violations of this article and to take such affirmative steps as necessary to effectuate the purposes of this article; 
(2)  Initiating an appropriate court action for the enforcement of this article and for such other or further relief as the court may deem appropriate, including, but not limited to injunctive relief, compensatory damages, punitive damages and/or attorneys' fees and costs for award to the complainant; 
(3)  Initiating proceedings for violation of federal or state law and/or regulations; 
(4)  Initiating proceedings with any contracting agency, in the case of any violation of this article by respondent in the course of performing under a contract or subcontract with the state or any political subdivision or agency thereof, or with the United States of America or any agency or instrumentality thereof, for the purpose of causing a termination of such contract or any portion thereof, or obtaining other relief; 
(5)  Initiating proceedings with the Illinois Department of Registration and Education, or any other agency, to revoke, suspend or refuse to renew the license of any person found to have violated any provision of this article; 
(6)  Directing the respondent to reimburse the complainant for his actual and reasonable expenses incurred and to be incurred as a result of each violation found, including, but not limited to, expenses for moving and temporary storage of household furnishings, additional expenses in connection with the purchase or rental of a dwelling for alternative accommodations and reasonable attorneys' fees and costs, provided that no such reimbursement by any respondent shall exceed the sum of five hundred dollars ($500.00) with respect to each violation found; and/or 
(7)  Directing the respondent to comply with such other or further relief as the fair housing review board may deem appropriate for the enforcement of this article. 
(Ord. No. 9-1983, § 1, 5-24-83; Ord. No. 27-1986, § 3, 12-23-86) 
Sec. 14-56. - Judicial review. 
    Within thirty-five (35) days following a decision by the fair housing review board, any party may apply for judicial review of such decision before a court of competent jurisdiction. 
(Ord. No. 9-1983, § 1, 5-24-83; Ord. No. 27-1986, § 3, 12-23-86) 
DIVISION 11. - PENALTIES AND OTHER REMEDIES 

Sec. 14-57. - Fines. 
    Any person found to have violated any provision of this article shall be fined not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) for each violation. Every day a violation continues shall be deemed a separate violation. 
(Ord. No. 9-1983, § 1, 5-24-83) 
Sec. 14-58. - Judicial relief. 
    The village or any person aggrieved by a violation of any provision of this article may apply to any court of competent jurisdiction for appropriate relief from such violation, including, but not limited to: 
(a)  Injunctive relief or an order otherwise compelling compliance with this article. 
(b)  Compensatory and/or punitive damages. 
(c)  Reasonable attorneys' fees and costs. 
(d)  Such other or further relief as is appropriate for the enforcement of this article and the elimination of violations thereof. 
(Ord. No. 9-1983, § 1, 5-24-83) 
Sec. 14-59. - Additional remedies. 
    This article shall not prevent the village or any person from exercising any right or seeking any remedy to which that person might otherwise be entitled, or from filing any complaint with any other agency or court of law or equity. 
(Ord. No. 9-1983, § 1, 5-24-83) 
Chapter 15 - LAUNDRIES AND DRY CLEANING[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Licenses and miscellaneous business regulations, Ch. 17. 
State Law reference- Authority to locate and regulate laundries, 65 ILCS 5/11-42-8. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 15-1-15-10. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - COIN-OPERATED DRY CLEANING ESTABLISHMENTS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 15-11. - Definitions. 
    The following definitions shall apply in the interpretation and enforcement of this article: 
    Attendant: A person thoroughly trained to supervise a coin-operated dry cleaning machine plant, to advise customers in the operation of coin-operated dry cleaning machines, and to recognize health and safety hazards. 
    Building commissioner: The building commissioner of the village or the duly authorized agent of such officer. 
    Coin-operated dry cleaning machine: Any dry cleaning machine, including integral parts, originally designed and intended for use as a self-service dry cleaning machine by the general public for a consideration. 
    Coin-operated dry cleaning machine plant: Any structure in which any number of coin-operated dry cleaning machines, as defined above, are installed for use as self-service dry cleaning machines. 
    Dry cleaning: The process of removing dirt, grease, paints and other stains from wearing apparel, textiles, fabrics, rugs and similar items by the use of nonaqueous liquid solvents, flammable or nonflammable. 
    Equipment: All mechanical and electrical items within or on the exterior of a dry cleaning machine plant necessary for the plant's operation and shall include but not be limited to dry cleaning machines, ductwork, fans, blowers, solvent storage tanks, pumps, heating devices and refuse containers. 
    Fire chief: The fire chief of the village or the duly authorized agent of such officer. 
    Machine: A coin-operated dry cleaning machine as defined in this section. 
    Plant: A coin-operated dry cleaning machine plant as defined in this section. 
    Spotting: The local application of solvent to spots, dirt, grease, paints and stains for removal thereof. 
(Ord. No. 7-1962, § 1, 3-27-62) 
Cross reference- Rules of construction and definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 15-12. - Inspection. 
(a)  Operation of a plant shall not begin prior to inspection and approval by the building inspector and fire chief. 
(b)  The building inspector and fire chief shall have the authority to inspect the plant premises and all equipment. Such inspection may be made at any reasonable time. 
(Ord. No. 7-1962, § 4, 3-27-62) 
Sec. 15-13. - Building requirements. 
    Structures intended for use as plants shall conform with all applicable village zoning and building ordinances, permits, rules and regulations, in addition to the following: 
(1)  Such structures shall be single story with concrete floors in good condition. 
(2)  Machines shall not be installed in buildings used in whole or in part as dwellings. 
(3)  Maintenance areas shall be separate from customer service areas. 
(Ord. No. 7-1962, § 5, 3-27-62) 
Cross reference- Buildings and building regulations, Ch. 6. 
Sec. 15-14. - Sanitation requirements. 
(a)  Every room or part of a plant shall at all times be kept in good repair and in a clean and sanitary condition. 
(b)  Separate toilet facilities for men and women shall be provided as follows: 
(1)  One (1) water closet and one (1) urinal for men; 
(2)  One (1) water closet for women. 
Both employees and customers shall have access to such facilities. Toilet rooms shall be installed with adequate ventilation to the exterior of the plant and shall be kept unlocked, except when in use, at all times the establishment is open to the public. 
(c)  Hand-washing facilities, including lavatory, soap and approved hand-drying facilities, shall be provided in each of the toilet rooms required in subsection (b). 
(Ord. No. 7-1962, § 5, 3-27-62) 
Cross reference- Health and sanitation, Ch. 13. 
Sec. 15-15. - Lighting requirements. 
    All rooms in which machines are installed and all maintenance areas shall be illuminated to a minimum of ten (10) footcandles of light in all parts of such rooms or places not directly obstructed by equipment. 
(Ord. No. 7-1962, § 5, 3-27-62) 
Sec. 15-16. - Ventilation requirements-General dilution ventilation. 
(a)  Customer service areas shall be provided with general dilution ventilation (exhaust airflow rates) according to the following schedule: 
Minimum Airflow Rate
Number of Machines     per Machine (CFM) 
    1 to 3 ..... 500 
    4 to 8 ..... 400 
    9 to 16 ..... 375 
    17 or more ..... 360 
(b)  Ventilation facilities shall be constructed so that air is exhausted from the customer service area either directly to the exterior of the plant or through properly sized openings in a partition separating the front of the machines from the maintenance portion of the machines. Such openings, if grilles are used, shall be sized on the basis of five hundred (500) cubic feet per minute per square foot of net grille area and each opening shall be located in such a manner that the bottom of the opening is from six (6) inches to twelve (12) inches above the tops of the machines. Such exhaust ventilation shall be provided on a continuous basis while the plant is open to the public or in operation. The exhaust ventilation equipment shall be wired in such a manner that machines cannot be placed in operation unless such ventilating equipment is in operation. 
(c)  A general dilution ventilation fan shall be installed in the maintenance area of the plant. Such ventilation shall, when combined with the system required above, enable the exhausting or air directly to the exterior of the plant in accordance with the following schedule: 
Minimum Airflow Rate
Number of Machines     per Machine (CFM) 
    1 to 3 ..... 1,000 
    4 to 8 ..... 800 
    9 to 16 ..... 750 
    17 or more ..... 720 
(d)  Solvent storage rooms, if separate from maintenance areas, shall be provided with exhaust ventilation equipment capable of exhausting air directly to the exterior of the plant at the rate of one thousand (1,000) cubic feet per minute. 
(Ord. No. 7-1962, § 5, 3-27-62) 
Sec. 15-17. - Same-Local exhaust ventilation. 
(a)  Each machine shall be provided with an exhaust system capable of maintaining a minimum of one hundred (100) feet per minute face velocity through the loading door of the machine whenever such loading door is open. Ductwork connections shall be sealed by solder or tape. The discharge stack shall be extended to a minimum of six (6) feet above the roof line of the plant and the end of such stack shall be located a minimum distance of twenty-five (25) feet horizontally from any fresh air intakes. 
(b)  One scavenger pipe shall be provided for every two (2) machines to provide adequate local exhaust ventilation around base tanks and machine bases. Each scavenger duct shall be located in back of and exactly between two (2) machines two (2) inches to four (4) inches above the floor line and exhausted to a discharge stack as described in subsection (a) of this section. 
(Ord. No. 7-1962, § 5, 3-27-62) 
Sec. 15-18. - Same-Minimum horizontal discharge from fresh air intake. 
    All air required to be exhausted shall discharge to the exterior of the plant and shall discharge a minimum of twenty-five (25) feet horizontally from any fresh air intake. 
(Ord. No. 7-1962, § 5, 3-27-62) 
Sec. 15-19. - Same-Makeup air. 
    A supply of tempered (heated to a minimum of sixty (60) degrees Fahrenheit) makeup air equal to or greater than the total volume of air exhaust from the plant shall be provided from the exterior. 
(Ord. No. 7-1962, § 5, 3-27-62) 
Sec. 15-20. - Machines-Specifications generally. 
(a)  The maximum size machine which shall be permitted shall have a rated capacity of not greater than ten (10) pounds dry weight. 
(b)  The machine shall be completely enclosed by a cabinet which shall be provided with scavenging vents at or near the bottom which shall be connected to exhaust ventilation adequate to prevent the escape of dry cleaning solvent vapor to the surrounding atmosphere. The exhaust vent shall be located at or near the top of the cabinet. 
(c)  The exhaust system of the machine shall be of such design as to afford compliance with this article. 
(d)  An interlock system shall be provided on the machine to prevent the loading door from being opened during the normal operating cycle. Such interlock system shall be either electrical or mechanical, but not one depending on air pressure, and shall be so connected that in the event of a power failure, the machine door shall remain locked. 
(e)  The cleaning cycle control shall be such that there is no odor of solvent or solvent vapor in the material being cleaned at the end of the complete cleaning cycle. 
(f)  The machine shall be equipped with a transparent door or port. 
(g)  The machine, if connected to a potable water supply, shall be equipped with an air gap or properly installed vacuum breaker in the water supply line upstream from the machine. There shall be no control valves downstream from the vacuum breaker. The waste water shall discharge through an air gap. 
(Ord. No. 7-1962, § 5, 3-27-62) 
Sec. 15-21. - Same-Installation requirements. 
(a)  Machines and filter assemblies shall be installed within either a liquidtight concrete dike of four (4) inch minimum height or a pan and piping system to contain the solvent should leakage occur. The floor within such dike shall be pitched to drain to a six (6) inch floor drain or a sump well. Such drain or sump well shall be connected to an emergency solvent storage tank and such tank shall be of sufficient capacity to hold all of the cleaning solvent contained in all of the machines installed. Storage tanks shall be suitably vented to the exterior of and a minimum of two (2) feet above the roof line. 
(b)  No machine shall be installed in the same room with any gas, oil or electrically fired equipment. Such combustion equipment shall be so installed that all combustion air is drawn directly from the exterior of the plant. 
(c)  Machines shall be installed in such a manner that only the fronts thereof shall be exposed in the customer service area. The maintenance portion of the machines shall be separated from the fronts of the machines by a solid partition, except for exhaust vents. Such partition shall be a wall so constructed that the only access to the maintenance portion of the machines is through one or more doors capable of being locked. 
(Ord. No. 7-1962, § 5, 3-27-62) 
Sec. 15-22. - Dry cleaning solvent requirements. 
    No cleaning solvents other than perchloroethylene and water shall be used in a plant; provided, however, the use of such solvent has been approved by the manufacturer of the machine. 
(Ord. No. 7-1962, § 5, 3-27-62) 
Sec. 15-23. - Plant and machine operation requirements. 
(a)  An attendant shall be on duty and present at all hours the plant is open for business. 
(b)  Customers shall not be permitted in maintenance service areas. The doors of any such areas shall be kept locked at all times, except when the attendant or other authorized plant personnel is entering, leaving or working within such areas. 
(c)  Complete step-by-step operating instructions shall be posted near the machines in the customer service area. Such instructions shall also include the following statements: "Notify the attendant if any odor or solvent remains in garment or material," and "Garment or materials bearing the odor of solvent are dangerous if enclosed in an automobile or other enclosed place." 
(d)  Warning signs shall be posted requiring the evacuation of the plant in the presence of noticeable vapor odor or in the presence of such symptoms as irritation of the eyes, nose or throat, lacrimation or dizziness. The attendant shall enforce such evacuation. 
(e)  The attendant shall take all reasonable precautions to see that materials that cannot be properly cleaned are not placed in machines. 
(f)  All machines shall be inspected by plant personnel daily and any machine found to be operating improperly or found to be unsafe shall not be placed in service, but shall be clearly marked, "Out of Order-Do Not Use." 
(g)  All pipes, connections and transfer pumps carrying the cleaning solvent shall be maintained tight and free from leaks. 
(h)  Servicing of machines shall be done only during the operation of the exhaust ventilation required in this article. 
(i)  The dry cleaning solvent shall be stored in tightly closed containers, and shall be transferred from the containers by means of a closed system. All solvent storage containers, external from machine tanks, must be adequately and properly labeled and stored in a maintenance or storage area of the plant. 
(j)  Filter residue and other residues containing dry cleaning solvent shall be stored in tightly covered metal containers outside of the plant in an area not accessible to the public and shall be collected by a scavenger according to the terms of chapter 12 of this Code. 
(k)  Spotting of materials shall be done with no solvent other than water. 
Sec. 15-24. - Safety and testing of equipment requirements. 
(a)  Respirator protective equipment, approved for use in the plant by the fire chief, shall be provided for attendants and maintenance personnel, and shall be kept in good repair and available for immediate use. 
(b)  Utility fire extinguishers shall be provided and maintained properly. The type, capacity, number and location of such extinguishers shall be designated by the fire chief. 
(c)  Safety goggles, rubber gloves and rubber safety aprons shall be provided for service personnel. 
(d)  A device for testing concentration of solvent vapors in the plant atmosphere shall be provided by the licensee. Such device shall be a Kitagawa Precision Gas Detector, Unico Model No. 400 or equivalent, and maintained with no fewer than ten (10) gas detector tubes of the appropriate type. Such equipment shall be kept at the plant and made available for on-site inspection by the building commissioner, health officer and fire chief. 
(e)  A telephone of the nonpay type shall be available at the plant for emergency use. Village fire and police numbers shall be posted conspicuously at the phone. 
(Ord. No. 7-1962, § 5, 3-27-62) 
Sec. 15-25. - Plant and equipment. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to effect an alteration, including additions or elimination of equipment, of a plant without first securing approval of the building commissioner. Operation or use thereof shall not commence until inspection has been made and approval been granted by the building commissioner. 
(Ord. No. 7-1962, § 5, 3-27-62) 
Secs. 15-26-15-31. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - LICENSE 

Sec. 15-32. - Required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to operate a plant in the village who does not possess a license from the village. 
(Ord. No. 7-1962, § 2, 3-27-62) 
Sec. 15-33. - Application. 
    The application for a license required by this division shall be made to the village clerk in writing, signed by the applicant if an individual, and signed by all the partners if a partnership, or by a duly authorized officer thereof if a corporation, verified by oath or affidavit, and shall contain the information required. 
(Ord. No. 7-1962, § 3, 3-27-62) 
Sec. 15-34. - Persons entitled to license. 
    Only persons who comply with the requirements of this article, all applicable state laws and regulations and local ordinances, rules and regulations shall be entitled to receive and retain the license required by this division. 
(Ord. No. 7-1962, § 2, 3-27-62) 
Sec. 15-35. - Fee. 
    The license fee for a plant shall be apply for each calendar year or any portion thereof, which fee shall be fifty dollars ($50.00) for each plant, in addition to twenty dollars ($20.00) per machine. 
(Ord. No. 7-1962, § 2, 3-27-62) 
Cross reference- License fees, § 17-37 et seq. 
Sec. 15-36. - Posting. 
    Each license issued pursuant to the provisions of this division shall be posted in a conspicuous place. 
(Ord. No. 7-1962, § 2, 3-27-62) 
Sec. 15-37. - Suspension; revocation. 
    The license required by this division may be suspended by the village president upon the violation by the holder thereof of any of the terms of this article, or may be revoked after an opportunity for a hearing upon serious or repeated violation. 
(Ord. No. 7-1962, § 2, 3-27-62) 
Chapter 16 - VIDEO, CABLE AND TELECOMMUNICATIONS PROVIDERS 
ARTICLE I. - CABLE/VIDEO SERVICE PROVIDER FEE AND PEG ACCESS SUPPORT FEE[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 24-2007, adopted Nov. 13, 2007, enacted provisions designated as §§ 16-1-1-16-1-6. In order to maintain the alphanumeric style of this Code, said provisions have been redesignated as §§ 16-1-16-17. The original section designations have been retained in the history note following each section. 

Sec. 16-1. - Definitions. 
    As used in this article, the following terms shall have the following meanings: 
    Cable service means that term as defined in 47 U.S.C. § 522(6). 
    Commission means the Illinois Commerce Commission. 
    Gross revenues means all consideration of any kind or nature, including without limitation, cash, credits, property, and in-kind contributions received by the holder for the operation of a cable or video system to provide cable service or video service within the holder's cable service or video service area within the village. 
(1)  Gross revenues shall include the following: 
a.  Recurring charges for cable or video service. 
b.  Event-based charges for cable service or video service, including, but not limited to, pay-per-view and video-on-demand charges. 
c.  Rental of set-top boxes and other cable service or video service equipment. 
d.  Service charges related to the provision of cable service or video service, including, but not limited to, activation, installation and repair charges. 
e.  Administrative charges related to the provision of cable service or video service, including, but not limited to, service order and service termination charges. 
f.  Late payment fees or charges, insufficient funds check charges, and other charges assessed to recover the costs of collecting delinquent payments. 
g.  A pro rata portion of all revenue derived by the holder or its affiliates pursuant to compensation arrangements for advertising or for promotion or exhibition of any products or services derived from the operation of the holder's network to provide cable service or video service within the village. The allocation shall be based on the number of subscribers in the village divided by the total number of subscribers in relation to the relevant regional or national compensation arrangement. 
h.  Compensation received by the holder that is derived from the operation of the holder's network to provide cable service or video service with respect to commissions that are received by the holder as compensation for promotion or exhibition of any products or services on the holder's network, such as a "home shopping" or similar channel, subject to subsection (1)i. 
i.  In the case of a cable service or video service that is bundled or integrated functionally with other services, capabilities, or applications, the portion of the holder's revenue attributable to the other services, capabilities, or applications shall be included in the gross revenue unless the holder can reasonably identify the division or exclusion of the revenue from its books and records that are kept in the regular course of business. 
j.  The service provider fee permitted by 220 ILCS 5/21-801(b). 
(2)  Gross revenues do not include any of the following: 
a.  Revenues not actually received, even if billed, such as bad debt, subject to 220 ILCS 5/21-801(c)(1)(vi). 
b.  Refunds, discounts, or other price adjustments that reduce the amount of gross revenues received by the holder of the state-issued authorization to the extent the refund, rebate, credit, or discount is attributable to cable service or video service. 
c.  Regardless of whether the services are bundled, packaged, or functionally integrated with cable service or video service, any revenues received from services not classified as cable service or video service, including, without limitation, revenue received from telecommunication services, information services, or the provision of directory or internet advertising, including yellow pages, white pages, banner advertisement, and electronic publishing or any other revenues attributed by the holder to noncable service or nonvideo service in accordance with the holder's books and records and records kept in the regular course of business and any applicable laws, rules, regulations, standards or orders. 
d.  The sale of cable services or video services for resale in which the purchaser is required to collect the service provider fee from the purchaser's subscribers to the extent the purchaser certifies in writing that it will resell the service within the village and pay the fee permitted by 220 ILCS 5/21-801(b) with respect to the service. 
e.  Any tax or fee of general applicability imposed upon the subscribers or the transaction by a city, state, federal, or any other governmental entity and collected by the holder of the state-issued authorization and required to be remitted to the taxing entity, including sales and use taxes. 
f.  Security deposits collected from subscribers. 
g.  Amounts paid by subscribers to "home shopping" or similar vendors for merchandise sold through any home shopping channel offered as part of the cable service or video service. 
(3)  Revenue of an affiliate of a holder shall be included in the calculation of gross revenues to the extent the treatment of the revenue as revenue of the affiliate rather than the holder has the effect of evading the payment of the fee permitted by 220 ILCS 5/21-801(b) which would otherwise be paid by the cable service or video service. 
    Holder means a person or entity that has received authorization to offer or provide cable or video service from the commission pursuant to 220 ILCS 5/21-401. 
    PEG means public, education and governmental. 
    PEG access support fee means the amount paid under this article and 220 ILCS 5/21-801(d) by the holder to the village for the service areas within its territorial jurisdiction. 
    Service means the provision of cable service or video service to subscribers and the interaction of subscribers with the person or entity that has received authorization to offer or provide cable or video service from the commission pursuant to 220 ILCS 5/21-401. 
    Service provider fee means the amount paid under this article and 220 ILCS 5/21-801 by the holder to the village for the service areas within its territorial jurisdiction. 
    Video service means video programming and subscriber interaction, if any, that is required for the selection or use of such video programming services, and which is provided through wireline facilities located at least in part in the public right-of-way without regard to delivery technology, including internet protocol technology. This definition does not include any video programming provided by a commercial mobile service provider defined in 47 U.S.C. § 332(d) or any video programming provided solely as part of, and via service that enables users to access content, information, electronic mail, or other services offered over the public internet. 
(Ord. No. 24-2007, § 3(16-1-1), 11-13-07) 
Sec. 16-2. - Cable/video service provider fee imposed. 
(a)  Fee imposed. A fee is hereby imposed on any holder providing cable service or video service in the village. 
(b)  Amount of fee. The amount of the fee imposed hereby shall be five (5) per cent of the holder's gross revenues. 
(c)  Notice to the village. The holder shall notify the village at least ten (10) days prior to the date on which the holder begins to offer cable service or video service in the village. 
(d)  Holder's liability. The holder shall be liable for and pay the service provider fee to the village. The holder's liability for the fee shall commence on the first day of the calendar month following thirty (30) days after receipt of the ordinance adopting this article by the holder. The ordinance adopting this article shall be sent by mail, postage prepaid, to the address listed on the holder's application notice sent pursuant to 220 ILCS 5/21-401(b)(6) to the village. 
(e)  Payment date. The payment of the service provider fee shall be due on a quarterly basis, forty-five (45) days after the close of the calendar quarter. If mailed, the fee is considered paid on the date it is postmarked. Each payment shall include a statement explaining the basis for the calculation of the fee. 
(f)  Exemption. The fee hereby imposed does not apply to existing cable service or video service providers that have an existing franchise agreement with the village in which a fee is paid. 
(g)  Credit for other payments. An incumbent cable operator that elects to terminate an existing agreement pursuant to 220 ILCS 5/21-301(c) with credit for prepaid franchise fees under that agreement, may deduct the amount of such credit from the fees that operator owes under subsection (b). 
(Ord. No. 24-2007, § 3(16-1-2), 11-13-07) 
Sec. 16-3. - PEG access support fee imposed. 
(a)  PEG fee imposed. A PEG access support fee is hereby imposed on any holder providing cable service or video service in the village in addition to the fee imposed pursuant to section 16-2. 
(b)  Amount of fee. The amount of the PEG access support fee imposed hereby shall be one (1) per cent of the holder's gross revenues or, if greater, the percentage of gross revenues that incumbent cable operators pay to the village or its designee for PEG access support in the village. 
(c)  Payment. The holder shall pay the PEG access support fee to the village or to the entity designated by the village to manage PEG access. The holder's liability for the PEG access support fee shall commence on the date set forth in subsection 16-2(d). 
(d)  Payment due. The payment of the PEG access support fee shall be due on a quarterly basis, forty-five (45) days after the close of the calendar quarter. If mailed, the fee is considered paid on the date it is postmarked. Each payment shall include a statement explaining the basis for the calculation of the fee. 
(e)  Credit for other payments. An incumbent cable operator that elects to terminate an existing agreement pursuant to 220 ILCS 5/21-301(c), shall pay, at the time they would have been due, all monetary payments for PEG access that would have been due during the remaining term of the agreement had it not been terminated pursuant to that section. All payments made by an incumbent cable operator pursuant to the previous sentence may be credited against the fees that the operator owes under subsection (b). 
(Ord. No. 24-2007, § 3(16-1-3), 11-13-07) 
Sec. 16-4. - Applicable principles. 
    All determinations and calculations under this article shall be made pursuant to generally accepted accounting principles. 
(Ord. No. 24-2007, § 3(16-1-4), 11-13-07) 
Sec. 16-5. - No impact on other taxes due from holder. 
    Nothing contained in this article shall be construed to exempt a holder from any tax that is or may later be imposed by the village, including any tax that is or may later be required to be paid by or through the holder with respect to cable service or video service. A state-issued authorization shall not affect any requirement of the holder with respect to payment of the village's simplified municipal telecommunications tax or any other tax as it applies to any telephone service provided by the holder. A state-issued authorization shall not affect any requirement of the holder with respect to payment of the local unit of government's 911 or E911 fees,taxes or charges. 
(Ord. No. 24-2007, § 3(16-1-5), 11-13-07) 
Sec. 16-6. - Audits of cable/video service provider. 
(a)  Audit requirement. The village will notify the holder of the requirements it imposes on other cable service or video service providers to submit to an audit of its books and records. The holder shall comply with the same requirements the village imposes on other cable service or video service providers in its jurisdiction to audit the holder's books and records and to recompute any amounts determined to be payable under the requirements of the village. If all local franchises between the village and cable operator terminate, the audit requirements shall be those adopted by the village pursuant to the Local Government Taxpayers' Bill of Rights Act 50 ILCS 45/1 et seq. No acceptance of amounts remitted should be construed as an accord that the amounts are correct. 
(b)  Additional payments. Any additional amount due after an audit shall be paid within thirty (30) days after the village's submission of an invoice for the sum. 
(Ord. No. 24-2007, § 3(16-1-5), 11-13-07) 
Sec. 16-7. - Late fees; payments. 
    All fees due and payments which are past due shall be governed by ordinances adopted by this village pursuant to the Local Government Taxpayers' Bill of Rights Act, 50 ILCS 45/1 et seq. 
(Ord. No. 24-2007, § 3(16-1-6), 11-13-07) 
Secs. 16-8-16-20. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - CABLE AND VIDEO CUSTOMER PROTECTION LAW[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 25-2007, adopted Nov. 13, 2007, enacted provisions designated as §§ 16-2-1-16-2-4. In order to maintain the alphanumeric style of this Code, said provisions have been redesignated as §§ 16-21-16-24. The original section designations have been retained in the history note following each section. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 220 ILCS 5/70. 

Sec. 16-21. - Customer service and privacy protection law. 
(a)  Adoption. The regulations of 220 ILCS 5/70-501 are hereby adopted by reference and made applicable to the cable or video providers offering services within the village's boundaries. 
(b)  Amendments. Any amendment to the Cable and Video Customer Protection Law that becomes effective after the effective date of this article shall be incorporated into this article by reference and shall be applicable to cable or video providers offering services within the municipality's boundaries. However, any amendment that makes its provisions optional for adoption by municipalities shall not be incorporated into this article by reference without formal action by the corporate authorities of the village. 
(Ord. No. 25-2007, § 2(16-2-1), 11-13-07) 
Sec. 16-22. - Enforcement. 
    The village does hereby, pursuant to law, declare its intent to enforce all of the customer service and privacy protection standards of the Cable and Video Customer Protection Law with respect to complaints received from residents within the village. 
(Ord. No. 25-2007, § 2(16-2-2), 11-13-07) 
Sec. 16-23. - Penalties. 
(a)  Pursuant to 220 ILCS 5/70-501(r)(1), the village does hereby provide for a schedule of penalties for any material breach of the Cable and Video Customer Protection Law by cable or video providers, which penalties shall be in addition to the penalties provided in the law. The monetary penalties shall apply on a competitively neutral basis and shall not exceed seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for each day of the material breach, and shall not exceed twenty-five thousand dollars ($25,000.00) for each occurrence of a material breach per customer. 
(b)  For purposes of this article, material breach means any substantial failure of a cable or video provider to comply with service quality and other standards specified in any provision of the Cable and Video Customer Protection Law. 
(c)  The village shall give the cable or video provider written notice of any alleged material breaches of the Cable and Video Customer Protection Law and allow such provider at least thirty (30) days from the receipt of the notice to remedy the specified material breach. 
(d)  For the purposes of assessing penalties, a material breach of the Cable and Video Customer Protection Law shall be deemed to occur for each day that a material breach has not been remedied by the cable or video service provider after notice as provided in subsection (c) hereof. 
(Ord. No. 25-2007, § 2(§ 16-2-3), 11-13-07) 
Sec. 16-24. - Customer credits. 
    The village hereby adopts the schedule of customer credits for violations set forth in 220 ILCS 5/70-501(s). Those credits shall be applied on the statement issued to the customer for the next billing cycle following the violation or following the discovery of the violation. The cable or video provider is responsible for providing the credits and the customer is under no obligation to request the credit. 
(Ord. No. 25-2007, § 2(§ 16-2-4), 11-13-07)

ARTICLE II. - BUSINESS OPERATIONS PERMITS[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 13-1995, § 1, adopted Feb. 28, 1995, retitled Art. II from "Licenses" to "Business Operations Permits." 
Cross reference- Licenses for raffles, § 17-85 et seq. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 17-14. - Purpose, scope of article. 
    The purpose of this article is to protect and safeguard the health, safety and welfare of the citizens of the village; to increase public confidence in legitimate commerce; to further insure adequate and periodic provision of essential governmental inspection services; and to provide for an accurate record of regulated commercial activities within the village. All commercial activities under the jurisdiction of this article shall in all respects be in full compliance with the provisions herein contained and all other applicable ordinances and regulations of the village. 
(Ord. No. 4-1968, § I, 4-23-68) 
Sec. 17-15. - Definitions. 
    The following words and terms, wherever they occur in this article, shall be construed as defined in this section: 
    Accessory activity: An activity or use which is customarily incidental and/or subordinate to a principal activity; provided, however, that such an activity, if conducted separately and independently of the principal activity would be subject to licensing under the provisions of this article, shall be included in the ownership of the establishment. 
    Business: All kinds of vocations, occupations, professions, enterprises, establishments and all other kinds of activities and matters, together with all devices, machines, vehicles and appurtenances used therein, any of which are conducted for private profit or benefit, either directly or indirectly, or not-for-profit, on any premises in the village, or anywhere else within its jurisdiction. 
    Business operations permit: A permit issued following inspection, payment of the appropriate fees and verification that the business or other operation complies with all village regulations and ordinances, public safety, zoning and code compliance. 
    Insignia or its singular number insigne: Any tag, plate, badge, emblem, sticker or any other kind of device which may be required for any use in connection with any license. 
    Owner: Any individual, firm, association, partnership, corporation, trust or other legal entity having sufficient proprietary interest in a commercial activity or establishment to maintain and manage its operation. 
    Person: Includes individual natural persons, partnerships, joint adventures, societies, associations, clubs, trustees, trusts or corporations, or any officer, agent, employee, factor or any other kind of personal representative of any thereof, in any capacity, acting either for himself or for any other person under either personal appointment or pursuant to law. 
    Personal items: Those items which were originally acquired for the use of the owner or his family. 
    Premises: Includes all lands, structures and places, the equipment and appurtenances connected or used therewith in any business, and also any personal property which is either affixed to or is otherwise used in connection with any such business conducted on such premises. 
    Principal activity: The activity or use which utilizes the major portion of gross floor and/or land area. 
(Ord. No. 4-1968, § II, 4-23-68; Ord. No. 13-1995, § 1, 2-28-95) 
Cross reference- Rules of construction and definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 17-16. - Required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person, either directly or indirectly, to conduct any business or nonprofit enterprise, or to use in connection therewith any vehicle, premises, machine or device, in whole or in part, for which a business operation permit is required by any law or ordinance of the village, without a permit therefor first being procured and kept in effect at all times as required by this chapter or other law or ordinance of the village. 
(Ord. No. 4-1968, § III, 4-23-68; Ord. No. 13-1995, § 1, 2-28-95) 
Sec. 17-17. - Article to apply to special sales. 
    This article shall apply to all business in the nature of special sales for which a business operation permit is required by any law or ordinance of the village, and it shall be unlawful for any person, either directly or indirectly, to conduct any such sales except in conformity with the provisions of this article. 
(Ord. No. 4-1968, § III, 4-23-68; Ord. No. 13-1995, § 1, 2-28-95) 
Sec. 17-18. - One act to constitute doing business. 
    For the purposes of this article, any person shall be deemed to be in business or engaging in a nonprofit enterprise, and thus subject to the requirements of sections 17-16 and 17-17, when he does any of the following: 
(1)  Sells any goods or services except personal items; 
(2)  Solicits business or offers goods or services for sale or hire; 
(3)  Acquires or uses any vehicle or any premises in the village for business purposes; 
(4)  Holds himself forth as being engaged in a business or an occupation; 
(5)  Solicits patronage, actively or passively, for a business or occupation; 
(6)  Performs or attempts to perform any part of a business or occupation in the village. 
(Ord. No. 4-1968, § III, 4-23-68) 
Sec. 17-19. - Agents responsible for obtaining business operation permit. 
    The agents or other representatives of nonresidents who are doing business in this village shall be personally responsible for the compliance of their principals and of the businesses they represent with this article. 
(Ord. No. 4-1968, § III, 4-23-68; Ord. No. 13-1995, § 1, 2-28-95) 
Sec. 17-20. - Separate business operation permit required for branch establishments. 
    A business operation permit shall be obtained in the manner prescribed in this chapter for each branch establishment or location of any business engaged in, as if each such branch establishment or location were a separate business. 
(Ord. No. 4-1968, § III, 4-23-68; Ord. No. 13-1995, § 1, 2-28-95) 
Sec. 17-21. - Certain rental real properties considered separate places of business. 
    Each rental real property shall be deemed a branch establishment or separate place of business for the purposes of this article when there is a representative of the owner or the owner's agent on the premises who is authorized to transact business for such owner or owner's agent or there is a regular employee of the owner or of the owner's agent working on the premises. 
(Ord. No. 4-1968, § III, 4-23-68) 
Sec. 17-22. - Village manager to administer article. 
    The administration of the provisions set forth in this article shall fall under the direct supervision of the village manager. 
(Ord. No. 4-1968, § IV, 4-23-68; Ord. No. 22-1992, § 2, 10-27-92). 
Sec. 17-23. - Applications; contents. 
    Each applicant for a business operation permit required by this article or other ordinances of the village shall properly execute she application form provided to him by the village manager, which application shall contain the following information: 
(1)  Name, address and telephone number of business; 
(2)  Name(s) of owner(s) or corporate officers; 
(3)  Name, address, telephone number and title of sole owner, partners, manager or agent of establishment within the village; 
(4)  Description of principal activity; 
(5)  Usable area and/or patron capacity; 
(6)  Description of accessory activity and area used for this purpose; 
(7)  Description of all vehicles used in the business; 
(8)  Certification of accuracy of information; 
(9)  Signature and title of owner, partner or agent of business; 
(10)  Issuing information such as business operation permit number, fee paid and signature of recipient of fee; 
(11)  Approval of various departments as provided in section 17-24. 
(Ord. No. 4-1968, § IV, 4-23-68; Ord. No. 22-1992, § 2, 10-27-92; Ord. No. 13-1995, § 1, 2-28-95) 
Sec. 17-24. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 13-1995, § 1, adopted Feb. 28, 1995, repealed former section 17-24 in its entirety which pertained to the departmental distribution of applications for business operation permits and derived from Ord. No. 4-1968, § IV, adopted April 23, 1968, and Ord. No. 22-1992, § 2, adopted Oct. 27, 1992. 
Sec. 17-25. - Issuance. 
(a)  The village manager, upon receipt of written notice of satisfactory inspections from the departments shall issue a business operations permit certificate and decal to the applicant. 
(b)  The village manager, upon receipt of written notices of satisfactory inspections from the officials and departments specified in section 17-24 shall issue a license certificate and decal to the applicant. 
(c)  Permanent facade signage required. No business occupancy permit shall be issued for any business, commercial, retail or service business (other than professional offices involving directory signage and home occupations) until such time as permanent approved facade signage has been affixed to the premises for which the permit is sought. All such signage shall conform to any and all applicable provisions of the Village Code. 
(Ord. No. 4-1968, § IV, 4-23-68; Ord. No. 22-1992, § 2, 10-27-92; Ord. No. 13-1995, § 1, 2-28-95; Ord. No. 22-2004, § 1, 9-28-04) 
Sec. 17-26. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 13-1995, § 1, adopted Feb. 28, 1995, repealed former § 17-26 in its entirety which pertained to the revocation of temporary licenses and derived from Ord. No. 4-1968, § IV, adopted April 23, 1968, and Ord. No. 22-1992, § 2, adopted Oct. 27, 1992. 
Sec. 17-27. - Transfer. 
    In the event a business is sold or transferred to another ownership, an unexpired business operations permit may be transferred to the new ownership; however, a new application must be executed and properly processed. The various inspections may be waived by the village manager provided that no significant change has occurred since the last business operations permit was issued. The fee for such a business operation permit shall be ten dollars ($10.00). 
(Ord. No. 4-1968, § IV, 4-23-68; Ord. No. 22-1992, § 2, 10-27-92; Ord. No. 13-1995, § 1, 2-28-95) 
Sec. 17-28. - Term; expiration. 
    No business operation permit required by this article or other ordinances of the village shall be granted for a period longer than one (1) year. Every business operation permit shall expire on the last day of April following the date of its issue, unless otherwise expressly provided in this Code. 
(Ord. No. 4-1968, § VIII, 4-23-68; Ord. No. 13-1995, § 1, 2-28-95) 
Sec. 17-29. - Suspensions and revocation after issuance of gambling stamp. 
    Any business operation permit issued pursuant to this chapter shall be suspended automatically upon the issuance of a federal gambling stamp for the premises for which the business operation permit has been issued. Such suspension shall remain in effect until written notice has been given by the village to the business operation permittee of the violation and the expiration of ten (10) days, whereupon, if the gambling stamp has not been returned or canceled, the business operation permit shall be revoked. 
(Ord. No. 9-1962, § II, 3-27-62; Ord. No. 13-1995, § 1, 2-28-95) 
Sec. 17-30. - Appeals from decisions of village manager. 
(a)  Rights: Any person aggrieved by any decision of the village manager in relation to his administration of this article shall have the right to appeal to the village board of trustees by filing a written appeal with the village president within ten (10) days following the effective date of the action or decision complained of. 
(b)  Contents of appeal: Such appeal shall set out a copy of the order or decision appealed from and shall include a statement of the facts relied upon to avoid such order. 
(c)  Hearing: The village president shall fix a time and place for hearing the appeal and shall personally serve a written notice upon the appellant informing him thereof. The village president shall also give such notice to the village clerk and such other officer as shall be entitled to appear and defend such order. 
(d)  Effect of decision: The findings of the village board of trustees shall be final and conclusive and shall be personally served upon the appellant. 
(Ord. No. 4-1968, § IX, 4-23-68; Ord. No. 22-1992, § 2, 10-27-92) 
Secs. 17-31-17-36. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - FEES[3] 

Footnotes:

Cross reference- License fees for retail sales of alcoholic beverages, § 4-33; certificate of compliance fee, § 6-6-6; fee for registration of building contractors, § 6-22; scavenger license fee, § 12.25; license fee for nursing home, sheltered care home or home for the aged, § 13-82; license fee for dry cleaning plant, § 15-35; license fee for raffles, § 17-90; license fee for coin-operated amusement devices, § 17-90. 

Sec. 17-37. - Generally. 
    Business operation permit fees for the various business operation permits required by the village shall be in the amounts established in this division or other ordinances of the village. 
(Ord. No. 4-1968, § V, 4-23-68; Ord. No. 13-1995, § 1, 2-28-95) 
Sec. 17-38. - Inspections services covered by fees. 
    The annual business operation permit fee to be charged in accordance with the provisions of this division shall cover and include all sign, awning, police, building and fire hazard inspection services to be rendered by the village as required during the annual fiscal year. 
(Ord. No. 4-1968, § V, 4-23-68; Ord. No. 13-1995, § 1, 2-28-95) 
Sec. 17-39. - Proration. 
    For any annual business operation permit provided by this article and issued prior to November first in any calendar year, the full prescribed annual fee shall be paid; for any such business operation permit issued on or after November first in any license year and expiring on the following April thirtieth, one-half the prescribed annual fee shall be paid. 
(Ord. No. 4-1968, § V, 4-23-68; Ord. No. 13-1995, § 1, 2-28-95) 
Sec. 17-40. - Rebates or refunds. 
    No rebate or refund of any license fee shall be made because of discontinuance, failure or other occupational interruption of any commercial establishment. 
(Ord. No. 4-1968, § V, 4-23-68) 
Sec. 17-41. - Multiple business activities. 
    All commercial establishments under the jurisdiction of this article shall pay an annual business operation permit fee for a principal activity which is included in one of the classifications set forth in this article, plus fifty (50) per cent of the annual license fee of any remaining classification applicable to any accessory activity of such establishments. 
(Ord. No. 4-1968, § V, 4-23-68; Ord. No. 13-1995, § 1, 2-28-95) 
Sec. 17-42. - Schedule-Flat fee. 
    The annual business operation permit fee for the following specified businesses shall be as follows: 
Carnivals or circuses, per day ..... $150.00 
Child daycare homes ..... 150.00 
Cleaning or laundry vehicles soliciting business in the village: 
For one (1) vehicle ..... 50.00 
For each additional vehicle ..... 25.00 
Food dispenser vehicles: 
For one (1) vehicle ..... 50.00 
For each additional vehicle ..... 25.00 
Handbills, samples and advertisements, distribution ..... 150.00 
(Except that the distribution of political, civic or religious items (not for sale) and advertising material for city businesses are hereby exempted.) 
Parking lots (for which fees are charged): 
Up to 20 spaces ..... 75.00 
For each additional space ..... 4.00 
Recreation centers, including golf courses, miniature golf courses and driving ranges ..... 300.00 
Solicitation for magazines, books and periodicals, per day, per person ..... 25.00 
Taxicabs (including office area), for each vehicle ..... 75.00 
Towing trucks, each ..... 40.00 
Vending machines and jukeboxes, each (for public use) ..... 75.00 
Penalty for late renewal (after May 1) ..... 50% of 
base fee 
(Ord. No. 4-1968, § V, 4-23-68; Ord. No. 4-1980, § 1, 4-22-80; Ord. No. 8-1982, § 1, 5-11-82; Ord. No. 15-1982, § 6, 6-22-82; Ord. No. 15-1989, § 1, 4-25-89; Ord. No. 13-1995, § 1, 2-28-95; Ord. No. 11-1998, § 2, 6-9-98) 
Sec. 17-43. - Same-Based on area. 
(a)  The business operations permit fee for all business operations not listed in section 17-42 will be based on square footage. 
(b)  In computing square footage for the purposes of this section, the entire floor area and any adjacent areas used as an integral part of the necessary operation of the business, but not necessarily under one (1) roof, shall be included. All measured area expressed in square feet shall be to the nearest integral square foot. Open areas shall be figured at fifty (50) per cent of their square foot area. 
(c)  The square footage permit fee shall be charged as follows: 
Less than 500 square feet ..... $25.00 
500 to 999 square feet ..... 50.00 
1,000 to 1,499 square feet ..... 100.00 
1,500 to 1,999 square feet ..... 125.00 
2,000 to 2,999 square feet ..... 150.00 
3,000 to 3,999 square feet ..... 175.00 
4,000 or more square feet ..... 200.00 
Plus, for each 1,000 square feet up to a maximum fee of $750.00 ..... 25.00 
Penalty for late renewal (after May 1) ..... 50% of 
base fee 
(Ord. No. 4-1968, § V, 4-23-68; Ord. No. 4-1980, § 2, 4-22-80; Ord. No. 15-1989, § 2, 4-25-89; Ord. No. 13-1995, § 1, 2-28-95; Ord. No. 11-1998, § 3, 6-9-98) 
Sec. 17-44. - Same-Food service establishments. 
(a)  For village will invoice the food service operator for the fee paid to the health inspection service employed by the village. The invoice will be for the cost borne by the village only. 
(Ord. No. 4-1968, § V, 4-23-86; Ord. No. 4-1980, § 3, 4-22-80; Ord. No. 15-1989, § 3, 4-25-89; Ord. No. 13-1995, § 1, 2-28-95) 
Sec. 17-45. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 13-1995, § 1, adopted Feb. 28, 1995, repealed former section 17-45 in its entirety which pertained to annual license fees for industrial establishments and derived from Ord. No. 4-1968, § V, 4-23-68; Ord. No. 4-1980, § 4, 4-22-80; Ord. No. 15-1989, § 4, 4-25-89. 
Sec. 17-46. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 13-1995, § 1, adopted Feb. 28, 1995, repealed former section 17-46 in its entirety which pertained to license fees for professional offices and derived from Ord. No. 4-1968, § V, 4-23-68; Ord. No. 4-1980, § 5, 4-22-80; Ord. No. 15-1989, § 5, 4-25-89. 
Sec. 17-47. - Extended operation hours. 
    The annual business operation permit fee for any business within the village operating in excess of eighteen (18) hours per day shall be increased fifty (50) per cent. 
(Ord. No. 15-1989, § 5, 4-25-89; Ord. No. 13-1995, § 1, 2-28-95) 
Secs. 17-48-17-52. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - DUTIES OF BUSINESS OPERATION PERMITTEES 

Sec. 17-53. - Compliance with division required. 
    Every business operation permittee under article shall comply with the provisions of this division. 
(Ord. No. 4-1968, § VII, 4-23-68; Ord. No. 13-1995, § 1, 2-28-95) 
Sec. 17-54. - Permit inspections. 
    Each business operation permittee under this article shall permit all reasonable inspections and investigations of his business and business property which are necessary to secure compliance with any ordinance provision or to detect violation thereof; and it shall be the duty of the business operation permittee or the person in charge of the premises to be inspected to admit thereto any official employee of the village who is authorized or directed to make such inspection at any reasonable time that admission is requested therefor. 
(Ord. No. 4-1968, § VII, 4-23-68; Ord. No. 13-1995, § 1, 2-28-95) 
Sec. 17-55. - Compliance with governing law. 
    Each business operation permittee under this article shall ascertain and at all times comply with all laws and regulations applicable to such licensed business; if any person so licensed shall violate any of the provisions of this Code or any other law and regulation, he shall be liable to be proceeded against for any fine or penalty imposed thereby, and his business operation permit may be revoked. 
(Ord. No. 4-1968, § VII, 4-23-68; Ord. No. 13-1995, § 1, 2-28-95) 
Sec. 17-56. - Proper operation. 
    Each business operation permittee under this article shall avoid all forbidden, improper or unnecessary practices or conditions which do or may affect the public health, morals or welfare. 
(Ord. No. 4-1968, § VII, 4-23-68; Ord. No. 13-1995, § 1, 2-28-95) 
Sec. 17-57. - Cease business upon expiration, revocation or suspension of business operation permit. 
    Each business operation permittee under this article shall refrain from operating any such licensed business on the premises after expiration of his license and during the period his business operation permit is revoked or suspended. 
(Ord. No. 4-1968, § VII, 4-23-68; Ord. No. 13-1995, § 1, 2-28-95) 
Sec. 17-58. - Display of business operation permit, insignia. 
    Every business operation permittee under this article shall display his business operation permit or insignia as follows: 
(a)  Premises: 
(1)  Post and maintain such business operation permit upon the licensed premises in a place where it may be seen at all times; 
(2)  Affix any insignia delivered for use in connection with such business premises on the inside glass part of the window of such establishment, facing the public way or on the inside glass part of the door opening on the public way. Such insignia shall be placed and maintained so as to be plainly visible from the public way. 
(b)  Vehicles: Affix any insignia delivered for use in connection with, a licensed motor vehicle on the inside of the windshield thereof or as may be prescribed otherwise by law. In addition, a business operation permittee performing services as a contractor shall clearly display its name on the exterior of each motor vehicle that said business operation permittee operates in the village. 
(c)  Persons: Carry such business operation permit on his person when he has no licensed business premises. 
(d)  Machines: Affix any insignia delivered for use in connection therewith upon the outside of any coin, vending or other business machine or device so that it may be seen at all times. 
(e)  Inoperative business operation permit, special permits and insignia: Not allow any business operation permit, special permit or insignia to remain posted, or be displayed or used after the period for which it was issued has expired, or when it has been suspended or revoked, or for any other reason becomes ineffective. The business operation permittee shall promptly return such inoperative business operation permit, special permit or insignia to the village clerk. 
(f)  Unlawful possession: Not loan, sell, give or assign to any other person, or allow any other person to use or display, or to destroy, damage or remove, or to have in his possession any business operation permit or insignia which has been issued to said business operation permittee. 
(Ord. No. 4-1968, § VII, 4-23-68; Ord. No. 13-1995, § 1, 2-28-95; Ord. No. 11-2011, § 3, 8-16-11) 
Sec. 17-59. - Hours of operation. 
(a)  No business shall be open for business between the hours of 12:00 a.m. and 6:00 a.m. seven (7) days a week, unless such business receives an extended hours permit as provided for in subsection (b). 
(b)  A business seeking to be open during all or a portion of the hours between 12:00 a.m. and 6:00 a.m., shall file an application for extended hours on a form provided by the village manager. The application shall be reviewed by the police chief and manager. The village board shall grant the application if the village board determines that the financial institution has an adequate on-site security system in place which will minimize the risk of criminal activity occurring on the premises during the extended hours. 
(Ord. No. 18-2007, § 2, 11-13-07) 
Secs. 17-60-17-64. - Reserved.
