(4)  The number of police escort vehicles shall be determined by the police department for dimension categories 3C through 5C and shall be based on the route and safety consideration. 
(Ord. No. 01-2011, § 2, 3-8-11) 
Sec. 19-161. - Suspension and reinstatement. 
(a)  Suspension of a current permit shall be for the time determined appropriate by the village police department. Reinstatement may be made upon conditions determined by the department and payment of outstanding fees. 
(b)  In addition to any other fees and costs pursuant to subsection (a) above, there shall be a reinstatement fee of fifty dollars ($50.00). 
(c)  The chief of police or his/her designee shall administer this section and shall have the authority to grant, deny, suspend or reinstate permits. Any applicant or permittee denied a permit or who has had a permit suspended, upon request, shall have the right to appeal the action of the chief of police or his/her designee. 
(Ord. No. 01-2011, § 2, 3-8-11) 
Sec. 19-162. - Violation and enforcement. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person issued a permit under section 19-157, or any employee or agent of such person, to violate any of the terms or conditions of the permit. Each and every violation of the terms or conditions of the permit shall constitute a separate and distinct offense. The owner and the operator of the vehicle may be held jointly and severally liable for any fines or other penalties imposed under this section. 
(b)  (1)  Except as specifically allowed by statute or other ordinance, no person shall operate on any street or highway under the jurisdiction of the village, any vehicle whose gross weight exceeds the limits described in Section 15-111 of the Illinois Vehicle Code, 625 ILCS 5/15-111. The weight limitations and formulae contained in Section 15-111 of the Illinois Vehicle Code, and as amended from time to time, are hereby incorporated by reference for the purposes of calculating permissible weights under this section. Any vehicle which exceeds the weight and size limitations set out in this section is hereby declared to be a public nuisance. 
(2)  Any person who refuses or fails to stop and submit his/her vehicle and load after being directed to do so by a police officer or who causes the removal of any portion of the load prior to weighing, shall be fined not less than five hundred dollars ($500.00) and not more than two thousand dollars ($2,000.00). Either the owner or driver of such vehicle may be prosecuted for such violation. 
(3)  Any person who violates the weight limitations imposed by subsection (b)(1) of this section shall be subject to a fine equal to the amount set out in Section 15-113(a) of the Illinois Vehicle Code, and as amended from time to time. All fines shall be payable to the Village of Hazel Crest. Section 15-113(a) of the Illinois Vehicle Code, and as amended from time to time, is hereby incorporated by reference for the purposes of calculating the permissible fines payable to the village. Each and every violation of this section shall constitute a separate and distinct offense. Either the owner or driver of such vehicle may be prosecuted for such violation. 
(4)  Any person who violates subsection (d) of section 3-401 of the Illinois Vehicle Code, 625 ILCS 5/3-401(d), and as amended from time to time, which provides for a vehicle of the second division moved or operated with the state to pay appropriate registration fees and flat weight tax, shall be subject to a fine equal to the amount set out in Section 15-113(a) of the Illinois Vehicle Code, and as amended from time to time. Either the owner or driver of such vehicle may be prosecuted for such violation. 
(c)  (1)  It shall be unlawful for any person to operate a vehicle not in conformity with the limitations for width of vehicles in Section 15-102, the limitations for height of vehicles in Section 15-103, and the limitation for length of vehicles in Section 15-107 of the Illinois Vehicle Code, and as amended from time to time, on any village street or highway without a permit issued for that vehicle by the village police department. Each and every violation of this section shall constitute a separate and distinct offense. Either the owner or driver of such vehicle may be prosecuted for such violation. 
(2)  Any person, firm or corporation operating a vehicle in violation of subsection (c)(1) of this section shall be prosecuted and fined, for the first or second conviction in any one-year period, in an amount equal to not less than fifty dollars ($50.00) and not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00). The fine for a third and subsequent conviction by the same person, firm or corporation within a one-year period, shall be in an amount equal to not less than five hundred dollars ($500.00) and not more than one thousand dollars ($1,000.00). 
(d)  In addition to any fine imposed, any person operating an overweight and/or oversized vehicle, shall assume total liability and shall pay all the costs incurred by the village to restore to a condition satisfactory to the village, any pavement, bridge, culvert, tunnel, sewer, pipe conduit or other facility or appurtenance located within the village street or highway right-of-way that is damaged by reason of the transportation of such vehicle. The owner and the operator of the vehicle may be held jointly and severally liable for any costs incurred under this subsection. 
(e)  If any person, firm or corporation violates section 19-157 and/or section 19-162 in any manner, three (3) times in one (1) 12-month period of time, the village crest police department may refuse to issue a permit to that person, firm or corporation for one (1) year following the date of the third violation. 
(f)  A person issued a notice of citation for a violation of any weight limitation, size limitation, or other limitation imposed by section 19-162, or any term or condition of a permit issued under section 19-157, shall, upon issuance of the notice of citation, deposit with the village crest police department, a cash bond in an amount equal to the minimum fine established for such violation, plus administrative costs in the amount of twenty-five dollars ($25.00). The defendant may, in lieu of cash bail, deposit a money order issued by a money transfer service company which has been approved by the village. The money order shall be payable to the Village of Hazel Crest. 
(g)  The owner and/or operator of the vehicle shall indemnify and hold the village harmless from all suits, claims, damages, proceedings, costs, judgments or settlements, including attorney's fees, of any kind for injury to persons or damage to public or private property caused, in whole or in part, by the operation of the vehicle in violation of any weight limitation, size limitation, or other limitation imposed by section 19-162, or any term or condition of a permit issued under section 19-157. 
(h)  Any notice or citation for a violation of any weight limitation, size limitation, or other limitation imposed by sections 19-157 and 19-162, shall specify the date, time, and location of a hearing before the administrative adjudication hearing officer pursuant to the Village Code. 
(i)  If at the hearing, the administrative hearing officer determines that the owner or operator violated any weight limitation, size limitation, or other limitation imposed by sections 19-157 and 19-162, the administrative hearing officer shall enter an order finding the owner and/or operator liable to the village for the amount of the administrative penalty prescribed for such violation, plus administrative costs in the amount of twenty-five dollars ($25.00). The proceeds of any bond or money order posted pursuant to subsection 19-162(f) shall first be used to satisfy in full or in part said penalty. 
(j)  If, at the hearing, the administrative hearing officer determines that the owner or operator did not violate any weight limitation, size limitation, or other limitation imposed by section 19-162, any term or condition of a permit issued under section 19-157, the administrative hearing officer shall enter an order finding the owner and/or operator not liable to the village and order a return of the proceeds of the bond or money order posted pursuant to subsection 19-162(f). 
(k)  If the owner or operator fails to appear, the administrative hearing officer may enter a default order against the respondent, and may further order the forfeiture of the bond or money order posted pursuant to subsection 19-162(f) to the village. 
(l)  Any fine or other sanction or costs imposed, or any part thereof, remaining unpaid after the expiration of the time limit prescribed for judicial review under the Administrative Review Law is a debt due and owed to the village and, as such, may be collected in accordance with applicable law. 
(m)  Service of the notice or citation on the operator of the vehicle shall constitute service of the notice of or citation for the violation on the owner of the vehicle. 
(n)  The owner and operator of the vehicle shall be jointly and severally liable for any claims, losses, expenses or damages incurred by the village for any injury to persons or damage to public or private property caused, in whole or in part, by the operation of the vehicle in violation of any weight limitation, size limitation, or other limitation imposed by section 19-162, or any violation of a term or condition of a permit issued under section 19-157. 
(o)  In addition to any other remedies, any permittee, its officers, agents or employees, found guilty of moving an oversized vehicle or overweight vehicle or load on village streets on a permit altered for purposes of deception or without a valid permit as required under section 19-157, shall be subject to a five hundred dollar ($500.00) fine for the first day during which a move was made and a seven hundred fifty dollar ($750.00) fine for each additional day during which as move was made. 
(Ord. No. 01-2011, § 2, 3-8-11) 
Sec. 19-163. - Construction equipment. 
(a)  Construction equipment that is capable of being self propelled or any construction equipment capable of being towed shall display on the side of the equipment the name of the company for which it is employed. The name shall be in letters at least two inches (2") tall and one-half inch (1/2") wide. 
(b)  Every second division vehicle operating commercially that is used by a construction contractor or subcontractor shall display on the side of the vehicle or its trailer the name of the company for which it is employed. The name shall be in letters at least two inches (2") tall and one-half inch (1/2") wide. 
(c)  This section does not apply to any motor vehicle upon which is affixed the insignia required under Section 18-4701 of the Illinois Commercial Transportation Law. 
(d)  Any person convicted of violating subsection 19-163(a) shall be guilty of a petty offense and subject to a fine not to exceed one hundred dollars ($100.00). Any person convicted of violating subsection 19-163(b) shall be guilty of a petty offense and subject to a fine not less than five hundred dollars ($500.00). 
(Ord. No. 01-2011, § 2, 3-8-11) 
Sec. 19-164. - Authority of the administrative adjudication hearing officer. 
    Any violations of the Illinois Motor Vehicle Code relating to overweight trucks, specifically violations of Chapter 15, 625 ILCS 5/15-100 et seq., or sections 19-157, 19-162 and 19-164 of chapter 19, article V of the Village Code, may be decided by the administrative adjudication hearing officer as set forth in the Village Code. 
(Ord. No. 01-2011, § 2, 3-8-11) 
Sec. 19-165. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - VEHICLE LICENSES[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
State Law reference- Authority to license and tax motor vehicles of residents and limitations thereon, 625 ILCS 5/8-11-4. 

Sec. 19-166. - Required; citation. 
(a)  Every owner of a motor vehicle who resides within the village and every firm or corporation having vehicles operating out of a permanent office or place of businesses within the village, shall pay to the village each year a tax or license fee for the use of each motor vehicle used on any public street or highway or alley in the village. The term "motor vehicle" as used in this article shall be construed to include automobiles and all other vehicles propelled otherwise than by muscular power. 
(b)  A motor vehicle which displays state registration reflecting an address within the village shall constitute prima facie evidence that the vehicle is being operated on the streets of the village and shall be construed to be in violation of this article, and therefore that motor vehicle can receive a citation anywhere within the village regardless of whether on public or private property. 
(Code 1956, § 14.91; Ord. No. 18-1958, § 1, 9-23-58; Ord. No. 14-1975, 4-22-75; Ord. No. 8-1985, 3-12-85) 
Sec. 19-167. - Grace period. 
    Any person who establishes residence in the village and who operates a motor vehicle as provided in this article, or any person who takes possession of a motor vehicle, shall be allowed a period of thirty (30) days from and after such residence is established, or vehicle is acquired, in which to comply with this article. Any person who purchases his/her sticker after the thirty-day grace period shall pay an additional penalty fee of ten dollars ($10.00). 
(Code 1956, § 14.91; Ord. No. 18-1958, § 1, 9-23-58; Ord. No. 24-1986, § 1, 10-28-86; Ord. No. 10-1999, § 2, 5-25-99) 
Sec. 19-168. - Exemption for governmental vehicles. 
    All vehicles owned and operated upon the public ways of the village by the United States government, or any agency thereof, or by the state, or any department thereof, or any political subdivision, public or municipal corporation of the state or any department or agency of such corporation, and all vehicles exempt from payment of the registry fee under section 8a of the Motor Vehicle Law of the State of Illinois shall be exempt from the village vehicle tax. 
(Ord. No. 8-1965, 6-8-65) 
Sec. 19-169. - Fees. 
(a)  License fees. The schedule of fees for licenses required by this article shall be paid annually by January 31st in the following amounts: 
Passenger automobiles and RV vehicles ..... $30.00 
Trucks (alphabetical license plate classifications refer to trucks of the second division): 
All first division trucks and second division trucks with Class "B" plates ..... $40.00 
Class D plates ..... 50.00 
Class F plates ..... 60.00 
Class H plates and above ..... 70.00 
Motorcycles ..... 25.00 
(b)  Senior citizens and disabled veterans. 
(1)  Persons ages sixty-five (65) or over and disabled veterans who own a single vehicle registered with the State of Illinois in said person's name shall be entitled to one (1) vehicle license sticker at the rate of five dollars ($5.00). 
(2)  Persons age sixty-five (65) or over and disabled veterans who own more than one (1) vehicle registered with the State of Illinois in said person's name shall be entitled to a single vehicle license sticker at the rate of five dollars ($5.00) for the vehicle with the lowest above-listed fee. Each additional vehicle license sticker shall be purchased in accordance with the schedule of fees listed in subsection (a). 
(3)  No person, or household, shall be entitled to purchase more than one (1) vehicle license sticker annually at the rate of five dollars ($5.00). For the purposes of this section "household" shall be defined as that group of collective individuals related by blood, marriage or adoption and living within the same residence. 
(c)  Penalty. Any person or entity who purchases a vehicle license sticker after January 31 of the license year but before May 1 of the license year shall pay an additional penalty fee of ten dollars ($10.00). Any person or entity who purchases a village vehicle license sticker on or after March 1 of each year shall pay an additional penalty fee of forty-five dollars ($45.00). 
(d)  Transfers. A fee of one dollar ($1.00) shall be charged for transferring a vehicle license from a currently registered vehicle to a newly acquired vehicle. 
(Code 1956, § 14.0; Ord. No. 18-1958, § 1, 9-23-58; Ord. No. 36-1975, § 1, 9-23-75; Ord. No. 30-1978, § 1, 11-14-78; Ord. No. 16-1979, § 1, 3-27-79; Ord. No. 10-1984, § 1, 4-10-84; Ord. No. 24-1986, § 1, 10-28-86; Ord. No. 4-1987, § 1, 3-10-87; Ord. No. 19-1995, § 1, 6-13-95; Ord. No. 10-1999, § 1, 5-25-99; Ord. No. 7-2003, § 4-22-03; Ord. No. 12-2010, § 1, 7-27-10) 
Sec. 19-170. - Proration of license fee. 
    The fee for licenses required by this article issued between July first through December thirty-first of each year shall be one-half the annual fee. 
(Code 1956, § 14.89; Ord. No. 18-1958, § 1, 9-23-58; Ord. No. 3-1964, § I, 1-28-64) 
Sec. 19-171. - Tag or sticker. 
(a)  A license tag or sticker shall be issued by the village and said sticker shall be displayed on the lower right-hand side of the windshield of the motor vehicle so licensed, other than motorcycles, motorbikes and motorscooters. A vehicle tag issued for a motorcycle, motorbike or motorscooter shall be securely fastened and conspicuously displayed upon such vehicles. Such tags or stickers shall be numbered serially and a record kept on file by the village clerk. 
(b)  Tags or stickers from prior years or other communities shall be removed from the windshield at the time the new sticker is displayed. 
(Code 1956, § 14.92; Ord. No. 14-1975, 4-22-75) 
Sec. 19-172. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- In order to avoid duplication of provisions, § 19-172, pertaining to the placement of tags or stickers, has been reserved. Reader is directed to §19-171(a) for similar provisions. 
Sec. 19-173. - Term. 
    Licenses required by this article shall be issued on a calendar-year basis. All licenses shall expire on the thirty-first day of December following the date of issue. 
(Code 1956, § 14.89; Ord. No. 18-1958, § 1, 9-23-58; Ord. No. 3-1964, § I, 1-28-64) 
Sec. 19-174. - Penalty for violation. 
    Any person convicted of operating a motor vehicle without having purchased and displayed a vehicle license as required by this article shall be fined in accordance with section 19-214(a). 
(Ord. No. 14-1975, 4-22-75; Ord. No. 24-1986, § 1, 10-28-86; Ord. No. 17-1992, § 3, 9-8-92) 
ARTICLE VII. - SEIZURE AND IMPOUNDMENT OF VEHICLES 

Sec. 19-175. - Motor vehicles, seizure and impoundment. 
(a)  Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Owner of record of a vehicle means the recorded title holder. 
(b)  Owner liability; exceptions. The owner of any motor vehicle, which vehicle is used during the commission of any of the qualified violations as set forth in section 19-176, shall be liable to the Village of Hazel Crest for an administrative penalty of five hundred dollars ($500.00) plus any towing and storage fees applicable to this section. This subsection shall not apply if: 
(1)  The vehicle used in the violation was stolen at the time and the theft was reported to the appropriate police authorities within twenty-four (24) hours after the theft was discovered or reasonably should have been discovered; or 
(2)  The vehicle is operating as a common carrier and the violation occurs without the knowledge of the person in control of the vehicle. 
(c)  Seizure and impoundment. Whenever the Village of Hazel Crest Police Department, or all members thereof assigned to traffic duty, has probable cause to believe that a vehicle is subject to a seizure and impoundment pursuant to this section, the police department shall provide for the towing of the vehicle to a facility controlled by the Village of Hazel Crest or its agents. Before or at the time the vehicle is towed, the police department shall notify any person identifying himself/herself as the owner of the vehicle or any person who is found to be in control of the vehicle at the time of the alleged violation of the fact of the seizure and of the alleged violation and of the vehicle owner's right to request a vehicle impoundment hearing to be conducted under this section. The police department may issue rules and regulations related to this section for enforcement notification procedures and proper forms necessary for administration of this section. 
(d)  Vehicle impoundment hearing. Whenever the owner of record of a vehicle seized pursuant to this section makes a request in person and in writing for a vehicle impoundment hearing within twelve (12) hours after the seizure, a hearing officer of the Village of Hazel Crest shall conduct the vehicle impoundment hearing within twenty-four (24) hours after the seizure, excluding Sundays and legal holidays. All interested persons shall be given a reasonable opportunity to be heard at the vehicle impoundment hearing. The formal and technical rules of evidence shall not apply in the conduct of the hearing. Evidence, including hearsay, may be admitted only if it is a type commonly relied upon by reasonably prudent persons in the conduct of their affairs. If, after the hearing, the hearing officer determines that there is probable cause to believe that the vehicle is subject to seizure and impoundment under subsection (c), the hearing officer shall order the continued impoundment of the vehicle as provided in this section unless the owner of the vehicle posts with the Village of Hazel Crest a cash bond in the amount of five hundred dollars ($500.00) plus any applicable towing and storage fees. 
(e)  Notification of impoundment; hearing scheduled; failure of owner to appear; determination; penalty. Within ten (10) days after a vehicle is seized and impounded pursuant to this section, the Village of Hazel Crest shall notify by certified mail, return receipt requested, the owner of record of the date, time and location of a hearing that will be conducted pursuant to this section. The hearing shall be scheduled and held, unless continued by order of the hearing officer, no later than thirty (30) days after the vehicle was seized. The hearing shall be conducted by a hearing officer of the Village of Hazel Crest. All interested persons shall be given a reasonable opportunity to be heard at the hearing. If, after the hearing, the hearing officer determines by a preponderance of the evidence that the vehicle violated this section and that none of the exceptions described in subsections (b)(1) and (2) of this section applies, the hearing officer shall enter a default order in favor of the Village of Hazel Crest requiring the payment to the Village of Hazel Crest of an administrative penalty in the amount of five hundred dollars ($500.00). If the hearing officer finds that no such violation occurred, the hearing officer shall order the immediate return of the owner's vehicle or cash bond. 
(f)  Administrative penalty constitutes debt owing to the Village of Hazel Crest. If an administrative penalty is imposed pursuant to this section, such penalty shall constitute a debt due and owing to the Village of Hazel Crest. If a cash bond has been posted pursuant to this section, the bond shall be applied to the penalty. If a vehicle has been impounded when such a penalty is imposed, the Village of Hazel Crest may seek to obtain judgment against the vehicle or enforce such judgment against the vehicle as provided by law. Except as provided otherwise in this division, a vehicle shall continue to be impounded until: 
(1)  The penalty, plus any applicable towing and storage fees, is paid to the Village of Hazel Crest, in which case possession of the vehicle shall be given to the person who is legally entitled to possess the vehicle; or 
(2)  The vehicle is sold or otherwise disposed of to satisfy a judgment or enforce a lien as provided by law. If the administrative penalty and applicable fees are not paid within thirty (30) days after an administrative penalty is imposed under subsection (e) of this section against an owner of record who defaults by failing to appear at the hearing, the vehicle shall be deemed unclaimed and shall be disposed of in the manner provided for by law for the disposition of unclaimed vehicles. In all other cases, if the administrative penalty and applicable fees are not paid within thirty (30) days after the expiration of time at which administrative review of the hearing officer's determination may be sought, or within thirty (30) days after an action seeking administrative review has been resolved in favor of the Village of Hazel Crest, whichever is applicable, the vehicle shall be deemed unclaimed and shall be disposed of in the manner provided by law for the disposition of unclaimed vehicles. 
    Except as otherwise specifically provided by law, no owner, lien holder or other person shall be legally entitled to take possession of a vehicle impounded under this section until the civil penalty and fees applicable under this section have been paid. However, whenever a person with a lien of record against an impounded vehicle has commenced foreclosure proceedings, possession of the vehicle shall be given to that person if the person agrees in writing to refund to the Village of Hazel Crest the amount of the net proceeds of any foreclosure sale, less any amounts required to pay all lien holders of record, up to five hundred dollars ($500.00) plus the applicable fees. 
(Ord. No. 15-2007, § 1, 10-9-07) 
Sec. 19-176. - Qualified violations for impoundment. 
(1)  Vehicles may be impounded as set forth in section 19-175 for the following offenses as described under the Illinois Criminal Code of 1961, and as amended from time to time (720 ILCS 5/1-1 et seq.): 
720 ILCS 5/11-14 Prostitution. 720 ILCS 5/11-15 Soliciting for a prostitute. 720 ILCS 5/11-15.1 Soliciting for a juvenile prostitute. 720 ILCS 5/11-16 Pandering. 720 ILCS 5/11-18 Patronizing a prostitute. 720 ILCS 5/11-18.1 Patronizing a juvenile prostitute. 720 ILCS 5/11-19 Pimping. 720 ILCS 5/11-19.1 Juvenile pimping. 720 ILCS 5/11-19.2 Exploitation of a child. 720 ILCS 5/20-2 Possession of explosives or incendiary device. 720 ILCS 550/4 Possession of cannabis. 720 ILCS 550/5 Manufacture, delivery, possession, intent to deliver cannabis. 720 ILCS 550/5.1 Cannabis. 720 ILCS 550/5.2 Delivery of cannabis on school grounds. 720 ILCS 550/8 Possession of cannabis sativa plant. 720 ILCS 570/1401-1413 Controlled Substances Act. 720 ILCS 600/3.5 Possession of drug paraphernalia. 720 ILCS 5/2-7 Commission of felony. 720 ILCS 5/2-8 Commission of forcible felony. 720 ILCS 5/25-1 et seq. Unlawful use of firearms/weapons. 430 ILCS 65/1.1 et seq. Possession/transfer of firearm(s) without valid firearm owner's identification card.  
(2)  Vehicles may be impounded as set forth in section 19-175 for the following offenses as described under the Illinois Vehicle Code: 
625 ILCS 5/6-101 Operating a motor vehicle with no valid driver's license. (Does NOT include expired driver's license.) 625 ILCS 
 5/6-303(a)(1) Operating a motor vehicle with a suspended driver's license. 625 ILCS 
 5/6-303(a)(2) Operating a motor vehicle with a revoked driver's license. (Note: Mandatory tow under 625 ILCS 5/6-303(e) if driver suspended/revoked and no insurance.) 625 ILCS 5/11-501 D.U.I. alcohol, intoxicating compounds and/or other drugs. (Note: Maximum twelve-hour tow and hold under 625 ILCS 4-203(e).) 625 ILCS 5/3-702 Operation when registration cancelled, suspended or revoked. 625 ILCS 5/3-703 Operation with false, fraudulent, stolen or altered registration. 625 ILCS 5/3-708 Operation while registration suspended for mandatory insurance. 625 ILCS 5/3-710 Presenting or displaying a false, fraudulent, insurance card. 625 ILCS 5/5-502 Transportation or possession of open alcoholic liquor in a vehicle.  
(3)  Radios, phonographs, etc. on public way. 
(a)  No person shall operate or permit to be operated any device used to receive broadcast sound, or reproduce any recorded sound if the device is located: 
1.  On the public way; or 
2.  In any motor vehicle on the public way; 
and the sound can be heard seventy-five (75) feet or more from the device. 
This provision does not apply to authorized emergency vehicles. This provision does not apply when the device is being operated solely to request assistance or warn of a hazardous condition. 
(b)  Public way means all streets, alleys, sidewalks, boulevards, public parking lots and other public rights-of-way. 
(c)  A motor vehicle used in violation of this provision is hereby declared a public nuisance. 
(d)  A motor vehicle operated with the permission, expressed or implied, of the owner of the vehicle which is used in violation of this provision, shall be subject to seizure and impoundment. 
(e)  For a first offense, the owner of any such motor vehicle shall be liable to the Village of Hazel Crest for an administrative penalty of five hundred dollars ($500.00) plus any towing and storage fees of the vehicle unless one (1) of the exceptions set forth in subsection 19-175(b) is applicable. 
(f)  For a second or subsequent offense within a two-year period, the owner of any such motor vehicle shall be liable to the Village of Hazel Crest for an administrative penalty of seven hundred and fifty dollars ($750.00) plus any towing and storage fees of the vehicle unless one (1) of the exceptions set forth in subsection 19-175(b) is applicable. 
(Ord. No. 15-2007, § 1, 10-9-07; Ord. No. 20-2007, § 1, 11-13-07; Ord. No. 02-2010, § 1, 2-9-10) 
Secs. 19-177-19-194. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VIII. - CITATION PROCEDURE[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 13-1994, §§ 1, 2, adopted May 10, 1994, repealed former Art. VIII, §§ 19-195-19-201, in its entirety and enacted new provisions as herein set out. Former Art. VIII pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Ord. No. 12-1984, 4-10-84; Ord. No. 17-1992, § 2, 9-8-92. 
Cross reference- Citation procedure for other violations, § 20-121 et seq. 

Sec. 19-195. - Administrative adjudication. 
    The Village of Hazel Crest hereby adopts the "Administrative Adjudication System for Parking, Standing and Compliance Violations" as set forth in Appendix "A" to this Chapter 19. 
(Ord. No. 13-1994, § 2, 5-10-94) 
APPENDIX A - ADMINISTRATIVE ADJUDICATION SYSTEM FOR PARKING, STANDING AND COMPLIANCE VIOLATIONS WITHIN THE VILLAGE OF HAZEL CREST[7] 

Footnotes: 
--- (7) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 13-1994, § 2, adopted May 10, 1994, added Appendix A, §§ 1-13, as herein set out. Minor stylistic changes have been made by the editor. 

Sec. 1. - Purpose. 
(a)  The stated purpose of this appendix is to provide a fair and efficient enforcement of municipal vehicular standing, parking, and condition of vehicle regulation violation(s) as nay be allowed by law, through an administrative adjudication of violation(s) of municipal ordinances regulating the standing, parking, and condition of vehicles within the geographic boundaries of the village of Hazel Crest and a schedule of uniform fines and penalties and authority and procedures for collection of unpaid fines and penalties. 
(b)  For purposes of this appendix "compliance violation" means a violation of a municipal regulation governing the condition or use of equipment on a vehicle, or governing the purchase or display of a vehicle license, or failing to wear a seatbelt when required to do so 
Note- The specific ordinance numbers for parking and compliance tickets have not been included in this appendix. 
(c)  The fact that a motor vehicle which is illegally operated or parked is registered with the secretary of state in the name of the alleged violator, or, that a vehicle sticker issued by a municipality has been issued in the name of the alleged violator, shall constitute proof that the alleged violator was in control of or was the operator or the motor vehicle at the time of the alleged violation. 
(d)  The commercial lessor or any vehicle, whether or not the registered owner, shall be responsible for all parking violations and subject to the penalty therefor. 
(Ord. No. 13-1994, § 2, 5-10-94) 
Note- Paragraphs (c) and (d) of section 1 were formerly included as section 19-201 of this chapter. 
Sec. 2. - Administrative composition. 
    The system of administrative adjudication of vehicular standing, parking, and compliance, regulation violation(s) shall provide for a traffic compliance administrator, hearing officer, computer operator/system coordinator and hearing room personnel (deputy), with the power, authority and limitations as are hereinafter set forth: 
2.1. Traffic compliance administrator: Shall be empowered and is hereby authorized and directed to: 
(a)  Operate and manage the system of administrative adjudication of vehicular standing, parking, and compliance regulation violation(s). 
(b)  Adopt, distribute and process standing, parking, and compliance violation notices and other notices as may be required under this appendix or as may be reasonably required to carry out the purpose of this appendix. 
(c)  Collect moneys paid as fines and/or penalties assessed after a final determination of vehicular standing, parking, or compliance regulation violation(s) liability. 
(d)  Conduct hearings, as a hearing officer with the same power and authority as is hereinafter set forth, during the absence of the appointed hearing officer. 
(e)  Certify copies of final determination(s) of, standing, parking, and compliance regulation violation(s) liability and factual report(s) verifying that the final determination of standing, parking, and compliance regulation violation(s) liability was issued in accordance with this appendix and 625 ILCS 5/11-208.3. 
(f)  Certify reports to the Secretary of State concerning initiation of suspension of driving privileges in accordance with the provisions of this appendix, hereinafter set forth, and those of Chapter 625 ILCS 5/6-306.5. 
(g)  Review final determination(s) of vehicular standing, parking, and compliance regulation violation(s) liability, validity of notice of impending drivers license suspension, in an administrative review capacity in accordance with the provisions of this appendix, hereinafter set forth. 
(h)  Promulgate rules and regulations reasonably required to operate and maintain the administrative adjudication system hereby created. 
(i)  Collect unpaid fines and penalties by filing complaints in the circuit court or selecting or appointing an individual or agency to act on behalf of this municipality in filing complaints seeking judgments for unpaid fines or penalties and pursuit of all post-judgment remedies available by current law. 
(j)  Perform other duties as may be assigned by the president and the board of trustees or the village manager from time to time. The traffic compliance administrator may, but need not, be an employee of the village. 
2.2. Hearing officer: Shall be empowered and is hereby authorized and directed to: 
(a)  Preside over the administrative hearings, established herein as the adjudicator. 
(b)  Administer oaths. 
(c)  Issue subpoenas to secure the attendance of witnesses and production of relevant papers or documentation. 
(d)  Assess fines and penalties for the violation of vehicular standing, parking, or compliance regulation violation(s) as are established in section 9 hereof. 
(e)  Makes final determination of: 
(1)  Vehicular standing, parking, and compliance regulation violation(s) liability. 
(2)  Validity of notice of impending drivers license suspension in accordance with the provisions of this appendix, herein set forth. 
(f)  Provide for the accurate recording of the administrative adjudication hearing(s). 
2.3 Appointments: The village president shall appoint persons to hold the positions set forth above with the advice and consent of the village board. One (1) person may hold and fulfill the requirements of one (1) or more of the above stated positions. 
2.4. Compensation: To be paid for each of the above stated positions shall be as determined by the village president and approved by the board of trustees. 
(Ord. No. 13-1994, § 2, 5-10-94) 
Sec. 3. - Procedure. 
    The system of administrative adjudication of vehicular standing, parking, and compliance regulation violation(s) shall be in accordance with the following procedures and final determination(s) of vehicular standing, parking, and compliance regulation violation(s) liability, validity of notice of impending impoundment, validity of notice of impending drivers license suspension and collections shall be made only in accordance with the provisions set forth below: 
3.1. Violation notice: Vehicular standing, parking, and compliance regulation violation(s) notice(s) ("violation notice"(s)) shall be issued by the person(s) authorized herein and shall contain information and shall be served, certified and have evidentiary admissibility as is hereinafter set forth. 
3.2. Authorization: All full-time, part-time and auxiliary police officers as well as other specifically appointed individuals shall have the authority to issue violation(s) notices. 
3.3. Detection of violations: Any individual authorized hereby to issue violation(s) notices and who detects a violation of any section of any applicable municipal ordinance, shall issue a notice of violation thereof and shall make service thereof as is hereinafter set forth. 
3.4. Contents of violation notice: The vehicular standing, parking, and compliance regulation "violation notice" shall contain, but shall not be limited to, the following information: 
(a)  The date, time and place of the violation (date of issuance). 
(b)  The particular vehicular standing, parking, or compliance regulation violated. 
(c)  Vehicle make and state registration number. 
(d)  The fine and any penalty which may be assessed for late payment. 
(e)  The signature and identification number of the person issuing the notice. 
(f)  A section entitled "Request for Hearing" (which may be a separate form) which shall clearly set forth that the registered owner or lessee may appear at the initial administrative hearing to contest the validity of the violation notice on the date and at the time and place as specified in the violation notice by: 
(1)  Checking or placing a mark in a space provided and clearly identified, "Request for Hearing". 
(2)  Placing his/her name and current address in the place provided. 
(3)  Signing his/her name in the appropriate indicated place. 
(4)  Filing the violation notice with the "Request for Hearing" portion fully completed; with the traffic compliance administrator postmarked by the 25th of the month, if the violation notice was issued between the 1st through the 15th day of the month; or postmarked by the 10th of the month, if the violation notice was issued between the 16th and the end of the prior month. The request shall be deemed filed upon receipt by the traffic compliance administrator. 
(g)  That payment of the indicted fine and any late payment penalty shall operate as a final disposition of the violation. 
(h)  A section entitled "Non-Resident Request for Hearing-Non-Appearance", which clearly sets forth that a non-resident registered owner or lessee may appear at the initial administrative hearing to contest the validity of the violation notice without personally appearing by: 
(1)  Checking or placing a mark in a space provided and clearly identified, "Non-Resident Request for Hearing-Nonappearance". 
(2)  Placing his/her name and current address in the place provided. 
(3)  Signing his/her name in the appropriate indicated place. 
(4)  Filing the violation notice with the "Non-Resident Request for Hearing" portion fully completed, with the traffic compliance administrator postmarked by the 25th of the month, if the violation notice was issued between the 1st through the 15th day of the month; or postmarked by the 10th of the month, if the violation notice was issued between the 16th and the end of the prior month. The request shall be deemed filed upon receipt by the traffic compliance administrator. 
(5)  Filing a notarized statement of facts specifying the grounds for challenging the violation notice which must be filed with the traffic compliance administrator postmarked by the 25th of the month, if the violation notice was issued between the 1st through the 15th day of the month; or postmarked by the 10th of the month, if the violation notice was issued between the 16th and the end of the prior month. The request shall be deemed filed, if post marked by the due dates herein specified. 
(6)  A clearly marked statement that execution of the non-resident request for hearing is a waiver of the non-resident's right to a personal appearance and that the adjudication will be made based upon the notarized statement of facts submitted by the non-resident and the facts contained in the violation(s) notice(s). 
3.5. Service of notice: Service of the violation(s) notice(s) shall be made by the person issuing such notice by: 
(a)  Affixing the original or a facsimile of the notice to an unlawfully standing or parked vehicle, or 
(b)  Handing the notice to the registered owner, operator or lessee of the vehicle, if present. 
3.6. Certification of facts: The correctness of facts contained in the vehicular standing, parking or compliance regulation violation(s) notice(s) shall be certified by the person issuing said notice by: 
(a)  Signing his/her name to the notice(s) at the time of service, or 
(b)  In the case of a notice produced by a computer device, by signing a single certificate, to be kept by the traffic compliance administrator, attesting to the correctness of all notices produced by the device while under his/her control. 
3.7. Copy to be returned: The original or a facsimile of the violation(s) notice(s) shall be retained by the traffic compliance administrator and kept as a record in the ordinary course of business. 
3.8. Prima facia evidence of correctness: Any violation(s) notice(s) issued, signed and served in accordance herewith, or a copy of the notice, shall be prima facia correct and shall be prima facia evidence of the correctness of the facts shown on the notice. 
3.9. Admissibility: The violation(s) notice(s) or a copy(s) shall be admissible in any subsequent administrative or legal proceeding. 
(Ord. No. 13-1994, § 2, 5-10-94) 
Sec. 4. - Administrative hearings. 
    An administrative hearing to adjudicate the alleged standing, parking, or compliance regulation violation(s) on its merits; 
4.1 Shall be granted to: The registered owner or operator of the "cited vehicle", pursuant to Chapter 625 ILCS 5/11-208.3 or the lessee of the "cited vehicle", pursuant to Chapter 625 ILCS 5/11-1306, incorporated herein by reference. 
4.2. Hearing dates: Shall be at the date, time and place as is set forth in the hearing notice sent by first class mail, or such additional notices issued in accordance with this appendix. Violators shall be given no less than three (3) opportunities to appear and failure to appear by the third (3rd) scheduled hearing date will result in a "final determination of liability" as hereinafter set forth. 
4.3. Recorded: Shall be tape recorded. 
4.4. Result in determination: Shall culminate in a determination of liability or non-liability, made by the hearing officer, who shall consider testimony and other evidence without the application of the formal or technical rules of evidence. The hearing officer shall, upon a determination of liability, assess fines and penalties in accordance with section 9 hereof. 
4.5. Representation by attorney: Persons appearing to contest the alleged standing, parking, or compliance violation on it's merits may be represented by counsel at their own expense. 
4.6. Review: The final determination of any matter which may be decided by the hearing officer may be reviewed as is hereinafter set forth. 
(Ord. No. 13-1994, § 2, 5-10-94) 
Sec. 5. - Additional notices. 
    Upon failure of the registered owner or lessee of the "cited vehicle" to appear at the administrative hearing indicated in the vehicular standing, parking, or compliance regulation violation(s) notice(s), or upon final determination of violation liability, the traffic compliance administrator shall send or cause to be sent additional notices which: 
5.1. Shall be sent to the registered owner or lessee of the "cited vehicle" at the address as is recorded with the Secretary of State. 
5.2. Shall be sent to the lessee of the "cited vehicle" at the address last known to the lessor of the "cited vehicle" at the time of the lease. 
5.3. Shall be sent by first class mail, postage prepaid. 
5.4. Service of additional notices sent in accordance herewith shall be complete as of the date of deposit in the United States mail. 
5.5. The additional notices sent in accordance herewith shall be in the following sequence and contain, but not be limited to, the following information: 
(a)  Upon the failure of the registered owner or lessee of the "cited vehicle" to appear at the hearing set forth in the vehicular standing, parking, or compliance regulation violation(s) notice(s), additional notice(s) shall be sent, as above set forth, and shall contain, but not be limited to the following information: 
(1)  Date and location of violation cited in the vehicular standing, parking, or compliance regulation violation(s) notice(s). 
(2)  Particular standing, parking, or compliance regulation violated. 
(3)  Vehicle make and state registration. 
(4)  Fine and any penalty that may be assessed for late payment. 
(5)  Notice to the registered owner or lessee of their current status, other than paid in full. 
(6)  Date, time and place of the administrative hearing at which the alleged violation may be contested on its merits. 
(7)  Statement that failure to either pay fine and any applicable penalty or failure to appear at the hearing on its merits on the date and at the time and place specified will result in a final determination of vehicle standing, parking, or compliance regulation violation(s) liability for the "cited" violation in the amount of the fine and penalty indicated. 
(8)  Statement that upon the occurrence of a final determination of vehicular standing, parking, or compliance violation(s) liability for the failure, and the exhaustion of, or the failure to exhaust, available administrative or judicial procedures for review, any unpaid fine or penalty will constitute a debt due and owing the municipality. 
(b)  A notice of final determination of vehicular standing, parking, or compliance regulation violation(s) liability shall be sent following an appearance by the violator and a determination of liability, or the failure to appear by the violator by the third (3rd) and final hearing date upon conclusion of any administrative and/or judicial review, as is hereinafter set forth, and the notice shall contain, but not be limited to, the following information and warnings: 
(1)  A statement that the unpaid fine and any penalty assessed is a debt due and owing the municipality. 
(2)  A warning that failure to pay the fine and any penalty due and owing the municipality within the time specified may result in the municipality's filing a complaint in the circuit court to have the unpaid fine or penalty rendered a judgement in accordance with Chapter 625 ILCS 5/11-208.3(f), incorporated herein by reference. 
(3)  A warning that the person's drivers license may be suspended for failure to pay fines or penalties for ten (10) or more vehicular standing or parking violations under Chapter 625 ILCS 5/16-306.5, incorporated herein by reference. 
(c)  A notice of impending suspension of a person's drivers license shall be sent to any person determined to be liable for the payment of any fine or penalty that remains due and owing on ten (10) or more vehicular standing or parking regulation violation(s): 
(1)  The notice shall state that the failure to pay the fine or penalty owing within forty-five (45) days of the date of the notice will result in the municipality's notifying the Secretary of State that the person is eligible for initiation of suspension proceedings under Chapter 625 ILCS 5/6-306.5 incorporated herein by reference. 
(2)  The notice of impending drivers license suspension shall be sent by first class mail, postage prepaid, to the address recorded with the Secretary of State. 
(Ord. No. 13-1994, § 2, 5-10-94) 
Sec. 6. - Final determination of liability. 
    A final determination of vehicular standing, parking, or compliance regulation violation(s) liability shall: 
6.1. Occur following the failure to pay the total assessed fine or penalty after the hearing officer's determination of vehicular standing, parking, or compliance regulation violation(s) liability and the exhaustion of or the failure to exhaust any administrative review procedures hereinafter set forth, or 
6.2. Where a person fails to appear at a prior hearing or by the third (3rd) and final administrative hearing provided to contest the alleged violation(s) on the date and at the time and place specified in a prior served or mailed notice, the hearing officer's determination of vehicular standing, parking, or compliance regulation violation(s) liability shall become final; 
(a)  Upon denial of a timely petition to set aside that determination, or 
(b)  Upon the expiration of the period for filing petition without a filing having been made. 
(Ord. No. 13-1994, § 2, 5-10-94) 
Sec. 7. - Administrative review. 
    A petition to set aside a determination of vehicular standing, parking, or compliance regulation violation(s) liability may be filed by a person owing an unpaid fine or penalty in the manner and subject to the restrictions and grounds hereinafter set forth: 
7.1. A written petition to set aside a determination of liability must be filed in the office of the traffic compliance administrator within, but not later than, fourteen (14) days from the date the determination of liability is made. 
7.2. The traffic compliance administrator shall act upon the petition(s) timely filed and render a decision thereon within fourteen (14) days of the date filed. 
7.3. The grounds for setting aside a determination of liability shall be limited to the following: 
(a)  The person against whom the determination of liability is made was not the owner or lessee of the "cited vehicle" on the date the vehicular standing, parking, or compliance regulation violation(s) notice(s) were issued. 
(b)  The person's having paid the fine or penalty prior to the determination of liability for the violation(s) in question. 
(c)  Excusable failure to appear at or request a new date for a hearing. 
7.4. Should the determination of liability be set aside, the traffic compliance administrator shall: 
(a)  Notify the registered owner, or lessee, as the case may be, that the determination of liability has been set aside. 
(b)  Notify the registered owner, or lessee, as the case may be, of a date, time and place for a hearing on the merits of the violation for which determination of liability has been set aside. 
(c)  Notice of setting aside of the determination of liability and the notice of the hearing date shall be by first class mail, postage prepaid to the address set forth on the petition to set aside the determination of liability. 
(d)  Service of the notice shall be complete on the date the notice(s) are deposited in the United States mail. 
(Ord. No. 13-1994, § 2, 5-10-94) 
Sec. 8. - Non-resident procedures. 
    Non-residents of this municipality who have been served vehicular standing, parking, or compliance regulation violation(s) notice(s), in accordance with this appendix, may contest the alleged violation on its merits, as could a resident, or may contest the validity without personally appearing at an administrative hearing by: 
8.1. Completing, in full, the "Non-Resident Request for Hearing" section of the violation notice, served upon him/her pursuant to this appendix. 
8.2. Signing the non-resident request for hearing in the space specified in the violation notice, and acknowledging that his/her personal appearance is waived and submitting to an adjudication based upon the notarized statement filed by him/her and the facts contained in the violation notice. 
8.3. Filing the violation notice with the "Request for Hearing" section fully completed with the traffic compliance administrator postmarked by the 25th of the month, if the violation notice was issued between the 1st through the 15th day of the month; or postmarked by the 10th of the month, if the violation notice was issued between the 16th and the end of the prior month. The request shall be deemed filed upon receipt by the traffic compliance administrator. 
8.4. Filing a notarized statement of facts specifying the grounds for challenging the violation notice which must be filed with the traffic compliance administrator postmarked by the 25th of the month, if the violation notice was issued between the 1st through the 15th day of the month; or postmarked by the 10th of the month, if the violation notice was issued between the 16th and the end of the prior month. The request shall be deemed filed upon receipt by the traffic compliance administrator. The acceptance of a "Non-Resident Request For Hearing" after the due date or with cause, at the discretion of the traffic compliance administrator, be accepted for hearing consideration and decision. 
8.5. The hearing officer shall make an adjudication based upon the facts set forth in the notarized statement of facts filed by the non-resident as is contained in the violation notice. 
8.6. Notice of the determination of the hearing officer shall be served upon the non-resident by first class mail, postage prepaid, addressed to the non-resident at the address set forth in the statement of facts submitted. 
8.7. Service of the notice shall be complete on the date the notice is placed in the United States mail. 
8.8. All other provisions of this appendix shall apply equally to non-residents of this municipality. 
Sec. 9. - Schedule of fines/penalties. 
9.1. The fines and penalties which shall be imposed for the violation of vehicular standing, parking, or compliance regulation violation(s) shall be as follows:

(Ord. No. 13-1994, § 2, 5-10-94) 
Sec. 10. - Certified report and contesting certified report. 
(a)  Upon a failure to pay fines and penalties deemed due and owing the village after the exhaustion of administrative procedures set forth herein for ten (10) or more vehicular parking regulation violations, the traffic compliance administrator shall make a certified report to the Secretary of State stating that the owner of a registered vehicle has failed to pay any fine or penalty due and owing the village as a result of ten (10) or more violations of municipal vehicular standing or parking regulations and thereby cause the suspension of that person's driver's license. 
(b)  The traffic compliance administrator shall take no further action unless and until the fines and penalties due and owing the village are paid or upon determination that the inclusion of the person's name on the certified report was in error. At such time, the traffic compliance administrator shall submit to the Secretary of State a notification which shall result in the halting of a driver's license suspension proceedings. The person named therein shall receive a certified copy of such notification upon request and at no charge. 
(c)  Persons may challenge the accuracy of the certified report by completing a form provided by the office of the traffic compliance administrator. The form shall specify the grounds on which such challenge is based. Grounds for challenge shall be limited to the following: 
(1)  The person was neither the owner nor the lessee of the vehicle(s) receiving ten (10) or more violation notices on the date or dates such notices were issued; or 
(2)  The person has paid the fine and/or penalty for the ten (10) or more violations indicated on the certified report. 
(d)  The traffic compliance administrator shall render a determination within fourteen (14) business days of receipt of the objection form and shall notify the objector of the determination. 
(Ord. No. 13-1994, § 2, 5-10-94) 
Sec. 11. - Judicial review. 
    Judicial review of final determinations of vehicular standing, parking, or compliance regulation violation(s) made under this section shall be subject to the provisions of the administrative Review Law as is set forth in 735 ILCS 5/301, et seq. incorporated herein by reference. 
(Ord. No. 13-1994, § 2, 5-10-94) 
Sec. 12. - Debt to municipality. 
    Any fine, penalty or part of any fine or any penalty assessed in accordance with the provisions of this appendix and remaining unpaid after the exhaustion of, or the failure to exhaust, administrative remedies created under this appendix and the conclusion of any judicial review procedures shall be a debt due and owing the municipality, and, as such, may be collected in accordance with the applicable law. Payment in full of any fine or penalty resulting from a standing, parking, or compliance violation shall constitute a final disposition of that violation. 
(Ord. No. 13-1994, § 2, 5-10-94) 
Sec. 13. - Judgment. 
    13.1. The traffic compliance administrator shall, following the expiration of the period within which administrative or judicial review may be sought for a final determination of violation, take all necessary action(s), execute all required documents and appoint or retain any individual or agency deemed appropriate to obtain a judgment against and collect moneys from the person(s) who have been assessed fines or penalties which remain unpaid and have become a debt due and owing the municipality in accordance with the provisions of this appendix and 625 ILCS 5/11-208.3 by: 
(a)  Filing a complaint in the circuit court praying for the entry of a judgment against the person for whom a final determination of standing, parking, or compliance regulation violation(s) liability has been made. 
(b)  The complaint filed by the traffic compliance administrator or individual or agency on behalf of the municipality seeking entry of a judgment against an individual for unpaid fines and/or penalties pursuant to a final determination of standing, parking, or compliance regulation violation(s) shall have appended: 
(1)  A certified copy of the final determination of the standing, parking, or compliance regulation violation(s). 
(2)  A certification that recites facts sufficient to show that the final determination of standing, parking, or compliance regulation violation(s) was issued in accordance with this appendix and 625 ILCS 5/11-208.3. 
(c)  Nothing shall prevent the municipality from consolidating multiple final determinations of standing, parking, or compliance regulation violation(s) liability in an action in the circuit court against an individual. 
(d)  Pursuing all available remedies, allowed by law, to collect money judgments. 
    13.2. Service of summons and a copy of the complaint may be served upon the person against whom a judgment is sought under the provisions of this appendix by any method provided under 735 ILCS 5/2-203, incorporated by reference, or by certified mail, return receipt requested, provided the total amount of fines and penalties for final determination of standing, parking, or compliance regulation violation(s) does not exceed two thousand five hundred dollars ($2,500.00). 
(Ord. No. 13-1994, § 2, 5-10-94) 
Chapter 20 - OFFENSES AND MISCELLANEOUS PROVISIONS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- General penalty, § 1-10; Halloween solicitation, § 21-23 et seq.; police, Ch. 24. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 20-1. - Definitions. 
    Terms used in this chapter but not defined herein shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them by the Criminal Code of 1961, Illinois Revised Statutes, chapter 38, as amended, or by the Code of Criminal Procedure of 1963, Illinois Revised Statutes, chapter 38 as amended, [720 ILCS], and those terms are hereby incorporated by reference herein and made a part thereof. 
Cross reference- Rules of construction and definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 20-2. - Prosecution to be authorized by officials. 
    No magistrate or judge shall issue any warrant or summons for the violation of any village ordinance, except on request of the village attorney, village police officer or village firefighter. In case a prosecution is begun in the name of the village, without the authority the village attorney, a village police officer or a village firefighter for the violation of any ordinance of the village in which the village might be made liable to pay costs, it shall be the duty of the village attorney to investigate the facts and if, in his opinion, the suit ought not to be maintained, he shall appear in behalf of the village and dismiss such prosecution. 
(Code 1956, § 17.12; Ord. No. 7-1994, § 1, 2-22-94) 
Sec. 20-3. - Arrests without process. 
    Members of the police force of the village and sworn members of the village fire department are hereby authorized to arrest, with or without process, or on view, any person who breaks the peace or violates any of the ordinances of the village, when they have reasonable grounds for believing that delay will permit the escape of the person committing such violation, but not otherwise; except, however, sworn members of the village fire department are not authorized to arrest any person who commits a traffic violation under Chapter 19 of the village code or the Illinois Vehicle Code. In lieu of arrest, a police officer or firefighter, as provided herein, may issue a citation to any person who violates any of the ordinances of the village. 
(Code 1956, § 17.01; Ord. No. 7-1994, § 1, 2-22-94) 
Sec. 20-4. - Procedure following arrests without process. 
    Whenever any person shall be arrested without process or on view for breaking the peace or violating any ordinance of the village, he shall be promptly taken before a magistrate or judge of the county. Such magistrate or judge shall note upon his docket the cause of such arrest as stated by the officer making the arrest, and shall proceed to hear and determine the case in the same manner as if the defendant had been arrested on a warrant; or may continue the case for lawful cause as provided in other actions before the magistrate, in which case, if the defendant shall give bond conditioned for his appearance before the magistrate or judge hearing the case on the day and at the place named therein, provided he abides the order of such magistrate or judge and does not depart the court without leave, with security in a sum to be approved by such magistrate or judge, he shall be discharged from the custody of the officer making the arrest; otherwise, in the discretion of the magistrate or judge, he shall be committed to the village jail or other place provided for the imprisonment of offenders against the ordinances of the village or shall remain in the custody of the officer making the arrest until the time set for the trial of the case. 
(Code 1956, § 17.02) 
Sec. 20-5. - Arrests during night or on Sunday. 
    The village board may by ordinance establish other jails and places of confinement, and any officer having arrested any person during the night or on Sunday may keep him at any such safe place, in his discretion, overnight or over Sunday until he can bring such person before the proper magistrate. 
(Code 1956, § 17.03) 
Sec. 20-6. - Sale of cigarettes to minors; sale in original package only. 
(a)  No person shall sell or offer for sale, or give away or deliver any cigarettes or tobacco, in any of its forms, or any manufactured article consisting in whole or a part of tobacco to persons under the age of eighteen (18). No owner, operator or other person in charge of a cigarette vending machine shall permit any minor under the age of eighteen (18) years to purchase any tobacco products from such vending machine. Owners of premises where such vending machines are located shall prominently display signage in the immediate vicinity of the machines setting forth the prohibitions of sections 20-6 and 20-6.2. The form and placement of such notice shall be approved by the village manager or his designee. 
(b)  No business which is licensed to operate in the Village of Hazel Crest shall sell cigarettes except in their original package. Sale of individual cigarettes, or sale of cigarettes in other than the original package, is prohibited. 
(c)  In the event the holder of any business operation permit issued by the village violates the provisions of this section, the village may suspend or revoke any such permit, including but not limited to any general permit to operate issued pursuant to Chapter 17 of this Municipal Code, and any license related to the sale of alcohol issued pursuant to Chapter 4 of this Municipal Code. For purposes of this section, every act or omission constituting a violation of this section by any officer, director, manager, agent or employee of any licensee shall be deemed and held to be the act or omission of such employer or licensee and the employer or licensee shall be punishable in the same manner as if such act or omission had been done or omitted by him personally. 
(d)  Any person convicted of violating any provision of this section 20-6 shall be fined not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) and not more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for each offense. The issuance of a citation and a fine shall not preclude any suspension or revocation of a business operation permit. 
(Ord. No. 3-1996, § 1, 2-27-96; Ord. No. 17-2002, § 1, 5-14-02) 
Sec. 20-6.1. - Sale of smoking paraphernalia to minors. 
(a)  As used herein, the term "smoking paraphernalia" means any article or equipment commonly used in connection with the consumption or ingestion, by smoking, of any tobacco product or cannabis in any of its forms, including but not limited to the following items: Cigarette papers, pipes or water pipes of any nature, and any item designed or used to hold cigarettes. 
(b)  No person shall sell, offer for sale, barter, give away or deliver any smoking paraphernalia to any individual under the age of eighteen (18) years. 
(Ord. No. 21-1978, §§ 1, 2, 6-13-78; Ord. No. 3-1996, § 3, 2-27-96) 
Sec. 20-6.2. - Possession of tobacco products by minors. 
    No minor under the age of eighteen (18) years shall buy or possess any cigars, cigarettes, smokeless tobacco or tobacco in any of its forms. For purposes of this section, "smokeless tobacco" means any tobacco products suitable for dipping or chewing. 
(Ord. No. 3-1996, § 2, 2-27-96) 
Sec. 20-6.3. - Self-service sales prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful to sell, offer for sale, give away, or display tobacco products for sale at any location where the consumer can acquire those products through self-service. All tobacco products will be displayed from behind a sales/service counter so that no consumer can access tobacco products without assistance by an employee of the licensee. This restriction shall not apply to customer self-service as described in section 20-6, Sale of cigarettes to minors. 
(Ord. No. 3-1996, § 4, 2-27-96; Ord. No. 24-2002, § 1, 8-27-02) 
Sec. 20-6.4. - Minimum age to sell tobacco products. 
    It shall be unlawful for any business operation or any officer, associate, member, representative, agent or employee of such business operation to engage, employ or permit any person under eighteen (18) years of age to sell tobacco products in any business operation premises. 
(Ord. No. 24-2002, § 2, 8-27-02) 
Sec. 20-6.5. - Penalty 
    Any person found in violation of sections 20-6, 20-6.1, 20-6.2, 20-6.3, or 20-6.4, shall be fined not less than fifty dollars ($50.00) nor more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00). Any owner of a cigarette vending machine who is found in violation of section 20-6 shall also have their existing cigarette vending permit suspended or revoked. 
(Ord. No. 24-2002, § 3, 8-27-02) 
Sec. 20-7. - Sale of plastic bags; warning. 
(a)  No person shall use a plastic covering, package or bag of any size ten (10) inches by ten (10) inches or larger for any article of dry cleaning or for packaging or bagging any article of merchandise for sale or distribution to the public, and no person shall have in his possession for use in any commercial business or for sale in any commercial business any such plastic bag, covering or package, unless there is printed thereon or on a tag securely attached thereto the following legend in letters at least one-quarter of an inch in height: 
"WARNING-To avoid danger of suffocation, keep this bag or material away from babies or children. Do not use in cribs, beds, carriages or playpens. This plastic material is not a toy." 
(b)  As used in this section, the term "plastic covering" or "plastic bag" shall mean any covering, package or bag made of a plastic material sufficiently thin and pliable to respond to static electricity created by contact with the human body to the extent that it clings thereto. 
(Ord. No. 13-1959, § 1, 8-25-59) 
Sec. 20-8. - Fences. 
(a)  Partition fences. No partition fence shall be constructed in the village which shall exceed six (6) feet in height above the surface of the ground, unless the written consent of the owner of the adjacent property is filed with the building inspector. 
(b)  Barbed-wire fences. No person shall build or use barbed wire on fences or railings fronting on any street within the village, except with the approval of the superintendent of public works. 
(c)  Nuisance. Any fence erected or in the process of erection contrary to the provisions of this section shall be a nuisance and it shall be the duty of the chief of police to abate the same. 
Sec. 20-8.1. - Vandalism generally; parental sufferance of acts of vandalism by minors prohibited. 
(a)  Definition. For the purposes of this section, the following definitions shall apply: 
(1)  "Person" shall include any individual, firm, partnership, association, corporation, company or organization of any kind. 
(2)  "Property" shall include any real estate, including any improvements thereon, and tangible personal property of any nature. 
(3)  "Parents" shall include the lawful father and mother of a minor child, whether by birth or adoption. 
(4)  "Legal guardian" shall include a person appointed guardian of a person, or given custody, of a minor by a circuit court of this state or any other state, but does not include a person appointed guardian only to the estate of a minor, or appointed guardian, or given custody, of a minor under the Illinois Juvenile Court Act. 
(5)  "Minor" shall include a person who is above the age of eleven (11) years, but not yet nineteen (19) years of age. 
(6)  "Vandalism" shall include any of the following acts: 
a.  Maliciously, recklessly, or knowingly damaging or destroying any property of another person without his consent; or 
b.  Maliciously, recklessly, or knowingly by means of fire or explosive device damage, debase, or destroy any property of another person; or 
c.  Maliciously, recklessly, or knowingly start a fire on land of another person without his consent; or 
d.  Maliciously, recklessly, or knowingly deposit on the land or in the building of another person, without his consent, any stink bomb, or any offensive smelling compound and thereby interfere with the use and occupancy by another, of the land or building; or 
e.  Maliciously, recklessly, or knowingly and without authority enter into any building, house trailer, motor vehicle, aircraft, or watercraft or any part thereof of another person without his consent. 
(7)  "Responsible parent" shall mean the parent or legal guardian of an unemancipated minor who resides with such parent or legal guardian. 
(b)  Vandalism prohibited. It shall be unlawful for any person to commit any act of vandalism upon either public or private property within the Village of Hazel Crest. Each separate act of vandalism shall be considered a separate violation of this section. 
(c)  Liability of responsible parent. A responsible parent of any minor found guilty of committing an act of vandalism upon either public or private property within the Village of Hazel Crest, shall be guilty of a violation of this section. Each separate act of vandalism shall be considered as a separate violation of this section. For purposes of enforcement of this provision the responsible parent shall be served with summons or notice to appear in the original proceeding as provided by law. 
(d)  Penalties; parental responsibility. Any person who violates any provisions of this section shall, upon conviction thereof, be fined in an amount not less than two hundred dollars ($200.00) nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) for each separate violation. In lieu thereof or in addition thereto, the penalty for violation of these provisions may include or consist of a requirement that the adult or minor violator perform some reasonable public service work, including but not limited to picking up litter on village property or maintenance of village facilities. 
(Ord. No. 36-1976, §§ 1-4, 11-23-76; Ord. No. 47-1979, § 1, 11-13-79; Ord. No. 25-1994, § 3, 11-9-94; Ord. No. 17-1995, § 1, 3-28-95) 
Sec. 20-9. - Destruction of property. 
    No person shall interfere with, injure, destroy, deface or assist in injuring, destroying or defacing any street, street sign, traffic device, curb, gutter, sewer, bridge, fence, building, sign, bulletin board, lamp, fire alarm box, post office box, police box, water hydrant or other public or private property within the village. 
(Code 1956, §§ 4.06, 17.34) 
Sec. 20-10. - Damaging public records. 
    No person shall remove, alter, damage or destroy any records kept or maintained by or in the custody of any village officer or employee, unless so authorized by the board of trustees. 
Sec. 20-11. - Tampering with utility meters. 
    No person shall break, deface, disturb, tamper or interfere with, carry away, or in any other way injure or destroy any water meter, gas meter or electric meter, or any seal attached to any portion of such meters, or any appliance connected therewith. No person shall make, attempt to make or cause to be made any connection between any water, gas or electric meter and any water or gas main, or any cable or wire supplying electric current, at any place within the village without a permit therefor. 
Sec. 20-12. - Trespassing. 
    No person shall enter upon any property in the village upon which there is conspicuously posted a notice forbidding trespassing or entering thereupon or after an oral warning not to trespass upon the same has been given by the owner or the agent of the owner, or otherwise commit a criminal trespass to either vehicle or land. 
Sec. 20-13. - Injuring plants. 
    No person shall cut, break or injure any flower, plant or tree upon any private property without the consent of the owner, or upon any public property except by permit approved by the superintendent of public works. 
Sec. 20-14. - Starting conflagrations. 
    No conflagration shall be maintained in the village except during the hours of daylight and as permitted by the village ordinances regulating burning. 
(Code 1956, § 17.32) 
Sec. 20-15. - Removal of grade stakes. 
    No person shall wilfully or heedlessly change, remove or destroy any stone, stake or post set to mark the corner of any lot or parcel of ground, street or alley, or to show the grade of any street, alley or sidewalk of the village. 
(Code 1956, § 17.33) 
Sec. 20-16. - False alarms. 
    No person shall knowingly give any false alarm of fire or other casualty, or give any false cry for assistance. 
(Code 1956, § 17.42) 
Sec. 20-17. - Illegal use of water. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to use a hose connected to the village hydrants without a permit. 
(Code 1956, § 17.43) 
Sec. 20-18. - Sale of poisons. 
    No person shall sell or deliver any poison, known to be a deadly poison, without legibly marking such fact and the word "poison" upon the phial, wrapper or other enclosure or package containing the same; or sell or deliver any arsenic, strychnine, prussic acid or other poison, usually known to be deadly poisons, to any person without registering the name of such person, the kind and quantity of the poison sold and delivered, and the purpose for which it was obtained; or sell or deliver any such poison to any person unknown to him; provided, however, that the sale of any such poison for medicine upon the prescription of a practicing physician shall not be deemed a violation of this section. 
(Code 1956, § 17.46) 
Sec. 20-19. - Restrictions on block or street parties. 
    Block or street parties shall be permitted in the village, subject to the following terms and conditions: 
(1)  The application for a permit for such party shall be made not later than ten (10) days before the date of such event. 
(2)  The applicant shall furnish a bond to indemnify the village against damages to property and to defend suits in law resulting from any accident by reason of such block or street parties. 
(3)  The application for such permit shall be approved as to location, area size and time, both by the department of police and the department of public works of the village. 
(Ord. No. 24-1968, § 1, 11-12-68) 
Sec. 20-20. - Theft by minors. 
(a)  No minor (as defined in section 20-8.1(a)(5) of this chapter) who knowingly: 
(1)  Obtains or exerts unauthorized control over property of the owner; 
(2)  Obtains by deception control over property of the owner; 
(3)  Obtains by threat control over property of the owner; or 
(4)  Obtains control over stolen property, knowing the property to have been stolen, or under such circumstances as would reasonably induce him to believe that the property was stolen; and either intends to deprive the owner permanently of the use or benefit of such property, knowingly uses, conceals or abandons the property in such manner as to deprive the owner permanently of such use or benefit, or uses, conceals or abandons the property, knowing such use, concealment or abandonment probably will deprive the owner permanently of such use or benefit, commits the offense of theft. 
(b)  A responsible parent (as defined in section 20-8.1(c) of this chapter) of any minor found guilty of committing an act of theft, shall be guilty of a violation of this section. Each separate act of theft shall be considered as a separate violation of this section. For purposes of enforcement of this provision, the responsible parent shall be served with summons or notice to appear in the original proceeding as provided by law. 
(c)  Penalties. Any person who violates any provision of this section shall upon conviction thereof be fined an amount not less than two hundred dollars ($200.00) nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) for each separate violation.
