Editor's note- Ord. No. 3-1982, § 1, adopted Feb. 9, 1982, repealed former §§ 21-1-21-7 which pertained to definitions, permits, and exemptions from Ch. 21, and were derived from Ord. No. 13-1963, §§ I-V, adopted Dec. 10, 1963. 
Cross reference- Licenses and miscellaneous business regulations, Ch. 17. 
State Law reference- Authority to license, tax, regulate or prohibit peddlers, itinerant merchants and transient vendors, 65 ILCS 5/11-42-5. 

Secs. 21-1-21-10. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - SOLICITING 

Sec. 21-11. - Definitions. 
    For the purpose of this article the following words as used herein shall be construed to have the meaning herein ascribed thereto, to wit: 
    Soliciting shall mean and include any one or more of the following activities: 
(1)  Seeking to obtain orders for the purchase of goods, wares, merchandise, foodstuffs, services, of any kind, character or description whatever, for any kind of consideration whatever; or 
(2)  Seeking to obtain prospective customers for application or purchase of insurance of any type, kind or character; or 
(3)  Seeking to obtain subscriptions to books, magazines, periodicals, newspapers and every other type or kind of publication; or 
(4)  Seeking to obtain gifts or contributions of money, clothing or any other valuable things for the support or benefit of any charitable or nonprofit association, organization, corporation, or project. 
    Residence shall mean and include every separate living unit occupied for residential purposes by one or more persons, contained within any type of building or structure. 
    Registered solicitor shall mean and include any person who has obtained a valid certificate of registration as hereinafter provided, and which certificate is in the possession of the solicitor on his or her person while engaged in soliciting. 
(Ord. No. 1-1974, § 1, 1-8-74) 
Sec. 21-12. - Certificate of registration required. 
    Every person desiring to engage in soliciting as herein defined from persons in residences within this municipality, is hereby required to make written application for a certificate of registration as hereinafter provided. 
(Ord. No. 1-1974, § 2, 1-8-74) 
Sec. 21-13. - Application for certificate of registration; contents; application to be under oath; records; persons to whom certificate will not issue. 
(a)  Application for a certificate of registration shall be made upon a form provided by the chief of police of this municipality and filed with such chief. The applicant shall truthfully state in full the information requested on the application, to wit: 
(1)  Name and address of present place of residence and length of residence at such address; also business address if other than residence address; also social security number; 
(2)  Address of place of residence during the past three (3) years if other than present address; 
(3)  Age of applicant and marital status; and if married, the name of spouse; 
(4)  Physical description of the applicant; 
(5)  Name and address of the person, firm or corporation or association whom the applicant is employed by or represents; and the length of time of such employment or representation; 
(6)  Name and address of employer during the past three (3) years if other than the present employer; 
(7)  Description sufficient for identification of the subject matter of the soliciting which the applicant will engage in; 
(8)  Period of time for which the certificate is applied for; 
(9)  The date, or approximate date, of the latest previous application for certificate under this article, if any; 
(10)  Has a certificate of registration issued to the applicant under this article ever been revoked; 
(11)  Has the applicant ever been convicted of a violation of any of the provisions of this article or the ordinance of any other Illinois municipality regulating soliciting; 
(12)  Has the applicant ever been convicted of the commission of a felony under the laws of the State of Illinois or any other state or federal law of the United States; 
(13)  Also such additional information as the chief of police may deem necessary to process the application. 
(b)  All statements made by the applicant upon the application or in connection therewith shall be under oath. 
(c)  The chief of police shall cause to be kept in his office an accurate record of every application received and acted upon together with all other information and data pertaining thereto and all certificates of registration issued under the provisions of this article, and of the denial of applications. Applications for certificates shall be numbered in consecutive order as filed, and every certificate issued and any renewal thereof, shall be identified with the duplicate number of the application upon which it was issued. 
(d)  No certificate of registration shall be issued to any person who has been convicted of the commission of a felony under the laws of the State of Illinois or any other state or federal law of the United States, within five (5) years of the date of the application; nor to any person who has been convicted of a violation of any of the provisions of this article; nor to any person whose certificate of registration issued hereunder has previously been revoked as herein provided. 
(Ord. No. 1-1974, § 3, 1-8-74) 
Sec. 21-14. - Issuance, denial, revocation of certificate. 
(a)  The chief of police or his designee, after consideration of the application and all information obtained relative thereto, shall deny the application if the applicant does not possess the qualifications for such certificate as herein required, and that the issuance of a certificate of registration to the applicant would not be in accord with the intent and purpose of this article. Endorsement shall be made by the chief of police or his designee upon the application of the denial of the application. The decision as to whether or not said certificate of registration shall issue shall be made in seven (7) days. 
(b)  Any certificate of registration issued hereunder shall be revoked by the chief of police if the holder of the certificate is convicted of a violation of any of the provisions of this article, or has made a false material statement in the application, or otherwise becomes disqualified for the issuance of a certificate of registration under the terms of this article. Immediately upon such revocation written notice thereof shall be given by the chief of police to the holder of the certificate in person or by certified U.S. mail addressed to his or her residence address set forth in the application. 
(c)  Immediately upon the giving of such notice the certificate of registration shall become null and void. 
(d)  The certificate of registration shall state the expiration date thereof. 
(Ord. No. 1-1974, § 4, 1-8-74; Ord. No. 3-1982, § 2, 2-9-82) 
Sec. 21-15. - Village policy of soliciting. 
    It is hereby declared to be the policy of the governing body of this municipality that the occupant or occupants of the residences in this municipality shall make the determination of whether solicitors shall be invited to their respective residences. 
(Ord. No. 1-1974, § 5, 1-8-74; Ord. No. 3-1982, § 3, 2-9-82) 
Sec. 21-16. - Notice regulating soliciting. 
    Every person desiring to secure the protection intended to be provided by the regulations pertaining to soliciting contained in this article, shall comply with the following directions, to wit: 
Notice of the determination by the occupant of the refusal of invitation to solicitors to any residence, shall be given in the manner following: A card, approximately three (3) inches by four (4) inches in size, shall be exhibited upon or near the main entrance door to the residence, indicating the determination by the occupant, containing the applicable words, as follows: 
"NO SOLICITORS INVITED" 
The letters shall be at least one-fourth (1/4) inch in height. For the purpose of uniformity, the cards shall be provided by the village clerk to persons requesting, at the cost thereof. 
Such card so exhibited shall constitute sufficient notice to any solicitor of the determination by the occupant of the residence of the information contained thereon. 
(Ord. No. 1-1974, § 6, 1-8-74; Ord. No. 3-1982, § 4, 2-9-82) 
Sec. 21-17. - Duty of solicitors. 
(a)  It shall be the duty of every solicitor upon going onto any premises in the municipality upon which a residence as herein defined is located to first examine the notice provided for in section 21-16 of this article, if any is attached, and be governed by the statement contained on the notice. If the notice states "NO SOLICITORS INVITED," then the solicitor shall immediately and peacefully depart from the premises. 
(b)  Any solicitor who has gained entrance to any residence, whether invited or not shall immediately and peacefully depart from the premises when requested to do so by the occupant. 
(Ord. No. 1-1974, § 7, 1-8-74; Ord. No. 3-1982, § 5, 2-9-82) 
Sec. 21-18. - Uninvited soliciting prohibited. 
    It is hereby declared to be unlawful and shall constitute a nuisance for any person to go upon any premises and ring the door bell upon or near any door, or create any sound in any other manner calculated to attract the attention of the occupant of such residence, for the purpose of securing an audience with the occupant thereof and engage in soliciting as herein defined, in defiance of the notice exhibited at the residence in accordance with the provisions of section 21-16 of this article. 
(Ord. No. 1-1974, § 8, 1-8-74) 
Sec. 21-19. - Time limit on soliciting. 
    It is hereby declared to be unlawful and shall constitute a nuisance for any person to go upon any premises and ring the door bell upon or near any door of a residence located thereon, or rap or knock upon any door, or create any sound in any other matter calculated to attract the attention of the occupant of such residence, for the purpose of securing an audience with the occupant thereof and engage in soliciting as herein defined, prior to 9:00 a.m. or after 9:00 p.m. on any weekday including Saturday, or at any time on a Sunday or on a state or national holiday. 
(Ord. No. 1-1974, § 9, 1-8-74; Ord. No. 3-1982, § 6, 2-9-82) 
Sec. 21-20. - Severance clause. 
    If any section, paragraph, clause or provision of this article shall be held invalid, the invalidity thereof shall not affect any of the other provisions of this article. 
(Ord. No. 1-1974, § 10, 1-8-74) 
Sec. 21-21. - Tag days; street solicitation prohibited. 
(a)  Permit required. It shall be unlawful for organizations of a charitable nature to solicit funds for charitable purposes within the village by the distribution of symbols, i.e. peanuts, poppies, paper emblems, etc., the possession of such symbol indicating that the possessor has contributed to such fund; provided, that a permit therefor shall have been granted therefor by the president and board of trustees. 
(b)  Organizations permitted. A permit provided for in this section shall be granted only to any charitable, religious or national or local society which shall have been in existence for not less than one year, and which shall be performing a charitable function or be engaged in charitable or religious work which, in the opinion of the village president and board of trustees, shall be commensurate with the funds received and distributed by it. 
(c)  Application for permit. An organization desiring to conduct a tag day shall make application for a permit therefor to the village clerk at least sixty (60) days before the day upon which it is proposed to hold tag day and shall, at the time such application is made, submit to the village clerk a statement showing its receipts from the tag day of the previous year in Hazel Crest and shall also submit a statement as to the date of any residential or other solicitation during the year with the village clerk who upon investigation shall present his/her recommendation granting or denying the permit to the board of trustees. 
(d)  Number of permits. No organization shall be granted a permit to conduct more than one tag day in any one calendar year. One day is defined as from 6:00 a.m. to 9:00 p.m. for the purpose of this section. 
(e)  Paid solicitors. The employment of paid solicitors or the paying for services in the conduct of any tag day by any organization is prohibited. 
(f)  Street solicitation prohibited. No person shall stand on a street or highway within the village for the purpose of soliciting employment, business, sales or contributions from the occupant of a vehicle. 
(Ord. No. 1-1974, § 11, 1-8-74; Ord. No. 23-1992, §§ 1-3, 10-27-92) 
Sec. 21-22. - Penalty. 
    Any person violating any of the provisions of this article shall, upon conviction thereof, be subject to a fine of not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) for each offense. 
(Ord. No. 1-1974, § 12, 1-8-74) 
ARTICLE III. - HALLOWEEN SOLICITATION[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 41-1975, § 1, adopted Oct. 28, 1975, specifically amended the Code by adding Art. III, §§ 21-23, 21-24 as herein set out. 
Cross reference- Offenses and miscellaneous provisions, Ch. 20. 

Sec. 21-23. - Definition. 
    For the purpose of this section, Halloween solicitation shall mean seeking or obtaining gifts, food, candy or contributions of money, as is customarily in the celebration of Halloween Day. 
(Ord. No. 41-1975, § 1, 10-28-75) 
Sec. 21-24. - Time limit on Halloween solicitation. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person, whether alone or in a group, to conduct such solicitation as set forth in the preceding section on any day other than October 31, provided further that all solicitation on October 31 be terminated by 7:30 p.m. 
(Ord. No. 41-1975, § 1, 10-28-75) 
ARTICLE IV. - PRECIOUS GEMS BUSINESSES 

Sec. 21-25. - Declaration of policy. 
    The purpose of this article is to protect the public health, safety and welfare through the enactment of this article, which: 
(1)  Establishes procedures for the regulation of businesses that participate in the buying and selling of precious gems and precious metals. 
(2)  Establishes license requirements for individuals buying and selling precious gems and precious metals. 
(3)  Provides for the administration and the enforcement of this article. 
    This article shall be liberally construed to carry out its intended purposes. 
(Ord. No. 10-2011, § 3, 8-16-11; Ord. No. 05-2012, § 3, 3-27-12) 
Sec. 21-26. - Other ordinances. 
    This article shall not be construed to prevent the enforcement of other applicable ordinances, codes, statutes, laws, orders, rules, or regulations that prescribe standards for the subject matter of this article. In the event of a conflict between the provisions of the article and any other ordinance, code, statute, law, order, rule or regulation, the most restrictive shall apply. 
(Ord. No. 10-2011, § 3, 8-16-11; Ord. No. 05-2012, § 3, 3-27-12) 
Sec. 21-27. - Definitions and scope. 
(a)  Definitions. The words and terms used in this article shall have the meanings as ascribed to them in this section, unless the context clearly indicates a different meaning. The use of any term in the present tense shall include the future and past tense of the term, when applicable, and all terms used in the singular shall include the plural and all words used in the masculine gender shall extend to and apply to the feminine gender, when applicable. 
    Employee permit means a permit issued to an employee or agent of a precious gems broker issued pursuant to this article. 
    Precious gems include, but are not limited to: diamonds, opals, citrine, garnet, sapphire, ruby, emerald, tourmaline, quartz, turquoise, morganite, kunzite, topaz, aquamarine, zircon, tanzanite, alexandrite, coral, pearl, amethyst, apalite, jade, peridot, moonstone, lapis, malachite, iolite, diopside, tiger's eye, onyx, ivory, or any composition or jewelry containing any amount of said gems. 
    Precious gems broker means any person having an interest in, employed by, acting as an agent of or on behalf of any person having an interest in a business whose undertakings involve the purchase or sale of precious gems or precious metals as defined herein, but excluding those persons or businesses licensed by the state under 205 ILCS 510/0.01, et seq., the Pawnbroker Regulation Act. 
    Precious gems businesses mean businesses that participate in the buying and selling of precious gems and or precious metals. 
    Precious metals include, but are not limited to: any metal or alloy thereof containing any amount of gold, silver, sterling, platinum, copper, brass, nickel, palladium, rhodium, iridium, osmium, rhenium, mercury, indium, bismuth, or gallium, and includes U.S. Minted Currency containing any of the above metals. 
(b)  Scope. The scope of this article and "transactions" as used herein shall be limited on individual non-stock or otherwise not accounted for sales of goods to a precious gem broker the sale of stock goods or the purchase of goods from a precious gem broker do not fall under the scope of under the restrictions of this article. 
(Ord. No. 10-2011, § 3, 8-16-11; Ord. No. 05-2012, § 3, 3-27-12) 
Sec. 21-28. - Records. 
(a)  Every precious gems broker, shall keep a record of all transactions involving the purchase, sale, barter, exchange or other conveyance or receipt of any precious gems or precious metals. 
(b)  All records must be kept in compliance with the following standards: 
(1)  Records must be legibly printed by hand or computer in the English language. 
(2)  Records must be made at the time of the transaction and shall display the following regarding the precious gems broker: Name, age, date of birth, gender and place of residence. 
(3)  Records must contain the following information regarding the transaction: General description of the individual with whom the transaction is had and the signature of the individual on the receipt of the permanent record, the date and time of the transaction and the signature of the precious gems broker who consummated said transaction. 
(4)  A photocopy of a valid state issued driver's license or state issued identification card bearing the photograph of the customer with whom the transaction was consummated. 
(5)  For each record, the precious gems broker shall photograph the customer with a clear and visible view of the customer's face and head. Customers name shall be inscribed on the back of said photograph, and the photograph shall be maintained with the other record of said transaction. 
(6)  If the customer does not have a valid state issued driver's license or identification card containing a photograph, name and address of the customer, two (2) kinds of identification must be shown, and one of the two (2) forms of identification must include the customer's residence address. These forms of identification shall include but not be limited to the following: passport, social security card, utility bill, employee or student identification card, or a civic, union or professional association membership card, at least one (1) of the aforementioned must contain a photographic identification. 
(7)  A description of every article received, purchased, sold or exchanged by giving the manufacturer's name and other marks of identification appearing on the article including, but not limited to, the serial number and engravings, if any, on the article, and a complete description of all components or pieces of each article, including any stones, gems and the weight and composition of the metal comprising the article. 
(8)  The price or other consideration received, and the name and address of the receiving party in the case of sale, and the sales price in the case of a purchase, and the method of payment. 
(c)  All entries in the record shall be signed and dated by the precious gems broker making the entry. 
(d)  Such records shall be retained for a period of one (1) year from the date of the transaction. 
(Ord. No. 10-2011, § 3, 8-16-11; Ord. No. 05-2012, § 3, 3-27-12) 
Sec. 21-29. - Daily report. 
    It shall be the duty of the precious gems broker to complete and make available for the inspection by the chief of police or his designee before 12:00 p.m., each business day, a copy of the records required to be kept under this article, reflecting the completed transactions of the previous day. 
(Ord. No. 10-2011, § 3, 8-16-11; Ord. No. 05-2012, § 3, 3-27-12) 
Sec. 21-30. - Inspections. 
    All precious gems brokers must prepare and keep available records to reflect all items purchased, received, kept for sale or exchange for inspection by any member of the village police department or any agent authorized in writing to conduct such inspections on behalf of the chief of police or his designee during reasonable business times. 
(Ord. No. 10-2011, § 3, 8-16-11; Ord. No. 05-2012, § 3, 3-27-12) 
Sec. 21-31. - Precious gems brokers license required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in precious gems businesses without first obtaining a license from the village, as set forth in this article. 
(Ord. No. 10-2011, § 3, 8-16-11; Ord. No. 05-2012, § 3, 3-27-12) 
Sec. 21-32. - Precious gems brokers license application. 
(a)  An application form shall be provided to potential precious gems brokers by the office of the village clerk. All applicants must truthfully express the following information upon the license application: 
(1)  Personal identification: Name, place of residence, length of residency at the aforementioned address, social security number and date of birth. 
(2)  Photographic identification: Copy of current state photo identification or driver's license. 
(3)  Date of previous application: The date, or approximate date, of any previous applications for a precious gems broker's license. 
(4)  Revocation history: The applicant's historical background related to the revocation of any prior precious gems broker licenses. 
(5)  History of a violation conviction: Whether the applicant has ever been convicted for violating any of the provisions of this chapter or the ordinances of any other Illinois municipality regulating the activities of precious gems brokers or similar such ordinances or laws of other jurisdictions. 
(6)  History of felony convictions: Whether the applicant has ever been convicted of the commission of a felony under the laws of the state or any other state or federal law of the United States, or had a legal disposition of a sentence for a crime involving theft or dishonesty. 
(b)  All statements made by the applicant upon the application or in connection therewith shall be under oath. 
(c)  Every applicant may be required to submit to fingerprinting by the police department in connection with the application for a precious gems brokers license. The applicant shall pay the fee as set by the Illinois State Police for fingerprint submissions. 
(d)  The office of the village clerk shall cause to be kept an accurate record of every application received and acted upon together with all other information and data pertaining thereto and all precious gems brokers' licenses issued under the provisions of this chapter and of the denial of applications. The clerk shall forward a copy of said record to the chief of police on a quarterly basis. 
(e)  No precious gems brokers license or precious gems broker's employee permit, shall be issued to any person who has been convicted of the commission of a felony under the laws of the state or federal law of the United Sates within five (5) years of the date of the application; nor to any person who has been convicted of a violation of any of the provisions of this chapter, nor to any person who has been convicted of any criminal offense involving theft, possession of stolen property or dishonesty, or whose precious gems broker's license issued hereunder has previously been revoked as herein provided. 
(f)  In the event any of the aforementioned regulations is superseded or conflicts with in any way with any provisions of this article and any other ordinance, code, statute, law, order, rule or regulation, the aforementioned regulation shall be read as having no force and effect. 
(Ord. No. 10-2011, § 3, 8-16-11; Ord. No. 05-2012, § 3, 3-27-12) 
Sec. 21-33. - License fee. 
    Each precious gems broker's license applicant shall pay a five hundred dollar ($500.00) application fee for the original application, and two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) for each annual renewal license application. A person or business licensed by the village and state to do business as a pawnbroker ("pawnbroker") defined in and pursuant to the Pawnbroker's Regulation Act, 205 ILCS 510/1 et seq. shall not be required to obtain a precious gems broker's license. However, those licensed by the village and state to transact business as pawnbrokers shall otherwise comply with all the rules and regulations established herein. Should there be any conflict between the terms of this article of the Village Code and the Pawnbroker's Regulation Act cited above, the provisions of the more restrictive law shall apply. 
(Ord. No. 10-2011, § 3, 8-16-11; Ord. No. 05-2012, § 3, 3-27-12) 
Sec. 21-34. - Issuance of license for precious gems broker's license. 
    The village manager or designee of the village president, after consideration of the application and all information obtained relative thereto, and after the return of the fingerprint check by the state police shall, within thirty (30) business days, shall approve or deny the application. If the applicant does not possess the qualifications for a license, as herein required, and the issuance of a license to the applicant would not be in accordance with the intent and purpose of this chapter, then the village manager or designee of the village president shall deny the application. If the applicant is found to be fully qualified, the license shall be issued only if the application fees have been paid in full. 
(Ord. No. 10-2011, § 3, 8-16-11; Ord. No. 05-2012, § 3, 3-27-12) 
Sec. 21-35. - Prohibitions. 
(a)  No precious gems broker licensed hereunder shall operate or allow its business to operate before the hour of 9:00 a.m. or after the hour of 9:00 p.m. 
(b)  The village shall establish rules and regulations regarding the engaging in precious gems businesses as needs require. 
(c)  No precious gems broker, precious gems broker's agent or employee shall sell, transfer, exchange, or dispose of, or melt, transfigure or transform from the design and form in which it was received any precious gem as defined herein within seven (7) days of the date it was received. 
(Ord. No. 10-2011, § 3, 8-16-11; Ord. No. 05-2012, § 3, 3-27-12) 
Sec. 21-36. - Employee permit. 
    No precious gem broker shall allow an agent, employee or other person to act on his behalf transacting any purchase, sale, exchange or other transfer of any precious metal or precious gem until such agent, employee, or person has applied for and been approved by the village for a precious gem broker's employee permit. 
    A precious gem broker's employee permit application shall be provided by the village clerk. The employee permit applicant shall be subject to the same processing regulations, rules and prohibitions as established herein and imposed upon a precious gem broker license applicant. Each employee permit applicant or precious gem broker shall bear the cost of fingerprinting which shall be paid at the time the permit application is made. The fee for an employee permit shall be fifty dollars ($50.00) and shall be paid to the village at the time application is made. 
(Ord. No. 10-2011, § 3, 8-16-11; Ord. No. 05-2012, § 3, 3-27-12) 
Sec. 21-37. - Penalties and enforcement. 
(a)  Violations of this article shall be civil in nature and prosecuted under the terms of the village administrative adjudication ordinance and the rules and regulations contained therein. Fines for violations may be imposed up to seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) per incident and administrative remedies including but not limited to the suspension and revocation of precious gems business licenses. 
(b)  A license or employee permit may be suspended or revoked in the sole discretion of the president, if after proper written notice to the precious gems broker and hearing by the president, or his/her designee, it is determined by a preponderance of the evidence that said offending precious gems broker, agent or employee violated this article, state statute or federal statute or any other law of general applicability in the operation of the licensed business. 
(Ord. No. 10-2011, § 3, 8-16-11; Ord. No. 05-2012, § 3, 3-27-12) 
Sec. 21-38. - Severability. 
    If any section, subsection, sentence, clause phrase or portion of this article is for any reason held invalid or unconstitutional by any court of competent jurisdiction, such portion shall be deemed a separate, distinct and independent provision and such holding shall not affect the validity of the remaining portions hereof. 
(Ord. No. 10-2011, § 3, 8-16-11; Ord. No. 05-2012, § 3, 3-27-12) 
Chapter 22 - PLANNING[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Administration generally, Ch. 2; civil defense and emergencies, Ch. 7; floodplain management, Ch. 11; subdivision regulations, App. A. 
State Law reference- Planning and planning commissions, 65 ILCS 5/11-12-4. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 22-1. - Official plan. 
(a)  Adoption. The Official Comprehensive Plan of the Village of Hazel Crest, adopted January 25, 1977, is hereby amended to include the June, 1985 update as recommended by the plan commission to the president and board of trustees on March 10, 1986. 
(b)  Designation; use. The plan, along with the June 1985 update described in subsection (a) of this section, shall be known as the "Updated Official Comprehensive Plan of the Village of Hazel Crest," and shall be used and followed in the making of public improvements and layout of streets, alleys, parks, thoroughfares, subdivision, resubdivision, areas of redevelopment, playgrounds, ways for public service, and other public grounds within the village, and in unincorporated contiguous territory outside the village limits and within the limits described by statute. 
(c)  Construction of plan. Such plan shall be advisory only and in and of itself shall not be construed to regulate or control the use of private property in any way, except as to such part as has been implemented by ordinances duly enacted by the president and board of trustees. 
(Ord. No. 3-1958, § 2, 2-25-58; Ord. No. 1-1977, § 1, 1-25-77; Ord. No. 14-1986, §§ 1, 2, 6-10-86) 
State Law reference- Adoption of plans, 65 ILCS 5/11-12-6, 5/11-12-27. 
Secs. 22-2-22-12. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - PLANNING AND ZONING COMMISSION[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 17-1999, adopted Dec. 14, 1999, amended Art. II, §§ 22-13-22-19 in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former Art. II, §§ 22-13-22-19, pertained to similar subject matter, and derived from Code 1956, §§ 6.01-6.07; Ord. No. 22-1974, § 1, 7-9-74; Ord. No. 33-1975, § 1, 9-9-75; Ord. No. 20-1994, § 8, 9-13-94. 
Cross reference- Subsidiary boards and commissions generally, § 2-220 et seq. 
State Law reference- Plan commissions, 65 ILCS 5/11-12-4 et seq. 

Sec. 22-13. - Created. 
    There is hereby created a commission for the village to be known as the Planning and Zoning Commission of the Village of Hazel Crest. 
(Code 1956, § 6.01; Ord. No. 17-1999, § 1, 12-14-99) 
Sec. 22-14. - Membership. 
    The commission created by this article shall consist of nine (9) members, one (1) of whom shall be the chairman. 
(Code 1956, § 6.02; Ord. No. 22-1974, § 1, 7-9-74; Ord. No. 33-1975, § 1, 9-9-75; Ord. No. 17-1999, § 1, 12-14-99) 
Sec. 22-15. - Appointment; qualifications. 
    The members of the planning and zoning commission shall be residents of the village. 
(Code 1956, § 6.03; Ord. No. 17-1999, § 1, 12-14-99) 
Sec. 22-16. - Terms of office. 
    All members of the planning and zoning commission shall be appointed by the village president, subject to the advice and consent of the board of trustees. Three (3) members of the commission shall be appointed for an initial term of five (5) years; three (3) members shall be appointed for an initial term of four (4) years; and three (3) members shall be appointed for an initial term of three (3) years. Thereafter, all members of the commission shall be appointed for a term of five (5) years and shall serve until their successors are appointed and qualified. 
    The terms of all commissioners appointed prior to May 1, 2008, shall expire on May 1, 2008. Thereafter, all commissioners shall serve one-year terms for a term of May 1 through the following April 30. All commissioners shall be appointed by the mayor with the advice and consent of the village board of trustees. 
(Code 1956, § 6.04; Ord. No. 17-1999, § 1, 12-14-99; Ord. No. 01-2008, § 3, 1-22-08) 
Sec. 22-17. - Statutory functions. 
    The planning and zoning commission shall be responsible for all matters assigned to it by the president and board of trustees pursuant to the Hazel Crest Village Code, the Hazel Crest Zoning Ordinance or any special direction. In those instances where the planning and zoning commission is deciding matters pursuant to specific statutory authority, two (2) of the nine (9) members of the commission shall recuse themselves in such a manner as the commission determines, so that such matter is being decided by a board of seven (7). 
(Code 1956, § 6.05; Ord. No. 17-1999, § 1, 12-14-99) 
Sec. 22-18. - Powers, duties. 
    The planning and zoning commission shall have the following powers and duties: 
(1)  To study the following: past growth and changes in land and building uses, present conditions and zoning, and trends of development which are especially pertinent to the commission's work; and to estimate the probable extent, character and location of future growth; 
(2)  To develop and recommend ammendments to the village's comprehensive plan periodically, but no less that every five (5) years. 
(3)  To initiate and recommend to the village board of trustees from time to time plans or recommendations for specific improvements to implement in furtherance of the official comprehensive plan; 
(4)  Reserved. 
(5)  To review and recommend petitions and projects for new development in compliance with the comprehensive plan; 
(6)  To perform all matters previously performed by either the Hazel Crest Plan Commission or the Hazel Crest Zoning Board of Appeals pursuant to the Hazel Crest Zoning Ordinance. 
(7)  To designate land suitable for annexation to the village and the recommended zoning classification for such land upon annexation; 
(8)  To cooperate with municipal or regional planning commissions and other agencies or groups to further the local planning program and to assure harmonious and integrated planning for the area; 
(9)  To review traffic planning issues and to formulate recommendations for resolution to the village board of trustees; 
(10)  To exercise such other duties germane to the powers granted under authority of law as may be conferred by the board of trustees of the village; 
(11)  To provide an annual report of its activities to the board of trustees. 
(Code 1956, § 6.06; Ord. No. 20-1994, § 8, 9-13-94; Ord. No. 17-1999, § 2, 12-14-99) 
Secs. 22-19-22-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT COMMISSION 

Sec. 22-31. - Created. 
    It is hereby created an economic development commission whose purpose it is to promote and encourage business development within the Village of Hazel Crest. 
(Ord. No. 4-2002, § 1, 1-22-02) 
Sec. 22-32. - Membership; terms; quorum. 
    The commission shall consist of seven (7) members appointed by the village president with the advice and consent of the board of trustees. Initially, two (2) members shall be appointed for a term ending April 30, 2003; two (2) members shall be appointed for a term ending April 30, 2004; three (3) members shall be appointed for a term ending April 30, 2005. Thereafter, each member appointed shall serve for a term of three (3) years or until the successor is duly appointed. Any four (4) members of the commission shall constitute a quorum. All members serve without salary or any other type of compensation, as a result of acting as a member of said commission. 
    The terms of all commissioners appointed prior to May 1, 2008, shall expire on May 1, 2008. Thereafter, all commissioners shall serve one-year terms for a term of May 1 through the following April 30. All commissioners shall be appointed by the mayor with the advice and consent of the village board of trustees. 
(Ord. No. 4-2002, § 1, 1-22-02; Ord. No. 01-2008, § 4, 1-22-08) 
Sec. 22-33. - Appointment; qualifications. 
    The members of the commission created by this article shall be appointed by the president and board of trustees, voting jointly, and the president shall appoint one (1) of the members as chairman of the commission. Members shall either be residents of the village or members of the village business community. Where possible, the appointed members will have a broad base of professional and complementary expertise in the fields of financing, advertising, retail and economic development. 
(Ord. No. 4-2002, § 1, 1-22-02) 
Sec. 22-34. - Filling of vacancies. 
    Upon the death, resignation, removal by disqualification or expiration of term of any member of said commission, the village president, with the advice and consent of the board of trustees, shall appoint a member who shall hold membership for the unexpired term in the event. 
(Ord. No. 4-2002, § 1, 1-22-02) 
Sec. 22-35. - Ethics policy. 
    All members shall adhere to and abide by the provisions of section 2-262 of the Hazel Crest Village Code. 
(Ord. No. 4-2002, § 1, 1-22-02) 
Sec. 22-36. - Responsibilities. 
    The commission shall advise the board of trustees on matters relating to maintaining a favorable economic climate in the village. To that end, the commission is charged with the following tasks and goals: 
(1)  Studying the conditions and trends of development, advise the trustees of growth and potential growth and recommend policies and objectives for economic development efforts; 
(2)  Developing recommendations for a village-wide marketing strategy for undeveloped business properties, including the development of promotional material; 
(3)  Developing strategy recommendations for a business expansion and retention (BEAR) program, and implementing visitations upon approval by the village board to identify and encourage businesses to remain in Hazel Crest; 
(4)  Following a board-approved plan to meet with owners of undeveloped business property to determine ways in which the village can assist them in the marketing of the property; 
(5)  Following a board-approved plan to meet with businesses to encourage and assist their locating in Hazel Crest; 
(6)  Advising the board on whether the employment of a professional marketing consultant is necessary to accomplish quality economic development; 
(7)  Assisting property owners in finding tenants for vacant businesses; 
(8)  Participating in welcoming new businesses to the village; 
(9)  When authorized by the board, sponsoring small business seminars as a mechanism to encourage the growth of small business development; and 
(10)  Engaging in such advisory functions as may be referred to the commission from time to time by the board of trustees. 
    The commission shall have no power to bind the village. 
(Ord. No. 4-2002, § 1, 1-22-02) 
Sec. 22-37. - Meetings. 
    Meetings of the commission created by this article shall be held in the municipal center and shall be held at such times as the commission may prescribe, provided that meetings shall be held not less often than once each quarter, and that the proper legal notifications of meetings have occurred. All meetings are subject to the Illinois Open Meetings Act. 
(Ord. No. 4-2002, § 1, 1-22-02) 
Sec. 22-38. - Reports. 
    The commission created by this article shall make an annual report on its activities at a village board meeting held in february. Minutes of all meetings must be filed with the village clerk. 
(Ord. No. 4-2002, § 1, 1-22-02) 
Secs. 22-39-22-49. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - BEAUTIFICATION COMMISSION[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference- Subsidiary boards and commissions generally, § 2-220 et seq. 

Sec. 22-50. - Duties and responsibilities. 
    The commission shall be responsible for, but not limited to the following: 
(1)  To develop and to encourage public awareness of beautification and environmental concerns through various educational outreach programs and to encourage the use of facilities or programs which promote the sensible use of natural resources, such as recycling and composting; 
(2)  To develop and coordinate a beautification awards program to promote community pride and to recognize efforts of local residents and businesses in the continued beautification of the village; 
(3)  To provide a program which advises village residents about methods of improving the appearance of their neighborhoods; 
(4)  To provide a village-wide program for new or replacement trees and other planting stock by overseeing and stimulating aesthetic improvements; 
(5)  To encourage and promote the general appearance of the village through the review and recommendation of landscape plans for new subdivisions and for businesses to the plan commission; 
(6)  To develop a volunteer corps for labor and expertise to draw upon when necessary; 
(7)  To maintain the village's Tree City USA designation; 
(8)  To actively pursue the development and improvements of open lands throughout the village; and 
(9)  To develop an annual work plan and to subsequently report to the village board of trustees summarizing the activities of the commission. 
(10)  Such other matters as may be specifically assigned by the board of trustees. 
(Ord. No. 25-1980, § 1, 9-23-80; Ord. No. 20-1994, § 1, 9-13-94) 
Sec. 22-51. - Number of members. 
    The commission shall consist of seven (7) members, none of whom shall be paid or granted any salary or other compensation from the village as a result of acting as a member of said commission. 
(Ord. No. 25-1980, § 1, 9-23-80; Ord. No. 29-1988, § 1, 7-26-88; Ord. No. 20-1994, § 1, 9-13-94) 
Sec. 22-52. - Appointments of members. 
    The chairperson and members of the commission shall be appointed by the village president with the advice and consent of the board of trustees. All appointive members shall serve until their successors are appointed and qualified unless removed from the commission as hereinafter provided in this article. 
(Ord. No. 25-1980, § 1, 9-23-80; Ord. No. 20-1994, § 3, 9-13-94) 
Sec. 22-53. - Terms of members. 
    All terms shall be for a three-year period provided, however, that the terms of office of the first commission shall be decided by the drawing of lots, three (3) members receiving one-year terms, three (3) members receiving two-year terms, and three (3) members receiving three-year terms. 
    The terms of all commissioners appointed prior to May 1, 2008, shall expire on May 1, 2008. Thereafter, all commissioners shall serve one-year terms for a term of May 1 through the following April 30. All commissioners shall be appointed by the mayor with the advice and consent of the village board of trustees. 
(Ord. No. 25-1980, § 1, 9-23-80; Ord. No. 01-2008, § 5, 1-22-08) 
Sec. 22-54. - Vacancies. 
    Upon the death, resignation, removal by disqualification or expiration of term of office of any members of said commission, the village president with the advice and consent of the board of trustees shall appoint a member or members of said commission who shall hold his membership on said commission for the unexpired term to which he is appointed in the event a vacancy created before a full term expired; otherwise, he shall serve the full term of three (3) years in the event he is succeeding a member whose term has fully expired. 
(Ord. No. 25-1980, § 1, 9-23-80) 
Sec. 22-55. - Qualifications of members. 
    No person shall be a voting member of said commission unless such person is a resident of the Village of Hazel Crest. 
(Ord. No. 25-1980, § 1, 9-23-80) 
Sec. 22-56. - Removal of commission members. 
    Any member who fails to attend three (3) consecutive regular meetings of the commission for any reason other than sickness or absence from the village or who shall fail to attend at least fifty (50) percent of the regular meetings in any one (1) year shall be disqualified from serving on the commission, and upon certification of such absence by the secretary of the commission, shall be replaced in the manner prescribed in this article. 
(Ord. No. 25-1980, § 1, 9-23-80) 
Sec. 22-57. - Chairperson. 
    The chairperson of the commission may establish such committees as may be necessary or appropriate to assist the commission in its studies and in the performance of its duties. Members of such committees may be appointed from among members of the commission, either voting or consulting, or from among the general public. However, the formation of such committees and the appointments thereto shall be first approved by the commission. The chairperson of the commission shall designate a voting commission member to serve as chairperson of each committee. It shall be the duty of the chairman of the commission to advise and consult with the village officials as to the work and recommendations of said commission and its committees; to work with organized community groups and others to carry forward all plans and policies of the commission and accident prevention which may be approved by the commission; and to perform such other duties as may be prescribed by said commission. 
(Ord. No. 25-1980, § 1, 9-23-80; Ord. No. 20-1994, § 3, 9-13-94) 
Sec. 22-58. - Meetings. 
    The commission shall meet at least once each month and shall meet on the call of the chairperson or on call by a majority of its members. 
(Ord. No. 25-1980, § 1, 9-23-80; Ord. No. 20-1994, § 3, 9-13-94) 
Sec. 22-59. - Quorum. 
    Four (4) members shall constitute a quorum. 
(Ord. No. 25-1980, § 1, 9-23-80; Ord. No. 24-2000, § 1, 10-10-00) 
Sec. 22-60. - Secretary. 
    It shall be the duty of the secretary to send all notices for the meetings of said commission, to keep and preserve the minutes, to have custody and keep all documents and papers filed with said commission. 
(Ord. No. 25-1980, § 1, 9-23-80) 
Chapter 23 - PLUMBING[1]

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 23-1, 23-2. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Former sections 23-1 and 23-2 have been deleted by the editor as being superseded by Ord. No. 13-1979, adopted March 27, 1979, codified as §§ 23-3-23-8, 23-14, 23-15, and 29-13-29-21. Said former sections relative to the requirement of a permit and permit and inspection fees, were derived from Ord. No. 2-1972, § 3, adopted January 11, 1972, and Ord. No. 6-1974, adopted January 22, 1974. 
Sec. 23-3. - Permits required; application; issuance of permits. 
    All sewerage construction and all plumbing construction shall require permits. All applications for sewer or plumbing construction permits shall state the name of the owner and the address and lot and block number of the property involved. All permits shall be issued by the fire chief or his designated representative, except permits for sewer and water tap connections shall be issued by the director of public works. Sewer and water tap connection charges are set forth in chapter 29, article III, "Rates, charges and fees," section 29-42 of the Municipal Code of the Village of Hazel Crest. 
(Ord. No. 6-1976, § 16, 3-9-76; Ord. No. 13-1979, § 17, 3-27-79; Ord. No. 19-1981, § 17, 9-22-81; Ord. No. 25-1985, § 17, 11-12-85; Ord. No. 4-1991, § 18, 3-26-91; Ord. No. 22-1992, § 2, 10-27-92; Ord. No. 05-2007, § 9, 3-27-07) 
Sec. 23-4. - Footing drains. 
    Footing drains shall be connected to sump pumps for further discharge into storm sewer or drainage ditches. No footing drain or drainage tile shall be connected to the sanitary sewer system. 
(Ord. No. 6-1976, § 18, 3-9-76; Ord. No. 13-1979, § 19, 3-27-79; Ord. No. 19-1981, § 19, 9-22-81; Ord. No. 25-1985, § 19, 11-12-85; Ord. No. 4-1991, § 20, 3-26-91) 
Sec. 23-5. - Overhead plumbing. 
    All new buildings with basements, floors, rooms or occupancy areas below ground level at the building site and served by a public or private sewer system shall have overhead plumbing. No building permit application will be accepted nor any permits issued for construction of any structure unless plans and specifications therefor provide for overhead plumbing as called for in this section. 
(Ord. No. 6-1976, § 20, 3-9-76; Ord. No. 13-1979, § 21, 3-27-79; Ord. No. 19-1981, § 21, 9-22-81; Ord. No. 25-1985, § 21, 11-12-85; Ord. No. 4-1991, § 22, 3-26-91) 
Sec. 23-6. - Taps and connections to be made by plumber. 
    All taps or connections shall be made by the plumber, from the village water main to and including the meter, under the supervision of the director of public works. 
(Ord. No. 6-1976, § 23, 3-9-76; Ord. No. 13-1979, § 24, 3-27-79; Ord. No. 19-1981, § 24, 9-22-81; Ord. No. 25-1985, § 24, 11-12-85; Ord. No. 4-1991, § 25, 3-26-91) 
Sec. 23-7. - Requirements of village standards. 
    All valves, fittings and piping shall be as per the requirements of the village standards and as directed by the director of public works. 
(Ord. No. 6-1976, § 27, 3-9-76; Ord. No. 13-1979, § 27, 3-27-79; Ord. No. 19-1981, § 27, 9-22-81; Ord. No. 25-1985, § 27, 11-12-85; Ord. No. 4-1991, § 28, 3-26-91) 
Sec. 23-8. - Penalty for violations. 
    Any person who shall violate a provision of sections 23-3-23-7 or shall fail to comply with any of the requirements thereof or who shall erect, construct, alter or repair a building or structure in violation of an approved plan or directive of the building official, or of a permit or certificate issued under the provisions of sections 23-3-23-7, shall be guilty of an offense against the village, punishable by a fine of not less than fifty dollars ($50.00), nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00). Each day that a violation continues shall be deemed a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 6-1976, § 30, 3-9-76; Ord. No. 13-1979, § 30, 3-27-79; Ord. No. 19-1981, § 31, 9-22-81; Ord. No. 25-1985, § 31, 11-12-85; Ord. No. 4-1991, § 32, 3-26-91) 
Sec. 23-9. - Installation of water-saving plumbing fixtures. 
(a)  Minimum flow rates, water usage. In all new construction and in all repair and/or replacement of fixtures or trim, only fixtures and trim not exceeding the flow rates and/or water usage shall be installed. These ratings are based on a pressure at the fixture of forty (40) to fifty (50) p.s.i. (pounds per square inch). 
Water closets, tank type ..... 3.5 gallons per flush 
Water closets, flushometer type ..... 3.0 gallons per flush 
Urinals, tank type ..... 3.0 gallons per flush 
Urinals, flushometer type ..... 3.0 gallons per flush 
Shower heads, except those used for safety 
  reasons ..... 3.0 gallons per min. 
Lavatory, sink faucets ..... 3.0 gallons per min. 
(b)  Lavatories for public use. In addition to the requirements of section 23-9(a) above, in all new construction and replacement of fixtures, faucets of lavatories located in restrooms intended for public use shall be volume limiting devices of self-closing type. 
(c)  Car wash installation. In all new construction and replacement of fixtures, car wash installations shall be equipped with a water recycling system capable of recycling a minimum of eighty (80) per cent of the water usage. 
(d)  Commercial installations. Approved water sewer equipment of current design shall be used in all new construction and all rehabilitation installation. 
(e)  Air conditioning installations. In all new construction and in all new remodeling, the installation of air conditioning systems utilizing water shall be a closed system. 
(Ord. No. 8-1978, § 2,3-28-78; Ord. No. 19-1981, § 28, 9-22-81; Ord. No. 25-1985, § 28, 11-12-85; Ord. No. 4-1991, § 29, 3-26-91) 
Secs. 23-10-23-13. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - PLUMBING CODE, 2004[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 17-2012, § 3.0, adopted October 9, 2012, amended the Code by renaming art. II. 

Sec. 23-14. - Adoption of plumbing code. 
    A certain document, three (3) copies of which are on file in the office of the village clerk, and have been on file there, and made available for public use, inspection and examination for at least thirty (30) days prior to the enactment of this section, being marked and designated as the Illinois Plumbing Code, 2004 (Ill. Admin. Code tit. 77, § 890.100, et seq. (2004)), be and is hereby adopted as the plumbing code of the village for the control of all plumbing as herein provided. All of the regulations, provisions, penalties, conditions, and terms of the Illinois Plumbing Code, 2004, are hereby referred to, adopted and made a part hereof, as if fully set out in this section, with the additions, insertions, deletions and changes prescribed in section 23-15, in accordance with 225 ILCS 320/36 and section 750.800 of the Plumbers Licensing Code (68 Ill. Admin Code § 750.800 (2000)). If in accordance with the Illinois Plumbing Code, 2004 or in the judgment of the director of public works or village plumbing inspector, an approved backflow prevention device is necessary for the safety of the public water supply system, the director of public works or plumbing inspector will give written notice to the water customer to install such an approved device immediately. The water customer shall, at his own expense, install such an approved device at a location and in a manner in accordance with the Illinois Plumbing Code, 2004, state environmental protection agency and all applicable local regulations, and shall have inspections and tests made of such approved devices upon installation and as required by the Illinois Plumbing Code, 2004, state environmental protection agency and local regulations. The village is further authorized to enter into any contracts it deems to be in the best interests of its residents to provide third party water monitoring services or to dispatch any agent or such agents as it deems necessary for water monitoring. 
(Ord. No. 13-1972, § 1, 6-27-72; Ord. No. 6-1976, § 1, 3-9-76; Ord. No. 13-1979, § 1, 3-27-79; Ord. No. 19-1981, § 1, 9-22-81; Ord. No. 25-1985, § 1, 11-12-85; Ord. No. 4-1991, § 1, 3-26-91; Ord. No. 22-1992, § 2, 10-27-92; Ord. No. 14-1995, § 1, 2-28-95; Ord. No. 23-2002, § 31, 8-13-02; Ord. No. 17-2012, § 3.0, 10-9-12) 
State Law reference- Adoption of technical codes by reference, 65 ILCS 5/1-3-1 et seq. 
Sec. 23-15. - Amendments. 
    The following sections of the Illinois Plumbing Code, 2004, are hereby revised as follows: 
    Section 890.110 and 890.1950, Insert: "an offense against the Village;" and Seven Hundred and Fifty Dollars ($750.00). 
    Section 890.110 and 890.1950, Insert: Unlawful continuance: Any person who shall continue any work in or about the structure after having been served with a stop work order, except such work as that person is directed to perform to remove a violation or unsafe condition, shall be liable to a fine of not less than Fifty Dollars ($50.00) or more than Seven Hundred Fifty Dollars ($750.00) per day, per project. 
    Section 890.170, Public Systems available: A public water main or public sewer system shall be considered available to a structure where the structure is located within six hundred (600) feet of the public water main or sewer. 
    Section 890.510, 890.520 and 890.530: Industrial wastes, waste products from manufacturing or industrial operations shall not be introduced into the public sewer system until it has been determined by the administrative authority and the Metropolitan Water Reclamation District of Greater Chicago that the introduction thereof will not cause damage to the public sewer system or interfere with the functioning of the sewage treatment plans. 
    Section 890.1150(a 3), Freezing: Water service piping shall be installed below recorded frost penetration but not less than five (5) feet zero (0) inches below grade. The property owner is responsible for the water service line from the interior of the structure up to the buffalo box at the Village's connection. 
    Section 890.1210(a), Plumbing piping in exterior building walls or areas subjected to freezing temperatures shall be protected against freezing by insulation or heat or both. 
    Section 890.1320(c), Sewer Depth: Building sewers shall be a minimum of forty-two (42) inches below grade. The property owner is responsible for the entire drainage system/waste line from the interior of the property up to and including the tap connection of the Village's sewer main. 
    Section 890.1200(a), Water Service Pipe: Water service pipe shall be made of brass pipe, copper pipe, copper tube, ductile iron pipe. Copper tube, when used underground, shall have a weight not less than copper water tube Type K. When used underground in corrosive soil or fill, the piping material and/or protective coating or covering shall be approved by the administrative authority. The minimum size of water service piping shall be one (1) inch. 
    Section 890.1210(b and c), Water Distribution System Pipe: The water distribution system shall be brass, or copper pipe, copper tube, galvanized wrought iron pipe, galvanized open-hearth iron pipe, galvanized steel pipe. Copper tube used shall have a weight of not less than copper water tube Type L. 
    Section 890.1310(a), Building Sewer Pipe: Building sewer pipe shall be made of cast iron pipe, copper tubing (Type K), Polyvinyl Chloride (PVC) Plastic Pipe Type (SDR26/Schedule 40 ref. IRC sec. P2904.4.2 & P3002.1). All connections to dissimilar materials shall be made with no shear couplings. 
    Section 890.200(B), General: All roofs, paved areas, yards, courts and courtyards shall drain into a separate storm sewer system. For one- and two-family dwellings, and where approved, storm water is permitted to discharge onto flat areas, such as streets or lawns, provided that the storm water flows away from the building. 
    Section 890.420: There shall be a clean-out near the junction of the building drain and the building sewer. This clean-out shall be located no more than ten (10) feet outside the building wall or at the 4" × 6" connection, brought up to finish grade and provided with an adequate water-tight cap or cover, as approved by administrative authority. 
    Section 890.1190, Individual Fixture Valves: In occupied buildings other than dwellings, the water service line to each fixture or other piece of equipment shall be provided with a valve or fixture stop to shut off the water to the fixture or to the room to which it is located. Sill cocks and wall hydrants shall be separately controlled by a valve inside the building. In dwellings, the water service to each bathroom lavatory, water closet and kitchen sink shall be provided with a valve or fixture stop to shut off the water to the fixture. The valves installed to control the supply of water to the water meter and water heater are to be full port ball valves as required by the state code. 
(Ord. No. 13-1972, §§ 1-12, 6-27-72; Ord. No. 6-1976, §§ 2-15, 3-9-76; Ord. No. 13-1979, §§ 2-16, 3-27-79; Ord. No. 19-1981, §§ 2-16, 9-22-81; Ord. No. 25-1985, §§ 2-16, 11-12-85; Ord. No. 4-1991, §§ 2-17, 3-26-91; Ord. No. 14-1995, § 2, 2-28-95; Ord. No. 23-2002, § 32, 8-13-02; Ord. No. 05-2007, § 10, 3-27-07; Ord. No. 17-2012, § 3.0, 10-9-12) 
Sec. 23-16. - Fees. 
    Plumbing fees shall comply with 225 ILCS 320/18 and be as follows: 
Single-family residence: 
First five (5) fixtures, minimum ..... $ 75.00 
Each additional fixture ..... 10.00 
Apartments and condominiums: 
Each fixture ..... 10.00 
Minimum ..... 50.00

Each fixture ..... 10.00 
Minimum ..... 50.00 
Remodeling and repairing: 
Each fixture ..... 10.00 
Minimum ..... 50.00 
Re-inspection ..... 35.00 
    Minimum of forty-eight (48) hours notice required for scheduling of inspections or cancellations. 
(Ord. No. 17-2012, § 3.0, 10-9-12)

Chapter 24 - POLICE[1] 
Footnotes:

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL

ARTICLE II. - DEPARTMENT[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Board of fire and police commissioners, Ch. 2, Art. IV. 

Sec. 24-11. - Created. 
    There is hereby created and established an executive department of the municipal government of the village, which shall be known as the Hazel Crest Police Department. The police department shall embrace the offices and positions hereinafter enumerated. 
(Code 1956, § 9.01; Ord. No. 10-1966, 6-28-66) 
Sec. 24-12. - Offices, positions. 
    The Hazel Crest Police Department shall include the following positions: Chief of police, two (2) deputy police chiefs, lieutenants, sergeants, patrolmen. Job descriptions for these positions shall be established by the village manager and may be revised from time to time as necessary. The village manager shall file with the board of fire and police commission a current copy of the job description for each of the positions. 
    The authorized number of lieutenants, sergeants, and patrol officer positions shall be determined from time to time by the village board. 
(Code 1956, § 9.02; Ord. No. 10-1966, 6-28-66; Ord. No. 11-1968, § 1, 7-9-68; Ord. No. 13-1971, § 1, 8-10-71; Ord. No. 14-1971, § 1, 12-14-71; Ord. No. 20-1972, § 1, 10-10-72; Ord. No. 1-1973, § 1, 1-23-73; Ord. No. 21-1973, § 1, 11-13-73; Ord. No. 20-1975, § 1, 6-24-75; Ord. No. 10-1976, § 1, 4-27-76; Ord. No. 12-1977, § 1, 4-12-77; Ord. No. 1-1979, § 1, 1-23-79; Ord. No. 2-1986, § 1, 1-28-86; Ord. No. 25-2001, § 1, 12-11-01) 
Sec. 24-13. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 03-2016, § 1, adopted April 12, 2016, repealed § 24-13, which pertained to community policing administrator, and derived from Ord. No. 07-2015, § 1, adopted July 28, 2015. Formerly, § 24-13 pertained to police matrons, and derived from the Code of 1956, § 17.09. 
Sec. 24-14. - Appointments, promotions and removals. 
(a)  Regular. All appointments to the police department, except the chief of police, shall be made and certified by the board of fire and police commissioners of the village. The police chief shall be appointed and removed by the village manager. All promotions and removals of full-time policemen, except the police chief, shall be made by the board of fire and police commissioners of the village, as provided by state statute. 
(b)  Temporary. In order to prevent a stoppage of public business, to meet extraordinary exigencies, or to prevent impairment of the police department, the board of fire and police commissioners may make temporary appointments, to remain in full force until regular appointments may be made under the provisions established for regular appointments, but never to exceed sixty (60) days. 
(Code 1956, § 9.03; Ord. No. 10-1966,6-28-66; Ord. No. 10-1985, § 2,4-23-85) 
Sec. 24-14.1. - Appointments, deputy police chiefs. 
    The chief of police shall have the authority to appoint two (2) deputy police chiefs. 
(1)  Exempt rank. The deputy police chief position shall be an exempt rank immediately below that of chief of police. 
(2)  Eligibility or appointment. The deputy police chief may be appointed from among any rank of sworn, full-time officers of the Village of Hazel Crest Police Department provided that he or she has at least five (5) years of full-time service as a police officer in the village police department. 
(3)  Term of service. The deputy police chief shall serve at the discretion of the chief of police, and, if removed from said position, shall revert to the rank held immediately prior to the appointment to the deputy police chief position. 
(Ord. No. 25-2001, § 2, 12-11-01) 
Sec. 24-15. - Suspensions. 
    The chief of police has authority to suspend without pay a member of the police department for a period of not more than five (5) days, but he shall notify the chairman or any other member of the board of fire and police commissioners immediately, in writing, of such suspension. Any member of the police department suspended by the chief of police may appeal to the board of fire and police commissioners for a review within twenty-four (24) hours after the suspension. 
(Code 1956, § 9.04; Ord. No. 10-1966, 6-28-66) 
Sec. 24-16. - Scope of sections 24-12, 24-14 and 24-15. 
    The provisions of sections 24-12, 24-14 and 24-15 of this article shall apply only to full-time policemen and not to any other personnel of any kind or description. 
(Code 1956, § 9.05; Ord. No. 10-1966, 6-28-66) 
Sec. 24-17. - Reserve officers-Appointment. 
(a)  In order to maintain adequate police coverage at all times, the chief of police may appoint and remove reserve officers within such budget limits as may be set from time to time by the president and board of trustees. Such police officers shall be considered "part-time police" as defined in 65 ILCS 5/3.1-30-21. 
(b)  Reserve officers shall not be "conservators of the peace" and shall only carry firearms while on duty, with the permission of the chief of police, and only after completing the state certified forty-hour mandatory firearms training course as provided under 50 ILCS 710/2. 
(c)  The number of hours that a reserve officer may work within a calendar year is restricted. 
(Code 1956, § 9.06; Ord. No. 10-1966, 6-28-66; Ord. No. 23-1972, 12-12-72; Ord. No. 5-1997, § 1, 2-11-97; Ord. No. 01-2013, § 3.0, 1-8-12) 
Sec. 24-17.1. - Hiring standards. 
(a)  No person shall be hired as a reserve officer who has not been fingerprinted, subject to the background check, and found to have never been convicted of a felony or other crime involving moral turpitude. The chief of police shall prefer residents of the village for hiring as reserve police officers. 
(b)  Any person employed as a reserve officer must meet the following standards: 
(1)  Be of good moral character, of temperate habits, of sound health, and physically and mentally able to perform assigned duties. 
(2)  Be at least twenty-one (21) years of age. 
(3)  No person who has attained thirty-five (35) years of age is eligible unless the person has had pervious employment status as a policeman in the village. 
(4)  Pass a medical examination. 
(5)  Possess a high school diploma or GED certificate. 
(6)  Possess a valid State of Illinois driver's license. 
(7)  Possess no prior felony convictions. 
(8)  Any individual who has served in the U.S. military must have been honorably discharged. 
(c)  Reserve officers must be trained in accordance with Illinois Law Enforcement Training and Standards Board requirements. The chief of police is hereby authorized to establish hiring standards for reserve officers and shall submit those standards to the Illinois Law Enforcement Training Standards Board. 
(Ord. No. 01-2013, § 3.0, 1-8-12) 
Sec. 24-18. - Same-Duties. 
(a)  Reserve officers shall be assigned to perform the following duties: 
(1)  All duties and responsibilities of patrol officers delineated in section 8 of the general order pursuant to the department operations manual, as may be amended from time to time; and 
(2)  Carrying out all regular assignments, special duties, and specific event assignments as required by the chief of police or the commander of the patrol division. 
(b)  Reserve officers shall only perform such duties as specified by the chief of police and as authorized and limited by law. 
(Code 1956, § 9.07; Ord. No. 10-1966, 6-28-66; Ord. No. 23-1972, 12-12-72; Ord. No. 5-1997, § 2, 2-11-97; Ord. No. 01-2013, § 3.0, 1-8-12) 
Sec. 24-18.1. - Discipline. 
    Reserve officers shall be under the disciplinary jurisdiction of the chief of police. Reserve officers serve at the discretion of the village authorities, shall not have any property rights in said employment, and may be removed by the village authorities at any time. Reserve officers shall comply with all applicable rules and general orders issued by the police department. 
(Ord. No. 01-2013, § 3.0, 1-8-12) 
Sec. 24-19. - Same-Scope of coverage by article. 
    All the provisions of this article shall apply to reserve officers except sections 24-12, 24-14 and 24-15. 
(Code 1956, § 9.08; Ord. No. 10-1966, 6-28-66; Ord. No. 23-1972, 12-12-72; Ord. No. 5-1997, § 3, 2-11-97) 
Sec. 24-20. - Duties of deputy police chief, lieutenant, sergeant. 
    In the absence of the chief of police, the deputy chief of police shall have full authority, direct charge and control of the police department and shall be responsible for the faithful and efficient conduct of the operations of the department. The deputy chief of police shall assist other members of the department in the enforcement and maintenance of law and order. In the absence of the chief of police and the deputy chief of police, the lieutenant shall have full authority and direct charge and control over the police department and shall be responsible for the faithful and efficient conduct of the operation of the department. The lieutenant shall assist other members of the department in the enforcement and maintenance of law and order. In the absence of the chief of police, the deputy chief of police, and the lieutenant, the duty or shift sergeant shall have full authority and direct charge and control over the police department and shall be responsible for the faithful and efficient conduct of the operation of the department. The sergeant of police shall assist other members of the department in the enforcement and maintenance of law and order. 
(Code 1956, § 9.09; Ord. No. 10-1966, 6-28-66; Ord. No. 2-1986, § 2, 1-28-86; Ord. No. 25-2001, § 3, 12-11-01) 
Sec. 24-21. - Duties of members. 
    It shall be the duty of the members of the police department to enforce this Code and all the ordinances of the village and all statutes and laws effective in the village, to preserve order and prevent infractions of the law, and to arrest violators thereof. Every member of the police department is hereby declared to be a conservator of the peace. 
(Code 1956, § 9.09; Ord. No. 10-1966, 6-28-66) 
Sec. 24-22. - Duties of members on election days. 
    It shall be the duty of all regular police officers and deputy marshals to preserve order at the polls on election days, but no such officer, whether on or off duty, shall electioneer or intervene for or against any candidate at such election. 
(Code 1956, § 9.09; Ord. No. 10-1966, 6-28-66; Ord. No. 23-1972, 12-12-72) 
Sec. 24-23. - Chief-Designated head of department. 
    The chief of police shall be ex officio village marshal and administrative head of the police department, and shall perform such duties as are prescribed in this Code or as may be ordered by the village board of trustees. 
(Code 1956, § 9.10; Ord. No. 10-1966, 6-28-66) 
Sec. 24-24. - Same-Duties; qualifications. 
    The chief of police shall have direct charge and control over the police department and shall be responsible for the faithful and efficient conduct of the operation thereof. The chief of police shall be qualified through training and experience to administer the police department and command men; he shall be responsible for the enforcement and maintenance of law and order; and he shall have custody of all apparatus and property pertaining to the department and shall be responsible for the maintenance thereof. He need not be a member of the police department nor a resident of the village at the time of his appointment. 
(Code 1956, § 9.09; Ord. No. 10-1966, 6-28-66) 
Sec. 24-25. - Same-To be keeper of jail. 
    The chief of police shall be keeper of the village jail and shall have custody of all persons incarcerated therein and of all property pertaining thereto. He or his designee shall purchase food necessary for the sustenance of the prisoners and shall keep and make a monthly report of expenditures to the village treasurer. 
(Code 1956, § 9.10; Ord. No. 10-1966, 6-28-66) 
Sec. 24-26. - Same-To keep records. 
    The chief of police shall keep or cause to be kept a record of arrests in a book to be provided for that purpose, with the name, age, sex, description, nativity, offense and disposition of the case, noting the police officer making the arrest and the person signing the complaint. He shall also keep a record of all accidents coming to his attention, and shall make such reports concerning the activities of his department as may be required by statute or ordinance. Such records shall be accessible to any officer of the village, but not all records shall be open to public inspection. Such records shall be made available for inspection by the public only if permission is secured from the village president, village attorney or chief of police. 
(Code 1956, § 9.10; Ord. No. 10-1966, 6-28-66) 
Sec. 24-27. - Rules and regulations. 
    The members of the police department shall be subject to such rules and regulations as shall be imposed by the village board of trustees, in addition to being subject to statute and the rules of the board of fire and police commissioners, and shall be disciplined by the board of fire and police commissioners. Every police officer is prohibited, when on duty, or when in uniform whether on or off duty, from spending his time in saloons, taverns or public houses, or playing pool, cards or any other games of chance in such places. 
(Code 1956, § 9.11; Ord. No. 10-1966, 6-28-66) 
Sec. 24-28. - Duty of citizens to assist police. 
    It shall be the duty of every person, when called upon by any member of the police department, to promptly aid and assist him in the execution of his police duties. 
(Code 1956, § 9.12; Ord. No. 10-1966, 6-28-66) 
Sec. 24-29. - Resisting an officer. 
    No person shall resist any member of the police department in the discharge of his duty, or in any way interfere with, hinder or prevent such discharge of duty, or offer or endeavor to do so; nor shall any person assist in any manner a person in custody of any member of the police force to escape or attempt to escape, nor rescue or attempt to rescue any person in custody. 
(Code 1956, § 9.13; Ord. No. 10-1966, 6-28-66) 
State Law reference- Resisting or obstructing peace officer, 720 ILCS 5/31-1. 
Sec. 24-30. - Impersonating an officer. 
    No person shall falsely represent himself to be a member of the police department or a special or reserve policeman or a watchman, or maliciously or with intent to deceive use or imitate any of the signs or signals of the department or wear a star or other device similar to that of a policeman, special or reserve policeman or a watchman, except as may be otherwise provided by ordinance. 
(Code 1956, § 9.14; Ord. No. 10-1966, 6-28-66) 
Sec. 24-31. - Seizure of gaming devices. 
    Any member of the police department may seize any instrument, device or other thing used for the purpose of gaming or gambling, and all such instruments, devices or things shall be destroyed or demolished under the supervision of the chief of police, and all moneys confiscated. It shall be the duty of the police department to suppress gaming and gambling houses, lotteries and fraudulent devices or practices for the purpose of gaming or obtaining money or property. All money confiscated from illegal sources shall be turned over to the police pension fund. 
(Code 1956, § 9.15; Ord. No. 10-1966, 6-28-66) 
Sec. 24-32. - License inspections. 
    Unless otherwise provided by ordinance, the police department shall make regular and periodic checks to ascertain whether business, vehicle, dog, liquor and other licenses required by this Code have been procured, and shall regularly inspect all places of business required to have a village license to see that such places of business are being operated according to the ordinances and laws in force, and in a manner so as to protect the public health, safety and morals, and to promote the general welfare of the village and its inhabitants. 
(Code 1956, § 9.16; Ord. No. 10-1966, 6-28-66) 
Sec. 24-33. - Service of process. 
    Any member of the police department shall be authorized to serve writs, summonses, warrants and other process, except where prohibited by statute or law. 
(Code 1956, § 9.17; Ord. No. 10-1966, 6-28-66) 
Sec. 24-34. - Duty to assist in prosecutions. 
    All police officers making arrests shall attend court as witnesses and otherwise assist in the prosecution of the offender. 
(Code 1956, § 9.18; Ord. No. 10-1966, 6-28-66) 
Sec. 24-35. - Village jail. 
(a)  Adequate and appropriate space now located on village property is hereby established as the village jail. 
(b)  Any person lawfully arrested for violation of any law of the United States or the state or of any provision of this Code or any other ordinance of the village may be incarcerated in the village jail until he furnishes proper bail, or can be given a hearing before a magistrate or judge, or is lawfully transferred to another place of incarceration, or otherwise lawfully released. 
(Code 1956, § 9.19; Ord. No. 10-1966, 6-28-66) 
Sec. 24-36. - Keeper of jail to receive prisoner. 
    In all cases of arrests on view for a violation of any of the ordinances of the village in which detention in custody of the person so arrested shall be authorized by any of the ordinances of the village, it shall be the duty of the keeper of the village jail or other place of confinement provided for such violators to receive from any officer of the village legally empowered to make such arrest any such person and to keep such person until he can be brought before the magistrate of the village or a judge of the county, and be tried in the manner prescribed by law. 
(Code 1956, § 17.06) 
Sec. 24-37. - Compensation. 
    The members of the police department shall receive for their services amounts to be fixed from time to time by the board of trustees, which will not be less than provided by state statute. No police officer shall receive any compensation as a policeman unless he is on duty by order or direction of the chief of police, or in case of emergency, if ordered to perform police duties by the chief of police. 
(Code 1956, § 9.20; Ord. No. 10-1966, 6-28-66) 
Secs. 24-38-24-50. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - PENSION FUND[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 34-1976, § 1, adopted Oct. 12, 1976, amended former Art. III, §§ 24-51-24-53 to read as herein set out in §§ 24-51-24-59. Formerly said §§ 24-51-24-53 had dealt with similar subject matter and had been derived from Ord. No. 4-1963, §§ 1-3, enacted May 28, 1963, and Ord. No. 40-1975, § 1, enacted Oct. 28, 1975. 
State Law reference- Police pension funds, 40 ILCS 5/3-101. 

Sec. 24-51. - Established. 
    There is hereby established a police pension fund for the village in accordance with the authority contained in Article 3 of the Illinois Pension Code (40 ILCS 5/3-101 et seq.). The purpose of such fund is to provide pensions and other benefits in accordance with the provisions of such Article 3 of the Illinois Pension Code, and of Article III of the Village Code. 
(Ord. No. 34-1976, § 1, 10-12-76) 
Sec. 24-52. - Board of trustees.
