(5)  Sale of use to the extent the tax imposed by this article would violate the state or United States Constitution. 
(6)  Sale to or use by the federal government or any state or local governmental body. 
(7)  Sale to or use by any air common carrier, certified by the carrier to be used for consumption, shipment or storage in the conduct of its business as an air common carrier, for a flight destined for a destination outside the United States. 
(Ord. No. 10-2006, § 1, 3-30-06) 
ARTICLE VIII. - MUNICIPAL GAS USE TAX[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 05-2016, § 1, adopted April 12, 2016, repealed Art. VIII, §§ 27-83-27-88, and enacted a new Art. VIII as set out herein. Former Art. VIII pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Ord. No. 08-2015, § 1, adopted September 8, 2015. 

Sec. 27-83. - Short title. 
    The tax imposed by this article shall be known as the "Municipal Gas Use Tax" and is imposed in addition to all other taxes imposed by the Village of Hazel Crest, the State of Illinois, or any other municipal corporation or political subdivision thereof. 
(Ord. No. 05-2016, § 2, 4-12-16) 
Sec. 27-84. - Definitions. 
    For the purpose of this article, the following definitions shall apply: 
    Person means any individual, firm, trust, estate, partnership, association, joint stock company, joint venture, corporation, limited liability company, municipal corporation or political subdivision of this state, or a receiver, trustee, conservator or other representative appointed by order of any court. 
    Public utility means a public utility as defined in Section 3-105 of the Public Utilities Act. 
    Public Utilities Act means the Public Utilities Act as amended, (220 ILCS 5/1-101 et seq.). 
    Retail purchaser means any person who purchases gas in a sale at retail. 
    Sale at retail means any sale of gas by a retailer to a person for use or consumption, and not for resale. For this purpose, the term "retailer" means any person engaged in the business of distributing, supplying, furnishing or selling gas. 
(Ord. No. 05-2016, § 2, 4-12-16) 
Sec. 27-85. - Tax. 
(a)  Except as otherwise provided by this article, a tax is imposed on the privilege of using or consuming gas in the village that is purchased in a sale at retail at the rate of five (5) cents per therm. 
(b)  The ultimate incidence of and liability for payment of the tax is on the retail purchaser, and nothing in this article shall be construed to impose a tax on the occupation of distributing, supplying, furnishing, selling or transporting gas. 
(c)  The retail purchaser shall pay the tax, measured by therms of gas delivered to the retail purchaser's premises, to the public utility designated to collect the tax pursuant to section 27-86 of this article on or before the payment due date of the public utility's bill first reflecting the tax, or directly to the village treasurer on or before the fifteenth day of the second month following the month in which the gas is delivered to the retail purchaser if no public utility has been designated to collect the tax pursuant to section 27-86 or if the gas is delivered by a person other than a public utility so designated. 
(d)  Nothing in this article shall be construed to impose a tax upon any person, business or activity which, under the constitutions of the United States or State of Illinois, may not be made the subject of taxation by the village. 
(e)  A person who purchases gas for resale and therefore does not pay the tax imposed by this article with respect to the use or consumption of the gas, but who later uses or consumes part or all of the gas, shall pay the tax directly to the village treasurer on or before the fifteenth day of the second month following the month in which the gas is used or consumed. 
(f)  The tax shall apply to gas for which the delivery to the retail purchaser is billed by a public utility on or after August 1, 2016. 
(g)  If it shall appear that an amount of tax has been paid which was not due under the provisions of this article, whether as a result of mistake of fact or an error of law, then such amount shall be (i) credited against any tax due, or to become due, under this article from the taxpayer who made the erroneous payment or (ii) subject to a refund if no such tax is due or to become due; provided that no amounts erroneously paid more than three (3) years prior to the filing of a claim therefore shall be so credited or refunded. 
(h)  No action to recover any amount of tax due under the provisions of this article shall be commenced more than three (3) years after the due date of such amount. 
(i)  To prevent multiple taxation, the use of gas in the village by a retail purchaser shall be exempt from the tax imposed by this article if the gross receipts from the sale at retail of such gas to the retail purchaser are properly subject to a tax imposed upon the seller of such gas pursuant to the village's municipal utility tax, as amended from time to time article III, section 27-27 authorized pursuant to Section 8-11-2 of the Illinois Municipal Code (65 ILCS 5/8-11-2). 
(Ord. No. 05-2016, § 2, 4-12-16; Ord. No. 10-2016, § 1, 7-26-16) 
Sec. 27-86. - Collection of gas tax by public utility. 
    The president, village treasurer, village manager and village finance director are each authorized to enter into a contract for collection of the tax imposed by this article with any public utility providing gas service in the village. The contract shall include and substantially conform with the following provisions: 
(1)  The public utility will collect the tax from retail purchasers as an independent contractor; 
(2)  The public utility will remit collected taxes to the village treasurer no more often than once each month; 
(3)  The public utility will be entitled to withhold from tax collections a service fee equal to three (3) per cent of the amounts collected and timely remitted to the village treasurer; 
(4)  The public utility shall not be responsible to the village for any tax not actually collected from a retail purchaser; and 
(5)  Such additional terms as the parties may agree upon. 
(Ord. No. 05-2016, § 2, 4-12-16) 
Sec. 27-87. - Books and records. 
    Every taxpayer shall keep accurate books and records, including original source documents and books of entry, denoting the activities or transactions that gave rise, or may have given rise to any tax liability or exemption under this article. All such books and records shall, at all times during business hours, be subject to and available for inspection by the village. 
(Ord. No. 05-2016, § 2, 4-12-16) 
Chapter 271/2 - TOWING[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 25-1984, § 1, enacted August 14, 1984, being nonamendatory of the Code, has been included as new Ch. 271/2, §§ 271/2-1-271/2-7, at the discretion of the editor. 
Cross reference- Motor vehicles and traffic, Ch. 19; storing inoperable motor vehicles outdoors, § 20-107(10), (30); streets, sidewalks and public places, Ch. 25. 

Sec. 271/2-1. - Definitions. 
    For the purposes of this chapter, the following terms shall have the meanings stated in this section. Any term not defined herein shall have the meaning ascribed to it in other ordinances of this municipality, and if not defined in any other municipal ordinances, it shall have the meaning ascribed in the Illinois Vehicle Code, 625 ILCS 5. 
(a)  Owner: A person who holds legal title to the vehicle, or the right of possession of the vehicle. 
(b)  Vehicle: Any device in, upon or by which any person or property is or may be transported or drawn upon a street, highway or any public way, except devices moved by human power, devices used exclusively upon stationary rails or tracks, and snowmobiles. 
(c)  Hazardous vehicle: 
(1)  A vehicle that has been involved in an accident and is disabled or cannot be immediately moved by the owner or operator of the vehicle; 
(2)  A vehicle that presents an immediate danger to the health or welfare of the members of the public; 
(3)  A vehicle abandoned or disabled on a public street, way or alley that is impeding the orderly flow of traffic or poses a potential danger to pedestrians and other operators of vehicles; or 
(4)  A vehicle that must be moved to allow for proper municipal snow removal from a public street, way or alley. 
(d)  Unlawful vehicle: 
(1)  A vehicle that has been reported stolen or is the subject of a search and seizure by the police department; or 
(2)  A vehicle parked in violation of State of Illinois statutes or ordinances of the municipality which prohibit parking at the location in question or for the period of time for which the vehicle has been parked, and where either the statute or the ordinance authorizes the vehicle to be towed and the signs posted at the general location note that fact. 
(e)  Abandoned or nuisance vehicle: 
(1)  A vehicle parked or otherwise located on the public way, or a vehicle parked on private property and in plain view from the public right-of-way, which: 
a.  Is in such a state of disrepair that it is incapable of being driven; or 
b.  Has been unmoved for a period of at least seven (7) days and from its condition, or some other circumstance, appears to have been abandoned by its owner, or represents a nuisance to neighboring property owners. 
(2)  Vehicles parked in a public parking lot or on private property without the consent of the lot owner, proprietor or agent of the property, which person has requested that the vehicle be towed; or 
(3)  A vehicle defined as "abandoned" or "capable of being towed", by any other ordinances of the municipality and which does not fall into the categories of "hazardous" or "unlawful" vehicles, and therefore is not subject to an immediate tow. 
(f)  Municipality: The Village of Hazel Crest. 
(Ord. No. 25-1984, § 1(1), 8-14-84; Ord. No. 21-2007, § 1, 11-13-07) 
Sec. 271/2-2. - Authorization for towing. 
    The towing of vehicles by the municipality or its approved towing service operators shall be authorized only by the police department and only under the circumstances herein provided. Towed vehicles shall be impounded at facilities designated by the police department until lawfully claimed or disposed of pursuant to state law, 625 ILCS 5. 
(a)  Towing without notice; immediate tows. Hazardous or unlawful vehicles may be towed without prior notice. By the close of the next business day after towing a vehicle pursuant to this chapter, a notice shall be sent to, or personally delivered to, the owner of the vehicle affording the opportunity for a hearing as provided in section 271/2-5 and section 271/2-6 of this chapter. 
(b)  Towing with prior notice; abandoned vehicles. Abandoned vehicles may be towed after the mailing or delivery of prior notice and the affording of an opportunity for a hearing as provided in section 271/2-3 and section 271/2-4 of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 25-1984, § 1(2), 8-14-84; Ord. No. 6-1986, § 1, 3-25-86) 
Sec. 271/2-3. - Pre-tow notice for abandoned or nuisance vehicles. 
(a)  Notice pursuant to subsection 271/2-2(b) shall be personally delivered to the owner or shall be forwarded by first class mail to the address of the owner of the vehicle as indicated in the most current registration list of the secretary of state, and to the owner of the property where the abandoned or nuisance vehicle is located. In the event that an out-of-state vehicle is proposed to be towed, inquiry by computer, telephone or letter shall be made of the secretary of state of the particular jurisdiction for the furnishing of the most current registered name and address of the owner of the vehicle, and notice shall be mailed as provided herein to the address furnished, though in no case will the municipality be required to delay towing more than seven (7) days after the date of the mailing or personal delivery of the notice if no request for a hearing has been received within that seven-day period. The notice shall be in such form as may be developed by regulation by the police department, and shall contain substantially the following information: 
(1)  A description of the vehicle; 
(2)  The present location of the vehicle; 
(3)  The legal and factual basis for the towing which is proposed; 
(4)  The opportunity to request a pre-tow hearing and the procedure for filing a written request for hearing; 
(5)  An advisement that a request for hearing must be filed within seven (7) days from mailing of the notice; 
(6)  The address and telephone number of the office to which a request for a hearing must be made. 
(b)  A "notice of intent to tow" sticker with the earliest date upon which the tow may take place and the address and phone number of the police department may be placed on the vehicle. 
(c)  Whenever a representative of the department of fire, rescue and inspectional services, or any other party, identifies an abandoned or nuisance vehicle, that representative shall promptly notify the police department of the identity of the vehicle and its location. 
(Ord. No. 25-1984, § 1(3), 8-14-84; Ord. No. 21-2007, § 2, 11-13-07) 
Sec. 271/2-4. - Pre-tow hearing procedures. 
(a)  The owner or person entitled to possession of a vehicle to be towed as an abandoned vehicle shall have seven (7) days after the date of the notice to request, in writing, a pre-tow hearing. The vehicle may be towed if the owner has not filed a written hearing request within the seven-day period, and any hearing rights under the provisions of this chapter will be deemed waived. 
(b)  The pre-tow hearing shall be scheduled for a date within fourteen (14) days of the mailing or personal delivery of the pre-tow notice. The municipality shall not be required to delay towing longer than such a fourteen-day period. 
(c)  Requests for a pre-tow hearing are to be made in person to the office indicated on the notice. Requests for hearing by persons who reside more than fifty (50) miles from the municipality may be made by mail. Forms for such requests shall be made available at the police department. At the time of making the request, the owner will be provided a hearing date and time by mail or in person, as the circumstances require. 
(d)  The police department shall develop pre-tow hearing procedures calling for an informal hearing by a hearing officer not involved in the initial enforcement decision who shall render a written decision as to whether the towing is authorized by law. If the evidence supports towing, the hearing officer shall direct that the vehicle be towed, with any towing and storage costs to then be imposed upon the owner thereof. The owner of said vehicle having had such a hearing may avoid the towing by immediately removing the vehicle from the improper location to a proper, lawful location and correcting any unlawful condition of the vehicle. If the evidence fails to support towing of the vehicle, the hearing officer shall direct that the vehicle shall not be towed. The municipality shall furnish a copy of such decision to the owner, who may place it inside the vehicle in a location plainly visible from the outside, such as the dashboard or rear window. No vehicle about which such a decision has been rendered shall be towed by the municipality unless the circumstances under which the decision was rendered have changed. If at some subsequent time the municipality should wish to tow the vehicle from the same location, it shall follow the same procedures required for the towing of any other similarly situated vehicle. 
(e)  Originals or copies of all notices, pre-tow hearing decisions, towing reports, and any associated police reports or documents shall be retained by the police department for such period of time as may be required by law. 
(Ord. No. 25-1984, § 1(4), 8-14-84) 
Sec. 271/2-5. - Post-tow notice for hazardous and unlawful vehicles. 
(a)  Delivery, contents of notice. The police department shall transmit information relating to the right to a hearing as provided in section 271/2-6, when mailing a notice of impoundment. Notice pursuant to this section shall be forwarded by certified or registered mail, return receipt requested, to the address of the owner of the vehicle as indicated in the most current registration list of the secretary of state, unless the notice is personally delivered to the owner, in which case, the date and time of the delivery and the name of the police officer making the delivery shall be noted in the police department records or reports. In the event that the municipality has towed an out-of-state, hazardous or unlawful vehicle, inquiry by computer, telephone or letter shall be made of the secretary of state of the particular jurisdiction for the furnishing of the most current registered name and address of the owner of the vehicle, and notice shall be mailed as provided herein to the address furnished. The notice shall be in such form as may be provided by the police department, and shall contain substantially the following information: 
(1)  A description of the vehicle; 
(2)  The present location of the impounded vehicle; 
(3)  The legal and factual basis for the particular tow; 
(4)  The opportunity to request a post-tow hearing and the procedure for filing a written request for hearing; 
(5)  An advisement that a request for hearing must be filed within fifteen (15) days from mailing or personal delivery of the notice, or from release of the vehicle, whichever occurs first; 
(6)  The address and telephone number of the office to which the request for the hearing must be made. 
    The notice required by this section may be appended to the police department's tow release form in accordance with section 271/2-2(a). 
(b)  Requests for hearings. 
(1)  Requests for hearings may be made in person at the office indicated on the notice within fifteen (15) days of the mailing or personal delivery of the notification of tow, or release of the vehicle, whichever occurs first; otherwise, the right to the hearing shall be deemed waived. Requests for hearings by persons who reside more than fifty (50) miles from the municipality may be made in person or by mail received by the municipality within the fifteen-day period; 
(2)  Any police personnel receiving inquiries in the field for hearings shall direct such person to the appropriate municipal office; 
(3)  Police personnel in the police department headquarters, when receiving a tow inquiry, shall advise the person making the inquiry of the right to a hearing as set forth herein, and upon request shall provide a hearing request form. 
(c)  Release of motor vehicles and establishment of fees. Before the owner or person entitled to possession of any impounded vehicle shall be permitted to remove same, he shall furnish evidence of his identity, ownership of the vehicle, or his right to possession, sign a receipt for the vehicle, and pay the amount currently owed for towing and storage fees to the towing operator. The police chief is authorized to promulgate regulations as to the documents or other proof necessary to establish these facts. 
(Ord. No. 25-1984, § 1(5), 8-14-84) 
Sec. 271/2-6. - Post-tow hearings. 
(a)  Generally. The owner of a vehicle towed as an immediate tow, by or pursuant to the authority of the police department as set forth herein, shall be provided the opportunity for a post-tow hearing to determine the validity of such tow and any towing or storage charges. The hearing will not be determinative of, or adjudicate, any citation issued relative to any towed vehicle. 
(b)  Hearing officer designated. An officer or employee not involved in the initial decision to tow the vehicle shall be designated as hearing officer by the municipality, and shall conduct said hearing. The hearing officer shall have the authority to require the presence of the enforcement officer who ordered the tow, or any other municipal personnel. 
(c)  Time of hearings. Hearings shall take place as follows: 
(1)  In those instances where the vehicle has been released upon the deposit of the full payment currently owed for towing and storage charges, and the owner has properly requested a hearing, the hearing shall take place within fifteen (15) days after the release of such vehicle, unless the owner requests a later date convenient to all parties; 
(2)  In those instances where the vehicle remains impounded, the hearing shall take place, at the option of the owner: 
a.  On the next calendar day after an owner's demand for such hearing, excluding Saturdays, Sundays and holidays. If such demand is made after 3:00 p.m., or if the unavailability of a necessary witness or evidence creates a particular difficulty in conducting the hearing on the next calendar day, then a hearing shall be held on the second day following the request, excluding Saturdays, Sundays and holidays; or 
b.  If acceptable to the owner, within fifteen (15) days of said request on a date convenient to all parties. 
(d)  Duties of vehicle tow hearing officer: 
(1)  The hearing officer, or other designated personnel of the municipality, processing the owner's request for hearing, shall have authority to designate in writing a hearing date and time, and to so inform the owner of the date and time of the hearing by personal service of the writing at the time the owner files a hearing request. In the event that a hearing request is made by mail by a person residing more than fifty (50) miles from the municipality, the written designation of the hearing date and time shall be mailed to the owner not less than seven (7) days before the designated hearing date, unless the owner waives such seven-day period by requesting an earlier hearing date; 
(2)  The hearing officer shall review all evidence presented by the vehicle owner and the police department or other municipal employees, and shall make a finding based upon the preponderance of the evidence presented, as to the lawful authority for the towing and storage of the vehicle. The municipality must establish such authority by a preponderance of the evidence; 
(3)  For each hearing, the hearing officer shall complete a post-tow hearing decision and attach such decision to the police department's original vehicle towing report, and supply a copy of the decision to the owner by personal delivery if the owner is present, otherwise by mail. 
(e)  Findings and decision of hearing officer. After receiving all relevant evidence, the hearing officer shall make one of the following written findings, which must be incorporated into the post-tow hearing decision. 
(1)  Tow authorized. The towing and storage of the vehicle was authorized by the laws of the State of Illinois or an ordinance of the municipality. One or more specific statutory or ordinance sections and the amount owned for towing and storage shall be stated in such a finding; 
(2)  Tow not authorized. There was no authorization in law for the towing and storage of the vehicle, or the municipal employee causing the vehicle to be towed did not comply with the requirements of the statute or ordinance authorizing the tow; 
(3)  Tow authorized; storage reimbursable. The towing of the vehicle was authorized by law, but the owner was caused to incur additional storage charges because of late notification of towing or other reasons not the fault of the owner. The specific amount owed by the owner, and the specific amount excused, shall be stated in the decision; 
(4)  Owner failed to appear; no continuance requested. A hearing was requested but the person requesting the hearing failed to appear and failed to request a continuance. This finding also constitutes a default finding that the tow was authorized by the applicable state statute or municipal ordinance as stated in the post-tow notice. 
(f)  Actions by hearing officer upon conclusion of hearing. The hearing officer shall advise the owner of his findings at the conclusion of the hearing, and take the following actions: 
(1)  If the towing and storage was found to be authorized by law, and is not otherwise reimbursable, the owner shall be so informed and further advised as to the amount then due for towing and storage if the vehicle has remained impounded; 
(2)  If the towing and/or storage are found to be unauthorized or reimbursable, the hearing officer shall: 
a.  If the vehicle has been released to the owner: 
1.  Note the amount of the towing and storage fees prepaid by the owner on the post-tow hearing decision; 
2.  Complete a printed voucher form for the amount to be reimbursed; 
3.  Transmit said decision and voucher form to the chief of police for his authorization for payment; 
4.  Advise the owner that a refund of said cash deposit or fees will be transmitted to the appropriate officials of the municipality for payment; 
5.  Transmit a copy of said hearing decision and the voucher to the appropriate officer of the municipality within forty-eight (48) hours of the hearing; 
6.  Unless the municipality files a lawsuit to contest the decision of the hearing officer, the owner shall be paid the money due within twenty-eight (28) days after the decision of the hearing officer. 
b.  If the vehicle is still in the possession of the towing company at the time of the hearing, the following procedure shall be followed: 
1.  An order for the release of the vehicle shall be prepared in duplicate; the owner shall be provided with the original, and a copy shall be attached to the post-tow hearing decision; 
2.  Upon presentation by the owner to the towing company of the order for release, said vehicle shall immediately be released to the owner without payment of any service charges excused by the hearing decision. 
(3)  All originals or copies of the notices, post-tow hearing decisions, towing reports, and any associated police reports or documents shall be retained by the police department for a period as may be required by law; 
(4)  The municipality or the owner may contest the decision of the hearing officer in any manner provided by law. 
(g)  Towing service operator-Police-ordered tows. Notwithstanding any other ordinance or statutory provisions to the contrary, any towing service operator authorized to perform tows on behalf of the municipality must perform its services subject to the provisions of this chapter. However, the towing company shall have the right to recover the reasonable value of its services for police-ordered tows, which are not paid by the vehicle owner, from the municipality. 
(Ord. No. 25-1984, § 1(6), 8-14-84) 
Sec. 271/2-7. - Severability of chapter provisions. 
    It is the intention of the municipality that this chapter, and every provision thereof, shall be considered separable, and that the invalidity of any section, clause, provision or part or portion of any section, clause or provisions of this chapter, shall not affect the validity of any other portion of this chapter. If any part or provision of this chapter or the application thereof to any person or circumstances shall be adjudged invalid by a court of competent jurisdiction, such judgment shall not affect the remaining portions of this chapter which can be given effect independently of any portion or provision ruled invalid, and to this end, the provisions of this chapter are declared to be severable. 
(Ord. No. 25-1984, § 1(7), 8-14-84) 
Chapter 28 - TREES, SHRUBS, WEEDS AND SODDING[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Section 1 of Ord. No. 08-2006, adopted April 11, 2006, amended the title of Ch. 28 from Trees, Shrubs and Weeds to read as herein set out. 
Cross reference- Streets, sidewalks and public places, Ch. 25. 

Sec. 28-1. - Certain trees prohibited on public property, discouraged on private property. 
(a)  No person shall plant or cause to be planted on public property or within public rights-of-way of the village any poplar, cottonwood, elm, silver (soft) maple, boxelder, black walnut, trees of heaven or willow trees. 
(b)  Because of the harmful effects produced by such trees, the owners or persons in possession of private property located within the village are discouraged from planting such trees on private property. 
(Code 1956, § 12.46; Ord. No. 38-1975, § 1, 9-23-75) 
Sec. 28-2. - Trimming of trees in streets and public places. 
    All trees kept, maintained or cultivated in any of the streets or public places of the village, the branches of which extend over the sidewalks or streets, shall be trimmed at least seven (7) feet above the ground so that the branches thereof will not interfere with persons using the sidewalks or streets. 
(Code 1956, § 12.47) 
Sec. 28-3. - Damaging trees and shrubs. 
    It shall be unlawful to injure any tree or shrub planted or growing in any public place, except by permission of the director of public works and buildings. 
(Code 1956, § 12.48) 
Sec. 28-4. - Attaching advertisements, notices to trees, shrubs prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful to attach any sign, advertisement or notice to any tree or shrub in any public place. 
(Code 1956, § 12.49) 
Cross reference- Advertising, Ch. 3. 
Sec. 28-5. - Removal of dangerous trees, limbs. 
(a)  Any tree or limb of a tree which is liable to fall on or across any public way or place shall be removed by the owner of the abutting premises or of the premises on which such tree is growing or standing. 
(b)  The director of public works and buildings or his designated representative may trim any such tree or remove any limb thereof so as to remove any obstruction or danger to traffic. 
(Code 1956, § 12.50) 
Sec. 28-6. - Attaching wires or ropes; maintenance of utility poles and wires. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful to attach any wire or rope to any tree or shrub in any public street, parkway or other public place without the permission of the board. 
(b)  Any person or company which maintains poles and wires in the streets, alleys or other public places, in the absence of provision in the franchise concerning the subject, shall keep such wires and poles free from and away from trees and shrubs so far as possible, and shall keep all trees and shrubs near such wires and poles properly trimmed, subject to the supervision of the director of public works and buildings, so that there will be no injury done either to the poles and wires or to the shrubs and trees by their contact. 
(Code 1956, § 12.51) 
Sec. 28-7. - Maintenance of gas pipes. 
    Any person or company maintaining any gas pipe in the village shall keep such pipes free from leaks so that no injury shall be done thereby to any trees or shrubs. 
(Code 1956, § 12.52) 
Sec. 28-8. - Excavations. 
    In making excavations in streets or other public places, proper care shall be taken to avoid injury to the roots of any tree or shrub wherever possible. 
(Code 1956, § 12.53) 
Sec. 28-9. - Diseased trees; duty of owner to remove; removal by village. 
(a)  All trees which become affected with Dutch elm disease are hereby declared to be a public nuisance. 
(b)  Any person owning any plot of ground upon which such a tree is situated, upon the appearance of evidence of such disease, shall cause such tree to be sprayed and be removed from the premises and burned. 
(c)  If the owner of any plot of ground upon which such a tree is situated fails to have such tree sprayed, removed and burned, the director of public works and buildings shall proceed to have such tree sprayed, removed and burned, and any expense incurred by the village in so doing shall be a charge against the owner, which may be recovered in an appropriate action at law instituted by the village attorney. 
(Code 1956, § 12.46-1; Ord. No. 14-1959, § I, 9-22-59) 
State Law reference- Authority of municipalities to adopt regulations for control of Dutch elm disease, 65 ILCS 5/11-20-1 & 11-20-12. 
Sec. 28-10. - Duty of property owners to cut weeds. 
    It is the duty of each owner of real property located within the village not to permit weeds, whether growing or not, to stand on his property at a height greater than eight (8) inches from the ground. Each property owner shall take such action as is lawful and as often as is necessary to cut weeds or remove them, such that they will not exceed the maximum permitted height. 
(Ord. No. 35-1975, § 2, 9-9-75) 
Sec. 28-11. - Notice to owner to cut weeds. 
    In the event that a property owner permits weeds on his property to exceed the maximum height, the village manager shall serve written notice upon him to comply with the provisions of section 28-10 of the Village Code within five (5) days from the date of such notice. Said notice may also provide that repeated failure to comply with the provisions of section 28-10 will result in additional enforcement action pursuant to sections 28-12 through 28-14 of this Code. 
(Ord. No. 35-1975, § 2, 9-9-75; Ord. No. 7-1991, § 1, 5-14-91) 
Sec. 28-12. - Action by village upon failure of owner to cut weeds. 
    If a property owner fails to comply with the provisions of section 28-10, and the village manager has given the notice provided for in section 28-11, at the expiration of the five (5) day period set forth in such notice, the village may enter upon the property and cut the weeds. The village manager shall keep accurate records of the cost incurred by the village in so doing, whether such cost arises out of a contract entered into by the village with others to cut the weeds, or whether the cost arises out of the assignment of village employees to cut the weeds. As soon as reasonably possible after weeds are cut by the village, and the cost thereof is determined, the village manager shall send a written demand to the property owner to reimburse the village for such cost. 
(Ord. No. 35-1975, § 2, 9-9-75) 
Sec. 28-13. - Lien upon real property. 
    The cost to the village of cutting weeds on the property of an owner who has failed to comply with section 28-10 is a lien in favor of the village against such property. If, after the demand for payment provided for in section 28-12 has been sent by the village, the property owner does not pay to the village the amount demanded, the village manager shall cause the notice of such lien to be recorded in the office of the Cook County recorder (or, if the property is subject to the Torrens Registration System, then in the office of the Cook County registrar of titles) not later than sixty (60) days after such cost is incurred. The notice shall contain a sworn statement setting out: 
(1)  A description of the real estate sufficient for identification thereof; 
(2)  The amount of money representing the cost incurred; and 
(3)  The date or dates when such cost was incurred by the village 
(Ord. No. 35-1975, § 2, 9-9-75) 
Sec. 28-14. - Release of lien upon payment. 
    Upon payment to the village of the amount demanded in the notice provided for in section 28-12, if the village has recorded or registered a notice of lien as provided in section 28-13, the village manager shall execute and deliver to the property owner a release of such lien which release may be recorded or registered by the property owner. 
(Ord. No. 35-1975, § 2, 9-9-75) 
Sec. 28-15. - Street tree responsibility, planting, trimming and removal. 
(a)  Definitions. "Street trees" are herein defined as trees, shrubs, bushes and all other woody vegetation on land lying between property lines on either side of all streets, avenues or ways within the village. 
(b)  Village tree superintendent. There is hereby created and established a village tree superintendent for the Village of Hazel Crest. The village manager shall appoint the village tree superintendent. 
(c)  Duties and responsibilities. It shall be the responsibility of the tree superintendent to study, investigate, counsel and develop and/or update annually, and administer a written plan for the care, preservation, pruning, planting, replanting, removal or disposition of trees and shrubs along streets and in other public areas. Such plan will be presented annually to the board of trustees and, upon their acceptance and approval, shall constitute the official comprehensive village tree plan for the Village of Hazel Crest. The superintendent, when requested by the village manager, shall consider, investigate, make findings, report and recommend upon any special matter of question coming within the scope of its work. 
(d)  Street species to be planted. The following list constitutes the official street tree species for Hazel Crest, Illinois. No species other than those included in this list may be planted as street trees without written permission of the village tree superintendent: 
Small Trees Medium Trees Large Trees Golden Rain Tree Ash, Green & White Coffeetree Hawthorne (sp) Ginkgo (male) Hackberry Pear, Bradford Honeylocust, thornless Kentucky Redbud Linden or Basswood (sp) Maple, Sugar Soapberry Mulberry, Red Maple, Sunset Red Lilac, Jap, Tree  (fruitless male) Oak, Bur Maple, Amur Oak, English Oak (all varieties Peach, Flowering Oak, Red  except Pin Oak) Plum, Purpleleaf Pagoda, Japanese Sycamore Serviceberry Pecan Sycamore, Sassafras  London Plane  
(e)  Spacing. The spacing of street trees will be in accordance with the three (3) species size classes listed in subsection (d) above, and no trees may be planted closer together than the following: 
    Small trees-Thirty (30) feet; 
    Medium trees-Forty (40) feet; 
    Large trees-Fifty (50) feet; 
except in special plantings designed or approved by the tree superintendent. 
(f)  Distance from curb and sidewalk. The distance trees may be planted from curbs or curblines and sidewalks will be in accordance with the three (3) species size classes listed in subsection (d) above. All trees planted must be centered in parkways to meet the following minimum requirements: 
    Small trees-Centered in at least a five-foot parkway; 
    Medium trees-Centered in at least an eight-foot parkway; 
    Large trees-Centered in at least a ten-foot parkway. 
(g)  Distance from street corners and fire hydrants. No street tree shall be planted closer than thirty-five (35) feet of any street corner, measured from the point of nearest intersecting curbs or curblines. Street trees planted near fire hydrants shall be planted no closer than the following: 
    Small trees-Ten (10) feet; 
    Medium trees-Ten (10) feet; 
    Large trees-Fifteen (15) feet. 
(h)  Utilities. No street tree, other than those species listed as small trees in subsection (d) above, may be planted under or within ten (10) lateral feet of any overhead utility wire, or over or within ten (10) lateral feet of any underground water line, sewer line, transmission line or other utility. 
(i)  Public tree care. The village shall have the right to plant, prune, maintain and remove trees, plants and shrubs within the lines of all streets, alleys, avenues, lanes, squares and public grounds as may be necessary to ensure public safety or to preserve or enhance the symmetry and beauty of such public grounds. 
The village tree superintendent may remove, or cause or order to be removed, any tree or part thereof which is in an unsafe condition or which by reason of its nature is injurious to sewers, electric power lines, gas lines, water lines or other public improvements, or is affected with any injurious fungus, insect or other pest. This section does not prohibit the planting of street trees by adjacent property owners providing that the selection and location of said trees is in accordance with subsections (d) through (k) of this section. 
(j)  Tree topping. It shall be unlawful as a normal practice for any person, firm or village department to top any street tree or other tree on public property. "Topping" is defined as the severe cutting back of limbs to stubs larger than three (3) inches in diameter within the tree's crown to such a degree so as to remove the normal canopy and disfigure the tree. Trees severely damaged by storms or other causes, or certain trees under utility wires or other obstructions where other pruning practices are impractical, may be exempted from this section at the determination of the village tree superintendent. 
(k)  Pruning, corner clearance. Every owner of any tree overhanging any street or right-of-way within the village shall prune the branches so that such branches shall not obstruct the light from any street lamp or obstruct the view of any street intersection, and so that there shall be a clear space of eight (8) feet above the surface of the street or sidewalk. Said owners shall remove all dead, diseased or dangerous trees, or broken or decayed limbs, which constitute a menace to the safety of the public. The village shall have the right to prune any tree or shrub on private property when it interferes with the proper spread of light along the street from a streetlight or interferes with visibility of any traffic-control device or signal. 
(l)  Removal of stumps. All stumps of street trees shall be removed below the surface of the ground so that the top of the stump shall not project above the surface of the ground. 
(m)  Interference with village tree superintendent. It shall be unlawful for any person to prevent, delay or interfere with the village tree superintendent, or any of his agents, while engaging in and about planting, cultivating, mulching, pruning, spraying or removing of any street trees, park trees or trees on private grounds, as authorized in this section. 
(n)  Arborists license and bond. It shall be unlawful for any person or firm to engage in the business or occupation of pruning, treating or removing street or park trees within the village without first applying for and procuring a license. The license fee shall be twenty-five dollars ($25.00) annually in advance; provided, however, that no license shall be required of any public service company or village employee doing such work in the pursuit of their public service endeavors. Before any license shall be issued, each applicant shall first file evidence of possession of liability insurance in the minimum amounts of fifty thousand dollars ($50,000.00) for bodily injury and one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00) property damage, indemnifying the village or any person injured or damage resulting from the pursuit of such endeavors as herein described. 
(o)  Penalty. Any person violating any provision of this section shall be, upon conviction or a plea of guilty, subject to a fine not to exceed five hundred dollars ($500.00). 
(Ord. No. 28-1985, § 1, 12-30-85) 
Sec. 28-16. - Overgrown trees and shrubs on vacant private property. 
(a)  It is the duty of each owner of vacant, improved or unimproved real property located within the village to keep all trees, shrubs and plantings properly trimmed so as not to obscure the view into the property, or to otherwise interfere with the quiet use and enjoyment of neighboring properties. 
(b)  In the event the village manager or his designee determines that a property is in violation of this section, he shall cause a notice to comply to be served on the owner-of-record of such property, calling for compliance within five (5) days from the date of such notice. 
(c)  If a property owner fails to comply with the requirements hereof, and the village manager has given the required notice, at the expiration of the notice period set forth hereinabove, the village may enter upon such property and properly trim all such trees, shrubs or other plantings. The village manager shall keep accurate records of the costs incurred by the village in so doing, and shall send written demand to the property owner for repayment in the manner set forth in section 28-12. 
(d)  The village may use any method authorized by law to receive reimbursement for the costs incurred in connection with enforcing this section. 
(e)  Any person violating the provisions of this section shall, upon conviction thereof, be subject to a fine of not less than fifty dollars ($50.00) nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00). 
(Ord. No. 5-1991, § 1, 4-23-91) 
Sec. 28-17. - Residential sodding requirements. 
(a)  The entire front lawn of all residential properties shall be sodded based on the following terms: 
(1)  Prior to the village's issuance of a final certificate of occupancy for any newly-constructed residential property, the applicant shall have sodded the entire front lawn of such property. However, if the closing for a newly-constructed residential property occurs in winter, the applicant shall make a cash payment into a village escrow account based on the village's cost estimate for such sodding. The village shall hold the applicant's money in escrow until the front lawn is established. At that time, the applicant may request a refund from the village for the entire escrow amount. The applicant will receive a refund within ninety (90) days of the date of request. 
(2)  Any newly-constructed residential properties existing at the time of the passage of this section [April 11, 2006], which do no not currently have entire front lawn sodding, must comply with subsection (a) of this section by June 15, 2006. For the purposes of this subsection (2), "newly-constructed" will mean within eighteen (18) months prior to the passage of this section. 
(3)  Should an applicant propose any landscaping material other than sod, it will be subject to review as part of the inspection process. Should the proposed landscaping not be approved, appeal can be made to the beautification commission. 
(b)  The village manager or designee is hereby authorized to establish and set the terms for escrow accounts referenced in subsection (a)(1). 
(Ord. No. 08-2006, § 1, 4-11-06) 
Chapter 29 - WATER AND SEWERS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Buildings and building regulations, Ch. 6; health and sanitation, Ch. 13; housing, Ch. 14; mobile homes, mobile home parks, Ch. 18; plumbing, Ch. 23; swimming pools, Ch. 26; sanitary sewer connections, §§ 29-13, 29-14.1; subdivisions, App. A. 
State Law reference- Water supply and sewerage systems, 65 ILCS 5/11-124-1. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 29-1. - Definition. 
    Where the term "department" is used in this chapter, it shall be considered to mean the combined water and sewer department of the village, unless the context clearly indicates otherwise. 
(Code 1956, § 13.01; Ord. No. 13-1961, 12-26-61) 
Cross reference- Rules of construction and definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 29-2. - Enforcement of chapter. 
    It shall be the duty of the director of public works, the police of the village and all persons in the employ of the village having police power to enforce the provisions of all ordinances, rules and regulations respecting the sewer and water system, and to arrest or cause to be arrested all persons violating the same. 
(Code 1956, § 13.20; Ord. No. 13-1961, 12-26-61) 
Sec. 29-3. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 1-1981, § 2, adopted Jan. 13, 1981, repealed former § 29-3 which pertained to the right of the village to shut off water and was derived from Code 1956, § 13.21 and Ord. No. 13-1961, adopted Dec. 26, 1961. 
Sec. 29-4. - Rules and regulations for system. 
    Water consumers and licensed plumbers shall be governed by the following rules and regulations: 
(1)  All work in connection with the sewer and water system shall be governed by section XX, as amended, of the March, 1969, building regulation ordinance of the village. So much of Ordinance No. 6-1973, and more particularly section 7 thereof, as purported to repeal the March, 1969, ordinance is repealed insofar as it purported to repeal section XX of the March, 1969, ordinance. 
(2)  All boilers connected with the sewer and water system shall be provided with a tank of sufficient capacity to hold at least six (6) hours' supply, and in case the supply is shut off for the purpose of repair or any other purpose, the village will not be responsible for any damage that may result. Consumers and other persons are prohibited from connecting pipes directly with the village pressure to supply steam boilers. 
(3)  All hydrants and plugs placed in the village for fire protection purposes are hereby declared to be public hydrants and no person, except such as have been authorized by the board of trustees, shall open or draw water therefrom or in any manner interfere therewith, except in case of fire. 
(4)  The director of public works and buildings, the village collector and other authorized persons shall have free access to any premises in which water is introduced for the purpose of examining the fixtures and pipes at any time between the hours of 7:00 a.m. and 6:00 p.m. of any day. 
(Code 1956, § 13.18; Ord. No. 13-1961, 12-26-61) 
Sec. 29-5. - Special connections. 
    Any person, being a regular consumer, may be permitted by the board of trustees to make special connections with the street mains, together with hydrants and hose cocks, to be used in case of fire. All such work in connection with the sewer and water system must be done by the village or under the direction of the director of public works and buildings. 
(Code 1956, § 13.18; Ord. No. 13-1961, 12-26-61) 
Sec. 29-6. - Water consumption during summer months restricted. 
(a)  The consumption of water during the hourly peaks within the village, except where the water supply is available from private wells, shall be subject to the following regulations and restrictions controlling the use of water for lawn sprinkling and other purposes, which regulations and restrictions shall be in effect from May 15th through September 15th of each year: 
(1)  Premises with even-numbered addresses may be sprinkled, watered or irrigated on the even-numbered days of the month. 
(2)  Premises with odd-numbered addresses may be sprinkled, watered or irrigated on odd-numbered days of the month. 
(3)  Industrial businesses, institutional premises, golf courses, parks and schools having even-numbered addresses may draw from the village main on even-numbered days while those having odd-numbered addresses may draw from the village main on odd-numbered days of the month for the purpose of filling reservoirs serving such premises, between the hours of 12:00 midnight and 6:00 a.m. 
(4)  The use of water from the village water mains for swimming pools shall be only by permission of the director of public works and buildings. 
(b)  Any person who shall violate the provisions of this section shall be punished as provided in section 1-10 of this Code for each offense, or by cutting off the water to the premises, of by the imposition of a fine levied upon any moneys deposited with the department as a guarantee for the payment of water and sewer charges. 
(Ord. No. 7-1965, § 1A, 6-8-65; Ord. No. 3-1990, § 1, 4-24-90) 
Sec. 29-7. - Limitation of water use during emergencies. 
(a)  During any period of time when the overall demand upon the water supply system of the village is so great as to endanger the public health, safety and welfare of the village, the village president is authorized to declare an emergency and to issue emergency water conservation regulations, limiting or prohibiting the use of water from the village water mains for the sprinkling, watering or irrigation of shrubbery, trees, lawns, grass, ground covers, plants, vines, gardens, vegetables, flowers, or for any other purpose. 
(b)  All emergency regulations issued by the village president pursuant to this section shall be published once in a newspaper having general circulation in the village and shall be effective upon publication. 
(c)  The director of public works and buildings, with the assistance of such other departments, officers and employees of the village as may be required, shall have the authority to enforce the provisions of this section and all regulations issued pursuant thereto, including the discontinuance of water service in the event of a violation hereof. 
(Ord. No. 13-1958, §§ 1-3, 5-27-58) 
Sec. 29-8. - Maintenance of privies restricted. 
    It shall be unlawful to maintain any privy vault not connected with the public sewer system in or on any premises abutting on a street or portion thereof which is served by a sanitary sewer. 
(Code 1956, § 7.26) 
Sec. 29-9. - Right of village to change chapter provisions. 
    Nothing contained in this chapter shall prevent the village from changing, altering, amending or repealing the provisions hereof, and the village shall have and retain authority from time to time to change, increase, decrease or improve the water and sewer system and plant, or any part of portion thereof, or to establish new or different rates, regulations or provisions concerning the use of such system or plant. 
(Code 1956, § 13.16; Ord. No. 13-1961, 12-26-61) 
Sec. 29-10. - Village not liable for damages. 
(a)  All connections and water applied for under this chapter and all water used hereunder shall be upon the express condition that the village shall not be liable, nor shall any claim be made against it for damage or injury caused by reason of the breakage of any main, branch, service pipe, apparatus or appurtenance connected with the water or sewer system or plant, or any part or portion of such plant, for any interruption of the supply by reason of the breakage of machinery or by reason of stoppage, alteration, extension and renewal. 
(b)  All repairs to service pipes and connections therefrom shall be at the expense of the owner or tenant of the premises supplied, except repairs on the section of the pipe included between the corporation cock at the main and the curb cock in the parkway. 
(Code 1956, § 13.17; Ord. No. 13-1961, 12-26-61) 
Sec. 29-11. - Collector-Duties. 
    The village collector shall be responsible for billing, meter reading, collection of bills for water and sewer service, and issuing water permits. 
(Code 1956, § 13.05; Ord. No. 13-1961, 12-26-61) 
Sec. 29-12. - Same-Monthly report. 
    The village collector shall, upon the first of each month, or more often if required, submit a report in writing to the president and board of trustees of all moneys collected by him pursuant to this chapter, the account whereon collected, and any and all other matters connected with his office. 
(Code 1956, § 13.06; Ord. No. 13-1961, 12-26-61) 
Sec. 29-13. - Direct connections to sanitary sewer regulated. 
    In all building classifications, except for residential use, no direct connections shall be made to main sanitary sewer from any sink, laundry, garage, or any other fixture where grease would be in evidence, or from any floor washer or any connection where grease would be in evidence, or from any floor washer or any connection where cinders or other refuse would be liable to enter the sanitary sewer and cause a stoppage of the free flow of the sewer. Such drainage shall first be emptied into good and sufficient catch basin or properly constructed trap, approved by the director of public works, for the purpose of preventing all the above accumulations from entering the main sanitary sewer. All sanitary sewer pipe within the foundation shall be cast iron soil pipe with caulked and leaded bell and spigot joints. Cast iron soil pipe shall not be laid in contact with cinder fill. 
(Ord. No. 6-1976, § 19, 3-9-76; Ord. No. 13-1979, § 20, 3-27-79; Ord. No. 19-1981, § 18, 9-22-81; Ord. No. 25-1985, § 18, 11-12-85; Ord. No. 4-1991, § 19, 3-26-91) 
Sec. 29-14. - Storm water disposal sewers. 
    Storm water disposal sewers, into which all downspouts, sidewalk washers, surface water drains, swimming pools, fish ponds, etc., shall discharge, shall be connected to the main storm sewerage system where available, or if storm sewer is not available, discharge at curbline or otherwise disposed of to the satisfaction of the director of public works. 
(Ord. No. 6-1976, § 19, 3-9-76; Ord. No. 13-1979, § 20, 3-27-79; Ord. No. 19-1981, § 20, 9-22-81; Ord. No. 25-1985, § 20, 11-12-85; Ord. No. 4-1991, § 21, 3-26-91) 
Sec. 29-14.1. - Connections between storm water drains and sanitary sewer prohibited. 
(a)  Storm water drain connections. No person, firm, partnership or corporation shall hereafter connect or maintain a connection of any roof drain, downspout, footing drain, areaway drain, driveway drain, yard drain, or any other storm water drain on any real estate owned, occupied or controlled by said entity, directly or indirectly, to any sanitary sewer main of the Village of Hazel Crest sanitary sewerage collection system or any interceptor of the metropolitan sanitary district of Greater Chicago. 
(b)  Sanitary sewer service line connections. No person, firm, partnership or corporation shall hereafter construct or maintain a sanitary sewer service line including any cleanouts or private manholes on any real estate owned, occupied or controlled by said person, firm, partnership or corporation in a condition which allows the entrance of storm water or groundwater into the sanitary sewage collection system of the Village of Hazel Crest or any interceptor sewer of the metropolitan sanitary district of Greater Chicago. 
(c)  Connections by plumbing and construction businesses. No person, firm, partnership or corporation authorized by the Village of Hazel Crest to engage in the plumbing business or in any business relating to the construction of buildings, roads or any other type construction shall hereafter make or cause to be made a connection between any sanitary sewer main of the sanitary sewerage collection system of the Village of Hazel Crest and any roof drain, footing drain, or any other storm water drain or make any such connection to any interceptor of the metropolitan sanitary district of Greater Chicago. Any such person, firm, partnership or corporation violating any provision of this section shall, in addition to all other penalties provided for in this section, be subject to the revocation of their authorization to conduct business in the Village of Hazel Crest for a period not to exceed sixty (60) days. 
(d)  Inspection, testing. Every person, firm, partnership or corporation shall, during reasonable hours, permit the proper village officers or employees to conduct an inspection and such test or tests as are necessary to ascertain if any roof drain, footing drain, or any other storm water drain is connected to a sanitary sewer main comprising or discharging to a part of the Village of Hazel Crest sewerage collection system in violation of this section or any other ordinance of the Village of Hazel Crest. Said inspection, test or tests may also ascertain if the condition of any sanitary sewer service line, cleanout or private manhole allows the entrance of storm water or groundwater to a sanitary sewer drain comprising or discharging to a part of the Village of Hazel Crest sewerage collection system in violation of this section or any other ordinances of the Village of Hazel Crest. Said inspection and test or tests shall be made at no expense to the owner, occupant, or person, firm, partnership or corporation in control of said real estate. 
(e)  Notice of violation; corrective action. In the event the inspection and test or tests provided for in this section shall reveal a violation of this section or any other ordinance or ordinances of the Village of Hazel Crest or the metropolitan sanitary district of Greater Chicago, the proper village officers or employees shall advise the owner, occupant, or person, firm, partnership or corporation in control of said real estate whereon said violation exists, by written notice, of the required corrective action that must be taken. After such notice it shall be the responsibility of said owner, occupant or person, firm, partnership or corporation in control of said real estate to make the necessary corrections at their own expense within sixty (60) days thereafter and advise the proper village officers and employees of progress being made from time to time and when the corrected work is ready for further inspection and testing. The director of public works is hereby directed and authorized to furnish necessary technical advice at the expense of the Village of Hazel Crest to every person, firm, partnership or corporation being the owner, occupant, or in control of real estate within the Village of Hazel Crest in compliance with the request for inspection provided for in subsection (d) of this section, and to grant extensions of time to allow for the completion of said corrective actions in cases of exceptional hardship or unusual circumstances. 
(f)  Duties of director of public works re notices, records, etc. The director of public works is hereby directed to prepare copies of this section, design and prepare report and testing forms as required, notices of required corrective work, and to keep an accurate and permanent record of the names and addresses of all owners, occupants, or person, firm, partnership or corporation notified, and to keep accurate and complete records of each request for inspection and testing received together with all information of such inspection and test, including location, name of inspector, date, description of testing methods, results of test, conclusion and signed certification by inspector. 
(g)  Application to future and existing connections. The provisions and requirements of this section shall apply to future construction in the village and shall also apply to existing building structures or other improvements where a connection has heretofore been made that is in violation of the terms of this section. 
(h)  Plumbing permits required. Plumbing permits shall be required for all corrective work necessitated by this section. Provisions for obtaining a plumbing permit are set out in the Village of Hazel Crest Plumbing Code. The fee for said plumbing permit for work required under this section is hereby waived. All provisions of the Village of Hazel Crest Plumbing Code and the State of Illinois Plumbing Code (1983) shall govern all work required by this section. 
(Ord. No. 16-1984, §§ 1-8, 5-22-84) 
Editor's note- Being nonamendatory of the Code, Ord. No. 16-1984, §§ 1-8, enacted May 22, 1984, has been codified herein as § 29-14.1, at the editor's discretion. 
Sec. 29-14.2. - [Illicit discharge and connection.] 
  
(Ord. No. 11-2008, § 1, 5-13-08) 
Editor's note- Section 1 of Ord. No. 11-2008, adopted May 13, 2008, added § 29-14.2 in order to comply with NSIT regulations regarding illicit discharge and connection. 
Sec. 29-15. - Additional permit required for disturbance of any street. 
    Where it is necessary to disturb any street, an additional permit shall be secured from the director of public works, authorizing such work as is to be performed on or under any public street. The applicant shall be required to deposit five hundred dollars ($500.00) with the village clerk for each street opening made. This deposit shall be held for a period of six (6) months after replacement of street where openings have been made; and if such replacement shall not be made in a manner satisfactory to the director of public works, within a period of six (6) months, the deposit, shall be forfeited. Where water or sewer mains are located in the rear of lots, no street opening permit is required. 
(Ord. No. 6-1976, § 21, 3-9-76; Ord. No. 13-1979, § 22, 3-27-79; Ord. No. 19-1981, § 22, 9-22-81; Ord. No. 25-1985, § 22, 11-12-85; Ord. No. 4-1991, § 23, 3-26-91) 
Sec. 29-16. - Septic tanks and fields. 
    The installation of septic tanks and fields will not be allowed within this village unless approved by the building official. 
(Ord. No. 6-1976, § 22, 3-9-76; Ord. No. 13-1979, § 23, 3-27-79; Ord. No. 19-1981, § 23, 9-22-81; Ord. No. 25-1985, § 23, 11-12-85; Ord. No. 4-1991, § 24, 3-26-91) 
Sec. 29-17. - Service lines from water mains. 
    All service lines from water mains into any building shall be not less than three-quarter-inch diameter Type "K" copper tubing tapped into the main with not less than three-quarter-inch standard corporation cock and curb stop valve to box, all of which shall be as per the village standard and shall be provided in the parkway or easement. An "S" form must be provided between the corporation cock and curb stop valve. 
(Ord. No. 6-1976, §§ 24, 25, 3-9-76; Ord. No. 13-1979, § 25, 3-27-79; Ord. No. 19-1981, § 25, 9-22-81; Ord. No. 25-1985, § 25, 11-12-85; Ord. No. 4-1991, § 26, 3-26-91) 
Sec. 29-18. - Water connection specifications. 
    No connection in excess of two (2) inches nominal diameter shall be made to any water main. 
(a)  Any connection to a four-inch water main shall be connected with a tapping valve and sleeve. 
(b)  Any connection to a six-inch water main over one inch inside diameter shall be connected with a tapping valve and sleeve. 
(c)  Any connection to an eight-inch water main over and one-half inch inside diameter shall be connected with a tapping valve and sleeve. 
(Ord. No. 6-1976, § 26, 3-9-76; Ord. No. 13-1979, § 26, 3-27-79; Ord. No. 19-1981, § 26, 9-22-81; Ord. No. 25-1985, § 26, 11-12-85; Ord. No. 4-1991, § 27, 3-26-91) 
Sec. 29-19. - Water meters; fire hydrants. 
(a)  Application. The application for a sewer and water permit shall be submitted on such forms as the building department may provide and shall be accompanied by the required fee as prescribed in Chapter 29 section 29-42 of the Village Municipal Code. Upon approval of the sewer and water permit by the director of public works, a water meter will be provided. No water shall be used for any purpose prior to the installation of a water meter unless approved in writing by the director of public works. 
(b)  Location of water meters. All water meters shall be located where the water service enters the building in an area easily accessible and free from obstructions, for the purpose of reading, inspecting and repair of said meters. Meters shall be a minimum of fourteen (14) inches off the floor. 
(c)  Installation of water meters. All water meters in single-family residences shall be installed by the village sewer and water department. All other water meters shall be installed by the plumber whose name appears on the sewer and water permit, under the supervision of the village sewer and water department. If any water meter requires a by-pass line and valve, said valve shall be secured by a lock box furnished by the village sewer and water department (excepting R-4 structures). 
(d)  Use of fire hydrants. The use of fire hydrants will be permitted upon submission of a temporary meter use form as supplied by the sewer and water department. Upon approval of the required form by the director of public works and posting of a three hundred dollars ($300.00) deposit, a water meter and a hydrant wrench will be issued. Fire hydrants shall only be operated by means of an approved hydrant wrench. 
(e)  Sealing of water meters. All water meters shall be sealed by the Village of Hazel Crest; stamped with the village seal. The seal placed by the village for the protection of any meter valve fitting or any water connection shall not be defaced or broken except by written authority of the village. 
(f)  Testing meters; liability for repair. The village may at any time remove a meter temporarily for the purpose of testing its accuracy. Any meter so tested and found to register within two (2) percent plus or minus of the correct amount shall be considered acceptable, and its registration shall be considered correct. Any meter which fails to register within two (2) percent plus or minus of the correct amount shall be repaired or replaced within fifteen (15) days at the expense of the village. The owner, however, shall be liable for damage to meters due to freezing, water back-up and damages resulting from their negligence. 
(g)  Tampering forbidden. It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation, not specifically authorized by the director of public works, to tamper with, injure, damage or alter any part of the village waterworks, supply system, or any water meter, including without limitation a "Buffalo-box" or "B-box," installed therein. 
(h)  Meter replacement. The village may at any time remove and replace a meter permanently for the purpose of changing out older meters and installing remote registers on a scheduled basis. 
(Ord. No. 6-1976, § 28, 3-9-76; Ord. No. 13-1979, § 28, 3-27-79; Ord. No. 19-1981, § 29, 9-22-81; Ord. No. 25-1985, § 29, 11-12-85; Ord. No. 4-1991, § 30, 3-26-91; Ord. No. 09-2011, § 3, 7-26-11) 
Sec. 29-20. - House service sewers. 
    House service sewers may be laid in a common trench with the water service pipe. Wherein sewer and water services are laid in the same trench, the water service pipe shall be laid on a shelf cut in the side of the sewer service trench; the top of the sewer service pipe shall be not less than eighteen (18) inches below the water service. The sewer trench shall be first backfilled up to the height of the shelf. The backfill shall be thoroughly compacted by placing in six-inch layers. Water service pipe shall be placed on the shelf at least twelve (12) inches from the side of the house sewer trench. 
(Ord. No. 6-1976, § 29, 3-9-76; Ord. No. 13-1979, § 29, 3-27-79; Ord. No. 19-1981, § 30, 9-22-81; Ord. No. 25-1985, § 30, 11-12-85; Ord. No. 4-1991, § 31, 3-26-91) 
Sec. 29-21. - Penalty for violations. 
    Any person who shall violate a provision of sections 29-13-29-20 or shall fail to comply with any of the requirements thereof or who shall erect, construct, alter or repair a building or structure in violation of an approved plan or directive of the building official, or of a permit or certificate issued under the provisions of sections 29-13-29-20, shall be guilty of an offense against the village, punishable by a fine of not less than fifty dollars ($50.00), nor more than seven hundred fifty dollars($750.00). Each day that a violation continues shall be deemed a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 13-1979, § 30, 3-27-79; Ord. No. 19-1981, § 31, 9-22-81; Ord. No. 4-1991, § 32, 3-26-91; Ord. No. 09-2011, § 3, 7-26-11) 
Editor's note- Section 30 of Ord. No. 13-1979, adopted March 27, 1979, did not specifically amend the Code, hence inclusion as § 29-21 was at the discretion of the editor. 
ARTICLE II. - WATER AND SEWER DEPARTMENT[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Administration generally, Ch. 2. 

Sec. 29-22. - Combined. 
    The waterworks system and the sewerage system of the village shall be maintained and operated together as a combined waterworks and sewerage system. 
(Code 1956, § 13.01; Ord. No. 13-1961, 12-26-61) 
Sec. 29-23. - Jurisdiction. 
    The department, under the direction of the director of public works, and such other offices and employees as may from time to time be lawfully appointed shall have the supervision, management and control, subject to the president and board of trustees, of the maintenance, enlargement and operation of the combined waterworks and sewerage system owned and controlled by the village, the procuring and selling of water, and all matters and things connected with the operation, maintenance and extension of the combined waterworks and sewerage system and preserving the property belonging thereto. 
(Code 1956, § 13.02; Ord. No. 13-1961, 12-26-61) 
Sec. 29-24. - Supervision. 
    The director of public works shall have supervision of all buildings and equipment used in the furnishing of water in the village, shall see that the objects and purposes of the department are carried out and that the combined waterworks and sewerage system is conducted on an economical and businesslike basis, and for this purpose, it shall be the duty of the director and all of the officers and employees of the department to enforce all the provisions of this chapter and to observe, obey and carry out the orders and directions of the village board. He shall prepare and keep in his office a complete atlas of the waterworks and sewerage system, with all valves, hydrants, water service connections and other appurtenances distinctly recorded therein. 
(Code 1956, § 13.03; Ord. No. 13-1961, 12-26-61) 
Sec. 29-25. - Compensation of officers and employees. 
    The director of public works and other officers and employees of the department shall receive as compensation for their services such amounts as are fixed by the board of trustees from time to time. 
(Code 1956, § 13.04; Ord. No. 13-1961, 12-26-61) 
Secs. 29-26-29-38. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - RATES, CHARGES AND FEES 

Sec. 29-39. - Generally. 
(a)  Reasonable charges, as hereinafter provided for, shall be made as follows: 
(1)  Use and service charge. A charge shall be made for the use and service of the combined waterworks and sewerage system of the village which, taken together with all other such use and service charges, shall be sufficient to pay the costs, maintenance, operation, depreciation and principal and interest on any revenue bond that may be issued by the village for the construction, installation, repair and improvement of the combined system. 
(2)  Connection charge. A charge shall be made at the time of the initial connection of the building to the combined system, or at the time of any connection thereafter which places a larger demand upon the system. 
(3)  Construction water use charge. A charge shall be made for the use of water during the construction of any building or other improvement. 
(4)  Storm sewer connection charge. A charge shall be made for the connection of any building to a storm drain or storm sewer. 
(5)  Refuse charge. A charge shall be made for garbage and collection services provided to single-family residences by the village's waste hauler contractor. 
(b)  All charges provided for herein shall be cumulative. 
(Code 1956, § 13.01; Ord. No. 13-1961, 12-26-61; Ord. No. 30-1976, § 1, 9-14-76; Ord. No. 02-2006, § 1, 1-17-06) 
Sec. 29-40. - Use and service charges established. 
    The following rates and charges are hereby established for the use of and for the service supplied by the combined waterworks and sewerage system of the village, effective the first billing period for each user which starts on or after November 13, 2007, thereafter based on the amount of water consumed as shown by water meters: 
INSIDE CORPORATE LIMITS 
    Combined water and sewer service: 
Per 1,000 gallons ..... $ 7.126 
Minimum charge per billing cycle (3,000 gallons or less during billing cycle) ..... 25.00 
    Water service only: 
Per 1,000 gallons ..... 7.126 
Minimum charge per billing cycle (3,000 gallons or less during billing cycle) ..... 25.00 
    Sewerage service only: 
The rate for sewerage service only shall be ten dollars and fifty cents ($10.50) per quarter for each connection to the sewer system. In cases where the character of sewage from an individual plant, building or premises is such as to impose a burden upon the system in addition to the burden imposed by the average flow of sewage, the president and board of trustees shall enter into separate contracts with such industrial plants for special rates and charges where the particular circumstances render the regular sewerage rates inadequate or unjust. 
    Multiple dwelling units: 
Apartment houses or multiple units may be served through one (1) meter. In such cases, the rates and charges above shall be multiplied by the number of individual dwelling units therein. For the purposes of this section, an "apartment" is defined as a portion of a building consisting of two (2) or more rooms equipped for living purposes. 
OUTSIDE CORPORATE LIMITS 
Users of the combined waterworks and sewerage system, of either the water or the sewer facilities of the village, which are located outside the corporate limits of the village shall have fifty (50) per cent added to their bill for the type of service as set out above. 
(Code 1956, § 13.09; Ord. No. 13-1961, 12-26-61; Ord. No. 3-1970, § 1, 3-24-70; Ord. No. 9-1973, § 1; Ord. No. 2-1974, § 1, 1-8-74; Ord. No. 21-1974, § A, 7-9-74; Ord. No. 12-1975, § 1, 4-13-75; Ord. No. 13-1988, § 1, 4-12-88; Ord. No. 16-1989, § 1, 5-9-89; Ord. No. 15-991, § 1, 8-13-91; Ord. No. 2-1992, § 1, 5-12-92; Ord. No. 1-1997, § 1, 1-14-97; Ord. No. 6-2003, § 1, 4-22-03; Ord. No. 23-2007, § 1, 11-13-07; Ord. No. 03-2010, § 1, 4-13-10) 
Sec. 29-40.1. - Garbage collection and disposal. 
    The following rates and charges are hereby established for garbage collection and disposal services provided to single-family residential customers by the village's contracted waste hauler shall be fifty-one dollars and seventy-five cents ($51.75) per quarter (forty-three dollars and fifty cents ($43.50) for residents sixty-five (65) years or older). For the period of October 1, 2006, to September 30, 2010, annual increases will be three (3) percent per year. 
(Ord. No. 02-2006, § 2, 1-17-06)

The deposit, or so much thereof as remains after deducting any unpaid service charge, will be refunded to the depositor when the village has received notice to discontinue water service and has conducted final reading procedures.

(3)  Remodeling: At the time an application for a building permit is submitted and prior to the installation of a water meter, the applicant shall pay a construction water use charge in the amount of eighty dollars ($80.00). 
(4)  Commercial: At the time an application for a building permit is submitted, the applicant shall pay a construction water use charge as determined by the director of public works. 
(c)  Storm sewer connection fee: 
(1)  New construction: At the time an application for a building permit is submitted, the applicant shall pay to the village a storm sewer connection fee of seventy-five dollars ($75.00). 
(d)  Alternate connection charge for water service only: 
(1)  New connections: In the event that no sanitary sewer service is available to the building for which a building permit is applied, but water service is available, the applicant shall pay to the village at the time the permit is applied for, the appropriate water service connection fee(s) set forth in subparagraph (a)(1) above. At the time sanitary sewer service is made available to such building, the owners thereof shall make application to the village for connection to such service, with such application as set forth in subparagraph (a)(1) above. 
(e)  Alternate connection charge for sewer service only: 
(1)  New connections: In the event that no water service is available to the building for which a building permit is applied, but sanitary sewer service is available, the applicant shall pay to the village at the time the permit is applied for, the appropriate sanitary sewer service connection fee(s) set forth in subparagraph (a)(1) above. At the time water service is made available to such building, the owners thereof shall make application to the village for connection to such service, with such application as set forth in subparagraph (a)(1) above. 
(f)  Performance bond: 
(1)  Surety bond: At the time a building permit is applied for, the applicant will deliver to the village a performance bond as hereinafter prescribed, when, in the opinion of the director of public works, the connection to the water service, sanitary sewer or storm sewer will require disturbing the condition of any village property. The bond shall be in the penal sum of not less than ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00). The principal on such bond shall be the applicant for the building permit.
